Text

CHAPTER I.

It is a truth universally acknowledged , that [a single man in possession of a good fortune]243-a single man in possession of a good fortune , must be in want of [a wife]244-a wife .

However little known the feelings or views of [such a man]245-such a man may be on [his]245-such a man first entering [a neighbourhood]246-a neighbourhood , this truth is so well fixed in the minds of [the surrounding families]247-the surrounding families , that [he]245-such a man is considered as the rightful property of [some one or other of [[their]247-the surrounding families daughters]249-their daughters]248-some one or other of their daughters .

" [[My]250-his lady dear]3018-my dear [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet , "[250-his lady] said [[his]245-such a man lady]250-his lady to [him]245-such a man one day , " have [you]245-such a man heard that [Netherfield Park]1-netherfield park is let at last ? "[250-his lady]

[Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet replied that [he]86-mr. bennet had not .

" But it is , "[250-his lady] returned [she]250-his lady ; " for [Mrs. Long]87-mrs. long has just been [here]3019-here , and [she]87-mrs. long told [me]250-his lady all about it . "[250-his lady]

[Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet made no answer .

" Do not [you]245-such a man want to know who has taken it ? "[251-his wife] cried [[his]245-such a man wife]251-his wife impatiently .

" _ [You]245-such a man _ want to tell [me]250-his lady , and [I]250-his lady have no objection to hearing it . "[250-his lady]

This was invitation enough .

" Why , [[my]250-his lady dear]3018-my dear , [you]3018-my dear must know , [Mrs. Long]87-mrs. long says that [Netherfield]2-netherfield is taken by [a young man of large fortune from [the north of [England]3-england]3022-the north of england]3021-a young man of large fortune from the north of england ; that [he]3021-a young man of large fortune from the north of england came down on Monday in a chaise and four to see [the place]3023-the place , and was so much delighted with it that [he]3021-a young man of large fortune from the north of england agreed with [Mr. Morris]88-mr. morris immediately ; that [he]3021-a young man of large fortune from the north of england is to take possession before [Michaelmas]89-michaelmas , and [some of [[his]3021-a young man of large fortune from the north of england servants]3025-his servants]3024-some of his servants are to be in [the house]3026-the house by the end of next week . "[250-his lady]

" What is [his]3021-a young man of large fortune from the north of england name ? "[250-his lady]

" [Bingley]90-mr. bingley . "[250-his lady]

" Is [he]3021-a young man of large fortune from the north of england married or single ? "[250-his lady]

" Oh ! single , [[my]250-his lady dear]3018-my dear , to be sure ! [A single man of large fortune]3028-a single man of large fortune ; four or five thousand a year . What a fine thing for [[our]3029-our girls]3030-our girls ! "[250-his lady]

" How so ? how can it affect [them]3030-our girls ? "[250-his lady]

" [[My]251-his wife dear]3018-my dear [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet , "[251-his wife] replied [[his]252-his wife]251-his wife , " how can [you]86-mr. bennet be so tiresome ! [You]86-mr. bennet must know that [I]251-his wife am thinking of [his]3021-a young man of large fortune from the north of england marrying one of [them]3030-our girls . "[251-his wife]

" Is that [his]3021-a young man of large fortune from the north of england design in settling [here]3019-here ? "[250-his lady]

" Design ! nonsense , how can [you]86-mr. bennet talk so ! But it is very likely that [he]3021-a young man of large fortune from the north of england _ may _ fall in love with one of [them]3030-our girls , and therefore [you]86-mr. bennet must visit [him]3021-a young man of large fortune from the north of england as soon as [he]3021-a young man of large fortune from the north of england comes . "[251-his wife]

" [I]250-his lady see no occasion for that . [You]86-mr. bennet and [the girls]3033-the girls may go , or [you]86-mr. bennet may send [them]3030-our girls by [themselves]3030-our girls , which perhaps will be still better , for as [you]86-mr. bennet are as handsome as any of [them]3030-our girls , [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley might like [you]86-mr. bennet the best of [the party]3034-the party . "[250-his lady]

" [[My]251-his wife dear]3018-my dear , [you]86-mr. bennet flatter [me]251-his wife . [I]251-his wife certainly _ have _ had [my]251-his wife share of beauty , but [I]251-his wife do not pretend to be any thing extraordinary now . When [a woman]3036-a woman has [five grown up daughters]3037-five grown up daughters , [she]3036-a woman ought to give over thinking of [her]3036-a woman own beauty . "[251-his wife]

" In such cases , [a woman]3036-a woman has not often much beauty to think of . "[250-his lady]

" But , [[my]251-his wife dear]3018-my dear , [you]86-mr. bennet must indeed go and see [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley when [he]90-mr. bingley comes into [the neighbourhood]3040-the neighbourhood . "[251-his wife]

" It is more than [I]250-his lady engage for , [I]250-his lady assure [you]86-mr. bennet . "[250-his lady]

" But consider [[your]86-mr. bennet daughters]3041-your daughters . Only think what an establishment it would be for [one of [them]3041-your daughters]3042-one of them . [Sir William]91-sir william and [Lady Lucas]92-lady lucas are determined to go , merely on that account , for in general [you]86-mr. bennet know [they]3041-your daughters visit [no new comers]3043-no new comers . Indeed [you]86-mr. bennet must go , for it will be impossible for _ [us]3044-us _ to visit [him]90-mr. bingley , if [you]86-mr. bennet do not . "[251-his wife]

" [You]86-mr. bennet are over scrupulous surely . [I]250-his lady dare say [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley will be very glad to see [you]86-mr. bennet ; and [I]250-his lady will send a few lines by [you]86-mr. bennet to assure [him]90-mr. bingley of [my]250-his lady hearty consent to [his]90-mr. bingley marrying which ever [he]90-mr. bingley chuses of [the girls]3033-the girls ; though [I]250-his lady must throw in a good word for [[my]250-his lady little [Lizzy]93-elizabeth]3046-my little lizzy . "[250-his lady]

" [I]251-his wife desire [you]86-mr. bennet will do no such thing . [Lizzy]93-elizabeth is not a bit better than the others ; and [I]251-his wife am sure [she]93-elizabeth is not half so handsome as [Jane]94-jane , nor half so good humoured as [Lydia]95-lydia . But [you]86-mr. bennet are always giving _ [her]93-elizabeth _ the preference . "[251-his wife]

" [They]3033-the girls have none of [them]3033-the girls much to recommend [them]3033-the girls , "[254-i] replied [he]254-i ; " [they]3033-the girls are all silly and ignorant like [other girls]3047-other girls ; but [Lizzy]93-elizabeth has something more of quickness than [[her]93-elizabeth sisters]3048-her sisters . "[254-i]

" [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet , how can [you]86-mr. bennet abuse [[your]86-mr. bennet own children]3049-your own children in such a way ? [You]86-mr. bennet take delight in vexing [me]251-his wife . [You]86-mr. bennet have no compassion on [my]251-his wife poor nerves . "[251-his wife]

" [You]86-mr. bennet mistake [me]254-i , [[my]254-i dear]3018-my dear . [I]254-i have a high respect for [your]86-mr. bennet nerves . [They]3033-the girls are [[my]254-i old friends]3051-my old friends . [I]254-i have heard [you]86-mr. bennet mention [them]3033-the girls with consideration these twenty years at least . "[254-i]

" Ah ! [you]86-mr. bennet do not know what [I]251-his wife suffer . "[251-his wife]

" But [I]254-i hope [you]86-mr. bennet will get over it , and live to see [many young men of four thousand a year]3052-many young men of four thousand a year come into [the neighbourhood]3040-the neighbourhood . "[254-i]

" It will be no use to [us]3054-us , if twenty such should come since [you]86-mr. bennet will not visit [them]3052-many young men of four thousand a year . "[251-his wife]

" Depend upon it , [[my]254-i dear]3018-my dear , that when there are twenty , [I]254-i will visit [them]3052-many young men of four thousand a year all . "[254-i]

[Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet was so odd a mixture of quick parts , sarcastic humour , reserve , and caprice , that the experience of three and twenty years had been insufficient to make [[his]86-mr. bennet wife]251-his wife understand [his]86-mr. bennet character . _ [Her]251-his wife _ mind was less difficult to develope . [She]251-his wife was [a woman of mean understanding , little information , and uncertain temper]256-a woman of mean understanding , little information , and uncertain temper . When [she]251-his wife was discontented [she]251-his wife fancied [herself]251-his wife nervous . The business of [her]251-his wife life was to get [[her]251-his wife daughters]257-her daughters married ; its solace was visiting and news .

CHAPTER II .

[Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet was among [the earliest of those who waited on [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley . [He]86-mr. bennet had always intended to visit [him]90-mr. bingley , though to the last always assuring [[his]86-mr. bennet wife]251-his wife that [he]86-mr. bennet should not go]258-the earliest of those who waited on mr. bingley . he had always intended to visit him , though to the last always assuring his wife that he should not go ; and till the evening after the visit was paid , [she]251-his wife had no knowledge of it . It was then disclosed in the following manner . Observing [[his]86-mr. bennet second daughter]260-his second daughter employed in trimming a hat , [he]86-mr. bennet suddenly addressed [her]260-his second daughter with ,

" [I]86-mr. bennet hope [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley will like it [Lizzy]93-elizabeth . "[86-mr. bennet]

" [We]3056-we are not in a way to know _ what _ [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley likes , "[261-her mother] said [[her]260-his second daughter mother]261-her mother resentfully , " since [we]3056-we are not to visit . "[261-her mother]

" But [you]261-her mother forget , [mama]3057-mama , "[93-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , " that [we]3056-we shall meet [him]90-mr. bingley at [the assemblies]3058-the assemblies , and that [Mrs. Long]87-mrs. long has promised to introduce [him]90-mr. bingley . "[93-elizabeth]

" [I]261-her mother do not believe [Mrs. Long]87-mrs. long will do any such thing . [She]87-mrs. long has [two nieces of [her]87-mrs. long own]3059-two nieces of her own . [She]87-mrs. long is [a selfish , hypocritical woman]3060-a selfish , hypocritical woman , and [I]261-her mother have no opinion of [her]87-mrs. long . "[261-her mother]

" No more have [I]86-mr. bennet , "[86-mr. bennet] said [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet ; " and [I]86-mr. bennet am glad to find that [you]261-her mother do not depend on [her]87-mrs. long serving [you]261-her mother . "[86-mr. bennet]

[Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet deigned not to make any reply ; but unable to contain [herself]96-mrs. bennet , began scolding [one of [[her]96-mrs. bennet daughters]257-her daughters]262-one of her daughters .

" Do n't keep coughing so , [Kitty]97-lady catherine , for heaven 's sake ! Have a little compassion on [my]86-mr. bennet nerves . [You]261-her mother tear [them]3061-them to pieces . "[86-mr. bennet]

" [Kitty]97-lady catherine has no discretion in [her]97-lady catherine coughs , "[264-her father] said [[her]262-one of her daughters father]264-her father ; " [she]97-lady catherine times [them]3061-them ill . "[264-her father]

" [I]97-lady catherine do not cough for [my]97-lady catherine own amusement , "[97-lady catherine] replied [Kitty]97-lady catherine fretfully .

" When is [your]264-her father next ball to be , [Lizzy]93-elizabeth ? "[86-mr. bennet]

" To - morrow fortnight . "[86-mr. bennet]

" Aye , so it is , "[261-her mother] cried [[her]262-one of her daughters mother]261-her mother , " and [Mrs. Long]87-mrs. long does not come back till the day before ; so , it will be impossible for [her]87-mrs. long to introduce [him]264-her father , for [she]87-mrs. long will not know [him]264-her father [herself]87-mrs. long . "[261-her mother]

" Then , [[my]264-her father dear]3018-my dear , [you]3018-my dear may have the advantage of [[your]3018-my dear friend]3063-your friend , and introduce [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley to _ [her]3063-your friend _ . "[264-her father]

" Impossible , [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet , impossible , when [I]261-her mother am not acquainted with [him]264-her father [myself]261-her mother ; how can [you]86-mr. bennet be so teazing ? "[261-her mother]

" [I]264-her father honour [your]86-mr. bennet circumspection . A fortnight 's acquaintance is certainly very little . [One]3064-one can not know what [a man]3065-a man really is by the end of a fortnight . But if _ [we]3066-we _ do not venture , [somebody else]3067-somebody else will ; and after all , [Mrs. Long]87-mrs. long and [[her]87-mrs. long nieces]3068-her nieces must stand [their]3033-the girls chance ; and therefore , as [she]87-mrs. long will think it an act of kindness , if [you]86-mr. bennet decline the office , [I]264-her father will take it on [myself]264-her father . "[264-her father]

[The girls]3033-the girls stared at [[their]3033-the girls father]267-their father . [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet said only , " Nonsense , nonsense ! "[96-mrs. bennet]

" What can be the meaning of that emphatic exclamation ? "[267-their father] cried [he]267-their father . " Do [you]98-mary consider the forms of introduction , and the stress that is laid on them , as nonsense ? [I]267-their father can not quite agree with [you]98-mary _ there _ . What say [you]98-mary , [Mary]98-mary ? for [you]98-mary are [a young lady of deep reflection]3069-a young lady of deep reflection [I]267-their father know , and read great books , and make extracts . "[267-their father]

[Mary]98-mary wished to say something very sensible , but knew not how .

" While [Mary]98-mary is adjusting [her]98-mary ideas , "[267-their father] [he]267-their father continued , " let [us]3070-us return to [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley . "[267-their father]

" [I]251-his wife am sick of [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley , "[251-his wife] cried [[his]267-their father wife]251-his wife .

" [I]269-the ladies am sorry to hear _ that _ ; but why did not [you]267-their father tell [me]269-the ladies so before ? If [I]269-the ladies had known as much this morning , [I]269-the ladies certainly would not have called on [him]90-mr. bingley . It is very unlucky ; but as [I]269-the ladies have actually paid the visit , [we]3070-us can not escape the acquaintance now . "[269-the ladies]

The astonishment of [the ladies]269-the ladies was just what [he]267-their father wished ; that of [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet perhaps surpassing [the rest]270-the rest ; though when the first tumult of joy was over , [she]251-his wife began to declare that it was what [she]251-his wife had expected all the while .

" How good it was in [you]267-their father , [[my]251-his wife dear]3018-my dear [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet ! But [I]251-his wife knew [I]251-his wife should persuade [you]267-their father at last . [I]251-his wife was sure [you]267-their father loved [[your]267-their father girls]3072-your girls too well to neglect such an acquaintance . Well , how pleased [I]251-his wife am ! and it is such a good joke , too , that [you]267-their father should have gone this morning , and never said a word about it till now . "[251-his wife]

" Now , [Kitty]97-lady catherine , [you]97-lady catherine may cough as much as [you]97-lady catherine chuse , "[86-mr. bennet] said [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet ; and , as [he]86-mr. bennet spoke , [he]86-mr. bennet left [the room]271-the room , fatigued with the raptures of [[his]86-mr. bennet wife]251-his wife .

" What [an excellent father]3073-an excellent father [you]267-their father have , [girls]3074-girls , "[251-his wife] said [she]251-his wife , when the door was shut . " [I]251-his wife do not know how [you]267-their father will ever make [him]86-mr. bennet amends for [his]86-mr. bennet kindness ; or [me]251-his wife either , for that matter . At [our]3075-our time of life , it is not so pleasant [I]251-his wife can tell [you]267-their father , to be making new acquaintance every day ; but for [your]267-their father sakes , [we]3075-our would do any thing . [Lydia]95-lydia , [[my]251-his wife love]3076-my love , though [you]95-lydia _ are _ the youngest , [I]251-his wife dare say [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley will dance with [you]95-lydia at the next ball . "[251-his wife]

" Oh ! "[95-lydia] said [Lydia]95-lydia stoutly , " [I]95-lydia am not afraid ; for though [I]95-lydia _ am _ [the youngest]3077-the youngest , [I]95-lydia 'm [the tallest]3078-the tallest . "[95-lydia]

The rest of the evening was spent in conjecturing how soon [he]273-he would return [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet 's visit , and determining when [they]274-they should ask [him]273-he to dinner .

CHAPTER III .

Not all that [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet , however , with the assistance of [[her]96-mrs. bennet five daughters]275-her five daughters , could ask on the subject was sufficient to draw from [[her]96-mrs. bennet husband]276-her husband any satisfactory description of [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley . [They]274-they attacked [him]90-mr. bingley in various ways ; with barefaced questions , ingenious suppositions , and distant surmises ; but [he]90-mr. bingley eluded the skill of [them]274-they all ; and [they]274-they were at last obliged to accept the second - hand intelligence of [[their]274-they neighbour]277-their neighbour [Lady Lucas]92-lady lucas . [Her]96-mrs. bennet report was highly favourable . [Sir William]91-sir william had been delighted with [him]90-mr. bingley . [He]90-mr. bingley was quite young , wonderfully handsome , extremely agreeable , and to crown the whole , [he]90-mr. bingley meant to be at the next assembly with [a large party]278-a large party . Nothing could be more delightful ! To be fond of dancing was a certain step towards falling in love ; and very lively hopes of [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley 's heart were entertained .

" If [I]96-mrs. bennet can but see [one of [[my]96-mrs. bennet daughters]3080-my daughters]3079-one of my daughters happily settled at [Netherfield]2-netherfield , "[96-mrs. bennet] said [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet to [[her]96-mrs. bennet husband]276-her husband , " and all the others equally well married , [I]96-mrs. bennet shall have nothing to wish for . "[96-mrs. bennet]

In a few days [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley returned [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet 's visit , and sat about ten minutes with [him]86-mr. bennet in [[his]86-mr. bennet library]280-his library . [He]90-mr. bingley had entertained hopes of being admitted to a sight of [the young ladies]281-the young ladies , of whose beauty [he]90-mr. bingley had heard much ; but [he]90-mr. bingley saw only [the father]282-the father . [The ladies]269-the ladies were somewhat more fortunate , for [they]269-the ladies had the advantage of ascertaining from an upper window , that [he]90-mr. bingley wore a blue coat and rode a black horse .

An invitation to dinner was soon afterwards dispatched ; and already had [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet planned the courses that were to do credit to [[her]96-mrs. bennet housekeeping]284-her housekeeping , when an answer arrived which deferred it all . [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley was obliged to be in [town]285-town the following day , and consequently unable to accept the honour of [their]286-their invitation , & c. [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet was quite disconcerted . [She]96-mrs. bennet could not imagine what business [he]90-mr. bingley could have in [town]285-town so soon after [his]90-mr. bingley arrival in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire ; and [she]96-mrs. bennet began to fear that [he]90-mr. bingley might be always flying about from [one place]288-one place to another , and never settled at [Netherfield]2-netherfield as [he]90-mr. bingley ought to be . [Lady Lucas]92-lady lucas quieted [her]92-lady lucas fears a little by starting the idea of [his]90-mr. bingley being gone to [London]5-london only to get a large party for the ball ; and a report soon followed that [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley was to bring [twelve ladies]289-twelve ladies and [seven gentlemen]290-seven gentlemen with [him]90-mr. bingley to the assembly . [The girls]3033-the girls grieved over [such a number of [ladies]293-ladies]292-such a number of ladies ; but were comforted the day before the ball by hearing , that instead of twelve , [he]90-mr. bingley had brought only six with [him]90-mr. bingley from [London]5-london , [[his]90-mr. bingley five sisters]294-his five sisters and [a cousin]295-a cousin . And when [the party]3034-the party entered [the assembly room]297-the assembly room , it consisted of only [five altogether]298-five altogether ; [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley , [[his]90-mr. bingley two sisters]299-his two sisters , [the husband of [the eldest]301-the eldest]300-the husband of the eldest , and [another young man]302-another young man .

[Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley was good looking and gentleman - like ; [he]90-mr. bingley had a pleasant countenance , and easy , unaffected manners . [[His]90-mr. bingley sisters]303-his sisters were [fine women , with an air of decided fashion]304-fine women , with an air of decided fashion . [[His]90-mr. bingley brother - in - law]305-his brother - in - law , [Mr. Hurst]99-mr. hurst , merely looked [the gentleman]306-the gentleman ; but [[his]90-mr. bingley friend]307-his friend [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy soon drew the attention of [the room]271-the room by [[his]100-mr. darcy fine , tall person , handsome features , [noble mien]310-noble mien]309-his fine , tall person , handsome features , noble mien ; and the report which was in general circulation within five minutes after [his]100-mr. darcy entrance , of [his]100-mr. darcy having ten thousand a year . [The gentlemen]311-the gentlemen pronounced [him]100-mr. darcy to be [a fine figure of a man]312-a fine figure of a man , [the ladies]269-the ladies declared [he]100-mr. darcy was much handsomer than [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley , and [he]100-mr. darcy was looked at with great admiration for about half the evening , till [his]100-mr. darcy manners gave a disgust which turned the tide of [his]100-mr. darcy popularity ; for [he]100-mr. darcy was discovered to be proud , to be above [his]100-mr. darcy company , and above being pleased ; and not all [[his]100-mr. darcy large estate in [Derbyshire]6-derbyshire]314-his large estate in derbyshire could then save [him]100-mr. darcy from having a most forbidding , disagreeable countenance , and being unworthy to be compared with [[his]100-mr. darcy friend]307-his friend .

[Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley had soon made [himself]90-mr. bingley acquainted with [all the principal people in the room]316-all the principal people in the room ; [he]90-mr. bingley was lively and unreserved , danced every dance , was angry that the ball closed so early , and talked of giving one [himself]90-mr. bingley at [Netherfield]2-netherfield . Such amiable qualities must speak for [themselves]317-themselves . What a contrast between [him]90-mr. bingley and [[his]90-mr. bingley friend]307-his friend ! [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy danced only once with [Mrs. Hurst]101-mrs. hurst and once with [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley , declined being introduced to [any other lady]319-any other lady , and spent the rest of the evening in walking about [the room]271-the room , speaking occasionally to one of [[his]100-mr. darcy own party]321-his own party . [His]90-mr. bingley character was decided . [He]90-mr. bingley was [the proudest , most disagreeable man in [the world]323-the world]322-the proudest , most disagreeable man in the world , and [every body]324-every body hoped that [he]90-mr. bingley would never come [there]325-there again . Amongst the most violent against [him]90-mr. bingley was [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet , whose dislike of [his]90-mr. bingley general behaviour , was sharpened into particular resentment , by [his]90-mr. bingley having slighted [one of [[her]96-mrs. bennet daughters]257-her daughters]262-one of her daughters .

[Elizabeth Bennet]93-elizabeth had been obliged , by the scarcity of [gentlemen]328-gentlemen , to sit down for two dances ; and during part of that time , [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy had been standing near enough for [her]93-elizabeth to overhear a conversation between [him]100-mr. darcy and [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley , who came from the dance for a few minutes , to press [[his]100-mr. darcy friend]307-his friend to join it .

" Come , [Darcy]100-mr. darcy , "[100-mr. darcy] said [he]100-mr. darcy , " [I]100-mr. darcy must have [you]100-mr. darcy dance . [I]100-mr. darcy hate to see [you]100-mr. darcy standing about by [yourself]100-mr. darcy in this stupid manner . [You]100-mr. darcy had much better dance . "[100-mr. darcy]

" [I]93-elizabeth certainly shall not . [You]100-mr. darcy know how [I]93-elizabeth detest it , unless [I]93-elizabeth am particularly acquainted with [[my]93-elizabeth partner]3081-my partner . At such an assembly as this , it would be insupportable . [[Your]100-mr. darcy sisters]3082-your sisters are engaged , and there is not another woman in [the room]271-the room , whom it would not be a punishment to [me]93-elizabeth to stand up with . "[93-elizabeth]

" [I]90-mr. bingley would not be so fastidious as [you]100-mr. darcy are , "[90-mr. bingley] cried [Bingley]90-mr. bingley , " for a kingdom ! Upon [my]90-mr. bingley honour , [I]90-mr. bingley never met with [so many pleasant girls in [my]90-mr. bingley life]3084-so many pleasant girls in my life , as [I]90-mr. bingley have this evening ; and there are several of [them]3084-so many pleasant girls in my life [you]100-mr. darcy see uncommonly pretty . "[90-mr. bingley]

" _ [You]100-mr. darcy _ are dancing with [the only handsome girl in [the room]271-the room]3085-the only handsome girl in the room , "[100-mr. darcy] said [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , looking at [the eldest Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth .

" Oh ! [she]3085-the only handsome girl in the room is the most beautiful creature [I]90-mr. bingley ever beheld ! But there is [one of [[her]93-elizabeth sisters]3048-her sisters sitting down just behind [you]100-mr. darcy , who is very pretty , and [I]90-mr. bingley dare say , very agreeable . "[90-mr. bingley]

" Which do [you]90-mr. bingley mean ? "[100-mr. darcy] and turning round , [he]100-mr. darcy looked for a moment at [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , till catching [her]93-elizabeth eye , [he]100-mr. darcy withdrew [his]100-mr. darcy own and coldly said , " [She]3085-the only handsome girl in the room is tolerable ; but not handsome enough to tempt _ [me]100-mr. darcy _ ; and [I]100-mr. darcy am in no humour at present to give consequence to [young ladies who are slighted by [other men]3091-other men]3090-young ladies who are slighted by other men . [You]100-mr. darcy had better return to [[your]100-mr. darcy partner]3092-your partner and enjoy [her]3085-the only handsome girl in the room smiles , for [you]100-mr. darcy are wasting [your]100-mr. darcy time with [me]100-mr. darcy . "[100-mr. darcy]

[Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley followed [his]100-mr. darcy advice . [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy walked off ; and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth remained with no very cordial feelings towards [him]100-mr. darcy . [She]93-elizabeth told the story however with great spirit among [[her]93-elizabeth friends]330-her friends ; for [she]93-elizabeth had a lively , playful disposition , which delighted in any thing ridiculous .

The evening altogether passed off pleasantly to [the whole family]331-the whole family . [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet had seen [[her]96-mrs. bennet eldest daughter]332-her eldest daughter much admired by the [Netherfield]2-netherfield party . [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley had danced with [her]332-her eldest daughter twice , and [she]332-her eldest daughter had been distinguished by [[his]90-mr. bingley sisters]303-his sisters . [Jane]94-jane was as much gratified by this , as [[her]94-jane mother]261-her mother could be , though in a quieter way . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth felt [Jane]94-jane 's pleasure . [Mary]98-mary had heard [herself]98-mary mentioned to [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley as [the most accomplished girl in [the neighbourhood]3040-the neighbourhood]335-the most accomplished girl in the neighbourhood ; and [Catherine]97-lady catherine and [Lydia]95-lydia had been fortunate enough to be never without [partners]337-partners , which was all that [they]338-they had yet learnt to care for at a ball . [They]338-they returned therefore in good spirits to [Longbourn]7-longbourn , [[the village]339-the village where [they]338-they lived , and of which [they]338-they were [the principal inhabitants]341-the principal inhabitants]340-the village where they lived , and of which they were the principal inhabitants . [They]338-they found [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet still up . With a book [he]86-mr. bennet was regardless of time ; and on the present occasion [he]86-mr. bennet had a good deal of curiosity as to the event of an evening which had raised such splendid expectations . [He]86-mr. bennet had rather hoped that all [[his]86-mr. bennet wife]251-his wife 's views on [the stranger]343-the stranger would be disappointed ; but [he]86-mr. bennet soon found that [he]86-mr. bennet had a very different story to hear .

" Oh ! [[my]251-his wife dear]3018-my dear [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet , "[251-his wife] as [she]251-his wife entered [the room]271-the room , " [we]338-they have had a most delightful evening , a most excellent ball . [I]251-his wife wish [you]86-mr. bennet had been [there]325-there . [Jane]94-jane was so admired , nothing could be like it . [Every body]324-every body said how well [she]94-jane looked ; and [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley thought [her]94-jane quite beautiful , and danced with [her]94-jane twice . Only think of _ that _ [[my]251-his wife dear]3018-my dear ; [he]90-mr. bingley actually danced with [her]94-jane twice ; and [she]94-jane was the only creature in [the room]271-the room that [he]90-mr. bingley asked a second time . First of all , [he]90-mr. bingley asked [Miss Lucas]103-miss lucas . [I]251-his wife was so vexed to see [him]90-mr. bingley stand up with [her]94-jane ; but , however , [he]90-mr. bingley did not admire [her]94-jane at all : indeed , [nobody]3098-nobody can , [you]3099-you know ; and [he]90-mr. bingley seemed quite struck with [Jane]94-jane as [she]94-jane was going down the dance . So , [he]90-mr. bingley enquired who [she]94-jane was , and got introduced , and asked [her]94-jane for the two next . "[276-her husband]

" Oh ! [[my]96-mrs. bennet dear]3018-my dear , "[96-mrs. bennet] continued [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet , " [I]96-mrs. bennet am quite delighted with [him]90-mr. bingley . [He]90-mr. bingley is so excessively handsome ! and [[his]90-mr. bingley sisters]303-his sisters are [charming women]3106-charming women . [I]96-mrs. bennet dare say the lace upon [Mrs. Hurst]101-mrs. hurst 's gown---- "[96-mrs. bennet]

Here [she]96-mrs. bennet was interrupted again . [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet protested against any description of finery . [She]96-mrs. bennet was therefore obliged to seek another branch of the subject , and related , with much bitterness of spirit and some exaggeration , the shocking rudeness of [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy .

" But [I]96-mrs. bennet can assure [you]3018-my dear , "[96-mrs. bennet] [she]96-mrs. bennet added , " that [Lizzy]93-elizabeth does not lose much by not suiting _ [his]90-mr. bingley _ fancy ; for [he]90-mr. bingley is [a most disagreeable , horrid man]3107-a most disagreeable , horrid man , not at all worth pleasing . So high and so conceited that there was no enduring [him]90-mr. bingley ! [I]96-mrs. bennet quite detest [the man]3112-the man . "[96-mrs. bennet]

CHAPTER IV .

When [Jane]94-jane and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth were alone , [the former]347-the former , who had been cautious in [her]347-the former praise of [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley before , expressed to [[her]347-the former sister]348-her sister how very much [she]347-the former admired [him]90-mr. bingley .

" [He]90-mr. bingley is just what [a young man]3113-a young man ought to be , "[347-the former] said [she]347-the former , " sensible , good humoured , lively ; and [I]347-the former never saw such happy manners!--so much ease , with such perfect good breeding ! "[347-the former]

" [He]90-mr. bingley is also handsome , "[93-elizabeth] replied [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , " which [a young man]3113-a young man ought likewise to be , if [he]90-mr. bingley possibly can . [His]90-mr. bingley character is thereby complete . "[93-elizabeth]

" [I]347-the former was very much flattered by [his]90-mr. bingley asking [me]347-the former to dance a second time . [I]347-the former did not expect such a compliment . "[347-the former]

" Did not [you]347-the former ? _ [I]93-elizabeth _ did for [you]347-the former . But that is one great difference between [us]3115-us . Compliments always take _ [you]347-the former _ by surprise , and _ [me]93-elizabeth _ never . What could be more natural than [his]90-mr. bingley asking [you]347-the former again ? [He]90-mr. bingley could not help seeing that [you]347-the former were about five times as pretty as [every other woman in [the room]271-the room]3116-every other woman in the room . No thanks to [his]90-mr. bingley gallantry for that . Well , [he]90-mr. bingley certainly is very agreeable , and [I]93-elizabeth give [you]347-the former leave to like [him]90-mr. bingley . [You]347-the former have liked many [a stupider person]3118-a stupider person . "[93-elizabeth]

" [Dear Lizzy]108-dear lizzy ! "[347-the former]

" Oh ! [you]347-the former are a great deal too apt [you]347-the former know , to like [people in general]3119-people in general . [You]347-the former never see a fault in any body . All [the world]323-the world are good and agreeable in [your]347-the former eyes . [I]93-elizabeth never heard [you]347-the former speak ill of [a human being]3121-a human being in [my]93-elizabeth life . "[93-elizabeth]

" [I]347-the former would wish not to be hasty in censuring [any one]3122-any one ; but [I]347-the former always speak what [I]347-the former think . "[347-the former]

" [I]93-elizabeth know [you]347-the former do ; and it is _ that _ which makes the wonder . With _ [your]347-the former _ good sense , to be so honestly blind to the follies and nonsense of [others]3123-others ! Affectation of candour is common enough;--one meets it every where . But to be candid without ostentation or design -- to take the good of every body 's character and make it still better , and say nothing of the bad -- belongs to [you]347-the former alone . And so , [you]347-the former like [[this man]3124-this man 's sisters]3125-this man 's sisters too , do [you]347-the former ? [Their]3125-this man 's sisters manners are not equal to [his]3124-this man . "[93-elizabeth]

" Certainly not ; at first . But [they]3125-this man 's sisters are very pleasing women when [you]347-the former converse with [them]3125-this man 's sisters . [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley is to live with [[her]102-miss bingley brother]3126-her brother and keep [[his]3126-her brother house]3127-his house ; and [I]347-the former am much mistaken if [we]3128-we shall not find [a very charming neighbour in [her]102-miss bingley]3129-a very charming neighbour in her . "[347-the former]

[Elizabeth]108-dear lizzy listened in silence , but was not convinced ; [their]349-they behaviour at the assembly had not been calculated to please in general ; and with more quickness of observation and less pliancy of temper than [[her]108-dear lizzy sister]348-her sister , and with a judgment too unassailed by any attention to [herself]108-dear lizzy , [she]108-dear lizzy was very little disposed to approve [them]349-they . [They]349-they were in fact [very fine ladies]351-very fine ladies ; not deficient in good humour when [they]349-they were pleased , nor in the power of being agreeable where [they]349-they chose it ; but proud and conceited . [They]349-they were rather handsome , had been educated in [one of [the first private seminaries in [town]285-town]353-the first private seminaries in town]352-one of the first private seminaries in town , had a fortune of twenty thousand pounds , were in the habit of spending more than [they]349-they ought , and of associating with [people of rank]355-people of rank ; and were therefore in every respect entitled to think well of [themselves]349-they , and meanly of [others]3123-others . [They]349-they were of [a respectable family in [the north of [England]3-england]3022-the north of england]357-a respectable family in the north of england ; a circumstance more deeply impressed on [their]349-they memories than that [[their]349-they brother]359-their brother 's fortune and [their]349-they own had been acquired by trade .

[Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley inherited property to the amount of nearly an hundred thousand pounds from [[his]90-mr. bingley father]360-his father , who had intended to purchase [an estate]361-an estate , but did not live to do it.--Mr . [Bingley]90-mr. bingley intended [it]361-an estate likewise , and sometimes made choice of [[his]90-mr. bingley county]362-his county ; but as [he]90-mr. bingley was now provided with [a good house]363-a good house and the liberty of [a manor]364-a manor , it was doubtful to [many of those who best knew the easiness of [his]90-mr. bingley temper , whether [he]90-mr. bingley might not spend the remainder of [his]90-mr. bingley days at [Netherfield]2-netherfield]365-many of those who best knew the easiness of his temper , whether he might not spend the remainder of his days at netherfield , and leave [the next generation to purchase]366-the next generation to purchase .

[[His]90-mr. bingley sisters]303-his sisters were very anxious for [his]90-mr. bingley having [an estate of [his]90-mr. bingley own]368-an estate of his own ; but though [he]90-mr. bingley was now established only as [a tenant]369-a tenant , [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley was by no means unwilling to preside at [his]90-mr. bingley table , nor was [Mrs. Hurst]101-mrs. hurst , who had married [a man of more fashion than fortune]370-a man of more fashion than fortune , less disposed to consider [[his]90-mr. bingley house]3127-his house as [[her]101-mrs. hurst home]372-her home when it suited [her]101-mrs. hurst . [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley had not been of age two years , when [he]90-mr. bingley was tempted by an accidental recommendation to look at [Netherfield House]8-netherfield house . [He]90-mr. bingley did look at [it]3127-his house and into it for half an hour , was pleased with the situation and [the principal rooms]373-the principal rooms , satisfied with what [the owner]374-the owner said in its praise , and took it immediately .

Between [him]90-mr. bingley and [Darcy]100-mr. darcy there was a very steady friendship , in spite of a great opposition of character.--Bingley was endeared to [Darcy]100-mr. darcy by the easiness , openness , ductility of [his]90-mr. bingley temper , though no disposition could offer a greater contrast to [his]90-mr. bingley own , and though with [his]90-mr. bingley own [he]90-mr. bingley never appeared dissatisfied . On the strength of [Darcy]100-mr. darcy 's regard [Bingley]90-mr. bingley had the firmest reliance , and of [his]90-mr. bingley judgment the highest opinion . In understanding [Darcy]100-mr. darcy was [the superior]375-the superior . [Bingley]90-mr. bingley was by no means deficient , but [Darcy]100-mr. darcy was clever . [He]100-mr. darcy was at the same time haughty , reserved , and fastidious , and [his]100-mr. darcy manners , though well bred , were not inviting . In that respect [[his]90-mr. bingley friend]307-his friend had greatly the advantage . [Bingley]90-mr. bingley was sure of being liked wherever [he]90-mr. bingley appeared , [Darcy]100-mr. darcy was continually giving offence .

The manner in which [they]377-they spoke of [the Meryton]9-meryton assembly was sufficiently characteristic . [Bingley]90-mr. bingley had never met with [pleasanter people]378-pleasanter people or [prettier girls]379-prettier girls in [his]90-mr. bingley life ; every body had been most kind and attentive to [him]90-mr. bingley , there had been no formality , no stiffness , [he]90-mr. bingley had soon felt acquainted with all [the room]271-the room ; and as to [Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth , [he]90-mr. bingley could not conceive [an angel more beautiful]381-an angel more beautiful . [Darcy]100-mr. darcy , on the contrary , had seen a collection of [people in whom there was little beauty and no fashion]382-people in whom there was little beauty and no fashion , for none of whom [he]100-mr. darcy had felt the smallest interest , and from [none received either attention or pleasure]383-none received either attention or pleasure . [Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth [he]100-mr. darcy acknowledged to be pretty , but [she]93-elizabeth smiled too much .

[Mrs. Hurst]101-mrs. hurst and [[her]101-mrs. hurst sister]348-her sister allowed it to be so -- but still [they]385-they admired [her]93-elizabeth and liked [her]93-elizabeth , and pronounced [her]93-elizabeth to be [a sweet girl]386-a sweet girl , and one whom [they]385-they should not object to know more of . [Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth was therefore established as [a sweet girl]386-a sweet girl , and [[their]385-they brother]359-their brother felt authorised by such commendation to think of [her]93-elizabeth as [he]359-their brother chose .

CHAPTER V.

Within a short walk of [Longbourn]7-longbourn lived [a family with whom [the Bennets]111-the bennets were particularly intimate]389-a family with whom the bennets were particularly intimate . [Sir William Lucas]91-sir william had been formerly in trade in [Meryton]9-meryton , where [he]91-sir william had made a tolerable fortune and risen to the honour of knighthood by an address to [the King]390-the king , during [his]91-sir william mayoralty . The distinction had perhaps been felt too strongly . It had given [him]91-sir william a disgust to [his]91-sir william business and to [[his]91-sir william residence in [a small market town]392-a small market town]391-his residence in a small market town ; and quitting [them]393-them both , [he]91-sir william had removed with [[his]91-sir william family]394-his family to [a house about a mile from [Meryton]9-meryton , denominated from that period [Lucas Lodge]10-lucas lodge , where [he]91-sir william could think with pleasure of [his]91-sir william own importance]395-a house about a mile from meryton , denominated from that period lucas lodge , where he could think with pleasure of his own importance , and unshackled by business , occupy [himself]91-sir william solely in being civil to [all the world]396-all the world . For though elated by [his]91-sir william rank , it did not render [him]91-sir william supercilious ; on the contrary , [he]91-sir william was all attention to every body . By nature inoffensive , friendly and obliging , [his]91-sir william presentation at [[St. James]11-st. james 's]397-st. james 's had made [him]91-sir william courteous .

[Lady Lucas]92-lady lucas was [a very good kind of woman]398-a very good kind of woman , not too clever to be [a valuable neighbour to [Mrs. Bennet.--They]112-mrs. bennet.--they]399-a valuable neighbour to mrs. bennet.--they had [several children]400-several children . [The eldest of [them]400-several children]401-the eldest of them , [a sensible , intelligent young woman , about twenty - seven]402-a sensible , intelligent young woman , about twenty - seven , was [[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth 's intimate friend]403-elizabeth 's intimate friend .

That [the Miss Lucases]113-the lucases and [the Miss Bennets]111-the bennets should meet to talk over a ball was absolutely necessary ; and the morning after the assembly brought [the former]347-the former to [Longbourn]7-longbourn to hear and to communicate .

" _ [You]103-miss lucas _ began the evening well , [Charlotte]114-charlotte , "[96-mrs. bennet] said [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet with civil self - command to [Miss Lucas]103-miss lucas . " _ [You]103-miss lucas _ were [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley 's first choice . "[96-mrs. bennet]

" Yes;--but [he]90-mr. bingley seemed to like [his]90-mr. bingley second better . "[347-the former]

" [Oh!--you]103-miss lucas mean [Jane]94-jane , [I]96-mrs. bennet suppose -- because [he]90-mr. bingley danced with [her]94-jane twice . To be sure that _ did _ seem as if [he]90-mr. bingley admired [her]94-jane -- indeed [I]96-mrs. bennet rather believe [he]90-mr. bingley _ did_--I heard something about it -- but [I]96-mrs. bennet hardly know what -- something about [Mr. Robinson]115-mr. robinson . "[96-mrs. bennet]

" Perhaps [you]103-miss lucas mean what [I]347-the former overheard between [him]90-mr. bingley and [Mr. Robinson]115-mr. robinson ; did not [I]347-the former mention it to [you]103-miss lucas ? [Mr. Robinson]115-mr. robinson 's asking [him]90-mr. bingley how [he]90-mr. bingley liked [our]3130-our Meryton assemblies , and whether [he]90-mr. bingley did not think there were [a great many pretty women in [the room]271-the room]3131-a great many pretty women in the room , and _ which _ [he]90-mr. bingley thought the prettiest ? and [his]90-mr. bingley answering immediately to the last question -- Oh ! [the eldest Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth beyond a doubt , there can not be two opinions on that point . "[347-the former]

" Upon [my]96-mrs. bennet word!--Well , that was very decided indeed -- that does seem as if----but however , it may all come to nothing [you]103-miss lucas know . "[96-mrs. bennet]

" _ [My]114-charlotte _ overhearings were more to the purpose than _ yours _ , [Eliza]93-elizabeth , "[114-charlotte] said [Charlotte]114-charlotte . " [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy is not so well worth listening to as [[his]100-mr. darcy friend]307-his friend , is [he?--Poor Eliza!--to]116-he?--poor eliza!--to be only just _ tolerable _ . "[114-charlotte]

" [I]96-mrs. bennet beg [you]103-miss lucas would not put it into [Lizzy]93-elizabeth 's head to be vexed by [his]90-mr. bingley ill - treatment ; for [he]90-mr. bingley is such [a disagreeable man]3134-a disagreeable man that it would be quite a misfortune to be liked by [him]90-mr. bingley . [Mrs. Long]87-mrs. long told [me]96-mrs. bennet last night that [he]90-mr. bingley sat close to [her]87-mrs. long for half an hour without once opening [his]90-mr. bingley lips . "[96-mrs. bennet]

" Are [you]103-miss lucas quite sure , [Ma'am?--is]117-ma'am?--is not there a little mistake ? "[114-charlotte] said [Jane.--"I]118-jane.--"i certainly saw [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy speaking to [her]87-mrs. long . "[96-mrs. bennet]

" Aye -- because [she]87-mrs. long asked [him]90-mr. bingley at last how [he]90-mr. bingley liked [Netherfield]2-netherfield , and [he]90-mr. bingley could not help answering her;--but [she]87-mrs. long said [he]90-mr. bingley seemed very angry at being spoke to . "[114-charlotte]

" [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley told [me]94-jane , "[94-jane] said [Jane]94-jane , " that [he]90-mr. bingley never speaks much unless among [his]90-mr. bingley intimate acquaintance . With _ [them]3135-them _ [he]90-mr. bingley is remarkably agreeable . "[94-jane]

" [I]114-charlotte do not believe a word of it , [[my]114-charlotte dear]3018-my dear . If [he]90-mr. bingley had been so very agreeable [he]90-mr. bingley would have talked to [Mrs. Long]87-mrs. long . But [I]114-charlotte can guess how it was ; [every body]324-every body says that [he]90-mr. bingley is ate up with pride , and [I]114-charlotte dare say [he]90-mr. bingley had heard somehow that [Mrs. Long]87-mrs. long does not keep [a carriage]3138-a carriage , and had come to the ball in a hack chaise . "[114-charlotte]

" [I]103-miss lucas do not mind [his]90-mr. bingley not talking to [Mrs. Long]87-mrs. long , "[103-miss lucas] said [Miss Lucas]103-miss lucas , " but [I]103-miss lucas wish [he]90-mr. bingley had danced with [Eliza]93-elizabeth . "[103-miss lucas]

" Another time , [Lizzy]93-elizabeth , "[261-her mother] said [[her]405-her mother]261-her mother , " [I]261-her mother would not dance with _ [him]90-mr. bingley _ , if [I]261-her mother were [you]93-elizabeth . "[261-her mother]

" [I]114-charlotte believe , [Ma'am]120-ma'am , [I]114-charlotte may safely promise [you]120-ma'am _ never _ to dance with [him]90-mr. bingley . "[114-charlotte]

" [His]90-mr. bingley pride , "[103-miss lucas] said [Miss Lucas]103-miss lucas , " does not offend _ [me]103-miss lucas _ so much as pride often does , because there is an excuse for it . [One]3064-one can not wonder that so very fine [a young man]3113-a young man , with [family]3141-family , fortune , every thing in [his]90-mr. bingley favour , should think highly of [himself]90-mr. bingley . If [I]103-miss lucas may so express it , [he]90-mr. bingley has a _ right _ to be proud . "[103-miss lucas]

" That is very true , "[93-elizabeth] replied [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , " and [I]93-elizabeth could easily forgive _ [his]90-mr. bingley _ pride , if [he]90-mr. bingley had not mortified _ [mine]93-elizabeth _ . "[93-elizabeth]

" Pride , "[98-mary] observed [Mary]98-mary , who piqued [herself]98-mary upon the solidity of [her]98-mary reflections , " is a very common failing [I]98-mary believe . By all that [I]98-mary have ever read , [I]98-mary am convinced that it is very common indeed , that human nature is particularly prone to it , and that there are very few of [us]3142-us who do not cherish a feeling of self - complacency on the score of some quality or other , real or imaginary . Vanity and pride are different things , though the words are often used synonimously . [A person]3143-a person may be proud without being vain . Pride relates more to [our]3142-us opinion of [ourselves]3142-us , vanity to what [we]3142-us would have [others]3123-others think of [us]3142-us . "[98-mary]

" If [I]407-a young lucas who came with his sisters were as rich as [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , "[407-a young lucas who came with his sisters] cried [a young Lucas who came with [[his]407-a young lucas who came with his sisters sisters]303-his sisters]407-a young lucas who came with his sisters , " [I]407-a young lucas who came with his sisters should not care how proud [I]407-a young lucas who came with his sisters was . [I]407-a young lucas who came with his sisters would keep a pack of foxhounds , and drink a bottle of wine every day . "[407-a young lucas who came with his sisters]

" Then [you]407-a young lucas who came with his sisters would drink a great deal more than [you]407-a young lucas who came with his sisters ought , "[96-mrs. bennet] said [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet ; " and if [I]96-mrs. bennet were to see [you]407-a young lucas who came with his sisters at it [I]96-mrs. bennet should take away [your]407-a young lucas who came with his sisters bottle directly . "[96-mrs. bennet]

[The boy]409-the boy protested that [she]96-mrs. bennet should not ; [she]96-mrs. bennet continued to declare that [she]96-mrs. bennet would , and the argument ended only with the visit .

CHAPTER VI .

[The ladies of [Longbourn]7-longbourn]410-the ladies of longbourn soon waited on [those of [Netherfield]2-netherfield]411-those of netherfield . The visit was returned in due form . [Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth 's pleasing manners grew on the good will of [Mrs. Hurst]101-mrs. hurst and [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley ; and though [the mother]412-the mother was found to be intolerable and [the younger sisters]413-the younger sisters not worth speaking to , a wish of being better acquainted with _ [them]413-the younger sisters _ , was expressed towards [the two eldest]414-the two eldest . By [Jane]94-jane this attention was received with the greatest pleasure ; but [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth still saw superciliousness in [their]413-the younger sisters treatment of every body , hardly excepting even [[her]93-elizabeth sister]348-her sister , and could not like [them]413-the younger sisters ; though [their]413-the younger sisters kindness to [Jane]94-jane , such as it was , had a value as arising in all probability from the influence of [[their]413-the younger sisters brother]359-their brother 's admiration . It was generally evident whenever [they]413-the younger sisters met , that [he]359-their brother _ did _ admire [her]94-jane ; and to _ [her]94-jane _ it was equally evident that [Jane]94-jane was yielding to the preference which [she]94-jane had begun to entertain for [him]359-their brother from the first , and was in a way to be very much in love ; but [she]94-jane considered with pleasure that it was not likely to be discovered by [the world]323-the world in general , since [Jane]94-jane united with great strength of feeling , a composure of temper and a uniform cheerfulness of manner , which would guard [her]94-jane from the suspicions of the impertinent . [She]94-jane mentioned this to [[her]94-jane friend]418-her friend [Miss Lucas]103-miss lucas .

" It may perhaps be pleasant , "[114-charlotte] replied [Charlotte]114-charlotte , " to be able to impose on [the public]3145-the public in such a case ; but it is sometimes a disadvantage to be so very guarded . If [a woman]3036-a woman conceals [her]3036-a woman affection with the same skill from the object of it , [she]3036-a woman may lose the opportunity of fixing [him]359-their brother ; and it will then be but poor consolation to believe [the world]323-the world equally in the dark . There is so much of gratitude or vanity in almost every attachment , that it is not safe to leave any to itself . [We]3148-we can all _ begin _ freely -- a slight preference is natural enough ; but there are very few of [us]3148-we who have [heart enough to be really in love without encouragement]3149-heart enough to be really in love without encouragement . In nine cases out of ten , [a woman]3036-a woman had better shew _ more _ affection than [she]3036-a woman feels . [Bingley]102-miss bingley likes [[your]3151-your sister]3152-your sister undoubtedly ; but [he]359-their brother may never do more than like [her]3152-your sister , if [she]3152-your sister does not help [him]359-their brother on . "[114-charlotte]

" But [she]3152-your sister does help [him]359-their brother on , as much as [her]3152-your sister nature will allow . If _ [I]94-jane _ can perceive [her]3152-your sister regard for [him]359-their brother , [he]359-their brother must be [a simpleton]3153-a simpleton indeed not to discover it too . "[94-jane]

" Remember , [Eliza]93-elizabeth , that [he]359-their brother does not know [Jane]94-jane 's disposition as [you]93-elizabeth do . "[114-charlotte]

" But if [a woman]3036-a woman is partial to [a man]3065-a man , and does not endeavour to conceal it , [he]359-their brother must find it out . "[94-jane]

" Perhaps [he]359-their brother must , if [he]359-their brother sees enough of [her]3152-your sister . But though [Bingley]102-miss bingley and [Jane]94-jane meet tolerably often , it is never for many hours together ; and as [they]3156-they always see [each other]3157-each other in large mixed parties , it is impossible that every moment should be employed in conversing together . [Jane]94-jane should therefore make the most of every half hour in which [she]94-jane can command [his]359-their brother attention . When [she]94-jane is secure of [him]359-their brother , there will be leisure for falling in love as much as [she]94-jane chuses . "[114-charlotte]

" [Your]93-elizabeth plan is a good one , "[94-jane] replied [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , " where nothing is in question but the desire of being well married ; and if [I]94-jane were determined to get [a rich husband]3158-a rich husband , or [any husband]3159-any husband , [I]94-jane dare say [I]94-jane should adopt it . But these are not [Jane]94-jane 's feelings ; [she]94-jane is not acting by design . As yet , [she]94-jane can not even be certain of the degree of [her]94-jane own regard , nor of its reasonableness . [She]94-jane has known [him]359-their brother only a fortnight . [She]94-jane danced four dances with [him]359-their brother at [Meryton]9-meryton ; [she]94-jane saw [him]359-their brother one morning at [[his]359-their brother own house]3160-his own house , and has since dined in company with [him]359-their brother four times . This is not quite enough to make [her]94-jane understand [his]359-their brother character . "[94-jane]

" Not as [you]94-jane represent it . Had [she]94-jane merely _ dined _ with [him]359-their brother , [she]94-jane might only have discovered whether [he]359-their brother had a good appetite ; but [you]94-jane must remember that four evenings have been also spent together -- and four evenings may do a great deal . "[93-elizabeth]

" Yes ; these four evenings have enabled [them]3161-they to ascertain that [they]3161-they both like [Vingt]121-vingt - un better than [Commerce]122-commerce ; but with respect to any other leading characteristic , [I]94-jane do not imagine that much has been unfolded . "[94-jane]

" Well , "[114-charlotte] said [Charlotte]114-charlotte , " [I]114-charlotte wish [Jane]94-jane success with all [my]114-charlotte heart ; and if [she]94-jane were married to [him]359-their brother to - morrow , [I]114-charlotte should think [she]94-jane had as good a chance of happiness , as if [she]94-jane were to be studying [his]359-their brother character for a twelvemonth . Happiness in marriage is entirely a matter of chance . If the dispositions of [the parties]3162-the parties are ever so well known to [each other]3157-each other , or ever so similar before - hand , it does not advance [their]3161-they felicity in the least . [They]3161-they always continue to grow sufficiently unlike afterwards to have [their]3161-they share of vexation ; and it is better to know as little as possible of the defects of [the person with whom [you]3165-you are to pass [your]3165-you life]3164-the person with whom you are to pass your life . "[114-charlotte]

" [You]3165-you make [me]93-elizabeth laugh , [Charlotte]114-charlotte ; but it is not sound . [You]3165-you know it is not sound , and that [you]3165-you would never act in this way [yourself]3165-you . "[93-elizabeth]

Occupied in observing [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley 's attentions to [[her]419-her sister]348-her sister , [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was far from suspecting that [she]93-elizabeth was [herself]93-elizabeth becoming an object of some interest in the eyes of [[his]90-mr. bingley friend]307-his friend . [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy had at first scarcely allowed [her]93-elizabeth to be pretty ; [he]100-mr. darcy had looked at [her]93-elizabeth without admiration at the ball ; and when [they]422-they next met , [he]100-mr. darcy looked at [her]93-elizabeth only to criticise . But no sooner had [he]100-mr. darcy made it clear to [himself]100-mr. darcy and [[his]100-mr. darcy friends]423-his friends that [she]93-elizabeth had hardly a good feature in [her]93-elizabeth face , than [he]100-mr. darcy began to find it was rendered uncommonly intelligent by the beautiful expression of [her]93-elizabeth dark eyes . To this discovery succeeded some others equally mortifying . Though [he]100-mr. darcy had detected with a critical eye more than one failure of perfect symmetry in [her]93-elizabeth form , [he]100-mr. darcy was forced to acknowledge [her]93-elizabeth figure to be light and pleasing ; and in spite of [his]100-mr. darcy asserting that [her]93-elizabeth manners were not those of the fashionable world , [he]100-mr. darcy was caught by [their]422-they easy playfulness . Of this [she]93-elizabeth was perfectly unaware;--to [her]93-elizabeth [he]100-mr. darcy was only [the man who made [himself]100-mr. darcy agreeable no where , and who had not thought [her]93-elizabeth handsome enough to dance with]424-the man who made himself agreeable no where , and who had not thought her handsome enough to dance with .

[He]100-mr. darcy began to wish to know more of [her]93-elizabeth , and as a step towards conversing with [her]93-elizabeth [himself]100-mr. darcy , attended to [her]93-elizabeth conversation with [others]3123-others . [His]100-mr. darcy doing so drew [her]93-elizabeth notice . It was at [[Sir William Lucas]91-sir william 's]426-sir william lucas 's , where [a large party were assembled]427-a large party were assembled .

" What does [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy mean , "[93-elizabeth] said [she]93-elizabeth to [Charlotte]114-charlotte , " by listening to [my]93-elizabeth conversation with [Colonel Forster]123-colonel forster ? "[93-elizabeth]

" That is a question which [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy only can answer . "[427-a large party were assembled]

" But if [he]100-mr. darcy does it any more [I]93-elizabeth shall certainly let [him]100-mr. darcy know that [I]93-elizabeth see what [he]100-mr. darcy is about . [He]100-mr. darcy has a very satirical eye , and if [I]93-elizabeth do not begin by being impertinent [myself]93-elizabeth , [I]93-elizabeth shall soon grow afraid of [him]100-mr. darcy . "[93-elizabeth]

On [his]91-sir william approaching [them]428-us soon afterwards , though without seeming to have any intention of speaking , [Miss Lucas]103-miss lucas defied [[her]103-miss lucas friend]418-her friend to mention such a subject to [him]91-sir william , which immediately provoking [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth to do it , [she]103-miss lucas turned to [him]91-sir william and said ,

" Did not [you]91-sir william think , [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , that [I]103-miss lucas expressed [myself]103-miss lucas uncommonly well just now , when [I]103-miss lucas was teazing [Colonel Forster]123-colonel forster to give [us]428-us a ball at [Meryton]9-meryton ? "[103-miss lucas]

" With great energy;--but it is a subject which always makes [a lady]3166-a lady energetic . "[103-miss lucas]

" [You]91-sir william are severe on [us]428-us . "[103-miss lucas]

" It will be _ [her]3166-a lady _ turn soon to be teazed , "[103-miss lucas] said [Miss Lucas]103-miss lucas . " [I]103-miss lucas am going to open the instrument , [Eliza]93-elizabeth , and [you]93-elizabeth know what follows . "[103-miss lucas]

" [You]93-elizabeth are a very strange creature by way of [a friend!--always]3167-a friend!--always wanting [me]103-miss lucas to play and sing before any body and every body!--If [my]103-miss lucas vanity had taken a musical turn , [you]93-elizabeth would have been invaluable , but as it is , [I]103-miss lucas would really rather not sit down before [those who must be in the habit of hearing the very best performers]3168-those who must be in the habit of hearing the very best performers . "[103-miss lucas] On [Miss Lucas]103-miss lucas 's persevering , however , [she]103-miss lucas added , " Very well ; if it must be so , it must . "[103-miss lucas] And gravely glancing at [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , " There is a fine old saying , which every body here is of course familiar with--'Keep [your]93-elizabeth breath to cool [your]93-elizabeth porridge,'--and [I]103-miss lucas shall keep [mine]103-miss lucas to swell [my]103-miss lucas song . "[103-miss lucas]

[Her]103-miss lucas performance was pleasing , though by no means capital . After a song or two , and before [she]103-miss lucas could reply to the entreaties of several that [she]103-miss lucas would sing again , [she]103-miss lucas was eagerly succeeded at the instrument by [[her]103-miss lucas sister]348-her sister [Mary]98-mary , who having , in consequence of being [the only plain one in [the family]432-the family]431-the only plain one in the family , worked hard for knowledge and accomplishments , was always impatient for display .

[Mary]98-mary had neither genius nor taste ; and though vanity had given [her]98-mary application , it had given [her]98-mary likewise a pedantic air and conceited manner , which would have injured a higher degree of excellence than [she]98-mary had reached . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , easy and unaffected , had been listened to with much more pleasure , though not playing half so well ; and [Mary]98-mary , at the end of a long concerto , was glad to purchase praise and gratitude by Scotch and Irish airs , at the request of [[her]98-mary younger sisters]433-her younger sisters , who with some of [the Lucases]113-the lucases and [two or three officers]434-two or three officers joined eagerly in dancing at one end of [the room]271-the room .

[Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy stood near [them]433-her younger sisters in silent indignation at such a mode of passing the evening , to the exclusion of all conversation , and was too much engrossed by [his]100-mr. darcy own thoughts to perceive that [Sir William Lucas]91-sir william was [[his]100-mr. darcy neighbour]436-his neighbour , till [Sir William]91-sir william thus began .

" What a charming amusement for [young people]3169-young people this is , [Mr. Darcy!--There]124-mr. darcy!--there is nothing like dancing after all.--I consider it as one of the first refinements of polished societies . "[436-his neighbour]

" Certainly , [Sir;--and]125-sir;--and it has the advantage also of being in vogue amongst [the less polished societies of the world.--Every savage can dance]3170-the less polished societies of the world.--every savage can dance . "[436-his neighbour]

[Sir William]91-sir william only smiled . " [[Your]91-sir william friend]3063-your friend performs delightfully ; "[91-sir william] [he]91-sir william continued after a pause , on seeing [Bingley]90-mr. bingley join the group;--"and [I]436-his neighbour doubt not that [you]91-sir william are an adept in the science [yourself]91-sir william , [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy . "[436-his neighbour]

" [You]91-sir william saw [me]436-his neighbour dance at [Meryton]9-meryton , [I]436-his neighbour believe , [Sir]3172-sir . "[436-his neighbour]

" Yes , indeed , and received no inconsiderable pleasure from the sight . Do [you]91-sir william often dance at [[St. James]11-st. james 's]397-st. james 's ? "[436-his neighbour]

" Never , [sir]3172-sir . "[436-his neighbour]

" Do [you]91-sir william not think it would be a proper compliment to [the place]3023-the place ? "[436-his neighbour]

" It is a compliment which [I]436-his neighbour never pay to any place if [I]436-his neighbour can avoid it . "[436-his neighbour]

" [You]91-sir william have [a house in [town]285-town]3176-a house in town , [I]436-his neighbour conclude ? "[436-his neighbour]

[Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy bowed .

" [I]436-his neighbour had once some thoughts of fixing in [town]285-town [myself]436-his neighbour -- for [I]436-his neighbour am fond of superior society ; but [I]436-his neighbour did not feel quite certain that the air of [London]5-london would agree with [Lady Lucas]92-lady lucas . "[436-his neighbour]

[He]100-mr. darcy paused in hopes of an answer ; but [[his]100-mr. darcy companion]437-his companion was not disposed to make any ; and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth at that instant moving towards [them]438-them , [he]100-mr. darcy was struck with the notion of doing a very gallant thing , and called out to [her]437-his companion ,

" [[My]100-mr. darcy dear]3018-my dear [Miss Eliza]93-elizabeth , why are not [you]437-his companion dancing?--Mr . [Darcy]100-mr. darcy , [you]437-his companion must allow [me]100-mr. darcy to present [this young lady]3180-this young lady to [you]437-his companion as [a very desirable partner.--You]3181-a very desirable partner.--you can not refuse to dance , [I]100-mr. darcy am sure , when so much beauty is before [you]437-his companion . "[100-mr. darcy] And taking [her]437-his companion hand , [he]100-mr. darcy would have given it to [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , who , though extremely surprised , was not unwilling to receive it , when [she]437-his companion instantly drew back , and said with some discomposure to [Sir William]91-sir william ,

" Indeed , [Sir]3172-sir , [I]437-his companion have not the least intention of dancing.--I entreat [you]3172-sir not to suppose that [I]437-his companion moved this way in order to beg for [a partner]3183-a partner . "[437-his companion]

[Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy with grave propriety requested to be allowed the honour of [her]437-his companion hand ; but in vain . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was determined ; nor did [Sir William]91-sir william at all shake [her]93-elizabeth purpose by [his]91-sir william attempt at persuasion .

" [You]93-elizabeth excel so much in the dance , [Miss Eliza]93-elizabeth , that it is cruel to deny [me]437-his companion the happiness of seeing [you]93-elizabeth ; and though [this gentleman]3184-this gentleman dislikes the amusement in general , [he]3184-this gentleman can have no objection , [I]437-his companion am sure , to oblige [us]3185-us for one half hour . "[437-his companion]

" [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy is all politeness , "[93-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , smiling .

" [He]100-mr. darcy is indeed -- but considering the inducement , [[my]437-his companion dear]3018-my dear [Miss Eliza]93-elizabeth , [we]3185-us can not wonder at [his]100-mr. darcy complaisance ; for who would object to [such a partner]3187-such a partner ? "[437-his companion]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth looked archly , and turned away . [Her]93-elizabeth resistance had not injured [her]93-elizabeth with [the gentleman]306-the gentleman , and [he]306-the gentleman was thinking of [her]93-elizabeth with some complacency , when thus accosted by [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley ,

" [I]437-his companion can guess the subject of [your]93-elizabeth reverie . "[437-his companion]

" [I]437-his companion should imagine not . "[437-his companion]

" [You]306-the gentleman are considering how insupportable it would be to pass many evenings in this manner -- in such society ; and indeed [I]437-his companion am quite of [your]306-the gentleman opinion . [I]437-his companion was never more annoyed ! The insipidity and yet the noise ; the nothingness and yet the self - importance of all these people!--What would [I]437-his companion give to hear [your]306-the gentleman strictures on them ! "[437-his companion]

" [Your]306-the gentleman conjecture is totally wrong , [I]437-his companion assure [you]306-the gentleman . [My]437-his companion mind was more agreeably engaged . [I]437-his companion have been meditating on the very great pleasure which a pair of fine eyes in the face of [a pretty woman]3188-a pretty woman can bestow . "[437-his companion]

[Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley immediately fixed [her]102-miss bingley eyes on [his]306-the gentleman face , and desired [he]306-the gentleman would tell [her]102-miss bingley what [lady]440-lady had the credit of inspiring such reflections . [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy replied with great intrepidity ,

" [Miss Elizabeth Bennet]93-elizabeth . "[100-mr. darcy]

" [Miss Elizabeth Bennet]93-elizabeth ! "[102-miss bingley] repeated [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley . " [I]102-miss bingley am all astonishment . How long has [she]93-elizabeth been such a favourite?--and pray when am [I]102-miss bingley to wish [you]306-the gentleman joy ? "[102-miss bingley]

" That is exactly the question which [I]100-mr. darcy expected [you]306-the gentleman to ask . [A lady]3166-a lady 's imagination is very rapid ; it jumps from admiration to love , from love to matrimony in a moment . [I]100-mr. darcy knew [you]306-the gentleman would be wishing [me]100-mr. darcy joy . "[100-mr. darcy]

" Nay , if [you]306-the gentleman are so serious about it , [I]102-miss bingley shall consider the matter as absolutely settled . [You]306-the gentleman will have [a charming mother - in - law]3190-a charming mother - in - law , indeed , and of course [she]3190-a charming mother - in - law will be always at [Pemberley]12-pemberley with [you]306-the gentleman . "[102-miss bingley]

[He]441-he listened to [her]102-miss bingley with perfect indifference , while [she]102-miss bingley chose to entertain [herself]102-miss bingley in this manner , and as [his]441-he composure convinced [her]102-miss bingley that all was safe , [her]102-miss bingley wit flowed long .

CHAPTER VII .

[[Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet 's property]442-mr. bennet 's property consisted almost entirely in an estate of two thousand a year , which , unfortunately for [[his]86-mr. bennet daughters]443-his daughters , was entailed in default of [heirs male]444-heirs male , on [a distant relation]445-a distant relation ; and [[their]443-his daughters mother]446-their mother 's fortune , though ample for [her]446-their mother situation in life , could but ill supply the deficiency of [his]86-mr. bennet . [[Her]446-their mother father]264-her father had been [an attorney in [Meryton]9-meryton]448-an attorney in meryton , and had left [her]446-their mother four thousand pounds .

[She]446-their mother had [a sister]449-a sister married to [a Mr. Philips]126-philips , who had been [a clerk to [[their]443-his daughters father]267-their father , and succeeded [him]86-mr. bennet in the business , and [a brother]452-a brother settled in [London]5-london in a respectable line of trade]450-a clerk to their father , and succeeded him in the business , and a brother settled in london in a respectable line of trade .

[The village of Longbourn]453-the village of longbourn was only one mile from [Meryton]9-meryton ; a most convenient distance for [the young ladies]281-the young ladies , who were usually tempted thither three or four times a week , to pay [their]281-the young ladies duty to [[their]281-the young ladies aunt]455-their aunt and to [a milliner 's shop just over the way]456-a milliner 's shop just over the way . [The two youngest of [the family]432-the family]457-the two youngest of the family , [Catherine]97-lady catherine and [Lydia]95-lydia , were particularly frequent in these attentions ; [their]457-the two youngest of the family minds were more vacant than [[their]457-the two youngest of the family sisters]459-their sisters ' , and when nothing better offered , a walk to [Meryton]9-meryton was necessary to amuse [their]457-the two youngest of the family morning hours and furnish conversation for the evening ; and however bare of news [the country]460-the country in general might be , [they]457-the two youngest of the family always contrived to learn some from [[their]457-the two youngest of the family aunt]455-their aunt . At present , indeed , [they]457-the two youngest of the family were well supplied both with news and happiness by the recent arrival of [a [militia regiment]463-militia regiment in [the neighbourhood]3040-the neighbourhood]462-a militia regiment in the neighbourhood ; it was to remain the whole winter , and [Meryton]9-meryton was [the head quarters]465-the head quarters .

[Their]457-the two youngest of the family visits to [Mrs. Philips]127-mrs. philips were now productive of the most interesting intelligence . Every day added something to [their]457-the two youngest of the family knowledge of [the officers]466-the officers ' names and connections . [[Their]457-the two youngest of the family lodgings]467-their lodgings were not long a secret , and at length [they]457-the two youngest of the family began to know [the officers]466-the officers [themselves]457-the two youngest of the family . [Mr. Philips]126-philips visited [them]457-the two youngest of the family all , and this opened to [[his]126-philips nieces]469-his nieces a source of felicity unknown before . [They]457-the two youngest of the family could talk of nothing but [officers]470-officers ; and [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley 's large fortune , the mention of which gave animation to [[their]457-the two youngest of the family mother]446-their mother , was worthless in [their]457-the two youngest of the family eyes when opposed to the regimentals of [an ensign]472-an ensign .

After listening one morning to [their]457-the two youngest of the family effusions on this subject , [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet coolly observed ,

" From all that [I]86-mr. bennet can collect by [your]457-the two youngest of the family manner of talking , [you]457-the two youngest of the family must be [two of [the silliest girls in [the country]460-the country]3192-the silliest girls in the country]3191-two of the silliest girls in the country . [I]86-mr. bennet have suspected it some time , but [I]86-mr. bennet am now convinced . "[86-mr. bennet]

[Catherine]97-lady catherine was disconcerted , and made no answer ; but [Lydia]95-lydia , with perfect indifference , continued to express [her]95-lydia admiration of [Captain Carter]128-captain carter , and [her]95-lydia hope of seeing [him]128-captain carter in the course of the day , as [he]128-captain carter was going the next morning to [London]5-london .

" [I]96-mrs. bennet am astonished , [[my]96-mrs. bennet dear]3018-my dear , "[96-mrs. bennet] said [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet , " that [you]3018-my dear should be so ready to think [[your]3018-my dear own children]3049-your own children silly . If [I]96-mrs. bennet wished to think slightingly of [any body 's children]3196-any body 's children , it should not be of [my]96-mrs. bennet own however . "[96-mrs. bennet]

" If [[my]95-lydia children]3197-my children are silly [I]95-lydia must hope to be always sensible of it . "[95-lydia]

" Yes -- but as it happens , [they]3197-my children are all of [them]3197-my children very clever . "[96-mrs. bennet]

" This is the only point , [I]95-lydia flatter [myself]95-lydia , on which [we]3198-our do not agree . [I]95-lydia had hoped that [our]3198-our sentiments coincided in every particular , but [I]95-lydia must so far differ from [you]3018-my dear as to think [[our]3198-our two youngest daughters]3199-our two youngest daughters uncommonly foolish . "[95-lydia]

" [[My]96-mrs. bennet dear]3018-my dear [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet , [you]3018-my dear must not expect [such girls]3201-such girls to have the sense of [[their]3201-such girls father]267-their father and mother.--When [they]3201-such girls get to [our]3198-our age [I]96-mrs. bennet dare say [they]3201-such girls will not think about [officers]470-officers any more than [we]3198-our do . [I]96-mrs. bennet remember the time when [I]96-mrs. bennet liked a red coat [myself]96-mrs. bennet very well -- and indeed so [I]96-mrs. bennet do still at [my]96-mrs. bennet heart ; and if [a smart young colonel , with five or six thousand a year]3204-a smart young colonel , with five or six thousand a year , should want [one of [[my]96-mrs. bennet girls]3206-my girls]3205-one of my girls , [I]96-mrs. bennet shall not say nay to [him]3204-a smart young colonel , with five or six thousand a year ; and [I]96-mrs. bennet thought [Colonel Forster]123-colonel forster looked very becoming the other night at [Sir William]91-sir william 's in [[his]123-colonel forster regimentals]3207-his regimentals . "[96-mrs. bennet]

" [Mama]129-mama , "[95-lydia] cried [Lydia]95-lydia , " [[my]95-lydia aunt]3208-my aunt says that [Colonel Forster]123-colonel forster and [Captain Carter]128-captain carter do not go so often to [Miss Watson]130-miss watson 's as [they]3209-they did when [they]3209-they first came ; [she]3208-my aunt sees [them]3209-they now very often standing in [[Clarke]131-clarke 's library]3210-clarke 's library . "[95-lydia]
