[Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet was prevented replying by the entrance of [the footman]473-the footman with a note for [Miss Bennet]95-lydia ; it came from [Netherfield]2-netherfield , and [the servant]474-the servant waited for an answer . [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet 's eyes sparkled with pleasure , and [she]96-mrs. bennet was eagerly calling out , while [[her]96-mrs. bennet daughter]475-her daughter read ,

" Well , [Jane]94-jane , who is it from ? what is it about ? what does [he]123-colonel forster say ? Well , [Jane]94-jane , make haste and tell [us]3211-us ; make haste , [[my]96-mrs. bennet love]3076-my love . "[96-mrs. bennet]

" It is from [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley , "[94-jane] said [Jane]94-jane , and then read it aloud .

" [[My]96-mrs. bennet dear]3018-my dear Friend ,[96-mrs. bennet]

" If [you]3018-my dear are not so compassionate as to dine to - day with [Louisa]132-louisa and [me]96-mrs. bennet , [we]3211-us shall be in danger of hating [each other]3157-each other for the rest of [our]3211-us lives , for a whole day 's t?te-?-t?te between [two women]3215-two women can never end without a quarrel . Come as soon as [you]3018-my dear can on the receipt of this . [[My]96-mrs. bennet brother]3216-my brother and [the gentlemen]311-the gentlemen are to dine with [the officers]466-the officers . [Yours]3018-my dear ever ,[96-mrs. bennet]

" [CAROLINE BINGLEY]133-caroline . "[96-mrs. bennet]

" With [the officers]466-the officers ! "[95-lydia] cried [Lydia]95-lydia . " [I]95-lydia wonder [[my]95-lydia aunt]3208-my aunt did not tell [us]3211-us of _ that _ . "[95-lydia]

" Dining out , "[96-mrs. bennet] said [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet , " that is very unlucky . "[96-mrs. bennet]

" Can [I]94-jane have [the carriage]3221-the carriage ? "[94-jane] said [Jane]94-jane .

" No , [[my]96-mrs. bennet dear]3018-my dear , [you]3018-my dear had better go on horseback , because it seems likely to rain ; and then [you]3018-my dear must stay all night . "[96-mrs. bennet]

" That would be a good scheme , "[93-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , " if [you]3018-my dear were sure that [they]466-the officers would not offer to send [her]3018-my dear [home]3223-home . "[93-elizabeth]

" Oh ! but [the gentlemen]311-the gentlemen will have [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley 's chaise to go to [Meryton]9-meryton ; and [the Hursts]134-the hursts have no horses to [theirs]134-the hursts . "[96-mrs. bennet]

" [I]93-elizabeth had much rather go in [the coach]3225-the coach . "[93-elizabeth]

" But , [[my]96-mrs. bennet dear]3018-my dear , [[your]3018-my dear father]3227-your father can not spare the horses , [I]96-mrs. bennet am sure . [They]466-the officers are wanted in [the farm]3228-the farm , [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet , are not [they]466-the officers ? "[96-mrs. bennet]

" [They]466-the officers are wanted in [the farm]3228-the farm much oftener than [I]93-elizabeth can get [them]466-the officers . "[93-elizabeth]

" But if [you]93-elizabeth have got [them]466-the officers to - day , "[93-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , " [[my]93-elizabeth mother]3230-my mother 's purpose will be answered . "[93-elizabeth]

[She]93-elizabeth did at last extort from [[her]93-elizabeth father]264-her father an acknowledgment that the horses were engaged . [Jane]94-jane was therefore obliged to go on horseback , and [[her]94-jane mother]261-her mother attended [her]94-jane to the door with many cheerful prognostics of a bad day . [Her]94-jane hopes were answered ; [Jane]94-jane had not been gone long before it rained hard . [[Her]94-jane sisters]3048-her sisters were uneasy for [her]94-jane , but [[her]94-jane mother]261-her mother was delighted . The rain continued the whole evening without intermission ; [Jane]94-jane certainly could not come back .

" This was a lucky idea of [mine]96-mrs. bennet , indeed ! "[96-mrs. bennet] said [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet , more than once , as if the credit of making it rain were all [her]96-mrs. bennet own . Till the next morning , however , [she]96-mrs. bennet was not aware of all the felicity of [her]96-mrs. bennet contrivance . Breakfast was scarcely over when [a servant from [Netherfield]2-netherfield]480-a servant from netherfield brought the following note for [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth :

" [[My]93-elizabeth dearest]3231-my dearest [Lizzy]93-elizabeth , "[93-elizabeth]

" [I]96-mrs. bennet FIND [myself]96-mrs. bennet very unwell this morning , which , [I]96-mrs. bennet suppose , is to be imputed to [my]96-mrs. bennet getting wet through yesterday . [[My]96-mrs. bennet kind friends]3232-my kind friends will not hear of [my]96-mrs. bennet returning [home]3223-home till [I]96-mrs. bennet am better . [They]3232-my kind friends insist also on [my]96-mrs. bennet seeing [Mr. Jones]135-mr. jones -- therefore do not be alarmed if [you]93-elizabeth should hear of [his]135-mr. jones having been to [me]96-mrs. bennet -- and excepting a sore - throat and head - ache there is not much the matter with [me]96-mrs. bennet . "[96-mrs. bennet]

" [Yours]93-elizabeth , & c. "[93-elizabeth]

" Well , [[my]86-mr. bennet dear]3018-my dear , "[86-mr. bennet] said [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet , when [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth had read the note aloud , " if [[your]86-mr. bennet daughter]3235-your daughter should have a dangerous fit of illness , if [she]3235-your daughter should die , it would be a comfort to know that it was all in pursuit of [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley , and under [your]86-mr. bennet orders . "[93-elizabeth]

" Oh ! [I]93-elizabeth am not at all afraid of [her]3235-your daughter dying . [People]3236-people do not die of little trifling colds . [She]3235-your daughter will be taken good care of . As long as [she]3235-your daughter stays [there]325-there , it is all very well . [I]93-elizabeth would go and see [her]3235-your daughter , if [I]93-elizabeth could have [the carriage]3221-the carriage . "[93-elizabeth]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , feeling really anxious , was determined to go to [her]93-elizabeth , though [the carriage]3221-the carriage was not to be had ; and as [she]93-elizabeth was [no horse - woman]482-no horse - woman , walking was [her]93-elizabeth only alternative . [She]93-elizabeth declared [her]93-elizabeth resolution .

" How can [you]93-elizabeth be so silly , "[261-her mother] cried [[her]93-elizabeth mother]261-her mother , " as to think of such a thing , in all this dirt ! [You]93-elizabeth will not be fit to be seen when [you]93-elizabeth get [there]325-there . "[261-her mother]

" [I]93-elizabeth shall be very fit to see [Jane]94-jane -- which is all [I]93-elizabeth want . "[93-elizabeth]

" Is this a hint to [me]264-her father , [Lizzy]93-elizabeth , "[264-her father] said [[her]93-elizabeth father]264-her father , " to send for [the horses]3240-the horses ? "[264-her father]

" No , indeed . [I]93-elizabeth do not wish to avoid the walk . The distance is nothing , when one has a motive ; only three miles . [I]93-elizabeth shall be back by dinner . "[93-elizabeth]

" [I]98-mary admire the activity of [your]93-elizabeth benevolence , "[98-mary] observed [Mary]98-mary , " but every impulse of feeling should be guided by reason ; and , in [my]98-mary opinion , exertion should always be in proportion to what is required . "[98-mary]

" [We]486-the three young ladies will go as far as [Meryton]9-meryton with [you]93-elizabeth , "[97-lady catherine] said [Catherine]97-lady catherine and [Lydia.--Elizabeth]136-lydia.--elizabeth accepted [their]485-their company , and [the three young ladies]486-the three young ladies set off together .

" If [we]486-the three young ladies make haste , "[95-lydia] said [Lydia]95-lydia , as [they]486-the three young ladies walked along , " perhaps [we]486-the three young ladies may see something of [Captain Carter]128-captain carter before [he]128-captain carter goes . "[95-lydia]

In [Meryton]9-meryton [they]486-the three young ladies parted ; [the two youngest]487-the two youngest repaired to [the lodgings of]488-the lodgings of [one of [[the officers]466-the officers ' wives]491-the officers ' wives]489-one of the officers ' wives , and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth continued [her]93-elizabeth walk alone , crossing [field]492-field after [field]492-field at a quick pace , jumping over stiles and springing over puddles with impatient activity , and finding [herself]93-elizabeth at last within view of [the house]3026-the house , with weary ancles , dirty stockings , and a face glowing with the warmth of exercise .

[She]93-elizabeth was shewn into [the breakfast - parlour]495-the breakfast - parlour , where all but [Jane]94-jane were assembled , and where [her]93-elizabeth appearance created a great deal of surprise.--That [she]93-elizabeth should have walked three miles so early in the day , in such dirty weather , and by [herself]93-elizabeth , was almost incredible to [Mrs. Hurst]101-mrs. hurst and [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley ; and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was convinced that [they]496-they held [her]93-elizabeth in contempt for it . [She]93-elizabeth was received , however , very politely by [them]496-they ; and in [[their]496-they brother]359-their brother 's manners there was something better than politeness ; there was good humour and kindness.--Mr . [Darcy]100-mr. darcy said very little , and [Mr. Hurst]99-mr. hurst nothing at all . [The former]347-the former was divided between admiration of the brilliancy which exercise had given to [her]93-elizabeth complexion , and doubt as to the occasion 's justifying [her]93-elizabeth coming so far alone . [The latter]499-the latter was thinking only of [his]99-mr. hurst breakfast .

[Her]93-elizabeth enquiries after [[her]93-elizabeth sister]348-her sister were not very favourably answered . [Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth had slept ill , and though up , was very feverish and not well enough to leave [[her]93-elizabeth room]501-her room . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was glad to be taken to [her]348-her sister immediately ; and [Jane]94-jane , who had [only been withheld by the fear of giving alarm or inconvenience]502-only been withheld by the fear of giving alarm or inconvenience , from expressing in [her]94-jane note how much [she]94-jane longed for such a visit , was delighted at [her]94-jane entrance . [She]93-elizabeth was not equal , however , to much conversation , and when [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley left [them]503-they together , could attempt little beside expressions of gratitude for the extraordinary kindness [she]93-elizabeth was treated with . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth silently attended [her]93-elizabeth .

When breakfast was over , [they]503-they were joined by [the sisters]504-the sisters ; and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth began to like [them]504-the sisters [herself]93-elizabeth , when [she]93-elizabeth saw how much affection and solicitude [they]504-the sisters shewed for [Jane]94-jane . [The apothecary]505-the apothecary came , and having examined [[his]505-the apothecary patient]506-his patient , said , as might be supposed , that [she]506-his patient had caught a violent cold , and that [they]503-they must endeavour to get the better of it ; advised [her]506-his patient to return to bed , and promised [her]506-his patient some draughts . The advice was followed readily , for the feverish symptoms increased , and [her]506-his patient head ached acutely . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth did not quit [[her]93-elizabeth room]501-her room for a moment , nor were [the other ladies]508-the other ladies often absent ; [the gentlemen]311-the gentlemen being out , [they]311-the gentlemen had in fact nothing to do elsewhere .

When the clock struck three , [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth felt that [she]93-elizabeth must go ; and very unwillingly said so . [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley offered [her]93-elizabeth the carriage , and [she]93-elizabeth only wanted a little pressing to accept it , when [Jane]94-jane testified such concern in parting with [her]93-elizabeth , that [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley was obliged to convert the offer of the chaise into an invitation to remain at [Netherfield]2-netherfield for the present . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth most thankfully consented , and [a servant]510-a servant was dispatched to [Longbourn]7-longbourn to acquaint [the family]432-the family with [her]93-elizabeth stay , and bring back a supply of clothes .

CHAPTER VIII .

At five o'clock [the two ladies]512-the two ladies retired to dress , and at half past six [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was summoned to dinner . To the civil enquiries which then poured in , and amongst which [she]93-elizabeth had the pleasure of distinguishing the much superior solicitude of [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley 's , [she]93-elizabeth could not make a very favourable answer . [Jane]94-jane was by no means better . [The sisters]504-the sisters , on hearing this , repeated three or four times how much [they]504-the sisters were grieved , how shocking it was to have a bad cold , and how excessively [they]504-the sisters disliked being ill [themselves]504-the sisters ; and then thought no more of the matter : and [their]504-the sisters indifference towards [Jane]94-jane when not immediately before [them]504-the sisters , restored [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth to the enjoyment of all [her]93-elizabeth original dislike .

[[Their]504-the sisters brother]359-their brother , indeed , was [the only one of the party whom [she]93-elizabeth could regard with any complacency]515-the only one of the party whom she could regard with any complacency . [His]359-their brother anxiety for [Jane]94-jane was evident , and [his]359-their brother attentions to [herself]93-elizabeth most pleasing , and [they]516-they prevented [her]93-elizabeth feeling [herself]93-elizabeth so much an intruder as [she]93-elizabeth believed [she]93-elizabeth was considered by [the others]517-the others . [She]93-elizabeth had very little notice from any but [him]359-their brother . [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley was engrossed by [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , [[her]102-miss bingley sister]348-her sister scarcely less so ; and as for [Mr. Hurst]99-mr. hurst , by whom [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth sat , [he]99-mr. hurst was [an indolent man , who lived only to eat , drink , and play at cards]519-an indolent man , who lived only to eat , drink , and play at cards , who when [he]99-mr. hurst found [her]93-elizabeth prefer a plain dish to a ragout , had nothing to say to [her]93-elizabeth .

When dinner was over , [she]93-elizabeth returned directly to [Jane]94-jane , and [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley began abusing [her]93-elizabeth as soon as [she]93-elizabeth was out of [the room]271-the room . [Her]93-elizabeth manners were pronounced to be very bad indeed , a mixture of pride and impertinence ; [she]93-elizabeth had no conversation , no style , no taste , no beauty . [Mrs. Hurst]101-mrs. hurst thought the same , and added ,

" [She]93-elizabeth has nothing , in short , to recommend [her]93-elizabeth , but being [an excellent walker]3241-an excellent walker . [I]101-mrs. hurst shall never forget [her]93-elizabeth appearance this morning . [She]93-elizabeth really looked almost wild . "[101-mrs. hurst]

" [She]93-elizabeth did indeed , [Louisa]132-louisa . [I]93-elizabeth could hardly keep [my]93-elizabeth countenance . Very nonsensical to come at all ! Why must _ [she]93-elizabeth _ be scampering about [the country]460-the country , because [[her]93-elizabeth sister]348-her sister had a cold ? [Her]93-elizabeth hair so untidy , so blowsy ! "[93-elizabeth]

" Yes , and [her]93-elizabeth petticoat ; [I]101-mrs. hurst hope [you]132-louisa saw [her]93-elizabeth petticoat , six inches deep in mud , [I]101-mrs. hurst am absolutely certain ; and the gown which had been let down to hide it , not doing its office . "[101-mrs. hurst]

" [Your]132-louisa picture may be very exact , [Louisa]132-louisa , "[102-miss bingley] said [Bingley]102-miss bingley ; " but this was all lost upon [me]102-miss bingley . [I]102-miss bingley thought [Miss Elizabeth Bennet]93-elizabeth looked remarkably well , when [she]93-elizabeth came into [the room]271-the room this morning . [Her]93-elizabeth dirty petticoat quite escaped [my]102-miss bingley notice . "[102-miss bingley]

" _ [You]132-louisa _ observed it , [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , [I]102-miss bingley am sure , "[102-miss bingley] said [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley ; " and [I]102-miss bingley am inclined to think that [you]100-mr. darcy would not wish to see _ [[your]100-mr. darcy sister]3152-your sister _ make such an exhibition . "[102-miss bingley]

" Certainly not . "[101-mrs. hurst]

" To walk three miles , or four miles , or five miles , or whatever it is , above [her]3152-your sister ancles in dirt , and alone , quite alone ! what could [she]3152-your sister mean by it ? It seems to [me]102-miss bingley to shew an abominable sort of conceited independence , a most country town indifference to decorum . "[102-miss bingley]

" It shews an affection for [[her]3152-your sister sister]348-her sister that is very pleasing , "[102-miss bingley] said [Bingley]102-miss bingley .

" [I]102-miss bingley am afraid , [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , "[102-miss bingley] observed [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley , in a half whisper , " that this adventure has rather affected [your]100-mr. darcy admiration of [her]3152-your sister fine eyes . "[102-miss bingley]

" Not at all , "[521-i] [he]521-i replied ; " they were brightened by the exercise . "--A[521-i] short pause followed this speech , and [Mrs. Hurst]101-mrs. hurst began again .

" [I]102-miss bingley have an excessive regard for [Jane Bennet]94-jane , [she]94-jane is really [a very sweet girl]3247-a very sweet girl , and [I]102-miss bingley wish with all [my]102-miss bingley heart [she]94-jane were well settled . But with such [a father]3248-a father and [mother]3249-mother , and such low connections , [I]102-miss bingley am afraid there is no chance of it . "[102-miss bingley]

" [I]521-i think [I]521-i have heard [you]100-mr. darcy say , that [[their]523-they uncle]3250-their uncle is [an attorney in [Meryton]9-meryton]448-an attorney in meryton . "[521-i]

" Yes ; and [they]523-they have another , who lives somewhere near [Cheapside]13-cheapside . "[102-miss bingley]

" That is capital , "[348-her sister] added [[her]101-mrs. hurst sister]348-her sister , and [they]523-they both laughed heartily .

" If [they]523-they had [uncles]3252-uncles enough to fill _ all _ [Cheapside]13-cheapside , "[102-miss bingley] cried [Bingley]102-miss bingley , " it would not make [them]523-they one jot less agreeable . "[102-miss bingley]

" But it must very materially lessen [their]523-they chance of marrying [men of any consideration]3253-men of any consideration in [the world]323-the world , "[100-mr. darcy] replied [Darcy]100-mr. darcy .

To this speech [Bingley]102-miss bingley made no answer ; but [[his]524-his sisters]303-his sisters gave it [their]303-his sisters hearty assent , and indulged [their]303-his sisters mirth for some time at the expense of [[their]303-his sisters dear friend]526-their dear friend 's vulgar relations .

With a renewal of tenderness , however , [they]303-his sisters repaired to [[her]101-mrs. hurst room]501-her room on leaving [the dining - parlour]528-the dining - parlour , and sat with [her]101-mrs. hurst till summoned to coffee . [She]101-mrs. hurst was still very poorly , and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth would not quit [her]101-mrs. hurst at all , till late in the evening , when [she]93-elizabeth had the comfort of seeing [her]101-mrs. hurst asleep , and when it appeared to [her]93-elizabeth rather right than pleasant that [she]93-elizabeth should go down [stairs]529-stairs [herself]93-elizabeth . On entering [the drawing - room]530-the drawing - room [she]93-elizabeth found [the whole party]531-the whole party at loo , and was immediately invited to join [them]531-the whole party ; but suspecting [them]531-the whole party to be playing high [she]93-elizabeth declined it , and making [[her]93-elizabeth sister]348-her sister the excuse , said [she]93-elizabeth would amuse [herself]93-elizabeth for the short time [she]93-elizabeth could stay below with a book . [Mr. Hurst]99-mr. hurst looked at [her]93-elizabeth with astonishment .

" Do [you]93-elizabeth prefer reading to cards ? "[99-mr. hurst] said [he]99-mr. hurst ; " that is rather singular . "[99-mr. hurst]

" [Miss Eliza Bennet]93-elizabeth , "[102-miss bingley] said [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley , " despises cards . [She]93-elizabeth is [a great reader]3255-a great reader and has no pleasure in anything else . "[102-miss bingley]

" [I]93-elizabeth deserve neither such praise nor such censure , "[93-elizabeth] cried [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth ; " [I]93-elizabeth am _ not _ [a great reader]3255-a great reader , and [I]93-elizabeth have pleasure in many things . "[93-elizabeth]

" In nursing [[your]93-elizabeth sister]3152-your sister [I]102-miss bingley am sure [you]93-elizabeth have pleasure , "[102-miss bingley] said [Bingley]102-miss bingley ; " and [I]102-miss bingley hope it will soon be increased by seeing [her]3152-your sister quite well . "[102-miss bingley]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth thanked [him]99-mr. hurst from [her]93-elizabeth heart , and then walked towards a table where a few books were lying . [He]99-mr. hurst immediately offered to fetch [her]93-elizabeth others ; all that [[his]99-mr. hurst library]280-his library afforded .

" And [I]93-elizabeth wish [my]93-elizabeth collection were larger for [your]93-elizabeth benefit and [my]93-elizabeth own credit ; but [I]93-elizabeth am [an idle fellow]3258-an idle fellow , and though [I]93-elizabeth have not many , [I]93-elizabeth have more than [I]93-elizabeth ever look into . "[93-elizabeth]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth assured [him]99-mr. hurst that [she]93-elizabeth could suit [herself]93-elizabeth perfectly with those in [the room]271-the room .

" [I]102-miss bingley am astonished , "[102-miss bingley] said [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley , " that [[my]102-miss bingley father]3259-my father should have left so small a collection of books.--What [a delightful library [you]93-elizabeth have at [Pemberley]12-pemberley]3260-a delightful library you have at pemberley , [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy ! "[102-miss bingley]

" It ought to be good , "[99-mr. hurst] [he]99-mr. hurst replied , " it has been the work of many generations . "[99-mr. hurst]

" And then [you]93-elizabeth have added so much to it [yourself]93-elizabeth , [you]93-elizabeth are always buying books . "[93-elizabeth]

" [I]99-mr. hurst can not comprehend the neglect of [a family library]3261-a family library in such days as these . "[99-mr. hurst]

" Neglect ! [I]93-elizabeth am sure [you]93-elizabeth neglect nothing that can add to the beauties of [that noble place]3262-that noble place . [Charles]137-charles , when [you]93-elizabeth build _ [[your]93-elizabeth _ house]3263-your _ house , [I]93-elizabeth wish it may be half as delightful as [Pemberley]12-pemberley . "[93-elizabeth]

" [I]99-mr. hurst wish it may . "[99-mr. hurst]

" But [I]93-elizabeth would really advise [you]93-elizabeth to make [your]93-elizabeth purchase in [that neighbourhood]3264-that neighbourhood , and take [Pemberley]12-pemberley for a kind of model . There is [not [a finer county]3266-a finer county in [England]3-england]3265-not a finer county in england than [Derbyshire]6-derbyshire . "[93-elizabeth]

" With all [my]99-mr. hurst heart ; [I]99-mr. hurst will buy [Pemberley]12-pemberley itself if [Darcy]100-mr. darcy will sell it . "[99-mr. hurst]

" [I]93-elizabeth am talking of possibilities , [Charles]137-charles . "[93-elizabeth]

" Upon [my]99-mr. hurst word , [Caroline]133-caroline , [I]99-mr. hurst should think it more possible to get [Pemberley]12-pemberley by purchase than by imitation . "[99-mr. hurst]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was so much caught by what passed , as to leave [her]93-elizabeth very little attention for [her]93-elizabeth book ; and soon laying it wholly aside , [she]93-elizabeth drew near the card - table , and stationed [herself]93-elizabeth between [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley and [[his]90-mr. bingley eldest sister]535-his eldest sister , to observe the game .

" Is [Miss Darcy]139-miss darcy much grown since the spring ? "[102-miss bingley] said [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley ; " will [she]139-miss darcy be as tall as [I]102-miss bingley am ? "[102-miss bingley]

" [I]93-elizabeth think [she]139-miss darcy will . [She]139-miss darcy is now about [Miss Elizabeth Bennet]93-elizabeth 's height , or rather taller . "[93-elizabeth]

" How [I]102-miss bingley long to see [her]139-miss darcy again ! [I]102-miss bingley never met with anybody who delighted [me]102-miss bingley so much . Such a countenance , such manners ! and so extremely accomplished for [her]139-miss darcy age ! [Her]139-miss darcy performance on the piano - forte is exquisite . "[102-miss bingley]

" It is amazing to [me]90-mr. bingley , "[90-mr. bingley] said [Bingley]90-mr. bingley , " how [young ladies]3267-young ladies can have patience to be so very accomplished , as [they]3267-young ladies all are . "[90-mr. bingley]

" [All young ladies]3268-all young ladies accomplished ! [[My]102-miss bingley dear]3018-my dear [Charles]137-charles , what do [you]137-charles mean ? "[102-miss bingley]

" Yes , all of [them]3268-all young ladies , [I]90-mr. bingley think . [They]3268-all young ladies all paint tables , cover skreens and net purses . [I]90-mr. bingley scarcely know [any one who can not do all this]3270-any one who can not do all this , and [I]90-mr. bingley am sure [I]90-mr. bingley never heard [a young lady]3271-a young lady spoken of for the first time , without being informed that [she]3271-a young lady was very accomplished . "[90-mr. bingley]

" [Your]90-mr. bingley list of the common extent of accomplishments , "[139-miss darcy] said [Darcy]139-miss darcy , " has too much truth . The word is applied to many [a woman who deserves it no otherwise than by netting a purse , or covering a skreen]3272-a woman who deserves it no otherwise than by netting a purse , or covering a skreen . But [I]139-miss darcy am very far from agreeing with [you]90-mr. bingley in [your]90-mr. bingley estimation of [ladies in general]3273-ladies in general . [I]139-miss darcy can not boast of knowing more than half a dozen , in the whole range of [my]139-miss darcy acquaintance , that are really accomplished . "[139-miss darcy]

" Nor [I]102-miss bingley , [I]102-miss bingley am sure , "[102-miss bingley] said [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley .

" Then , "[93-elizabeth] observed [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , " [you]90-mr. bingley must comprehend a great deal in [your]90-mr. bingley idea of [an accomplished woman]3274-an accomplished woman . "[93-elizabeth]

" Yes ; [I]139-miss darcy do comprehend a great deal in it . "[139-miss darcy]

" Oh ! certainly , "[537-his faithful assistant] cried [[his]536-his faithful assistant]537-his faithful assistant , " [no one]3275-no one can be really esteemed accomplished , who does not greatly surpass what is usually met with . [A woman]3036-a woman must have a thorough knowledge of music , singing , drawing , dancing , and the modern languages , to deserve the word ; and besides all this , [she]3036-a woman must possess a certain something in [her]3036-a woman air and manner of walking , the tone of [her]3036-a woman voice , [her]3036-a woman address and expressions , or the word will be but half deserved . "[537-his faithful assistant]

" All this [she]3036-a woman must possess , "[139-miss darcy] added [Darcy]139-miss darcy , " and to all this [she]3036-a woman must yet add something more substantial , in the improvement of [her]3036-a woman mind by extensive reading . "[139-miss darcy]

" [I]537-his faithful assistant am no longer surprised at [your]90-mr. bingley knowing _ only _ [six accomplished women]3277-six accomplished women . [I]537-his faithful assistant rather wonder now at [your]90-mr. bingley knowing _ any _ . "[537-his faithful assistant]

" Are [you]90-mr. bingley so severe upon [your]90-mr. bingley own sex , as to doubt the possibility of all this ? "[139-miss darcy]

" _ [I]537-his faithful assistant _ never saw [such a woman]3278-such a woman . _ [I]537-his faithful assistant _ never saw such capacity , and taste , and application , and elegance , as [you]90-mr. bingley describe , united . "[537-his faithful assistant]

[Mrs. Hurst]101-mrs. hurst and [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley both cried out against the injustice of [her]102-miss bingley implied doubt , and were both protesting that [they]538-them knew [many women who answered this description]539-many women who answered this description , when [Mr. Hurst]99-mr. hurst called [them]538-them to order , with bitter complaints of [their]538-them inattention to what was going forward . As all conversation was thereby at an end , [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth soon afterwards left [the room]271-the room .

" [Eliza Bennet]93-elizabeth , "[102-miss bingley] said [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley , when the door was closed on [her]93-elizabeth , " is one of [those young ladies who seek to recommend [themselves]3279-those young ladies who seek to recommend themselves to the other sex , by undervaluing their own to the other sex , by undervaluing [their]3279-those young ladies who seek to recommend themselves to the other sex , by undervaluing their own own]3279-those young ladies who seek to recommend themselves to the other sex , by undervaluing their own ; and with [many men]3280-many men , [I]102-miss bingley dare say , it succeeds . But , in [my]102-miss bingley opinion , it is a paltry device , a very mean art . "[102-miss bingley]

" Undoubtedly , "[139-miss darcy] replied [Darcy]139-miss darcy , to whom this remark was chiefly addressed , " there is meanness in _ all _ the arts which [ladies]293-ladies sometimes condescend to employ for captivation . Whatever bears affinity to cunning is despicable . "[139-miss darcy]

[Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley was not so entirely satisfied with this reply as to continue the subject .

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth joined [them]538-them again only to say that [[her]93-elizabeth sister]348-her sister was worse , and that [she]93-elizabeth could not leave [her]348-her sister . [Bingley]102-miss bingley urged [Mr. Jones]135-mr. jones 's being sent for immediately ; while [[his]135-mr. jones sisters]303-his sisters , convinced that no country advice could be of any service , recommended an express to [town]285-town for [one of [the most eminent physicians]545-the most eminent physicians]544-one of the most eminent physicians . This , [she]93-elizabeth would not hear of ; but [she]93-elizabeth was not so unwilling to comply with [[their]538-them brother]359-their brother 's proposal ; and it was settled that [Mr. Jones]135-mr. jones should be sent for early in the morning , if [Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth were not decidedly better . [Bingley]102-miss bingley was quite uncomfortable ; [[his]135-mr. jones sisters]303-his sisters declared that [they]303-his sisters were miserable . [They]303-his sisters solaced [their]303-his sisters wretchedness , however , by duets after supper , while [he]135-mr. jones could find no better relief to [his]135-mr. jones feelings than by giving [[his]135-mr. jones housekeeper]548-his housekeeper directions that every possible attention might be paid to [the sick lady]549-the sick lady and [[her]549-the sick lady sister]348-her sister .

[CHAPTER IX .

Elizabeth]140-chapter ix . elizabeth passed the chief of the night in [[[her]93-elizabeth sister]348-her sister 's room]552-her sister 's room , and in the morning had the pleasure of being able to send a tolerable answer to the enquiries which [she]93-elizabeth very early received from [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley by [a housemaid]553-a housemaid , and some time afterwards from [the two elegant ladies who waited on [[his]135-mr. jones sisters]303-his sisters]554-the two elegant ladies who waited on his sisters . In spite of this amendment , however , [she]93-elizabeth requested to have a note sent to [Longbourn]7-longbourn , desiring [[her]93-elizabeth mother]261-her mother to visit [Jane]94-jane , and form [her]93-elizabeth own judgment of [her]93-elizabeth situation . The note was immediately dispatched , and its contents as quickly complied with . [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet , accompanied by [[her]96-mrs. bennet two youngest girls]557-her two youngest girls , reached [Netherfield]2-netherfield soon after the family breakfast .

Had [she]96-mrs. bennet found [Jane]94-jane in any apparent danger , [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet would have been very miserable ; but being satisfied on seeing [her]96-mrs. bennet that [her]96-mrs. bennet illness was not alarming , [she]96-mrs. bennet had no wish of [her]96-mrs. bennet recovering immediately , as [her]96-mrs. bennet restoration to health would probably remove [her]96-mrs. bennet from [Netherfield]2-netherfield . [She]96-mrs. bennet would not listen therefore to [[her]96-mrs. bennet daughter]475-her daughter 's proposal of being carried [home]3223-home ; neither did [the apothecary , who arrived about the same time]560-the apothecary , who arrived about the same time , think it at all advisable . After sitting a little while with [Jane]94-jane , on [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley 's appearance and invitation , [the mother]412-the mother and [three daughters]562-three daughters all attended [her]96-mrs. bennet into [the breakfast parlour]563-the breakfast parlour . [Bingley]102-miss bingley met [them]562-three daughters with hopes that [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet had not found [Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth worse than [she]96-mrs. bennet expected .

" Indeed [I]96-mrs. bennet have , [Sir]3172-sir , "[96-mrs. bennet] was [her]96-mrs. bennet answer . " [She]93-elizabeth is a great deal too ill to be moved . [Mr. Jones]135-mr. jones says [we]3283-we must not think of moving [her]93-elizabeth . [We]3283-we must trespass a little longer on [your]135-mr. jones kindness . "[96-mrs. bennet]

" Removed ! "[102-miss bingley] cried [Bingley]102-miss bingley . " It must not be thought of . [[My]102-miss bingley sister]3284-my sister , [I]102-miss bingley am sure , will not hear of [her]93-elizabeth removal . "[102-miss bingley]

" [You]96-mrs. bennet may depend upon it , [Madam]3285-madam , "[102-miss bingley] said [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley , with cold civility , " that [Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth shall receive every possible attention while [she]93-elizabeth remains with [us]3283-we . "[102-miss bingley]

[Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet was profuse in [her]96-mrs. bennet acknowledgments .

" [I]96-mrs. bennet am sure , "[96-mrs. bennet] [she]96-mrs. bennet added , " if it was not for [such good friends]3286-such good friends [I]96-mrs. bennet do not know what would become of [her]93-elizabeth , for [she]93-elizabeth is very ill indeed , and suffers a vast deal , though with the greatest patience in [the world]323-the world , which is always the way with [her]93-elizabeth , for [she]93-elizabeth has , without exception , the sweetest temper [I]96-mrs. bennet ever met with . [I]96-mrs. bennet often tell [[my]96-mrs. bennet other girls]3288-my other girls [they]3288-my other girls are nothing to _ [her]93-elizabeth _ . [You]3289-you have [a sweet room]3290-a sweet room [here]3019-here , [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley , and a charming prospect over [that gravel walk]3292-that gravel walk . [I]96-mrs. bennet do not know [a place in [the country]460-the country that is equal to [Netherfield]2-netherfield]3293-a place in the country that is equal to netherfield . [You]3289-you will not think of quitting [it]3293-a place in the country that is equal to netherfield in a hurry [I]96-mrs. bennet hope , though [you]3289-you have but a short lease . "[96-mrs. bennet]

" Whatever [I]564-i do is done in a hurry , "[564-i] replied [he]564-i ; " and therefore if [I]564-i should resolve to quit [Netherfield]2-netherfield , [I]564-i should probably be off in five minutes . At present , however , [I]564-i consider [myself]564-i as quite fixed [here]3019-here . "[564-i]

" That is exactly what [I]93-elizabeth should have supposed of [you]564-i , "[93-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth .

" [You]93-elizabeth begin to comprehend [me]564-i , do [you]93-elizabeth ? "[564-i] cried [he]564-i , turning towards [her]93-elizabeth .

" Oh ! yes -- [I]564-i understand [you]93-elizabeth perfectly . "[564-i]

" [I]564-i wish [I]564-i might take this for a compliment ; but to be so easily seen through [I]564-i am afraid is pitiful . "[564-i]

" That is as it happens . It does not necessarily follow that a deep , intricate character is more or less estimable than such a one as [yours]564-i . "[564-i]

" [Lizzy]93-elizabeth , "[564-i] cried [[her]93-elizabeth mother]261-her mother , " remember where [you]93-elizabeth are , and do not run on in the wild manner that [you]93-elizabeth are suffered to do at [home]3223-home . "[564-i]

" [I]90-mr. bingley did not know before , "[90-mr. bingley] continued [Bingley]90-mr. bingley immediately , " that [you]90-mr. bingley were [a studier of character]3297-a studier of character . It must be an amusing study . "[90-mr. bingley]

" Yes ; but [intricate characters]3298-intricate characters are the _ most _ amusing . [They]3298-intricate characters have at least that advantage . "[564-i]

" [The country]460-the country , "[139-miss darcy] said [Darcy]139-miss darcy , " can in general supply but few subjects for such a study . In [a country neighbourhood]3300-a country neighbourhood [you]90-mr. bingley move in a very confined and unvarying society . "[139-miss darcy]

" But [people]3236-people [themselves]3236-people alter so much , that there is something new to be observed in [them]3236-people for ever . "[564-i]

" Yes , indeed , "[96-mrs. bennet] cried [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet , offended by [his]90-mr. bingley manner of mentioning [a country neighbourhood]3300-a country neighbourhood . " [I]96-mrs. bennet assure [you]139-miss darcy there is quite as much of _ that _ going on in [the country]460-the country as in [town]285-town . "[96-mrs. bennet]

[Every body]324-every body was surprised ; and [Darcy]139-miss darcy , after looking at [her]96-mrs. bennet for a moment , turned silently away . [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet , who fancied [she]96-mrs. bennet had gained a complete victory over [him]90-mr. bingley , continued [her]96-mrs. bennet triumph .

" [I]96-mrs. bennet can not see that [London]5-london has any great advantage over [the country]460-the country for [my]96-mrs. bennet part , except [the shops]3305-the shops and [public places]3306-public places . [The country]460-the country is a vast deal pleasanter , is not it , [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley ? "[96-mrs. bennet]

" When [I]90-mr. bingley am in [the country]460-the country , "[90-mr. bingley] [he]90-mr. bingley replied , " [I]90-mr. bingley never wish to leave it ; and when [I]90-mr. bingley am in [town]285-town it is pretty much the same . [They]3310-they have each [their]3310-they advantages , and [I]90-mr. bingley can be equally happy in either . "[90-mr. bingley]

" Aye -- that is because [you]139-miss darcy have the right disposition . But [that gentleman]3311-that gentleman , "[139-miss darcy] looking at [Darcy]139-miss darcy , " seemed to think [the country]460-the country was nothing at all . "[139-miss darcy]

" Indeed , [Mama]129-mama , [you]129-mama are mistaken , "[93-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , blushing for [[her]93-elizabeth mother]261-her mother . " [You]129-mama quite mistook [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy . [He]100-mr. darcy only meant that there were not such a variety of people to be met with in [the country]460-the country as in [town]285-town , which [you]129-mama must acknowledge to be true . "[93-elizabeth]

" Certainly , [[my]261-her mother dear]3018-my dear , [nobody]3098-nobody said there were ; but as to not meeting with [many people in [this neighbourhood]3318-this neighbourhood]3317-many people in this neighbourhood , [I]261-her mother believe there are [few neighbourhoods larger . [I]261-her mother know [we]3320-we dine with [four and twenty families]3321-four and twenty families]3319-few neighbourhoods larger . i know we dine with four and twenty families . "[261-her mother]

Nothing but concern for [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth could enable [Bingley]90-mr. bingley to keep [his]90-mr. bingley countenance . [[His]90-mr. bingley sister]569-his sister was less delicate , and directed [her]569-his sister eye towards [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy with a very expressive smile . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , for the sake of saying something that might turn [[her]93-elizabeth mother]261-her mother 's thoughts , now asked [her]261-her mother if [Charlotte Lucas]114-charlotte had been at [Longbourn]7-longbourn since _ [her]114-charlotte _ coming away .

" Yes , [she]114-charlotte called yesterday with [[her]114-charlotte father]264-her father . What [an agreeable man]3323-an agreeable man [Sir William]91-sir william is , [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley -- is not [he]91-sir william ? so much [the man of fashion]3324-the man of fashion ! so genteel and so easy!--He has always something to say to every body.--_That _ is [my]114-charlotte idea of good breeding ; and [those persons who fancy [themselves]3325-those persons who fancy themselves very important and never open their mouths very important and never open [their]3325-those persons who fancy themselves very important and never open their mouths mouths]3325-those persons who fancy themselves very important and never open their mouths , quite mistake the matter . "[114-charlotte]

" Did [Charlotte]114-charlotte dine with [you]90-mr. bingley ? "[114-charlotte]

" No , [she]114-charlotte would go [home]3223-home . [I]114-charlotte fancy [she]114-charlotte was wanted about the mince pies . For [my]114-charlotte part , [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley , _ [I]114-charlotte _ always keep servants that can do [their]3325-those persons who fancy themselves very important and never open their mouths own work ; _ [[my]114-charlotte _ daughters]3327-my _ daughters are brought up differently . But every body is to judge for [themselves]3327-my _ daughters , and [the Lucases]113-the lucases are very good sort of [girls]3074-girls , [I]114-charlotte assure [you]90-mr. bingley . It is a pity [they]113-the lucases are not handsome ! Not that _ [I]114-charlotte _ think [Charlotte]114-charlotte so _ very _ plain -- but then [she]114-charlotte is [[our]3329-our particular friend]3330-our particular friend . "[114-charlotte]

" [She]114-charlotte seems [a very pleasant young woman]3331-a very pleasant young woman , "[90-mr. bingley] said [Bingley]90-mr. bingley .

" Oh ! dear , yes;--but [you]90-mr. bingley must own [she]114-charlotte is very plain . [Lady Lucas]92-lady lucas [herself]92-lady lucas has often said so , and envied [me]114-charlotte [Jane]94-jane 's beauty . [I]114-charlotte do not like to boast of [[my]114-charlotte own child]3332-my own child , but to be sure , [Jane]94-jane -- [one]3064-one does not often see any body better looking . It is what [every body]324-every body says . [I]114-charlotte do not trust [my]114-charlotte own partiality . When [she]94-jane was only fifteen , there was [a gentleman at [[my]114-charlotte brother]3216-my brother [Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner 's in [town]285-town]3335-a gentleman at my brother gardiner 's in town , so much in love with [her]94-jane , that [[my]114-charlotte sister - in - law]3338-my sister - in - law was sure [he]3335-a gentleman at my brother gardiner 's in town would make [her]94-jane an offer before [we]3339-we came away . But however [he]3335-a gentleman at my brother gardiner 's in town did not . Perhaps [he]3335-a gentleman at my brother gardiner 's in town thought [her]94-jane too young . However , [he]3335-a gentleman at my brother gardiner 's in town wrote some verses on [her]94-jane , and very pretty they were . "[114-charlotte]

" And so ended [his]3335-a gentleman at my brother gardiner 's in town affection , "[93-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth impatiently . " There has been many a one , [I]93-elizabeth fancy , overcome in the same way . [I]93-elizabeth wonder who first discovered the efficacy of poetry in driving away love ! "[93-elizabeth]

" [I]100-mr. darcy have been used to consider poetry as the _ food _ of love , "[100-mr. darcy] said [Darcy]100-mr. darcy .

" Of a fine , stout , healthy love it may . Every thing nourishes what is strong already . But if it be only a slight , thin sort of inclination , [I]261-her mother am convinced that [one good sonnet]3340-one good sonnet will starve it entirely away . "[261-her mother]

[Darcy]100-mr. darcy only smiled ; and the general pause which ensued made [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth tremble lest [[her]93-elizabeth mother]261-her mother should be exposing [herself]93-elizabeth again . [She]93-elizabeth longed to speak , but could think of nothing to say ; and after a short silence [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet began repeating [her]96-mrs. bennet thanks to [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley for [his]90-mr. bingley kindness to [Jane]94-jane , with an apology for troubling [him]90-mr. bingley also with [Lizzy]93-elizabeth . [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley was unaffectedly civil in [his]90-mr. bingley answer , and forced [[his]90-mr. bingley younger sister]572-his younger sister to be civil also , and say what the occasion required . [She]93-elizabeth performed [her]93-elizabeth part indeed without much graciousness , but [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet was satisfied , and soon afterwards ordered [her]96-mrs. bennet carriage . Upon this signal , [the youngest of [[her]96-mrs. bennet daughters]257-her daughters]573-the youngest of her daughters put [herself]573-the youngest of her daughters forward . [The two girls]575-the two girls had been whispering to [each other]3157-each other during the whole visit , and the result of it was , that [the youngest]3077-the youngest should tax [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley with having promised on [his]90-mr. bingley first coming into [the country]460-the country to give a ball at [Netherfield]2-netherfield .

[Lydia]95-lydia was [a stout , well - grown girl of fifteen , with a fine complexion and good - humoured countenance]579-a stout , well - grown girl of fifteen , with a fine complexion and good - humoured countenance ; [a favourite with [[her]95-lydia mother]261-her mother , whose affection had brought [her]95-lydia into public at an early age]580-a favourite with her mother , whose affection had brought her into public at an early age . [She]95-lydia had high animal spirits , and a sort of natural self - consequence , which the attentions of [the officers]466-the officers , to whom [[her]95-lydia uncle]583-her uncle 's good dinners and [her]95-lydia own easy manners recommended [her]95-lydia , had increased into assurance . [She]95-lydia was very equal therefore to address [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley on the subject of the ball , and abruptly reminded [him]90-mr. bingley of [his]90-mr. bingley promise ; adding , that it would be the most shameful thing in [the world]323-the world if [he]90-mr. bingley did not keep it . [His]90-mr. bingley answer to this sudden attack was delightful to [[their]585-their mother]446-their mother 's ear .

" [I]95-lydia am perfectly ready , [I]95-lydia assure [you]446-their mother , to keep [my]95-lydia engagement ; and when [[your]446-their mother sister]3152-your sister is recovered , [you]446-their mother shall if [you]446-their mother please name the very day of the ball . But [you]446-their mother would not wish to be dancing while [she]3152-your sister is ill . "[95-lydia]

[Lydia]95-lydia declared [herself]95-lydia satisfied . " Oh ! yes -- it would be much better to wait till [Jane]94-jane was well , and by that time most likely [Captain Carter]128-captain carter would be at [Meryton]9-meryton again . And when [you]446-their mother have given _ [your]446-their mother _ ball , "[95-lydia] [she]95-lydia added , " [I]95-lydia shall insist on [their]3342-their giving one also . [I]95-lydia shall tell [Colonel Forster]123-colonel forster it will be quite a shame if [he]123-colonel forster does not . "[95-lydia]

[Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet and [[her]96-mrs. bennet daughters]257-her daughters then departed , and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth returned instantly to [Jane]94-jane , leaving [her]93-elizabeth own and [[her]93-elizabeth relations]588-her relations ' behaviour to the remarks of [the two ladies]512-the two ladies and [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy ; the latter of whom , however , could not be prevailed on to join in [their]512-the two ladies censure of _ [her]94-jane _ , in spite of all [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley 's witticisms on _ fine eyes _ .

CHAPTER X.

The day passed much as the day before had done . [Mrs. Hurst]101-mrs. hurst and [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley had spent some hours of the morning with [the invalid]590-the invalid , who continued , though slowly , to mend ; and in the evening [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth joined [[their]512-the two ladies party]591-their party in [the drawing - room]530-the drawing - room . The loo table , however , did not appear . [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy was writing , and [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley , seated near [him]100-mr. darcy , was watching the progress of [his]100-mr. darcy letter , and repeatedly calling off [his]100-mr. darcy attention by messages to [[his]100-mr. darcy sister]569-his sister . [Mr. Hurst]99-mr. hurst and [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley were at piquet , and [Mrs. Hurst]101-mrs. hurst was observing [their]512-the two ladies game .

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth took up some needlework , and was sufficiently amused in attending to what passed between [Darcy]100-mr. darcy and [[his]100-mr. darcy companion]437-his companion . The perpetual commendations of [the lady]595-the lady either on [his]100-mr. darcy hand - writing , or on the evenness of [his]100-mr. darcy lines , or on the length of [his]100-mr. darcy letter , with the perfect unconcern with which [her]595-the lady praises were received , formed a curious dialogue , and was exactly in unison with [her]595-the lady opinion of each .

" How delighted [Miss Darcy]139-miss darcy will be to receive such a letter ! "[596-you]

[He]100-mr. darcy made no answer .

" [You]139-miss darcy write uncommonly fast . "[596-you]

" [You]139-miss darcy are mistaken . [I]596-you write rather slowly . "[596-you]

" How many letters [you]100-mr. darcy must have occasion to write in the course of the year ! Letters of business too ! How odious [I]596-you should think them ! "[596-you]

" It is fortunate , then , that they fall to [my]596-you lot instead of to [yours]100-mr. darcy . "[596-you]

" Pray tell [[your]100-mr. darcy sister]3152-your sister that [I]596-you long to see [her]3152-your sister . "[596-you]

" [I]596-you have already told [her]3152-your sister so once , by [your]100-mr. darcy desire . "[596-you]

" [I]596-you am afraid [you]100-mr. darcy do not like [your]100-mr. darcy pen . Let [me]596-you mend it for [you]100-mr. darcy . [I]596-you mend pens remarkably well . "[596-you]

" Thank [you]100-mr. darcy -- but [I]596-you always mend [my]596-you own . "[596-you]

" How can [you]596-you contrive to write so even ? "[596-you]

[He]596-you was silent .

" Tell [[your]100-mr. darcy sister]3152-your sister [I]596-you am delighted to hear of [her]3152-your sister improvement on the harp , and pray let [her]3152-your sister know that [I]596-you am quite in raptures with [her]3152-your sister beautiful little design for a table , and [I]596-you think it infinitely superior to [Miss Grantley]142-miss grantley 's . "[596-you]

" Will [you]596-you give [me]596-you leave to defer [your]596-you raptures till [I]596-you write again?--At present [I]596-you have not room to do them justice . "[596-you]

" Oh ! it is of no consequence . [I]596-you shall see [her]3152-your sister in [January]14-january . But do [you]596-you always write such charming long letters to [her]3152-your sister , [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy ? "[596-you]

" They are generally long ; but whether always charming , it is not for [me]596-you to determine . "[596-you]

" It is a rule with [me]596-you , that [a person who can write a long letter , with ease]3345-a person who can write a long letter , with ease , can not write ill . "[596-you]

" That will not do for a compliment to [Darcy]100-mr. darcy , [Caroline]133-caroline , "[596-you] cried [her]597-her brother--"because [he]100-mr. darcy does _ not _ write with ease . [He]100-mr. darcy studies too much for words of four syllables.--Do not [you]596-you , [Darcy]100-mr. darcy ? "[596-you]

" [My]596-you style of writing is very different from [yours]100-mr. darcy . "[596-you]

" Oh ! "[102-miss bingley] cried [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley , " [Charles]137-charles writes in the most careless way imaginable . [He]137-charles leaves out half [his]137-charles words , and blots the rest . "[102-miss bingley]

" [My]596-you ideas flow so rapidly that [I]596-you have not time to express them -- by which means [my]596-you letters sometimes convey no ideas at all to [[my]596-you correspondents]3346-my correspondents . "[596-you]

" [Your]596-you humility , [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley , "[93-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , " must disarm reproof . "[93-elizabeth]

" Nothing is more deceitful , "[100-mr. darcy] said [Darcy]100-mr. darcy , " than the appearance of humility . It is often only carelessness of opinion , and sometimes an indirect boast . "[100-mr. darcy]

" And which of the two do [you]596-you call _ [my]596-you _ little recent piece of modesty ? "[596-you]

" The indirect boast;--for [you]596-you are really proud of [your]596-you defects in writing , because [you]596-you consider them as proceeding from a rapidity of thought and carelessness of execution , which if not estimable , [you]596-you think at least highly interesting . The power of doing any thing with quickness is always much prized by [the possessor]3347-the possessor , and often without any attention to the imperfection of the performance . When [you]596-you told [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet this morning that if [you]596-you ever resolved on quitting [Netherfield]2-netherfield [you]596-you should be gone in five minutes , [you]596-you meant it to be a sort of panegyric , of compliment to [yourself]596-you -- and yet what is there so very laudable in a precipitance which must leave very necessary business undone , and can be of no real advantage to [yourself]596-you or [any one else]3348-any one else ? "[100-mr. darcy]

" Nay , "[596-you] cried [Bingley]90-mr. bingley , " this is too much , to remember at night all the foolish things that were said in the morning . And yet , upon [my]90-mr. bingley honour , [I]90-mr. bingley believed what [I]90-mr. bingley said of [myself]90-mr. bingley to be true , and [I]90-mr. bingley believe it at this moment . At least , therefore , [I]90-mr. bingley did not assume the character of needless precipitance merely to shew off before [the ladies]269-the ladies . "[90-mr. bingley]

" [I]100-mr. darcy dare say [you]596-you believed it ; but [I]100-mr. darcy am by no means convinced that [you]596-you would be gone with such celerity . [Your]596-you conduct would be quite as dependant on chance as that of [any man]3350-any man [I]100-mr. darcy know ; and if , as [you]596-you were mounting [your]596-you horse , [a friend]3351-a friend were to say , ' [Bingley]90-mr. bingley , [you]596-you had better stay till next week , ' [you]596-you would probably do it , [you]596-you would probably not go -- and , at another word , might stay a month . "[100-mr. darcy]

" [You]596-you have only proved by this , "[93-elizabeth] cried [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , " that [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley did not do justice to [his]90-mr. bingley own disposition . [You]596-you have shewn [him]90-mr. bingley off now much more than [he]90-mr. bingley did [himself]90-mr. bingley . "[93-elizabeth]

" [I]90-mr. bingley am exceedingly gratified , "[90-mr. bingley] said [Bingley]90-mr. bingley , " by [your]596-you converting what [[my]90-mr. bingley friend]3352-my friend says into a compliment on the sweetness of [my]90-mr. bingley temper . But [I]90-mr. bingley am afraid [you]596-you are giving it a turn which [that gentleman]3311-that gentleman did by no means intend ; for [he]3311-that gentleman would certainly think the better of [me]90-mr. bingley , if under such a circumstance [I]90-mr. bingley were to give a flat denial , and ride off as fast as [I]90-mr. bingley could . "[90-mr. bingley]

" Would [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy then consider the rashness of [your]596-you original intention as atoned for by [your]596-you obstinacy in adhering to it ? "[100-mr. darcy]

" Upon [my]90-mr. bingley word [I]90-mr. bingley can not exactly explain the matter , [Darcy]100-mr. darcy must speak for [himself]100-mr. darcy . "[90-mr. bingley]

" [You]596-you expect [me]100-mr. darcy to account for opinions which [you]596-you chuse to call [mine]100-mr. darcy , but which [I]100-mr. darcy have never acknowledged . Allowing the case , however , to stand according to [your]596-you representation , [you]596-you must remember , [Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth , that [the friend who is supposed to desire [his]3311-that gentleman return to [the house]3026-the house , and the delay of [his]3311-that gentleman plan]3354-the friend who is supposed to desire his return to the house , and the delay of his plan , has merely desired it , asked it without offering one argument in favour of its propriety . "[100-mr. darcy]

" To yield readily -- easily -- to the _ persuasion _ of [a friend]3351-a friend is no merit with [you]596-you . "[90-mr. bingley]

" To yield without conviction is no compliment to the understanding of either . "[100-mr. darcy]

" [You]596-you appear to [me]90-mr. bingley , [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , to allow nothing for the influence of friendship and affection . A regard for [the requester]3357-the requester would often make [one]3064-one readily yield to a request , without waiting for arguments to reason one into it . [I]90-mr. bingley am not particularly speaking of such a case as [you]596-you have supposed about [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley . [We]3359-we may as well wait , perhaps , till the circumstance occurs , before [we]3359-we discuss the discretion of [his]90-mr. bingley behaviour thereupon . But in general and ordinary cases between [friend]3360-friend and [friend]3360-friend , where one of [them]3362-them is desired by [the other]3363-the other to change a resolution of no very great moment , should [you]596-you think ill of [that person for complying with the desire , without waiting to be argued into it]3364-that person for complying with the desire , without waiting to be argued into it ? "[90-mr. bingley]

" Will it not be advisable , before [we]3359-we proceed on this subject , to arrange with rather more precision the degree of importance which is to appertain to this request , as well as the degree of intimacy subsisting between [the parties]3162-the parties ? "[100-mr. darcy]

" By all means , "[90-mr. bingley] cried [Bingley]90-mr. bingley ; " let [us]3359-we hear all the particulars , not forgetting their comparative height and size ; for that will have more weight in the argument , [Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth , than [you]596-you may be aware of . [I]90-mr. bingley assure [you]596-you that if [Darcy]100-mr. darcy were not such [a great tall fellow]3366-a great tall fellow , in comparison with [myself]90-mr. bingley , [I]90-mr. bingley should not pay [him]100-mr. darcy half so much deference . [I]90-mr. bingley declare [I]90-mr. bingley do not know a more aweful object than [Darcy]100-mr. darcy , on particular occasions , and in particular places ; at [[his]100-mr. darcy own house]3160-his own house especially , and of a Sunday evening when [he]100-mr. darcy has nothing to do . "[90-mr. bingley]

[Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy smiled ; but [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth thought [she]93-elizabeth could perceive that [he]100-mr. darcy was rather offended ; and therefore checked [her]93-elizabeth laugh . [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley warmly resented the indignity [he]100-mr. darcy had received , in an expostulation with [[her]102-miss bingley brother]3126-her brother for talking such nonsense .

" [I]100-mr. darcy see [your]100-mr. darcy design , [Bingley]90-mr. bingley , "[100-mr. darcy] said [his]100-mr. darcy friend.--"You dislike an argument , and want to silence this . "[102-miss bingley]

" Perhaps [I]100-mr. darcy do . Arguments are too much like disputes . If [you]100-mr. darcy and [Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth will defer [yours]100-mr. darcy till [I]100-mr. darcy am out of [the room]271-the room , [I]100-mr. darcy shall be very thankful ; and then [you]100-mr. darcy may say whatever [you]100-mr. darcy like of [me]100-mr. darcy . "[100-mr. darcy]

" What [you]100-mr. darcy ask , "[93-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , " is no sacrifice on [my]93-elizabeth side ; and [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy had much better finish [his]100-mr. darcy letter . "[93-elizabeth]

[Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy took [her]93-elizabeth advice , and did finish [his]100-mr. darcy letter .

When that business was over , [he]100-mr. darcy applied to [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth for the indulgence of some music . [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley moved with alacrity to the piano - forte , and after a polite request that [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth would lead the way , which [the other as politely]599-the other as politely and more earnestly negatived , [she]93-elizabeth seated [herself]93-elizabeth .

[Mrs. Hurst]101-mrs. hurst sang with [[her]101-mrs. hurst sister]348-her sister , and while [they]601-they were thus employed [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth could not help observing as [she]93-elizabeth turned over some music books that lay on the instrument , how frequently [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy 's eyes were fixed on [her]93-elizabeth . [She]93-elizabeth hardly knew how to suppose that [she]93-elizabeth could be an object of admiration to [so great a man]602-so great a man ; and yet that [he]100-mr. darcy should look at [her]93-elizabeth because [he]100-mr. darcy disliked [her]93-elizabeth , was still more strange . [She]93-elizabeth could only imagine however at last , that [she]93-elizabeth drew [his]100-mr. darcy notice because there was a something about [her]93-elizabeth more wrong and reprehensible , according to [his]100-mr. darcy ideas of right , than in [any other person present]603-any other person present . The supposition did not pain [her]93-elizabeth . [She]93-elizabeth liked [him]100-mr. darcy too little to care for [his]100-mr. darcy approbation .

After playing some Italian songs , [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley varied the charm by a lively Scotch air ; and soon afterwards [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , drawing near [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , said to [her--]93-elizabeth

" Do not [you]93-elizabeth feel a great inclination , [Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth , to seize such an opportunity of dancing a reel ? "[100-mr. darcy]

[She]93-elizabeth smiled , but made no answer . [He]100-mr. darcy repeated the question , with some surprise at [her]93-elizabeth silence .

" Oh ! "[93-elizabeth] said [she]93-elizabeth , " [I]93-elizabeth heard [you]100-mr. darcy before ; but [I]93-elizabeth could not immediately determine what to say in reply . [You]100-mr. darcy wanted [me]93-elizabeth , [I]93-elizabeth know , to say ' Yes , ' that [you]100-mr. darcy might have the pleasure of despising [my]93-elizabeth taste ; but [I]93-elizabeth always delight in overthrowing those kind of schemes , and cheating [a person]3143-a person of [their]3143-a person premeditated contempt . [I]93-elizabeth have therefore made up [my]93-elizabeth mind to tell [you]100-mr. darcy , that [I]93-elizabeth do not want to dance a reel at all -- and now despise [me]93-elizabeth if [you]100-mr. darcy dare . "[93-elizabeth]

" Indeed [I]93-elizabeth do not dare . "[93-elizabeth]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , having rather expected to affront [him]604-he , was amazed at [his]604-he gallantry ; but there was a mixture of sweetness and archness in [her]93-elizabeth manner which made it difficult for [her]93-elizabeth to affront [anybody]605-anybody ; and [Darcy]100-mr. darcy had never been so bewitched by any woman as [he]604-he was by [her]93-elizabeth . [He]604-he really believed , that were it not for the inferiority of [her]93-elizabeth connections , [he]604-he should be in some danger .

[Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley saw , or suspected enough to be jealous ; and [her]102-miss bingley great anxiety for the recovery of [[her]102-miss bingley dear friend]606-her dear friend [Jane]94-jane , received some assistance from [her]102-miss bingley desire of getting rid of [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth .

[She]102-miss bingley often tried to provoke [Darcy]100-mr. darcy into disliking [[her]102-miss bingley guest]607-her guest , by talking of [their]608-their supposed marriage , and planning [his]100-mr. darcy happiness in such an alliance .

" [I]102-miss bingley hope , "[102-miss bingley] said [she]102-miss bingley , as [they]608-their were walking together in the shrubbery the next day , " [you]100-mr. darcy will give [[your]100-mr. darcy mother - in - law]3370-your mother - in - law a few hints , when this desirable event takes place , as to the advantage of holding [her]3370-your mother - in - law tongue ; and if [you]100-mr. darcy can compass it , do cure [the younger girls]3371-the younger girls of running after the officers.--And , if [I]102-miss bingley may mention so delicate a subject , endeavour to check that little something , bordering on conceit and impertinence , which [[your]100-mr. darcy lady]3372-your lady possesses . "[102-miss bingley]

" Have [you]102-miss bingley any thing else to propose for [my]100-mr. darcy domestic felicity ? "[100-mr. darcy]

" Oh ! yes.--Do let the portraits of [[your]100-mr. darcy uncle]3373-your uncle and [aunt Philips]3374-aunt philips be placed in [the gallery at [Pemberley]12-pemberley]3375-the gallery at pemberley . Put them next to [[your]100-mr. darcy great uncle]3376-your great uncle [the judge]3377-the judge . [They]609-they are in the same profession , [you]100-mr. darcy know ; only in different lines . As for [your]100-mr. darcy [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth 's picture , [you]100-mr. darcy must not attempt to have it taken , for what painter could do justice to those beautiful eyes ? "[102-miss bingley]

" It would not be easy , indeed , to catch [their]609-they expression , but their colour and shape , and the eye - lashes , so remarkably fine , might be copied . "[100-mr. darcy]

At that moment [they]609-they were met from another walk , by [Mrs. Hurst]101-mrs. hurst and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth [herself]93-elizabeth .

" [I]102-miss bingley did not know that [you]100-mr. darcy intended to walk , "[102-miss bingley] said [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley , in some confusion , lest [they]609-they had been overheard .

" [You]100-mr. darcy used [us]609-they abominably ill , "[101-mrs. hurst] answered [Mrs. Hurst]101-mrs. hurst , " in running away without telling [us]609-they that [you]100-mr. darcy were coming out . "[101-mrs. hurst]

Then taking the disengaged arm of [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , [she]93-elizabeth left [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth to walk by [herself]93-elizabeth . [The path]610-the path just admitted three . [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy felt [their]609-they rudeness and immediately said,--

" [This walk]3378-this walk is not wide enough for [[our]609-they party]3379-our party . [We]609-they had better go into [the avenue]3380-the avenue . "[609-they]

But [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , who had not the least inclination to remain with [them]609-they , laughingly answered ,

" No , no ; stay where [you]609-they are.--You are charmingly group'd , and appear to uncommon advantage . The picturesque would be spoilt by admitting a fourth . Good bye . "[609-they]

[She]93-elizabeth then ran gaily off , rejoicing as [she]93-elizabeth rambled about , in the hope of being at [home]3223-home again in a day or two . [Jane]94-jane was already so much recovered as to intend leaving [[her]94-jane room]501-her room for a couple of hours that evening .

CHAPTER XI .

When [the ladies]269-the ladies removed after dinner , [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth ran up to [[her]93-elizabeth sister]348-her sister , and seeing [her]348-her sister well guarded from cold , attended [her]348-her sister into [the drawing - room]530-the drawing - room ; where [she]93-elizabeth was welcomed by [[her]93-elizabeth two friends]616-her two friends with many professions of pleasure ; and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth had never seen [them]609-they so agreeable as [they]609-they were during the hour which passed before [the gentlemen]311-the gentlemen appeared . [Their]609-they powers of conversation were considerable . [They]609-they could describe an entertainment with accuracy , relate an anecdote with humour , and laugh at [their]609-they acquaintance with spirit .

But when [the gentlemen]311-the gentlemen entered , [Jane]94-jane was no longer [the first object]619-the first object . [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley 's eyes were instantly turned towards [Darcy]100-mr. darcy , and [she]102-miss bingley had something to say to [him]100-mr. darcy before [he]100-mr. darcy had advanced many steps . [He]100-mr. darcy addressed [himself]100-mr. darcy directly to [Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth , with a polite congratulation ; [Mr. Hurst]99-mr. hurst also made [her]102-miss bingley a slight bow , and said [he]99-mr. hurst was " very glad ; "[99-mr. hurst] but diffuseness and warmth remained for [Bingley]102-miss bingley 's salutation . [He]100-mr. darcy was full of joy and attention . The first half hour was spent in piling up the fire , lest [she]102-miss bingley should suffer from the change of room ; and [she]102-miss bingley removed at [his]100-mr. darcy desire to the other side of [the fire - place]620-the fire - place , that [she]102-miss bingley might be farther from the door . [He]100-mr. darcy then sat down by [her]102-miss bingley , and talked scarcely to [any one else]3348-any one else . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , at work in the opposite corner , saw it all with great delight .

When tea was over , [Mr. Hurst]99-mr. hurst reminded [[his]99-mr. hurst sister - in - law]622-his sister - in - law of the card - table -- but in vain . [She]622-his sister - in - law had obtained private intelligence that [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy did not wish for cards ; and [Mr. Hurst]99-mr. hurst soon found even [his]99-mr. hurst open petition rejected . [She]622-his sister - in - law assured [him]99-mr. hurst that [no one]3275-no one intended to play , and the silence of [the whole party]531-the whole party on the subject , seemed to justify [her]622-his sister - in - law . [Mr. Hurst]99-mr. hurst had therefore nothing to do , but to stretch [himself]99-mr. hurst on one of the sophas and go to sleep . [Darcy]100-mr. darcy took up a book ; [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley did the same ; and [Mrs. Hurst]101-mrs. hurst , principally occupied in playing with [her]102-miss bingley bracelets and rings , joined now and then in [[her]102-miss bingley brother]3126-her brother 's conversation with [Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth .

[Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley 's attention was quite as much engaged in watching [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy 's progress through _ [his]100-mr. darcy _ book , as in reading [her]622-his sister - in - law own ; and [she]622-his sister - in - law was perpetually either making some inquiry , or looking at [his]100-mr. darcy page . [She]622-his sister - in - law could not win [him]100-mr. darcy , however , to any conversation ; [he]100-mr. darcy merely answered [her]622-his sister - in - law question , and read on . At length , quite exhausted by the attempt to be amused with [her]622-his sister - in - law own book , which [she]622-his sister - in - law had only chosen because it was the second volume of [his]100-mr. darcy , [she]622-his sister - in - law gave a great yawn and said , " How pleasant it is to spend an evening in this way ! [I]622-his sister - in - law declare after all there is no enjoyment like reading ! How much sooner one tires of any thing than of a book!--When [I]622-his sister - in - law have [a house of [my]622-his sister - in - law own]3381-a house of my own , [I]622-his sister - in - law shall be miserable if [I]622-his sister - in - law have not an excellent library . "[622-his sister - in - law]

[No one]3275-no one made any reply . [She]622-his sister - in - law then yawned again , threw aside [her]622-his sister - in - law book , and cast [her]622-his sister - in - law eyes round [the room]271-the room in quest of some amusement ; when hearing [[her]622-his sister - in - law brother]3126-her brother mentioning a ball to [Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth , [she]622-his sister - in - law turned suddenly towards [him]3126-her brother and said ,

" By the bye , [Charles]137-charles , are [you]3126-her brother really serious in meditating a dance at [Netherfield?--I]15-netherfield?--i would advise [you]3126-her brother , before [you]3126-her brother determine on it , to consult the wishes of [the present party]3382-the present party ; [I]622-his sister - in - law am much mistaken if there are not some among [us]3383-us [to whom a ball would be rather a punishment than a pleasure]3384-to whom a ball would be rather a punishment than a pleasure . "[622-his sister - in - law]

" If [you]622-his sister - in - law mean [Darcy]100-mr. darcy , "[3126-her brother] cried [[her]622-his sister - in - law brother]3126-her brother , " [he]100-mr. darcy may go to bed , if [he]100-mr. darcy chuses , before it begins -- but as for the ball , it is quite a settled thing ; and as soon as [Nicholls]143-nicholls has made white soup enough [I]3126-her brother shall send round [my]3126-her brother cards . "[3126-her brother]

" [I]622-his sister - in - law should like balls infinitely better , "[622-his sister - in - law] [she]622-his sister - in - law replied , " if they were carried on in a different manner ; but there is something insufferably tedious in the usual process of such a meeting . It would surely be much more rational if conversation instead of dancing made the order of the day . "[622-his sister - in - law]

" Much more rational , [my]102-miss bingley dear [Caroline]133-caroline , [I]102-miss bingley dare say , but it would not be near so much like a ball . "[102-miss bingley]

[Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley made no answer ; and soon afterwards got up and walked about [the room]271-the room . [Her]102-miss bingley figure was elegant , and [she]102-miss bingley walked well;--but [Darcy]100-mr. darcy , at whom it was all aimed , was still inflexibly studious . In the desperation of [her]102-miss bingley feelings [she]102-miss bingley resolved on one effort more ; and , turning to [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , said ,

" [Miss Eliza Bennet]93-elizabeth , let [me]102-miss bingley persuade [you]93-elizabeth to follow [my]102-miss bingley example , and take a turn about the room.--I assure [you]93-elizabeth it is very refreshing after sitting so long in one attitude . "[102-miss bingley]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was surprised , but agreed to it immediately . [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley succeeded no less in the real object of [her]102-miss bingley civility ; [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy looked up . [He]100-mr. darcy was as much awake to the novelty of attention in that quarter as [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth [herself]93-elizabeth could be , and unconsciously closed [his]100-mr. darcy book . [He]100-mr. darcy was directly invited to join [their]631-their party , but [he]100-mr. darcy declined it , observing , that [he]100-mr. darcy could imagine but two motives for [their]631-their chusing to walk up and down [the room]271-the room together , with either of which motives [his]100-mr. darcy joining [them]631-their would interfere . " What could [he]100-mr. darcy mean ? [she]93-elizabeth was dying to know what could be [his]100-mr. darcy meaning"--and[93-elizabeth] asked [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth whether [she]93-elizabeth could at all understand [him]100-mr. darcy ?

" Not at all , "[102-miss bingley] was [her]102-miss bingley answer ; " but depend upon it , [he]100-mr. darcy means to be severe on [us]631-their , and [our]631-their surest way of disappointing [him]100-mr. darcy , will be to ask nothing about it . "[102-miss bingley]

[Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley , however , was incapable of disappointing [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy in any thing , and persevered therefore in requiring an explanation of [his]100-mr. darcy two motives .

" [I]100-mr. darcy have not the smallest objection to explaining them , "[100-mr. darcy] said [he]100-mr. darcy , as soon as [she]102-miss bingley allowed [him]100-mr. darcy to speak . " [You]93-elizabeth either chuse this method of passing the evening because [you]93-elizabeth are in [each other]3157-each other 's confidence and have secret affairs to discuss , or because [you]93-elizabeth are conscious that [your]93-elizabeth figures appear to the greatest advantage in walking;--if the first , [I]100-mr. darcy should be completely in [your]93-elizabeth way;--and if the second , [I]100-mr. darcy can admire [you]93-elizabeth much better as [I]100-mr. darcy sit by the fire . "[100-mr. darcy]

" Oh ! shocking ! "[102-miss bingley] cried [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley . " [I]102-miss bingley never heard any thing so abominable . How shall [we]3386-we punish [him]100-mr. darcy for such a speech ? "[102-miss bingley]

" Nothing so easy , if [you]100-mr. darcy have but the inclination , "[93-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth . " [We]3386-we can all plague and punish [one another]3387-one another . Teaze [him]100-mr. darcy -- laugh at him.--Intimate as [you]100-mr. darcy are , [you]100-mr. darcy must know how it is to be done . "[93-elizabeth]

" But upon [my]100-mr. darcy honour [I]100-mr. darcy do _ not _ . [I]100-mr. darcy do assure [you]100-mr. darcy that [my]100-mr. darcy intimacy has not yet taught [me]100-mr. darcy _ that _ . [Teaze]144-teaze calmness of temper and presence of mind ! No , no -- [I]100-mr. darcy feel [he]100-mr. darcy may defy [us]3386-we [there]325-there . And as to laughter , [we]3386-we will not expose [ourselves]3386-we , if [you]100-mr. darcy please , by attempting to laugh without a subject . [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy may hug [himself]100-mr. darcy . "[100-mr. darcy]

" [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy is not to be laughed at ! "[93-elizabeth] cried [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth . " That is an uncommon advantage , and uncommon [I]93-elizabeth hope it will continue , for it would be a great loss to _ [me]93-elizabeth _ to have [many such acquaintance]3389-many such acquaintance . [I]93-elizabeth dearly love a laugh . "[93-elizabeth]

" [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley , "[633-i] said [he]633-i , " has given [me]633-i credit for more than can be . [The wisest and the best of [men]3391-men]3390-the wisest and the best of men , nay , the wisest and best of [their]3391-men actions , may be rendered ridiculous by [a person whose first object in life is a joke]3392-a person whose first object in life is a joke . "[633-i]

" Certainly , "[100-mr. darcy] replied [Elizabeth--"there]3393-elizabeth--"there are [such people]3394-such people , but [I]633-i hope [I]633-i am not [one of _ [them]3394-such people _]3395-one of _ them _ . [I]633-i hope [I]633-i never ridicule what is wise or good .
