Follies and nonsense , whims and inconsistencies _ do _ divert [me]633-i , [I]633-i own , and [I]633-i laugh at [them]3394-such people whenever [I]633-i can.--But these , [I]633-i suppose , are precisely what [you]93-elizabeth are without . "[633-i]

" Perhaps that is not possible for [any one]3122-any one . But it has been the study of [my]93-elizabeth life to avoid those weaknesses which often expose a strong understanding to ridicule . "[93-elizabeth]

" Such as vanity and pride . "[633-i]

" Yes , vanity is a weakness indeed . But pride -- where there is a real superiority of mind , pride will be always under good regulation . "[93-elizabeth]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth turned away to hide a smile .

" [Your]93-elizabeth examination of [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy is over , [I]633-i presume , "[145-miss bingley;--"and] said [Miss Bingley;--"and]145-miss bingley;--"and pray what is the result ? "[633-i]

" [I]93-elizabeth am perfectly convinced by it that [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy has no defect . [He]100-mr. darcy owns it [himself]100-mr. darcy without disguise . "[93-elizabeth]

" No"--said[633-i] [Darcy]100-mr. darcy , " [I]93-elizabeth have made no such pretension . [I]93-elizabeth have faults enough , but they are not , [I]93-elizabeth hope , of understanding . [My]93-elizabeth temper [I]93-elizabeth dare not vouch for.--It is [I]93-elizabeth believe too little yielding -- certainly too little for the convenience of [the world]323-the world . [I]93-elizabeth can not forget the follies and vices of [others]3123-others so soon as [I]93-elizabeth ought , nor [their]3123-others offences against [myself]93-elizabeth . [My]93-elizabeth feelings are not puffed about with every attempt to move them . [My]93-elizabeth temper would perhaps be called resentful.--My good opinion once lost is lost for ever . "[93-elizabeth]

" _ That _ is a failing indeed!"--cried[93-elizabeth] [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth . " Implacable resentment _ is _ a shade in a character . But [you]634-you have chosen [your]634-you fault well.--I really can not _ laugh _ at it . [You]634-you are safe from [me]93-elizabeth . "[93-elizabeth]

" There is , [I]93-elizabeth believe , in every disposition a tendency to some particular evil , a natural defect , which not even the best education can overcome . "[93-elizabeth]

" And _ [your]634-you _ defect is a propensity to hate every body . "[93-elizabeth]

" And [yours]634-you , "[634-you] [he]634-you replied with a smile , " is wilfully to misunderstand [them]3123-others . "[634-you]

" Do let [us]3399-us have a little music,"--cried[102-miss bingley] [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley , tired of a conversation in which [she]102-miss bingley had no share.--"Louisa , [you]634-you will not mind [my]634-you waking [Mr. Hurst]99-mr. hurst . "[634-you]

[[Her]93-elizabeth sister]348-her sister made not the smallest objection , and the piano - forte was opened , and [Darcy]100-mr. darcy , after a few moments recollection , was not sorry for it . [He]100-mr. darcy began to feel the danger of paying [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth too much attention .

CHAPTER XII .

In consequence of an agreement between [the sisters]504-the sisters , [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth wrote the next morning to [[her]93-elizabeth mother]261-her mother , to beg that [the carriage]3221-the carriage might be sent for [them]504-the sisters in the course of the day . But [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet , who had calculated on [[her]96-mrs. bennet daughters]257-her daughters remaining at [Netherfield]2-netherfield till the following Tuesday , which would exactly finish [Jane]94-jane 's week , could not bring [herself]96-mrs. bennet to receive [them]504-the sisters with pleasure before . [Her]96-mrs. bennet answer , therefore , was not propitious , at least not to [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth 's wishes , for [she]96-mrs. bennet was impatient to get [home]3223-home . [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet sent [them]504-the sisters word that [they]504-the sisters could not possibly have [the carriage]3221-the carriage before Tuesday ; and in [her]96-mrs. bennet postscript it was added , that if [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley and [[his]90-mr. bingley sister]569-his sister pressed [them]504-the sisters to stay longer , [she]96-mrs. bennet could spare [them]504-the sisters very well.--Against staying longer , however , [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was positively resolved -- nor did [she]93-elizabeth much expect it would be asked ; and fearful , on the contrary , as being considered as intruding [themselves]504-the sisters needlessly long , [she]93-elizabeth urged [Jane]94-jane to borrow [[Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley 's carriage]643-mr. bingley 's carriage immediately , and at length it was settled that [their]504-the sisters original design of leaving [Netherfield]2-netherfield that morning should be mentioned , and the request made .

The communication excited many professions of concern ; and enough was said of wishing [them]504-the sisters to stay at least till the following day to work on [Jane]94-jane ; and till the morrow , [their]504-the sisters going was deferred . [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley was then sorry that [she]102-miss bingley had proposed the delay , for [her]102-miss bingley jealousy and dislike of [one sister]644-one sister much exceeded [her]102-miss bingley affection for [the other]3363-the other .

[The master of [the house]3026-the house]646-the master of the house heard with real sorrow that [they]504-the sisters were to go so soon , and repeatedly tried to persuade [Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth that it would not be safe for [her]102-miss bingley -- that [she]102-miss bingley was not enough recovered ; but [Jane]94-jane was firm where [she]94-jane felt [herself]94-jane to be right .

To [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy it was welcome intelligence -- [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth had been at [Netherfield]2-netherfield long enough . [She]93-elizabeth attracted [him]100-mr. darcy more than [he]100-mr. darcy liked -- and [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley was uncivil to _ [her]93-elizabeth _ , and more teazing than usual to [himself]100-mr. darcy . [He]100-mr. darcy wisely resolved to be particularly careful that no sign of admiration should _ now _ escape [him]100-mr. darcy , nothing that could elevate [her]93-elizabeth with the hope of influencing [his]100-mr. darcy felicity ; sensible that if such an idea had been suggested , [his]100-mr. darcy behaviour during the last day must have material weight in confirming or crushing it . Steady to [his]100-mr. darcy purpose , [he]100-mr. darcy scarcely spoke ten words to [her]93-elizabeth through the whole of Saturday , and though [they]648-they were at one time left by [themselves]648-they for half an hour , [he]100-mr. darcy adhered most conscientiously to [his]100-mr. darcy book , and would not even look at [her]93-elizabeth .

On Sunday , after morning service , the separation , so agreeable to almost all , took place . [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley 's civility to [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth increased at last very rapidly , as well as [her]102-miss bingley affection for [Jane]94-jane ; and when [they]648-they parted , after assuring [the latter]499-the latter of the pleasure it would always give [her]102-miss bingley to see [her]93-elizabeth either at [Longbourn]7-longbourn or [Netherfield]2-netherfield , and embracing [her]93-elizabeth most tenderly , [she]102-miss bingley even shook hands with [the former.--Elizabeth]650-the former.--elizabeth took leave of [the whole party]531-the whole party in the liveliest spirits .

[They]648-they were not welcomed [home]3223-home very cordially by [[their]648-they mother]446-their mother . [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet wondered at [their]648-they coming , and thought [them]648-they very wrong to give so much trouble , and was sure [Jane]94-jane would have caught cold again.--But [[their]648-they father]267-their father , though very laconic in [his]267-their father expressions of pleasure , was really glad to see [them]648-they ; [he]267-their father had felt [their]648-they importance in [the family circle]655-the family circle . The evening conversation , when [they]648-they were all assembled , had lost much of its animation , and almost all its sense , by the absence of [Jane]94-jane and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth .

[They]648-they found [Mary]98-mary , as usual , deep in the study of thorough bass and human nature ; and had some new extracts to admire , and some new observations of thread - bare morality to listen to . [Catherine]97-lady catherine and [Lydia]95-lydia had information for [them]648-they of a different sort . Much had been done , and much had been said in [the regiment]656-the regiment since the preceding Wednesday ; [several of [the officers]466-the officers]657-several of the officers had dined lately with [[their]657-several of the officers uncle]3250-their uncle , [a private]660-a private had been flogged , and it had actually been hinted that [Colonel Forster]123-colonel forster was going to be married .

[CHAPTER XIII]146-chapter xiii .

" [I]86-mr. bennet hope , [[my]86-mr. bennet dear]3018-my dear , "[86-mr. bennet] said [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet to [[his]86-mr. bennet wife]251-his wife , as [they]648-they were at breakfast the next morning , " that [you]251-his wife have ordered a good dinner to - day , because [I]86-mr. bennet have reason to expect an addition to [our]648-they family party . "[86-mr. bennet]

" Who do [you]251-his wife mean , [[my]146-chapter xiii dear]3018-my dear ? [I]146-chapter xiii know of nobody that is coming [I]146-chapter xiii am sure , unless [Charlotte Lucas]114-charlotte should happen to call in , and [I]146-chapter xiii hope _ [my]146-chapter xiii _ dinners are good enough for [her]114-charlotte . [I]146-chapter xiii do not believe [she]114-charlotte often sees such at [home]3223-home . "[146-chapter xiii]

" [The person of whom [I]96-mrs. bennet speak]3403-the person of whom i speak , is [a gentleman]3404-a gentleman and [a stranger]3405-a stranger . "[96-mrs. bennet] [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet 's eyes sparkled.--"A [gentleman]3406-gentleman and [a stranger]3405-a stranger ! It is [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley [I]146-chapter xiii am sure . Why [Jane]94-jane -- [you]94-jane never dropt a word of this ; [you]94-jane sly thing ! Well , [I]146-chapter xiii am sure [I]146-chapter xiii shall be extremely glad to see [Mr. Bingley.--But]147-mr. bingley.--but -- [good lord]3408-good lord ! how unlucky ! there is not a bit of fish to be got to - day . [Lydia]95-lydia , [[my]146-chapter xiii love]3076-my love , ring the bell . [I]146-chapter xiii must speak to [Hill]148-hill , this moment . "[146-chapter xiii]

" It is _ not _ [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley , "[276-her husband] said [[her]96-mrs. bennet husband]276-her husband ; " it is [a person whom [I]276-her husband never saw in the whole course of [my]276-her husband life]3410-a person whom i never saw in the whole course of my life . "[276-her husband]

This roused a general astonishment ; and [he]276-her husband had the pleasure of being eagerly questioned by [[his]276-her husband wife]251-his wife and [five daughters]664-five daughters at once .

After amusing [himself]276-her husband some time with [their]665-their curiosity , [he]276-her husband thus explained . " About a month ago [I]276-her husband received this letter , and about a fortnight ago [I]276-her husband answered it , for [I]276-her husband thought it a case of some delicacy , and requiring early attention . It is from [[my]276-her husband cousin]3411-my cousin , [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins , who , when [I]276-her husband am dead , may turn [you]3412-you all out of [this house]3413-this house as soon as [he]3411-my cousin pleases . "[276-her husband]

" Oh ! [[my]251-his wife dear]3018-my dear , "[251-his wife] cried [[his]276-her husband wife]251-his wife , " [I]251-his wife can not bear to hear that mentioned . Pray do not talk of [that odious man]3415-that odious man . [I]251-his wife do think it is the hardest thing in [the world]323-the world , that [your]3412-you estate should be entailed away from [[your]3412-you own children]3049-your own children ; and [I]251-his wife am sure if [I]251-his wife had been [you]3412-you , [I]251-his wife should have tried long ago to do something or other about it . "[251-his wife]

[Jane]94-jane and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth attempted to explain to [her]251-his wife the nature of an entail . [They]667-they had often attempted it before , but it was a subject on which [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet was beyond the reach of reason ; and [she]96-mrs. bennet continued to rail bitterly against the cruelty of settling [an estate]361-an estate away from [a family of five daughters]669-a family of five daughters , in favour of [a man whom [nobody cared anything about]671-nobody cared anything about]670-a man whom nobody cared anything about .

" It certainly is a most iniquitous affair , "[86-mr. bennet] said [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet , " and nothing can clear [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins from the guilt of inheriting [Longbourn]7-longbourn . But if [you]3412-you will listen to [his]149-mr. collins letter , [you]3412-you may perhaps be a little softened by [his]149-mr. collins manner of expressing [himself]149-mr. collins . "[86-mr. bennet]

" No , that [I]670-a man whom nobody cared anything about am sure [I]670-a man whom nobody cared anything about shall not ; and [I]670-a man whom nobody cared anything about think it was very impertinent of [him]149-mr. collins to write to [you]3412-you at all , and very hypocritical . "[670-a man whom nobody cared anything about]

" Why , indeed , [he]149-mr. collins does seem to have had some filial scruples on that head , as [you]3412-you will hear . "[86-mr. bennet]

" _ [Hunsford]16-hunsford , near [Westerham]17-westerham , [Kent]18-kent ,[670-a man whom nobody cared anything about]

15th October . _

[DEAR SIR]672-dear sir ,

The disagreement subsisting between [yourself]672-dear sir and [[my]7-longbourn late honoured father]673-my late honoured father , always gave [me]7-longbourn much uneasiness , and since [I]7-longbourn have had the misfortune to lose [him]673-my late honoured father , [I]7-longbourn have frequently wished to heal the breach ; but for some time [I]7-longbourn was kept back by [my]7-longbourn own doubts , fearing lest it might seem disrespectful to [his]673-my late honoured father memory for [me]7-longbourn to be on good terms with any one , with whom it had always pleased [him]673-my late honoured father to be at variance.--"There , [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet . "--My[673-my late honoured father] mind however is now made up on the subject , for having received ordination at [Easter]19-easter , [I]7-longbourn have been so fortunate as to be distinguished by the patronage of [the Right Honourable Lady Catherine de Bourgh]97-lady catherine , [widow of [Sir Lewis de Bourgh]150-sir lewis de bourgh , whose bounty and beneficence has preferred [me]7-longbourn to [the valuable rectory of [this parish]676-this parish]675-the valuable rectory of this parish , where it shall be [my]7-longbourn earnest endeavour to demean [myself]7-longbourn with grateful respect towards [[her]97-lady catherine Ladyship]677-her ladyship , and be ever ready to perform those rites and ceremonies which are instituted by [the Church of England]678-the church of england]674-widow of sir lewis de bourgh , whose bounty and beneficence has preferred me to the valuable rectory of this parish , where it shall be my earnest endeavour to demean myself with grateful respect towards her ladyship , and be ever ready to perform those rites and ceremonies which are instituted by the church of england . As [a clergyman]679-a clergyman , moreover , [I]7-longbourn feel it [my]7-longbourn duty to promote and establish the blessing of peace in [all families]680-all families within the reach of [my]7-longbourn influence ; and on these grounds [I]7-longbourn flatter [myself]7-longbourn that [my]7-longbourn present overtures of good - will are highly commendable , and that the circumstance of [my]7-longbourn being next in the entail of [Longbourn estate]681-longbourn estate , will be kindly overlooked on [your]682-your side , and not lead [you]682-your to reject the offered olive branch . [I]7-longbourn can not be otherwise than concerned at being the means of injuring [[your]682-your amiable daughters]683-your amiable daughters , and beg leave to apologise for it , as well as to assure [you]682-your of [my]7-longbourn readiness to make [them]683-your amiable daughters every possible amends,--but of this hereafter . If [you]682-your should have no objection to receive [me]7-longbourn into [[your]682-your house]684-your house , [I]7-longbourn propose [myself]7-longbourn the satisfaction of waiting on [you]682-your and [[your]682-your family]685-your family , Monday , November 18th , by four o'clock , and shall probably trespass on [your]682-your hospitality till the Saturday se'night following , which [I]7-longbourn can do without any inconvenience , as [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine is far from objecting to [my]7-longbourn occasional absence on a Sunday , provided that [some other clergyman]686-some other clergyman is engaged to do the duty of the day . [I]7-longbourn remain , [dear sir]672-dear sir , with respectful compliments to [[your]682-your lady]3372-your lady and daughters , [[your]682-your well - wisher]689-your well - wisher and friend ,

[WILLIAM COLLINS]151-william collins . "[151-william collins]

" At four o'clock , therefore , [we]3420-us may expect [this peace - making gentleman]3421-this peace - making gentleman , "[86-mr. bennet] said [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet , as [he]86-mr. bennet folded up the letter . " [He]3421-this peace - making gentleman seems to be [a most conscientious and polite young man]3422-a most conscientious and polite young man , upon [my]86-mr. bennet word ; and [I]86-mr. bennet doubt not will prove a valuable acquaintance , especially if [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine should be so indulgent as to let [him]3421-this peace - making gentleman come to [us]3420-us again . "[86-mr. bennet]

" There is some sense in what [he]3421-this peace - making gentleman says about [the girls]3033-the girls however ; and if [he]3421-this peace - making gentleman is disposed to make [them]3033-the girls any amends , [I]690-his shall not be the person to discourage [him]3421-this peace - making gentleman . "[690-his]

" Though it is difficult , "[94-jane] said [Jane]94-jane , " to guess in what way [he]3421-this peace - making gentleman can mean to make [us]3420-us the atonement [he]3421-this peace - making gentleman thinks [our]3420-us due , the wish is certainly to [his]3421-this peace - making gentleman credit . "[94-jane]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was chiefly struck with [his]690-his extraordinary deference for [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine , and [his]690-his kind intention of christening , marrying , and burying [[his]690-his parishioners]691-his parishioners whenever it were required .

" [He]3421-this peace - making gentleman must be [an oddity]3424-an oddity , [I]93-elizabeth think , "[93-elizabeth] said [she]93-elizabeth . " [I]93-elizabeth can not make [him]3421-this peace - making gentleman out.--There is something very pompous in [his]3421-this peace - making gentleman style.--And what can [he]3421-this peace - making gentleman mean by apologizing for being next in the entail?--We can not suppose [he]3421-this peace - making gentleman would help it , if [he]3421-this peace - making gentleman could.--Can [he]3421-this peace - making gentleman be [a sensible man]3425-a sensible man , [sir]3172-sir ? "[93-elizabeth]

" No , [[my]691-his parishioners dear]3018-my dear ; [I]691-his parishioners think not . [I]691-his parishioners have great hopes of finding [him]3421-this peace - making gentleman quite the reverse . There is a mixture of servility and self - importance in [his]3421-this peace - making gentleman letter , which promises well . [I]691-his parishioners am impatient to see [him]3421-this peace - making gentleman . "[691-his parishioners]

" In point of composition , "[98-mary] said [Mary]98-mary , " [his]3421-this peace - making gentleman letter does not seem defective . The idea of the olive branch perhaps is not wholly new , yet [I]98-mary think it is well expressed . "[98-mary]

To [Catherine]97-lady catherine and [Lydia]95-lydia , neither the letter nor [its writer]692-its writer were in any degree interesting . It was next to impossible that [[their]693-their cousin]694-their cousin should come in a scarlet coat , and it was now some weeks since [they]693-their had received pleasure from the society of [a man in any other colour]695-a man in any other colour . As for [[their]693-their mother]446-their mother , [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins 's letter had done away much of [her]446-their mother ill - will , and [she]446-their mother was preparing to see [him]149-mr. collins with a degree of composure , which astonished [[her]446-their mother husband]276-her husband and [daughters]698-daughters .

[Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins was punctual to [his]149-mr. collins time , and was received with great politeness by [the whole family]331-the whole family . [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet indeed said little ; but [the ladies]269-the ladies were ready enough to talk , and [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins seemed neither in need of encouragement , nor inclined to be silent [himself]149-mr. collins . [He]149-mr. collins was [a tall , heavy looking young man of five and twenty]701-a tall , heavy looking young man of five and twenty . [His]149-mr. collins air was grave and stately , and [his]149-mr. collins manners were very formal . [He]149-mr. collins had not been long seated before [he]149-mr. collins complimented [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet on having so fine [a family of daughters]702-a family of daughters , said [he]149-mr. collins had heard much of [their]702-a family of daughters beauty , but that , in this instance , fame had fallen short of the truth ; and added , that [he]149-mr. collins did not doubt [her]96-mrs. bennet seeing [them]702-a family of daughters all in due time well disposed of in marriage . This gallantry was not much to the taste of [some of [[his]149-mr. collins hearers]704-his hearers]703-some of his hearers , but [Mrs. Bennet , who quarrelled with no compliments]96-mrs. bennet , answered most readily ,

" [You]149-mr. collins are very kind , [sir]3172-sir , [I]96-mrs. bennet am sure ; and [I]96-mrs. bennet wish with all [my]96-mrs. bennet heart it may prove so ; for else [they]702-a family of daughters will be destitute enough . Things are settled so oddly . "[96-mrs. bennet]

" [You]149-mr. collins allude perhaps to the entail of [this estate]3429-this estate . "[96-mrs. bennet]

" Ah ! [sir]3172-sir , [I]96-mrs. bennet do indeed . It is a grievous affair to [[my]96-mrs. bennet poor girls]3431-my poor girls , [you]3172-sir must confess . Not that [I]96-mrs. bennet mean to find fault with _ [you]3172-sir _ , for such things [I]96-mrs. bennet know are all chance in [this world]3432-this world . There is no knowing how estates will go when once they come to be entailed . "[96-mrs. bennet]

" [I]96-mrs. bennet am very sensible , [madam]3285-madam , of the hardship to [[my]96-mrs. bennet fair cousins,--and]3434-my fair cousins,--and could say much on the subject , but that [I]96-mrs. bennet am cautious of appearing forward and precipitate . But [I]96-mrs. bennet can assure [the young ladies]281-the young ladies that [I]96-mrs. bennet come prepared to admire [them]281-the young ladies . At present [I]96-mrs. bennet will not say more , but perhaps when [we]3436-we are better acquainted---- "[96-mrs. bennet]

[He]705-he was interrupted by a summons to dinner ; and [the girls]3033-the girls smiled on [each other]3157-each other . [They]3033-the girls were not the only objects of [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins 's admiration . [The hall]708-the hall , [the dining - room]709-the dining - room , and all [its]709-the dining - room furniture were examined and praised ; and [his]705-he commendation of every thing would have touched [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet 's heart , but for the mortifying supposition of [his]705-he viewing it all as [[his]705-he own future property]710-his own future property . The dinner too in its turn was highly admired ; and [he]705-he begged to know to which of [[his]705-he fair cousins]711-his fair cousins , the excellence of its cookery was owing . But here [he]705-he was set right by [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet , who assured [him]705-he with some asperity that [they]711-his fair cousins were very well able to keep [a good cook]712-a good cook , and that [[her]96-mrs. bennet daughters]257-her daughters had nothing to do in [the kitchen]714-the kitchen . [He]705-he begged pardon for having displeased [her]96-mrs. bennet . In a softened tone [she]96-mrs. bennet declared [herself]96-mrs. bennet not at all offended ; but [he]705-he continued to apologise for about a quarter of an hour .

CHAPTER XIV .

During dinner , [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet scarcely spoke at all ; but when [the servants]715-the servants were withdrawn , [he]86-mr. bennet thought it time to have some conversation with [[his]86-mr. bennet guest]716-his guest , and therefore started a subject in which [he]86-mr. bennet expected [him]705-he to shine , by observing that [he]705-he seemed very fortunate in [[his]705-he patroness]717-his patroness . [Lady Catherine de Bourgh]97-lady catherine 's attention to [his]705-he wishes , and consideration for [his]705-he comfort , appeared very remarkable . [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet could not have chosen better . [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins was eloquent in [her]97-lady catherine praise . The subject elevated [him]705-he to more than usual solemnity of manner , and with a most important aspect [he]705-he protested that [he]705-he had never in [his]705-he life witnessed such behaviour in [a person of rank]718-a person of rank -- such affability and condescension , as [he]705-he had [himself]705-he experienced from [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine . [She]97-lady catherine had been graciously pleased to approve of both the discourses , which [he]705-he had already had the honour of preaching before [her]97-lady catherine . [She]97-lady catherine had also asked [him]705-he twice to dine at [Rosings]22-rosings , and had sent for [him]705-he only the Saturday before , to make up [her]97-lady catherine pool of quadrille in the evening . [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine was reckoned proud by [many people [he]705-he knew]719-many people he knew , but _ [he]705-he _ had never seen any thing but affability in [her]97-lady catherine . [She]97-lady catherine had always spoken to [him]705-he as [she]97-lady catherine would to [any other gentleman]720-any other gentleman ; [she]97-lady catherine made not the smallest objection to [his]705-he joining in [the society of [the neighbourhood]3040-the neighbourhood]721-the society of the neighbourhood , nor to [his]705-he leaving [[his]705-he parish]723-his parish occasionally for a week or two , to visit [[his]705-he relations]724-his relations . [She]97-lady catherine had even condescended to advise [him]705-he to marry as soon as [he]705-he could , provided [he]705-he chose with discretion ; and had once paid [him]705-he a visit in [[his]705-he humble parsonage]725-his humble parsonage ; where [she]97-lady catherine had perfectly approved all the alterations [he]705-he had been making , and had even vouchsafed to suggest some herself,--some shelves in the closets up [stairs]529-stairs .

" That is all very proper and civil , [I]96-mrs. bennet am sure , "[96-mrs. bennet] said [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet , " and [I]96-mrs. bennet dare say [she]97-lady catherine is [a very agreeable woman]3437-a very agreeable woman . It is a pity that [great ladies in general]3438-great ladies in general are not more like [her]97-lady catherine . Does [she]97-lady catherine live near [you]705-he , [sir]3172-sir ? "[96-mrs. bennet]

" [The garden in which stands [[my]97-lady catherine humble abode]3441-my humble abode]3440-the garden in which stands my humble abode , is separated only by [a lane from [Rosings Park]21-rosings park]3442-a lane from rosings park , [[[her]97-lady catherine ladyship]677-her ladyship 's residence]3444-her ladyship 's residence . "[97-lady catherine]

" [I]96-mrs. bennet think [you]705-he said [she]97-lady catherine was [a widow]3445-a widow , [sir]3172-sir ? has [she]97-lady catherine [any family]3447-any family ? "[96-mrs. bennet]

" [She]97-lady catherine has [one only daughter]3448-one only daughter , [the heiress of [Rosings]22-rosings]3449-the heiress of rosings , and of very extensive property . "[97-lady catherine]

" Ah ! "[96-mrs. bennet] cried [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet , shaking [her]96-mrs. bennet head , " then [she]97-lady catherine is better off than [many girls]3450-many girls . And what sort of [young lady]3451-young lady is [she]97-lady catherine ? is [she]97-lady catherine handsome ? "[96-mrs. bennet]

" [She]97-lady catherine is [a most charming young lady]3452-a most charming young lady indeed . [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine [herself]97-lady catherine says that in point of true beauty , [Miss De Bourgh]152-miss de bourgh is far superior to the handsomest of [her]97-lady catherine sex ; because there is that in [her]97-lady catherine features which marks [the young woman of distinguished birth]3453-the young woman of distinguished birth . [She]97-lady catherine is unfortunately of a sickly constitution , which has prevented [her]97-lady catherine making that progress in many accomplishments , which [she]97-lady catherine could not otherwise have failed of ; as [I]97-lady catherine am informed by [the lady who superintended [her]97-lady catherine education , and who still resides with [them]3455-them]3454-the lady who superintended her education , and who still resides with them . But [she]97-lady catherine is perfectly amiable , and often condescends to drive by [[my]97-lady catherine humble abode]3441-my humble abode in [her]97-lady catherine little phaeton and ponies . "[97-lady catherine]

" Has [she]97-lady catherine been presented ? [I]96-mrs. bennet do not remember [her]97-lady catherine name among [the ladies at court]3457-the ladies at court . "[96-mrs. bennet]

" [Her]97-lady catherine indifferent state of health unhappily prevents [her]97-lady catherine being in [town]285-town ; and by that means , as [I]97-lady catherine told [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine [myself]97-lady catherine one day , has deprived [the British court]3459-the british court of [its]3459-the british court brightest ornament . [[Her]97-lady catherine ladyship]677-her ladyship seemed pleased with the idea , and [you]3461-you may imagine that [I]97-lady catherine am happy on every occasion to offer those little delicate compliments which are always acceptable to [ladies]293-ladies . [I]97-lady catherine have more than once observed to [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine , that [[her]97-lady catherine charming daughter]3463-her charming daughter seemed born to be [a duchess]3464-a duchess , and that the most elevated rank , instead of giving [her]97-lady catherine consequence , would be adorned by her.--These are the kind of little things which please [[her]97-lady catherine ladyship]677-her ladyship , and it is a sort of attention which [I]97-lady catherine conceive [myself]97-lady catherine peculiarly bound to pay . "[97-lady catherine]

" [You]3461-you judge very properly , "[86-mr. bennet] said [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet , " and it is happy for [you]3461-you that [you]3461-you possess the talent of flattering with delicacy . May [I]86-mr. bennet ask whether these pleasing attentions proceed from the impulse of the moment , or are the result of previous study ? "[86-mr. bennet]

" [They]3466-they arise chiefly from what is passing at the time , and though [I]86-mr. bennet sometimes amuse [myself]86-mr. bennet with suggesting and arranging such little elegant compliments as may be adapted to ordinary occasions , [I]86-mr. bennet always wish to give them as unstudied an air as possible . "[86-mr. bennet]

[Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet 's expectations were fully answered . [[His]86-mr. bennet cousin]727-his cousin was as absurd as [he]86-mr. bennet had hoped , and [he]86-mr. bennet listened to [him]727-his cousin with the keenest enjoyment , maintaining at the same time the most resolute composure of countenance , and except in an occasional glance at [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , requiring [no partner]728-no partner in [his]86-mr. bennet pleasure .

By tea - time however the dose had been enough , and [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet was glad to take [[his]86-mr. bennet guest]716-his guest into [the drawing - room]530-the drawing - room again , and when tea was over , glad to invite [him]86-mr. bennet to read aloud to [the ladies]269-the ladies . [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins readily assented , and a book was produced ; but on beholding it , ( for every thing announced it to be from a circulating library , ) [he]149-mr. collins started back , and begging pardon , protested that [he]149-mr. collins never read novels.--Kitty stared at [him]149-mr. collins , and [Lydia]95-lydia exclaimed.--Other books were produced , and after some deliberation [he]149-mr. collins chose [Fordyce]153-fordyce 's Sermons . [Lydia]95-lydia gaped as [he]149-mr. collins opened the volume , and before [he]149-mr. collins had , with very monotonous solemnity , read three pages , [she]95-lydia interrupted [him]149-mr. collins with ,

" Do [you]149-mr. collins know , [mama]3057-mama , that [[my]95-lydia uncle]3468-my uncle [Philips]127-mrs. philips talks of turning away [Richard]154-richard , and if [he]154-richard does , [Colonel Forster]123-colonel forster will hire [him]154-richard . [[My]95-lydia aunt]3208-my aunt told [me]95-lydia so [herself]3208-my aunt on Saturday . [I]95-lydia shall walk to [Meryton]9-meryton to - morrow to hear more about it , and to ask when [Mr. Denny]155-denny comes back from [town]285-town . "[95-lydia]

[Lydia]95-lydia was bid by [[her]95-lydia two eldest sisters]732-her two eldest sisters to hold [her]95-lydia tongue ; but [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins , much offended , laid aside [his]149-mr. collins book , and said ,

" [I]149-mr. collins have often observed how [little young ladies]3471-little young ladies are interested by books of a serious stamp , though written solely for [their]3471-little young ladies benefit . It amazes [me]149-mr. collins , [I]149-mr. collins confess;--for certainly , there can be nothing so advantageous to [them]3471-little young ladies as instruction . But [I]149-mr. collins will no longer importune [[my]149-mr. collins young cousin]3472-my young cousin . "[149-mr. collins]

Then turning to [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet , [he]149-mr. collins offered [himself]149-mr. collins as [[his]149-mr. collins antagonist]733-his antagonist at backgammon . [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet accepted the challenge , observing that [he]149-mr. collins acted very wisely in leaving [the girls]3033-the girls to [their]3033-the girls own trifling amusements . [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet and [[her]96-mrs. bennet daughters]257-her daughters apologised most civilly for [Lydia]95-lydia 's interruption , and promised that it should not occur again , if [he]149-mr. collins would resume [his]149-mr. collins book ; but [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins , after assuring [them]736-them that [he]149-mr. collins bore [[his]149-mr. collins young cousin]737-his young cousin no ill will , and should never resent [her]737-his young cousin behaviour as any affront , seated [himself]149-mr. collins at another table with [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet , and prepared for backgammon .

CHAPTER XV .

[Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins was not [a sensible man]3425-a sensible man , and the deficiency of nature had been but little assisted by education or society ; the greatest part of [his]149-mr. collins life having been spent under the guidance of [an illiterate and miserly father]739-an illiterate and miserly father ; and though [he]149-mr. collins belonged to [one of [the universities]741-the universities]740-one of the universities , [he]149-mr. collins had merely kept the necessary terms , without forming at it any useful acquaintance . The subjection in which [[his]149-mr. collins father]360-his father had brought [him]149-mr. collins up , had given [him]149-mr. collins originally great humility of manner , but it was now a good deal counteracted by the self - conceit of a weak head , living in retirement , and the consequential feelings of early and unexpected prosperity . A fortunate chance had recommended [him]149-mr. collins to [Lady Catherine de Bourgh]97-lady catherine when [the living of [Hunsford]16-hunsford]743-the living of hunsford was vacant ; and the respect which [he]149-mr. collins felt for [her]97-lady catherine high rank , and [his]149-mr. collins veneration for [her]97-lady catherine as [[his]149-mr. collins patroness]717-his patroness , mingling with a very good opinion of [himself]149-mr. collins , of [his]149-mr. collins authority as [a clergyman]679-a clergyman , and [his]149-mr. collins rights as [a rector]746-a rector , made [him]149-mr. collins altogether a mixture of pride and obsequiousness , self - importance and humility .

Having now [a good house]363-a good house and very sufficient income , [he]149-mr. collins intended to marry ; and in seeking a reconciliation with [[the Longbourn]7-longbourn family]748-the longbourn family [he]149-mr. collins had [a wife in view]749-a wife in view , as [he]149-mr. collins meant to chuse [one of [the daughters]751-the daughters]750-one of the daughters , if [he]149-mr. collins found [them]751-the daughters as handsome and amiable as [they]751-the daughters were represented by common report . This was [his]149-mr. collins plan of amends -- of atonement -- for inheriting [[their]751-the daughters father]267-their father 's estate ; and [he]149-mr. collins thought it an excellent one , full of eligibility and suitableness , and excessively generous and disinterested on [his]149-mr. collins own part .

[His]149-mr. collins plan did not vary on seeing [them.--Miss Bennet]96-mrs. bennet 's lovely face confirmed [his]149-mr. collins views , and established all [his]149-mr. collins strictest notions of what was due to seniority ; and for the first evening _ [she]749-a wife in view _ was [his]149-mr. collins settled choice . The next morning , however , made an alteration ; for in a quarter of an hour 's t?te-?-t?te with [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet before breakfast , a conversation beginning with [[his]149-mr. collins parsonage - house]753-his parsonage - house , and leading naturally to the avowal of [his]149-mr. collins hopes , that [a mistress for it]754-a mistress for it might be found at [Longbourn]7-longbourn , produced from [her]96-mrs. bennet , amid very complaisant smiles and general encouragement , a caution against the very Jane [he]149-mr. collins had fixed on.--"As to [[her]96-mrs. bennet _ younger _ daughters]3473-her _ younger _ daughters [she]96-mrs. bennet could not take upon [her]96-mrs. bennet to say -- [she]96-mrs. bennet could not positively answer -- but [she]96-mrs. bennet did not _ know _ of any prepossession;--her _ [eldest _ daughter]3474-eldest _ daughter , [she]96-mrs. bennet must just mention -- [she]96-mrs. bennet felt it incumbent on [her]96-mrs. bennet to hint , was likely to be very soon engaged . "[149-mr. collins]

[Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins had only to change from [Jane]94-jane to [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth -- and it was soon done -- done while [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet was stirring the fire . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , equally next to [Jane]94-jane in birth and beauty , succeeded [her]94-jane of course .

[Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet treasured up the hint , and trusted that [she]96-mrs. bennet might soon have [two daughters]755-two daughters married ; and the man whom [she]96-mrs. bennet [could not bear to speak of the day before]756-could not bear to speak of the day before , was now high in [her]96-mrs. bennet good graces .

[Lydia]95-lydia 's intention of walking to [Meryton]9-meryton was not forgotten ; [every sister]757-every sister except [Mary]98-mary agreed to go with [her]95-lydia ; and [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins was to attend [them]758-them , at the request of [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet , who was most anxious to get rid of [him]86-mr. bennet , and have [[his]86-mr. bennet library to [himself]86-mr. bennet]759-his library to himself ; for thither [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins had followed [him]86-mr. bennet after breakfast , and there [he]149-mr. collins would continue , nominally engaged with one of the largest folios in the collection , but really talking to [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet , with little cessation , of [[his]86-mr. bennet house and garden at [Hunsford]16-hunsford]760-his house and garden at hunsford . Such doings discomposed [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet exceedingly . In [[his]86-mr. bennet library]280-his library [he]86-mr. bennet had been always sure of leisure and tranquillity ; and though prepared , as [he]86-mr. bennet told [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , to meet with folly and conceit in [every other room in [the house]3026-the house]762-every other room in the house , [he]86-mr. bennet was used to be free from [them]764-them [there]325-there ; [his]86-mr. bennet civility , therefore , was most prompt in inviting [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins to join [[his]86-mr. bennet daughters]443-his daughters in [their]443-his daughters walk ; and [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins , being in fact much better fitted for [a walker]767-a walker than [a reader]768-a reader , was extremely well pleased to close [his]149-mr. collins large book , and go .

In pompous nothings on [his]86-mr. bennet side , and civil assents on that of [[his]86-mr. bennet cousins]769-his cousins , [their]443-his daughters time passed till [they]443-his daughters entered [Meryton]9-meryton . The attention of [the younger ones]770-the younger ones was then no longer to be gained by _ [him]86-mr. bennet _ . [Their]770-the younger ones eyes were immediately wandering up in [the street]771-the street in quest of [the officers]466-the officers , and [nothing less than a very smart bonnet indeed]773-nothing less than a very smart bonnet indeed , or a really new muslin in a shop window , could recal [them]770-the younger ones .

But the attention of [every lady]774-every lady was soon caught by [a young man , whom [they]443-his daughters had never seen before , of most gentleman - like appearance , walking with [an officer on the other side of the way]776-an officer on the other side of the way]775-a young man , whom they had never seen before , of most gentleman - like appearance , walking with an officer on the other side of the way . [The officer]777-the officer was [the very Mr. Denny]155-denny , concerning whose return from [London]5-london [Lydia]95-lydia came to inquire , and [he]777-the officer bowed as [they]443-his daughters passed . [All]778-all were struck with [the stranger]343-the stranger 's air , all wondered who [he]343-the stranger could be , and [Kitty]97-lady catherine and [Lydia]95-lydia , determined if possible to find out , led the way across [the street]771-the street , under pretence of wanting something in [an opposite shop]781-an opposite shop , and fortunately had just gained the pavement when [the two gentlemen]782-the two gentlemen turning back had reached the same spot . [Mr. Denny]155-denny addressed [them]782-the two gentlemen directly , and entreated permission to introduce [[his]155-denny friend]307-his friend , [[Mr. Wickham]156-wickham , who had returned with [him]155-denny the day before from [town]285-town , and [he]155-denny was happy to say had accepted a commission in [[their]443-his daughters corps]786-their corps]784-mr. wickham , who had returned with him the day before from town , and he was happy to say had accepted a commission in their corps . This was exactly as it should be ; for [the young man]787-the young man wanted only regimentals to make [him]787-the young man completely charming . [His]787-the young man appearance was greatly in [his]787-the young man favour ; [he]787-the young man had all the best part of beauty , a fine countenance , a good figure , and very pleasing address . The introduction was followed up on [his]787-the young man side by a happy readiness of conversation -- a readiness at the same time perfectly correct and unassuming ; and [the whole party]531-the whole party were still standing and talking together very agreeably , when the sound of horses drew [their]782-the two gentlemen notice , and [Darcy]100-mr. darcy and [Bingley]90-mr. bingley were seen riding down [the street]771-the street . On distinguishing [the ladies of the group]790-the ladies of the group , [the two gentlemen]782-the two gentlemen came directly towards [them]443-his daughters , and began the usual civilities . [Bingley]90-mr. bingley was [the principal spokesman]792-the principal spokesman , and [Miss Bennet]95-lydia the principal object . [He]90-mr. bingley was then , [he]90-mr. bingley said , on [his]90-mr. bingley way to [Longbourn]793-longbourn on purpose to inquire after [her]95-lydia . [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy corroborated it with a bow , and was beginning to determine not to fix [his]100-mr. darcy eyes on [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , when [they]782-the two gentlemen were suddenly arrested by the sight of [the stranger]343-the stranger , and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth happening to see the countenance of both as [they]782-the two gentlemen looked at [each other]3157-each other , was all astonishment at the effect of the meeting . [Both]796-both changed colour , one looked white , the other red . [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham , after a few moments , touched [his]156-wickham hat -- a salutation which [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy just deigned to return . What could be the meaning of it?--It was impossible to imagine ; it was impossible not to long to know .

In another minute [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley , but without seeming to have noticed what passed , took leave and rode on with [[his]90-mr. bingley friend]307-his friend .

[Mr. Denny]155-denny and [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham walked with [the young ladies]281-the young ladies to the door of [[Mr. Philips]126-philips 's house]799-mr. philips 's house , and then made [their]782-the two gentlemen bows , in spite of [Miss Lydia]95-lydia 's pressing entreaties that [they]782-the two gentlemen would come in , and even in spite of [Mrs. Philips]127-mrs. philips ' throwing up the parlour window , and loudly seconding the invitation .

[Mrs. Philips]127-mrs. philips was always glad to see [[her]127-mrs. philips nieces]3068-her nieces , and [the two eldest]414-the two eldest , from [their]782-the two gentlemen recent absence , were particularly welcome , and [she]127-mrs. philips was eagerly expressing [her]127-mrs. philips surprise at [their]782-the two gentlemen sudden return [home]3223-home , which , as [[their]782-the two gentlemen own carriage]803-their own carriage had not fetched [them]782-the two gentlemen , [she]127-mrs. philips should have known nothing about , if [she]127-mrs. philips had not happened to see [[Mr. Jones]135-mr. jones 's shop boy]804-mr. jones 's shop boy in [the street]771-the street , who had told [her]127-mrs. philips that [they]782-the two gentlemen were not to send any more draughts to [Netherfield]2-netherfield because [the Miss Bennets]111-the bennets were come away , when [her]127-mrs. philips civility was claimed towards [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins by [Jane]94-jane 's introduction of [him]149-mr. collins . [She]127-mrs. philips received [him]149-mr. collins with [her]127-mrs. philips very best politeness , which [he]149-mr. collins returned with as much more , apologising for [his]149-mr. collins intrusion , without any previous acquaintance with [her]127-mrs. philips , which [he]149-mr. collins could not help flattering [himself]149-mr. collins however might be justified by [his]149-mr. collins relationship to [the young ladies who introduced [him]149-mr. collins to [her]127-mrs. philips notice]806-the young ladies who introduced him to her notice . [Mrs. Philips]127-mrs. philips was quite awed by such an excess of good breeding ; but [her]127-mrs. philips contemplation of [one stranger]807-one stranger was soon put an end to by exclamations and inquiries about the other , of whom , however , [she]127-mrs. philips could only tell [[her]127-mrs. philips nieces]3068-her nieces what [they]3068-her nieces already knew , that [Mr. Denny]155-denny had brought [him]149-mr. collins from [London]5-london , and that [he]149-mr. collins was to have [a lieutenant]809-a lieutenant 's commission in [the ----shire]7-longbourn . [She]127-mrs. philips had been watching [him]149-mr. collins the last hour , [she]127-mrs. philips said , as [he]149-mr. collins walked up and down [the street]771-the street , and had [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham appeared [Kitty]97-lady catherine and [Lydia]95-lydia would certainly have continued the occupation , but unluckily [no one]3275-no one passed the windows now except [a few of [the officers]466-the officers , who in comparison with [the stranger]343-the stranger]812-a few of the officers , who in comparison with the stranger , were become " [stupid , disagreeable fellows]3475-stupid , disagreeable fellows . "[815-some of them] [Some of [them]466-the officers]815-some of them were to dine with [the Philipses]157-the philipses the next day , and [[their]157-the philipses aunt]455-their aunt promised to make [[her]455-their aunt husband]276-her husband call on [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham , and give [him]156-wickham an invitation also , if [the family]432-the family from [Longbourn]7-longbourn would come in the evening . This was agreed to , and [Mrs. Philips]127-mrs. philips protested that [they]157-the philipses would have a nice comfortable noisy game of lottery tickets , and a little bit of hot supper afterwards . The prospect of such delights was very cheering , and [they]157-the philipses parted in mutual good spirits . [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins repeated [his]149-mr. collins apologies in quitting [the room]271-the room , and was assured with unwearying civility that [they]157-the philipses were perfectly needless .

As [they]157-the philipses walked [home]3223-home , [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth related to [Jane]94-jane what [she]94-jane had seen pass between [the two gentlemen]782-the two gentlemen ; but though [Jane]94-jane would have defended either or both , had [they]782-the two gentlemen appeared to be wrong , [she]94-jane could no more explain such behaviour than [[her]94-jane sister]348-her sister .

[Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins on [his]149-mr. collins return highly gratified [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet by admiring [Mrs. Philips]127-mrs. philips 's manners and politeness . [He]149-mr. collins protested that except [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine and [[her]97-lady catherine daughter]475-her daughter , [he]149-mr. collins had never seen [a more elegant woman]824-a more elegant woman ; for [she]97-lady catherine had not only received [him]149-mr. collins with the utmost civility , but had even pointedly included [him]149-mr. collins in [her]97-lady catherine invitation for the next evening , although utterly unknown to [her]97-lady catherine before . Something [he]149-mr. collins supposed might be attributed to [his]149-mr. collins connection with [them]825-them , but yet [he]149-mr. collins had never met with so much attention in the whole course of [his]149-mr. collins life .

[CHAPTER XVI]158-chapter xvi .

As no objection was made to [the young people]826-the young people 's engagement with [[their]826-the young people aunt]455-their aunt , and all [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins 's scruples of leaving [Mr.]828-mr. and [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet for a single evening during [his]149-mr. collins visit were most steadily resisted , [the coach]3225-the coach conveyed [him]149-mr. collins and [[his]149-mr. collins five cousins]830-his five cousins at a suitable hour to [Meryton]9-meryton ; and [the girls]3033-the girls had the pleasure of hearing , as [they]3033-the girls entered [the drawing - room]530-the drawing - room , that [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham had accepted [[their]3033-the girls uncle]3250-their uncle 's invitation , and was then in [the house]3026-the house .

When this information was given , and [they]3033-the girls had all taken [their]3033-the girls seats , [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins was at leisure to look around [him]149-mr. collins and admire , and [he]149-mr. collins was so much struck with the size and furniture of [the apartment]835-the apartment , that [he]149-mr. collins declared [he]149-mr. collins might almost have supposed [himself]149-mr. collins in [the small summer breakfast parlour at [Rosings]22-rosings]836-the small summer breakfast parlour at rosings ; a comparison that did not at first convey much gratification ; but when [Mrs. Philips]127-mrs. philips understood from [him]149-mr. collins what Rosings was , and who was [its proprietor]837-its proprietor , when [she]127-mrs. philips had listened to the description of only one of [[Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine 's drawing - rooms]838-lady catherine 's drawing - rooms , and found that the chimney - piece alone had cost eight hundred pounds , [she]127-mrs. philips felt all the force of the compliment , and would hardly have resented a comparison with [[the housekeeper]839-the housekeeper 's room]840-the housekeeper 's room .

In describing to [her]127-mrs. philips all the grandeur of [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine and [[her]97-lady catherine mansion]841-her mansion , with occasional digressions in praise of [[his]149-mr. collins own humble abode]842-his own humble abode , and the improvements it was receiving , [he]149-mr. collins was happily employed until [the gentlemen]311-the gentlemen joined [them]311-the gentlemen ; and [he]149-mr. collins found in [Mrs. Philips]127-mrs. philips a very attentive listener , whose opinion of [his]149-mr. collins consequence increased with what [she]127-mrs. philips heard , and who was resolving to retail it all among [[her]127-mrs. philips neighbours]844-her neighbours as soon as [she]127-mrs. philips could . To [the girls]3033-the girls , who could not listen to [[their]3033-the girls cousin]694-their cousin , and [who had nothing to do but to wish for an instrument]847-who had nothing to do but to wish for an instrument , and examine [their]3033-the girls own indifferent imitations of china on the mantle - piece , the interval of waiting appeared very long . It was over at last however . [The gentlemen]311-the gentlemen did approach ; and when [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham walked into [the room]271-the room , [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth felt that [she]93-elizabeth had neither been seeing [him]156-wickham before , nor thinking of [him]156-wickham since , with the smallest degree of unreasonable admiration . [The officers of the ----shire]850-the officers of the ----shire were in general a very creditable , [gentleman - like set]851-gentleman - like set , and the best of [them]850-the officers of the ----shire were of [the present party]3382-the present party ; but [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham was as far beyond [them]850-the officers of the ----shire all in person , countenance , air , and walk , as _ [they]850-the officers of the ----shire _ were superior to [the broad - faced stuffy uncle [Philips]127-mrs. philips , breathing port wine , who followed [them]850-the officers of the ----shire into [the room]271-the room]853-the broad - faced stuffy uncle philips , breathing port wine , who followed them into the room .

[Mr. Wickham]156-wickham was [the happy man towards whom almost every female eye was turned]855-the happy man towards whom almost every female eye was turned , and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was [the happy woman by whom [he]156-wickham finally seated [himself]156-wickham]856-the happy woman by whom he finally seated himself ; and the agreeable manner in which [he]156-wickham immediately fell into conversation , though it was only on its being a wet night , and on the probability of a rainy season , made [her]93-elizabeth feel that the commonest , dullest , most thread - bare topic might be rendered interesting by the skill of [the speaker]857-the speaker .

With such rivals for the notice of the fair , as [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham and [the officers]466-the officers , [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins seemed likely to sink into insignificance ; to [the young ladies]281-the young ladies [he]149-mr. collins certainly was nothing ; but [he]149-mr. collins had still at intervals a kind listener in [Mrs. Philips]127-mrs. philips , and was , by [her]127-mrs. philips watchfulness , most abundantly supplied with coffee and muffin .

When the card tables were placed , [he]149-mr. collins had an opportunity of obliging [her]127-mrs. philips in return , by sitting down to whist .

" [I]149-mr. collins know little of the game , at present , "[149-mr. collins] said [he]149-mr. collins , " but [I]149-mr. collins shall be glad to improve [myself]149-mr. collins , for in [my]149-mr. collins situation of life---- "[149-mr. collins] [Mrs. Philips]127-mrs. philips was very thankful for [his]149-mr. collins compliance , but could not wait for [his]149-mr. collins reason .

[Mr. Wickham]156-wickham did not play at whist , and with ready delight was [he]149-mr. collins received at the other table between [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth and [Lydia]95-lydia . At first there seemed danger of [Lydia]95-lydia 's engrossing [him]149-mr. collins entirely , for [she]95-lydia was [a most determined talker]860-a most determined talker ; but being likewise extremely fond of lottery tickets , [she]95-lydia soon grew too much interested in the game , too eager in making bets and exclaiming after prizes , to have attention for any one in particular . Allowing for the common demands of the game , [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham was therefore at leisure to talk to [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , and [she]93-elizabeth was very willing to hear [him]156-wickham , though what [she]93-elizabeth chiefly wished to hear [she]93-elizabeth could not hope to be told , the history of [his]156-wickham acquaintance with [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy . [She]93-elizabeth dared not even mention [that gentleman]3311-that gentleman . [Her]93-elizabeth curiosity however was unexpectedly relieved . [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham began the subject [himself]156-wickham . [He]156-wickham inquired how far [Netherfield]2-netherfield was from [Meryton]9-meryton ; and , after receiving [her]93-elizabeth answer , asked in an hesitating manner how long [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy had been staying [there]325-there .

" About a month , "[93-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth ; and then , unwilling to let the subject drop , added , " [He]100-mr. darcy is [a man of very large property in [Derbyshire]6-derbyshire]3476-a man of very large property in derbyshire , [I]93-elizabeth understand . "[93-elizabeth]

" Yes , "[93-elizabeth] replied [Wickham;--"his estate]3477-wickham;--"his estate there is a noble one . A clear ten thousand per annum . [You]93-elizabeth could not have met with [a person more capable of giving [you]93-elizabeth certain information on that head than [myself]93-elizabeth]3478-a person more capable of giving you certain information on that head than myself -- for [I]93-elizabeth have been connected with [[his]100-mr. darcy family]394-his family in a particular manner from [my]93-elizabeth infancy . "[93-elizabeth]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth could not but look surprised .

" [You]93-elizabeth may well be surprised , [Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth , at such an assertion , after seeing , as [you]93-elizabeth probably might , the very cold manner of [our]3480-our meeting yesterday.--Are [you]93-elizabeth much acquainted with [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy ? "[93-elizabeth]

" As much as [I]93-elizabeth ever wish to be , "[93-elizabeth] cried [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth warmly,--"I have spent four days in [the same house]3481-the same house with [him]100-mr. darcy , and [I]93-elizabeth think [him]100-mr. darcy very disagreeable . "[93-elizabeth]

" [I]156-wickham have no right to give [_]3482-_ [my]156-wickham _ opinion , "[156-wickham] said [Wickham]156-wickham , " as to [his]100-mr. darcy being agreeable or otherwise . [I]156-wickham am not qualified to form one . [I]156-wickham have known [him]100-mr. darcy too long and too well to be [a fair judge]3483-a fair judge . It is impossible for _ [me]156-wickham _ to be impartial . But [I]156-wickham believe [your]93-elizabeth opinion of [him]100-mr. darcy would in general astonish -- and perhaps [you]93-elizabeth would not express it quite so strongly anywhere else.--Here [you]93-elizabeth are in [[your]93-elizabeth own family]3484-your own family . "[156-wickham]

" Upon [my]93-elizabeth word [I]93-elizabeth say no more _ here _ than [I]93-elizabeth might say in [any house in [the neighbourhood]3040-the neighbourhood]3485-any house in the neighbourhood , except [Netherfield]2-netherfield . [He]100-mr. darcy is not at all liked in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire . [Every body]324-every body is disgusted with [his]100-mr. darcy pride . [You]93-elizabeth will not find [him]100-mr. darcy more favourably spoken of by [any one]3122-any one . "[93-elizabeth]

" [I]156-wickham can not pretend to be sorry , "[156-wickham] said [Wickham]156-wickham , after a short interruption , " that [he]100-mr. darcy or that [any man]3350-any man should not be estimated beyond [their]3490-their deserts ; but with _ [him]100-mr. darcy _ [I]156-wickham believe it does not often happen . [The world]323-the world is blinded by [his]100-mr. darcy fortune and consequence , or frightened by [his]100-mr. darcy high and imposing manners , and sees [him]100-mr. darcy only as [he]100-mr. darcy chuses to be seen . "[156-wickham]

" [I]156-wickham should take [him]100-mr. darcy , even on _ [my]156-wickham _ slight acquaintance , to be [an ill - tempered man]3492-an ill - tempered man . "[156-wickham] [Wickham]156-wickham only shook [his]156-wickham head .

" [I]156-wickham wonder , "[156-wickham] said [he]156-wickham , at the next opportunity of speaking , " whether [he]100-mr. darcy is likely to be in [this country]3493-this country much longer . "[156-wickham]

" [I]93-elizabeth do not at all know ; but [I]93-elizabeth _ heard _ nothing of [his]100-mr. darcy going away when [I]93-elizabeth was at [Netherfield]2-netherfield . [I]93-elizabeth hope [your]156-wickham plans in favour of [the ----shire]7-longbourn will not be affected by [his]100-mr. darcy being in [the neighbourhood]3040-the neighbourhood . "[93-elizabeth]

" Oh ! no -- it is not for _ [me]156-wickham _ to be driven away by [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy . If _ [he]100-mr. darcy _ wishes to avoid seeing _ [me]156-wickham _ , [he]100-mr. darcy must go . [We]3495-we are not on friendly terms , and it always gives [me]156-wickham pain to meet [him]100-mr. darcy , but [I]156-wickham have no reason for avoiding _ [him]100-mr. darcy _ but what [I]156-wickham might proclaim to all [the world]323-the world ; a sense of very great ill usage , and most painful regrets at [his]100-mr. darcy being what [he]100-mr. darcy is . [[His]100-mr. darcy father]360-his father , [Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth , [the late Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , was [one of [the best men that ever breathed]3499-the best men that ever breathed , and [the truest friend [I]156-wickham ever had]3500-the truest friend i ever had]3498-one of the best men that ever breathed , and the truest friend i ever had ; and [I]156-wickham can never be in company with [this Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy without being grieved to the soul by a thousand tender recollections . [His]100-mr. darcy behaviour to [myself]156-wickham has been scandalous ; but [I]156-wickham verily believe [I]156-wickham could forgive [him]100-mr. darcy any thing and every thing , rather than [his]100-mr. darcy disappointing the hopes and disgracing the memory of [[his]100-mr. darcy father]360-his father . "[156-wickham]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth found the interest of the subject increase , and listened with all [her]93-elizabeth heart ; but the delicacy of it prevented farther inquiry .

[Mr. Wickham]156-wickham began to speak on more general topics , [Meryton]9-meryton , [the neighbourhood]3040-the neighbourhood , [the society]864-the society , appearing highly pleased with all that [he]156-wickham had yet seen , and speaking of [the latter]499-the latter especially , with gentle but very intelligible gallantry .

" It was the prospect of constant society , and good society , "[156-wickham] [he]156-wickham added , " which was [my]156-wickham chief inducement to enter the ----shire . [I]156-wickham knew it to be [a most respectable , agreeable corps]3502-a most respectable , agreeable corps , and [[my]156-wickham friend]3352-my friend [Denny]155-denny tempted [me]156-wickham farther by [his]3352-my friend account of [[their]3504-their present quarters]3505-their present quarters , and the very great attentions and excellent acquaintance [Meryton]9-meryton had procured [them]3504-their . Society , [I]156-wickham own , is necessary to [me]156-wickham . [I]156-wickham have been [a disappointed man]3506-a disappointed man , and [my]156-wickham spirits will not bear solitude . [I]156-wickham _ must _ have employment and society . A military life is not what [I]156-wickham was intended for , but circumstances have now made it eligible . [The church]3507-the church _ ought _ to have been [my]156-wickham profession -- [I]156-wickham was brought up for the church , and [I]156-wickham should at this time have been in possession of a most valuable living , had it pleased [the gentleman [we]3509-we were speaking of just now]3508-the gentleman we were speaking of just now . "[156-wickham]

" Indeed ! "[864-the society]

" Yes -- [the late Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy bequeathed [me]156-wickham the next presentation of the best living in [his]100-mr. darcy gift . [He]100-mr. darcy was [[my]156-wickham godfather]3510-my godfather , and excessively attached to [me]156-wickham . [I]156-wickham can not do justice to [his]100-mr. darcy kindness . [He]100-mr. darcy meant to provide for [me]156-wickham amply , and thought [he]100-mr. darcy had done it ; but when the living fell , it was given elsewhere . "[156-wickham]

" Good heavens ! "[93-elizabeth] cried [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth ; " but how could _ that _ be?--How could [his]100-mr. darcy will be disregarded?--Why did not [you]156-wickham seek legal redress ? "[93-elizabeth]

" There was just such an informality in the terms of the bequest as to give [me]156-wickham no hope from law . [A man of honour]3511-a man of honour could not have doubted the intention , but [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy chose to doubt it -- or to treat it as a merely conditional recommendation , and to assert that [I]156-wickham had forfeited all claim to it by extravagance , imprudence , in short any thing or nothing . Certain it is , that the living became vacant two years ago , exactly as [I]156-wickham was of an age to hold it , and that it was given to [another man]3512-another man ; and no less certain is it , that [I]156-wickham can not accuse [myself]156-wickham of having really done any thing to deserve to lose it . [I]156-wickham have a warm , unguarded temper , and [I]156-wickham may perhaps have sometimes spoken [my]156-wickham opinion _ of _ [him]100-mr. darcy , and _ to _ [him]100-mr. darcy , too freely . [I]156-wickham can recal nothing worse . But the fact is , that [we]3513-we are very different sort of [men]3391-men , and that [he]100-mr. darcy hates [me]156-wickham . "[156-wickham]

" This is quite shocking!--He deserves to be publicly disgraced . "[93-elizabeth]

" Some time or other [he]100-mr. darcy _ will _ be -- but it shall not be by _ [me]156-wickham _ . Till [I]156-wickham can forget [[his]100-mr. darcy father]360-his father , [I]156-wickham can never defy or expose _ [him]100-mr. darcy _ . "[156-wickham]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth honoured [him]866-me for such feelings , and thought [him]866-me handsomer than ever as [he]866-me expressed them .

" But what , "[93-elizabeth] said [she]93-elizabeth , after a pause , " can have been [his]100-mr. darcy motive?--what can have induced [him]100-mr. darcy to behave so cruelly ? "[93-elizabeth]

" A thorough , determined dislike of [me]866-me -- a dislike which [I]866-me can not but attribute in some measure to jealousy . Had [the late Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy liked [me]866-me less , [[his]100-mr. darcy son]3516-his son might have borne with [me]866-me better ; but [[his]100-mr. darcy father]360-his father 's uncommon attachment to [me]866-me , irritated [him]100-mr. darcy [I]866-me believe very early in life . [He]100-mr. darcy had not a temper to bear the sort of competition in which [we]3518-we stood -- the sort of preference which was often given [me]866-me . "[866-me]

" [I]93-elizabeth had not thought [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy so bad as this -- though [I]93-elizabeth have never liked [him]100-mr. darcy , [I]93-elizabeth had not thought so very ill of [him]100-mr. darcy -- [I]93-elizabeth had supposed [him]100-mr. darcy to be despising [his]100-mr. darcy fellow - creatures in general , but did not suspect [him]100-mr. darcy of descending to such malicious revenge , such injustice , such inhumanity as this ! "[93-elizabeth]

After a few minutes reflection , however , [she]867-she continued , " [I]867-she _ do _ remember [his]100-mr. darcy boasting one day , at [Netherfield]2-netherfield , of the implacability of [his]100-mr. darcy resentments , of [his]100-mr. darcy having an unforgiving temper . [His]100-mr. darcy disposition must be dreadful . "[867-she]

" [I]156-wickham will not trust [myself]156-wickham on the subject , "[156-wickham] replied [Wickham]156-wickham , " _ [I]156-wickham _ can hardly be just to [him]100-mr. darcy . "[156-wickham]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was again deep in thought , and after a time exclaimed , " To treat in such a manner , [the god - son]3519-the god - son , [the friend]3520-the friend , [the favourite of [[his]100-mr. darcy father!"--She]3522-his father!"--she]3521-the favourite of his father!"--she[93-elizabeth] could have added , " [A young man too , like _ [you]93-elizabeth _]3523-a young man too , like _ you _ , whose very countenance may vouch for [your]93-elizabeth being amiable"--but[93-elizabeth] [she]93-elizabeth contented [herself]93-elizabeth with " And one , too , who had probably been [[his]100-mr. darcy own companion]3524-his own companion from childhood , connected together , as [I]93-elizabeth think [you]93-elizabeth said , in the closest manner ! "[93-elizabeth]

" [We]3525-we were born in [the same parish]3526-the same parish , within [the same park]3527-the same park , the greatest part of [our]3525-we youth was passed together ; [inmates of [the same house]3481-the same house]3528-inmates of the same house , sharing the same amusements , objects of the same parental care . _ [[My]93-elizabeth _ father]3530-my _ father began life in the profession which [[your]93-elizabeth uncle]3373-your uncle , [Mr. Philips]126-philips , appears to do so much credit to -- but [he]3530-my _ father gave up every thing to be of use to [the late Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , and devoted all [his]3530-my _ father time to the care of [the Pemberley property]3532-the pemberley property . [He]3530-my _ father was most highly esteemed by [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , [a most intimate , confidential friend]3533-a most intimate , confidential friend . [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy often acknowledged [himself]100-mr. darcy to be under the greatest obligations to [[my]93-elizabeth father]3259-my father 's active superintendance , and when immediately before [[my]93-elizabeth father]3259-my father 's death , [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy gave [him]100-mr. darcy a voluntary promise of providing for [me]93-elizabeth , [I]93-elizabeth am convinced that [he]100-mr. darcy felt it to be as much a debt of gratitude to _ [him]100-mr. darcy _ , as of affection to [myself]93-elizabeth . "[93-elizabeth]

" How strange ! "[93-elizabeth] cried [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth . " How [abominable!--I]93-elizabeth wonder that the very pride of [this Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy has not made [him]100-mr. darcy just to you!--If from no better motive , that [he]100-mr. darcy should not have been too proud to be dishonest,--for dishonesty [I]93-elizabeth must call it . "[93-elizabeth]

" It _ is _ wonderful,"--replied[93-elizabeth] Wickham,--"for almost all [his]100-mr. darcy actions may be traced to pride;--and pride has often been [[his]100-mr. darcy best friend]3536-his best friend . It has connected [him]100-mr. darcy nearer with virtue than any other feeling . But [we]3537-we are none of [us]3537-we consistent ; and in [his]100-mr. darcy behaviour to [me]93-elizabeth , there were stronger impulses even than pride . "[93-elizabeth]

" Can such abominable pride as [his]100-mr. darcy , have ever done [him]100-mr. darcy good ? "[93-elizabeth]

" Yes . It has often led [him]100-mr. darcy to be liberal and generous,--to give [his]100-mr. darcy money freely , to display hospitality , to assist [[his]100-mr. darcy tenants]3538-his tenants , and relieve [the poor]3539-the poor . [Family pride]3540-family pride , and _ filial _ pride , for [he]100-mr. darcy is very proud of what [[his]100-mr. darcy father]360-his father was , have done this . Not to appear to disgrace [[his]100-mr. darcy family]394-his family , to degenerate from the popular qualities , or lose the influence of [the Pemberley House]56-pemberley house , is a powerful motive . [He]100-mr. darcy has also _ brotherly _ pride , which with _ some _ brotherly affection , makes [him]100-mr. darcy [a very kind and careful guardian of [[his]100-mr. darcy sister]569-his sister]3543-a very kind and careful guardian of his sister ; and [you]3545-you will hear [him]100-mr. darcy generally cried up as [the most attentive and best of [brothers]3547-brothers]3546-the most attentive and best of brothers . "[93-elizabeth]

" What sort of [a girl]3548-a girl is [Miss Darcy]139-miss darcy ? "[93-elizabeth]

[He]868-i shook [his]868-i head.--"I wish [I]868-i could call [her]139-miss darcy amiable . It gives [me]868-i pain to speak ill of [a Darcy]139-miss darcy . "[868-i]

After many pauses and many trials of other subjects , [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth could not help reverting once more to the first , and saying ,

" [I]869-the whist party am astonished at [his]264-her father intimacy with [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley ! " Not at all . "[869-the whist party]

" [He]90-mr. bingley is [a sweet tempered , amiable , charming man]3557-a sweet tempered , amiable , charming man . [He]90-mr. bingley can not know what [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy is . "[869-the whist party]

" Probably not;--but [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy can please where [he]100-mr. darcy chuses . [He]100-mr. darcy does not want abilities . "[869-the whist party]

[The whist party]869-the whist party soon afterwards breaking up , [the players]870-the players gathered round the other table , and [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins took [his]149-mr. collins station between [[his]149-mr. collins cousin]727-his cousin [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth and [Mrs. Philips.--The]159-mrs. philips.--the usual inquiries as to [his]149-mr. collins success were made by [the latter]499-the latter . It had not been very great ; [he]149-mr. collins had lost every point ; but when [Mrs. Philips]127-mrs. philips began to express [her]127-mrs. philips concern thereupon , [he]149-mr. collins assured [her]127-mrs. philips with much earnest gravity that it was not of the least importance , that [he]149-mr. collins considered the money as a mere trifle , and begged [she]127-mrs. philips would not make [herself]127-mrs. philips uneasy .

" [I]149-mr. collins know very well , [madam]3285-madam , "[149-mr. collins] said [he]149-mr. collins , " that when [persons]3562-persons sit down to a card table , [they]3562-persons must take [their]3562-persons chance of these things,--and happily [I]149-mr. collins am not in such circumstances as to make five shillings any object . There are undoubtedly many who could not say the same , but thanks to [Lady Catherine de Bourgh]97-lady catherine , [I]149-mr. collins am removed far beyond the necessity of regarding little matters . "[149-mr. collins]

[Mr. Wickham]156-wickham 's attention was caught ; and after observing [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins for a few moments , [he]149-mr. collins asked [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth in a low voice whether [[her]93-elizabeth relation]873-her relation were very intimately acquainted with [the family of [de Bourgh]97-lady catherine]874-the family of de bourgh .

" [Lady Catherine de Bourgh]97-lady catherine , "[93-elizabeth] [she]93-elizabeth replied , " has very lately given [him]149-mr. collins a living .
