"[93-elizabeth]

" [You]149-mr. collins know of course that [Lady Catherine de Bourgh]97-lady catherine and [Lady Anne Darcy]160-anne were [sisters]3563-sisters ; consequently that [she]97-lady catherine is aunt to [the present Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy . "[149-mr. collins]

" No , indeed , [I]93-elizabeth did not.--I knew nothing at all of [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine 's connections . [I]93-elizabeth never heard of [her]97-lady catherine existence till the day before yesterday . "[93-elizabeth]

" [[Her]97-lady catherine daughter]475-her daughter , [Miss de Bourgh]152-miss de bourgh , will have a very large fortune , and it is believed that [she]97-lady catherine and [[her]97-lady catherine cousin]3565-her cousin will unite [the two estates]3566-the two estates . "[149-mr. collins]

This information made [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth smile , as [she]93-elizabeth thought of poor [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley . [Vain]161-vain indeed must be all [her]102-miss bingley attentions , vain and useless [her]102-miss bingley affection for [[his]875-his sister]569-his sister and [her]102-miss bingley praise of [himself]875-his , if [he]875-his were already self - destined to another .

" [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins , "[93-elizabeth] said [she]93-elizabeth , " speaks highly both of [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine and [[her]97-lady catherine daughter]475-her daughter ; but from some particulars that [he]149-mr. collins has related of [[her]97-lady catherine ladyship]677-her ladyship , [I]93-elizabeth suspect [his]149-mr. collins gratitude misleads [him]149-mr. collins , and that in spite of [her]97-lady catherine being [[his]149-mr. collins patroness]717-his patroness , [she]97-lady catherine is [an arrogant , conceited woman]3570-an arrogant , conceited woman . "[93-elizabeth]

" [I]156-wickham believe [her]97-lady catherine to be both in a great degree , "[156-wickham] replied [Wickham]156-wickham ; " [I]156-wickham have not seen [her]97-lady catherine for many years , but [I]156-wickham very well remember that [I]156-wickham never liked [her]97-lady catherine , and that [her]97-lady catherine manners were dictatorial and insolent . [She]97-lady catherine has the reputation of being remarkably sensible and clever ; but [I]156-wickham rather believe [she]97-lady catherine derives part of [her]97-lady catherine abilities from [her]97-lady catherine rank and fortune , part from [her]97-lady catherine authoritative manner , and the rest from the pride of [[her]97-lady catherine nephew]3571-her nephew , who chuses that [every one connected with [him]3571-her nephew]3572-every one connected with him should have an understanding of [the first class]3573-the first class . "[156-wickham]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth allowed that [he]156-wickham had given a very rational account of it , and [they]877-they continued talking together with mutual satisfaction till supper put an end to cards ; and gave [the rest of [the ladies]269-the ladies]878-the rest of the ladies [their]878-the rest of the ladies share of [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham 's attentions . There could be no conversation in the noise of [Mrs. Philips]127-mrs. philips 's supper party , but [his]156-wickham manners recommended [him]156-wickham to every body . Whatever [he]156-wickham said , was said well ; and whatever [he]156-wickham did , done gracefully . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth went away with [her]93-elizabeth head full of [him]156-wickham . [She]93-elizabeth could think of nothing but of [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham , and of what [he]156-wickham had told [her]93-elizabeth , all the way [home]3223-home ; but there was not time for [her]93-elizabeth even to mention [his]156-wickham name as [they]877-they went , for neither [Lydia]95-lydia nor [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins were once silent . [Lydia]95-lydia talked incessantly of lottery tickets , of the fish [she]95-lydia had lost and the fish [she]95-lydia had won , and [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins , in describing the civility of [Mr.]881-mr. and [Mrs. Philips]127-mrs. philips , protesting that [he]149-mr. collins did not in the least regard [his]149-mr. collins losses at whist , enumerating all the dishes at supper , and repeatedly fearing that [he]149-mr. collins crouded [[his]149-mr. collins cousins]769-his cousins , had more to say than [he]149-mr. collins could well manage before [the carriage]3221-the carriage stopped at [Longbourn House]25-longbourn house .

CHAPTER XVII .

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth related to [Jane]94-jane the next day , what had passed between [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham and [herself]94-jane . [Jane]94-jane listened with astonishment and concern;--she knew not how to believe that [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy could be so unworthy of [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley 's regard ; and yet , it was not in [her]94-jane nature to question the veracity of [a young man of such amiable appearance]884-a young man of such amiable appearance as [Wickham.--The]885-wickham.--the possibility of [his]156-wickham having really endured such unkindness , was enough to interest all [her]94-jane tender feelings ; and nothing therefore remained to be done , but to think well of [them]886-them both , to defend the conduct of [each]887-each , and throw into the account of accident or mistake , whatever could not be otherwise explained .

" [They]886-them have both , "[94-jane] said [she]94-jane , " been deceived , [I]94-jane dare say , in some way or other , of which [we]3574-we can form no idea . [Interested people]3575-interested people have perhaps misrepresented each to [the other]3363-the other . It is , in short , impossible for [us]3574-we to conjecture the causes or circumstances which may have alienated [them]3575-interested people , without actual blame on either side . "[94-jane]

" Very true , indeed;--and now , [[my]90-mr. bingley dear [Jane]94-jane]3577-my dear jane , what have [you]94-jane got to say in behalf of [the interested people who have probably been concerned in the business?--Do clear _ them]3578-the interested people who have probably been concerned in the business?--do clear _ them _ too , or [we]3574-we shall be obliged to think ill of [somebody]3579-somebody . "[90-mr. bingley]

" Laugh as much as [you]94-jane chuse , but [you]94-jane will not laugh [me]94-jane out of [my]94-jane opinion . [[My]94-jane dearest]3231-my dearest [Lizzy]93-elizabeth , do but consider in what a disgraceful light it places [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , to be treating [[[his]100-mr. darcy father]360-his father 's favourite in such a manner,--one , whom [[his]100-mr. darcy father]360-his father had promised to provide for.--It]3582-his father 's favourite in such a manner,--one , whom his father had promised to provide for.--it is impossible . [No man of common humanity]3584-no man of common humanity , [no man who had any value for [his]100-mr. darcy character]3585-no man who had any value for his character , could be capable of it . Can [[his]100-mr. darcy most intimate friends]3586-his most intimate friends be so excessively deceived in [him]100-mr. darcy ? oh ! no . "[94-jane]

" [I]90-mr. bingley can much more easily believe [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley 's being imposed on , than that [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham should invent such a history of [himself]90-mr. bingley as [he]90-mr. bingley gave [me]90-mr. bingley last night ; names , facts , every thing mentioned without ceremony.--If it be not so , let [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy contradict it . Besides , there was truth in [his]90-mr. bingley looks . "[90-mr. bingley]

" It is difficult indeed -- it is distressing.--One does not know what to think . "[94-jane]

" [I]90-mr. bingley beg [your]90-mr. bingley pardon;--one knows exactly what to think . "[90-mr. bingley]

But [Jane]94-jane could think with certainty on only one point,--that [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley , if [he]90-mr. bingley _ had been _ imposed on , would have much to suffer when the affair became public .

[The two young ladies]888-the two young ladies were summoned from the shrubbery where this conversation passed , by the arrival of [some of [the very persons of whom [they]888-the two young ladies had been speaking]890-the very persons of whom they had been speaking]889-some of the very persons of whom they had been speaking ; [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley and [[his]90-mr. bingley sisters]303-his sisters came to give [their]888-the two young ladies personal invitation for the long expected ball at [Netherfield]2-netherfield , which was fixed for the following Tuesday . [The two ladies]512-the two ladies were delighted to see [[their]512-the two ladies dear friend]526-their dear friend again , called it an age since [they]512-the two ladies had met , and repeatedly asked what [she]526-their dear friend had been doing with [herself]526-their dear friend since [their]512-the two ladies separation . To [the rest of [the family]432-the family]894-the rest of the family [they]512-the two ladies paid little attention ; avoiding [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet as much as possible , saying not much to [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , and nothing at all to [the others]517-the others . [They]512-the two ladies were soon gone again , rising from [their]512-the two ladies seats with an activity which took [[their]512-the two ladies brother]359-their brother by surprise , and hurrying off as if eager to escape from [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet 's civilities .

The prospect of the [Netherfield]2-netherfield ball was extremely agreeable to [every female of [the family]432-the family]898-every female of the family . [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet chose to consider it as given in compliment to [[her]96-mrs. bennet eldest daughter]332-her eldest daughter , and was particularly flattered by receiving the invitation from [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley [himself]90-mr. bingley , instead of a ceremonious card . [Jane]94-jane pictured to [herself]94-jane a happy evening in the society of [[her]94-jane two friends]616-her two friends , and the attentions of [[their]512-the two ladies brother]359-their brother ; and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth thought with pleasure of dancing a great deal with [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham , and of seeing a confirmation of every thing in [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy 's looks and behaviour . The happiness anticipated by [Catherine]97-lady catherine and [Lydia]95-lydia , depended less on any single event , or [any particular person]903-any particular person , for though [they]616-her two friends each , like [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , meant to dance half the evening with [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham , [he]156-wickham was by no means [the only partner who could satisfy [them]616-her two friends]904-the only partner who could satisfy them , and a ball was at any rate , a ball . And even [Mary]98-mary could assure [[her]98-mary family]905-her family that [she]98-mary had no disinclination for it .

" While [I]98-mary can have [my]98-mary mornings to [myself]98-mary , "[98-mary] said [she]98-mary , " it is [enough.--I]98-mary think it no sacrifice to join occasionally in evening engagements . Society has claims on [us]3587-us all ; and [I]98-mary profess [myself]98-mary one of those who consider intervals of recreation and amusement as desirable for every body . "[98-mary]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth 's spirits were so high on the occasion , that though [she]93-elizabeth did not often speak unnecessarily to [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins , [she]93-elizabeth could not help asking [him]149-mr. collins whether [he]149-mr. collins intended to accept [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley 's invitation , and if [he]149-mr. collins did , whether [he]149-mr. collins would think it proper to join in the evening 's amusement ; and [she]93-elizabeth was rather surprised to find that [he]149-mr. collins entertained no scruple whatever on that head , and was very far from dreading a rebuke either from [the Archbishop]906-the archbishop , or [Lady Catherine de Bourgh]97-lady catherine , by venturing to dance .

" [I]149-mr. collins am by no means of opinion , [I]149-mr. collins assure [you]93-elizabeth , "[149-mr. collins] said [he]149-mr. collins , " that a ball of this kind , given by [a young man of character]3588-a young man of character , to [respectable people]3589-respectable people , can have any evil tendency ; and [I]149-mr. collins am so far from objecting to dancing [myself]149-mr. collins that [I]149-mr. collins shall hope to be honoured with the hands of all [[my]149-mr. collins fair cousins]3590-my fair cousins in the course of the evening , and [I]149-mr. collins take this opportunity of soliciting [yours]93-elizabeth , [Miss Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , for the two first dances especially,--a preference which [I]149-mr. collins trust [[my]149-mr. collins cousin]3411-my cousin [Jane]94-jane will attribute to the right cause , and not to any disrespect for [her]94-jane . "[149-mr. collins]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth felt [herself]93-elizabeth completely taken in . [She]93-elizabeth had fully proposed being engaged by [Wickham]156-wickham for those very dances:--and to have [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins instead ! [her]93-elizabeth liveliness had been never worse timed . There was no help for it however . [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham 's happiness and [her]93-elizabeth own was per force delayed a little longer , and [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins 's proposal accepted with as good a grace as [she]93-elizabeth could . [She]93-elizabeth was not the better pleased with [his]149-mr. collins gallantry , from the idea it suggested of something more.--It now first struck [her]93-elizabeth , that _ [she]93-elizabeth _ was selected from among [[her]93-elizabeth sisters]3048-her sisters as worthy of being [the mistress of [Hunsford Parsonage]26-hunsford parsonage]908-the mistress of hunsford parsonage , and of assisting to form a quadrille table at [Rosings]22-rosings , in the absence of [more eligible visitors]909-more eligible visitors . The idea soon reached to conviction , as [she]93-elizabeth observed [his]149-mr. collins increasing civilities toward [herself]93-elizabeth , and heard [his]149-mr. collins frequent attempt at a compliment on [her]93-elizabeth wit and vivacity ; and though more astonished than gratified [herself]93-elizabeth , by this effect of [her]93-elizabeth charms , it was not long before [[her]93-elizabeth mother]261-her mother gave [her]93-elizabeth to understand that the probability of [their]911-their marriage was exceedingly agreeable to _ [her]93-elizabeth _ . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth however did not chuse to take the hint , being well aware that a serious dispute must be the consequence of any reply . [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins might never make the offer , and till [he]149-mr. collins did , it was useless to quarrel about [him]149-mr. collins .

If there had not been a Netherfield ball to prepare for and talk of , [the younger Miss Bennets]111-the bennets would have been in a pitiable state at this time , for from the day of the invitation , to the day of the ball , there was such a succession of rain as prevented [their]911-their walking to [Meryton]9-meryton once . [No aunt]912-no aunt , [no officers]913-no officers , no news could be sought after;--the very shoe - roses for [Netherfield]2-netherfield were got by proxy . Even [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth might have found some trial of [her]93-elizabeth patience in weather , which totally suspended the improvement of [her]93-elizabeth acquaintance with [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham ; and nothing less than a dance on Tuesday , could have made such a Friday , Saturday , Sunday and Monday , endurable to [Kitty]97-lady catherine and [Lydia]95-lydia .

CHAPTER XVIII .

Till [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth entered [the drawing - room at [Netherfield]2-netherfield]914-the drawing - room at netherfield and looked in vain for [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham among the cluster of red coats there assembled , a doubt of [his]156-wickham being present had never occurred to [her]93-elizabeth . The certainty of meeting [him]156-wickham had not been checked by any of those recollections that might not unreasonably have alarmed [her]93-elizabeth . [She]93-elizabeth had dressed with more than usual care , and prepared in the highest spirits for the conquest of all that remained unsubdued of [his]156-wickham heart , trusting that it was not more than might be won in the course of the evening . But in an instant arose the dreadful suspicion of [his]156-wickham being purposely omitted for [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy 's pleasure in the Bingleys ' invitation to [the officers]466-the officers ; and though this was not exactly the case , the absolute fact of [his]156-wickham absence was pronounced by [[his]156-wickham friend]307-his friend [Mr. Denny]155-denny , to whom [Lydia]95-lydia eagerly applied , and who told [them]917-them that [Wickham]156-wickham had been obliged to go to [town]285-town on business the day before , and was not yet returned ; adding , with a significant smile ,

" [I]156-wickham do not imagine [his]156-wickham business would have called [him]156-wickham away just now , if [he]156-wickham had not wished to avoid [a certain gentleman]3592-a certain gentleman [here]3019-here . "[156-wickham]

This part of [his]156-wickham intelligence , though unheard by [Lydia]95-lydia , was caught by [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , and as it assured [her]93-elizabeth that [Darcy]100-mr. darcy was not less answerable for [Wickham]156-wickham 's absence than if [her]93-elizabeth first surmise had been just , every feeling of displeasure against [the former]347-the former was so sharpened by immediate disappointment , that [she]93-elizabeth could hardly reply with tolerable civility to the polite inquiries which [he]100-mr. darcy directly afterwards approached to make.--Attention , forbearance , patience with [Darcy]100-mr. darcy , was injury to [Wickham]156-wickham . [She]93-elizabeth was resolved against any sort of conversation with [him]100-mr. darcy , and turned away with a degree of ill humour , which [she]93-elizabeth could not wholly surmount even in speaking to [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley , whose blind partiality provoked [her]93-elizabeth .

But [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was not formed for ill - humour ; and though every prospect of [her]93-elizabeth own was destroyed for the evening , it could not dwell long on [her]93-elizabeth spirits ; and having told all [her]93-elizabeth griefs to [Charlotte Lucas]114-charlotte , whom [she]93-elizabeth had not seen for a week , [she]93-elizabeth was soon able to make a voluntary transition to the oddities of [[her]93-elizabeth cousin]3565-her cousin , and to point [him]3565-her cousin out to [her]93-elizabeth particular notice . The two first dances , however , brought a return of distress ; they were dances of mortification . [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins , awkward and solemn , apologising instead of attending , and often moving wrong without being aware of it , gave [her]93-elizabeth all the shame and misery which [a disagreeable partner for a couple of dances]921-a disagreeable partner for a couple of dances can give . The moment of [her]93-elizabeth release from [him]100-mr. darcy was ecstacy .

[She]93-elizabeth danced next with [an officer]922-an officer , and had the refreshment of talking of [Wickham]156-wickham , and of hearing that [he]100-mr. darcy was universally liked . When those dances were over [she]93-elizabeth returned to [Charlotte Lucas]114-charlotte , and was in conversation with [her]114-charlotte , when [she]93-elizabeth found [herself]93-elizabeth suddenly addressed by [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , who took [her]93-elizabeth so much by surprise in [his]100-mr. darcy application for [her]93-elizabeth hand , that , without knowing what [she]93-elizabeth did , [she]93-elizabeth accepted [him]100-mr. darcy . [He]100-mr. darcy walked away again immediately , and [she]93-elizabeth was left to fret over [her]93-elizabeth own want of presence of mind ; [Charlotte]114-charlotte tried to console [her]93-elizabeth .

" [I]93-elizabeth dare say [you]93-elizabeth will find [him]100-mr. darcy very agreeable . "[93-elizabeth]

" Heaven forbid!--_That _ would be the greatest misfortune of all!--To find [a man agreeable whom [one]3064-one is determined to hate!--Do not wish [me]3153-a simpleton such an evil]3594-a man agreeable whom one is determined to hate!--do not wish me such an evil . "[3153-a simpleton]

When the dancing recommenced , however , and [Darcy]100-mr. darcy approached to claim [her]93-elizabeth hand , [Charlotte]114-charlotte could not help cautioning [her]93-elizabeth in a whisper not to be [a simpleton]3153-a simpleton and allow [her]93-elizabeth fancy for [Wickham]156-wickham to make [her]93-elizabeth appear unpleasant in the eyes of [a man of ten times [his]100-mr. darcy consequence]924-a man of ten times his consequence . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth made no answer , and took [her]93-elizabeth place in the set , amazed at the dignity to which [she]93-elizabeth was arrived in being allowed to stand opposite to [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , and reading in [[her]93-elizabeth neighbours]844-her neighbours ' looks [their]844-her neighbours equal amazement in beholding it . [They]926-we stood for some time without speaking a word ; and [she]93-elizabeth began to imagine that [their]926-we silence was to last through the two dances , and at first was resolved not to break it ; till suddenly fancying that it would be the greater punishment to [[her]93-elizabeth partner]927-her partner to oblige [him]927-her partner to talk , [she]93-elizabeth made some slight observation on the dance . [He]927-her partner replied , and was again silent . After a pause of some minutes [she]93-elizabeth addressed [him]927-her partner a second time with

" It is _ [your]927-her partner _ turn to say something now , [Mr. Darcy.--_I]162-mr. darcy.--_i _ talked about the dance , and _ [you]927-her partner _ ought to make some kind of remark on the size of [the room]271-the room , or the number of [couples]3597-couples . "[93-elizabeth]

[He]927-her partner smiled , and assured [her]93-elizabeth that whatever [she]93-elizabeth wished [him]927-her partner to say should be said .

" Very well.--That reply will do for the present.--Perhaps by and bye [I]93-elizabeth may observe that private balls are much pleasanter than public ones.--But _ now _ [we]926-we may be silent . "[93-elizabeth]

" Do [you]927-her partner talk by rule then , while [you]927-her partner are dancing ? "[93-elizabeth]

" Sometimes . [One]3064-one must speak a little , [you]927-her partner know . It would look odd to be entirely silent for half an hour together , and yet for the advantage of _ some _ , conversation ought to be so arranged as that [they]3599-they may have the trouble of saying as little as possible . "[93-elizabeth]

" Are [you]927-her partner consulting [your]927-her partner own feelings in the present case , or do [you]927-her partner imagine that [you]927-her partner are gratifying [mine]927-her partner ? "[93-elizabeth]

" Both , "[93-elizabeth] replied [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth archly ; " for [I]93-elizabeth have always seen a great similarity in the turn of [our]926-we minds.--We are [each of an unsocial , taciturn disposition]3600-each of an unsocial , taciturn disposition , unwilling to speak , unless [we]926-we expect to say something that will amaze [the whole room]3601-the whole room , and be handed down to posterity with all the eclat of a proverb . "[93-elizabeth]

" This is no very striking resemblance of [your]93-elizabeth own character , [I]928-he am sure , "[928-he] said [he]928-he . " How near it may be to _ mine _ , [I]928-he can not pretend to say.--_You _ think it a faithful portrait undoubtedly . "[928-he]

" [I]93-elizabeth must not decide on [my]93-elizabeth own performance . "[93-elizabeth]

[He]928-he made no answer , and [they]929-they were again silent till [they]929-they had gone down the dance , when [he]928-he asked [her]93-elizabeth if [she]93-elizabeth and [[her]93-elizabeth sisters]3048-her sisters did not very often walk to [Meryton]9-meryton . [She]93-elizabeth answered in the affirmative , and , unable to resist the temptation , added , " When [you]928-he met [us]929-they [there]325-there the other day , [we]929-they had just been forming [a new acquaintance]3603-a new acquaintance . "[93-elizabeth]

The effect was immediate . A deeper shade of hauteur overspread [his]928-he features , but [he]928-he said not a word , and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , though blaming [herself]93-elizabeth for [her]93-elizabeth own weakness , could not go on . At length [Darcy]100-mr. darcy spoke , and in a constrained manner said ,

" [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham is blessed with such happy manners as may ensure [his]156-wickham _ making _ friends -- whether [he]156-wickham may be equally capable of _ retaining _ [them]3604-them , is less certain . "[100-mr. darcy]

" [He]156-wickham has been so unlucky as to lose _ [your]100-mr. darcy _ friendship , "[93-elizabeth] replied [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth with emphasis , " and in a manner which [he]156-wickham is likely to suffer from all [his]156-wickham life . "[93-elizabeth]

[Darcy]100-mr. darcy made no answer , and seemed desirous of changing the subject . At that moment [Sir William Lucas]91-sir william appeared close to [them]931-them , meaning to pass through the set to the other side of [the room]271-the room ; but on perceiving [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy [he]91-sir william stopt with a bow of superior courtesy to compliment [him]100-mr. darcy on [his]100-mr. darcy dancing and [[his]100-mr. darcy partner]933-his partner .

" [I]91-sir william have been most highly gratified indeed , [[my]91-sir william dear]3018-my dear [Sir]3172-sir . Such very superior dancing is not often seen . It is evident that [you]3172-sir belong to the first circles . Allow [me]91-sir william to say , however , that [[your]3172-sir fair partner]3607-your fair partner does not disgrace [you]3172-sir , and that [I]91-sir william must hope to have this pleasure often repeated , especially when a certain desirable event , [[my]91-sir william dear]3018-my dear [Miss Eliza]93-elizabeth , ( glancing at [[her]93-elizabeth sister]348-her sister and [Bingley]90-mr. bingley , ) shall take place . What congratulations will then flow in ! [I]91-sir william appeal to [Mr. Darcy:--but]163-mr. darcy:--but let [me]91-sir william not interrupt [you]3172-sir , [Sir.--You]3172-sir will not thank [me]91-sir william for detaining [you]3172-sir from the bewitching converse of [that young lady]3610-that young lady , whose bright eyes are also upbraiding [me]91-sir william . "[91-sir william]

The latter part of this address was scarcely heard by [Darcy]100-mr. darcy ; but [Sir William]91-sir william 's allusion to [[his]91-sir william friend]307-his friend seemed to strike [him]91-sir william forcibly , and [his]91-sir william eyes were directed with a very serious expression towards [Bingley]90-mr. bingley and [Jane]94-jane , who were dancing together . Recovering [himself]91-sir william , however , shortly , [he]91-sir william turned to [[his]91-sir william partner]933-his partner , and said ,

" [Sir William]91-sir william 's interruption has made [me]91-sir william forget what [we]3611-we were talking of . "[91-sir william]

" [I]91-sir william do not think [we]3611-we were speaking at all . [Sir William]91-sir william could not have interrupted [any two people in [the room]271-the room who had less to say for themselves.--We have tried two or three subjects already without success , and what [we]3611-we are to talk of next [I]91-sir william can not imagine]3612-any two people in the room who had less to say for themselves.--we have tried two or three subjects already without success , and what we are to talk of next i can not imagine . "[91-sir william]

" What think [you]933-his partner of books ? "[91-sir william] said [he]91-sir william , smiling .

" Books -- Oh ! no.--I am sure [we]3611-we never read the same , or not with the same feelings . "[91-sir william]

" [I]91-sir william am sorry [you]91-sir william think so ; but if that be the case , there can at least be no want of subject.--We may compare [our]3611-we different opinions . "[91-sir william]

" No -- [I]91-sir william can not talk of books in [a ball - room]3614-a ball - room ; [my]91-sir william head is always full of something else . "[91-sir william]

" The _ present _ always occupies [you]936-i in such scenes -- does it ? "[91-sir william] said [he]91-sir william , with a look of doubt .

" Yes , always , "[936-i] [she]936-i replied , without knowing what [she]936-i said , for [her]936-i thoughts had wandered far from the subject , as soon afterwards appeared by [her]936-i suddenly exclaiming , " [I]936-i remember hearing [you]91-sir william once say , [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , that [you]91-sir william hardly ever forgave , that [your]91-sir william resentment once created was unappeasable . [You]91-sir william are very cautious , [I]936-i suppose , as to its _ being created _ . "[936-i]

" [I]91-sir william am , "[91-sir william] said [he]91-sir william , with a firm voice .

" And never allow [yourself]91-sir william to be blinded by prejudice ? "[936-i]

" [I]936-i hope not . "[936-i]

" It is particularly incumbent on those who never change [their]3615-their opinion , to be secure of judging properly at first . "[936-i]

" May [I]936-i ask to what these questions tend ? "[936-i]

" Merely to the illustration of _ [your]91-sir william _ character , "[936-i] said [she]936-i , endeavouring to shake off [her]936-i gravity . " [I]936-i am trying to make it out . "[936-i]

" And what is [your]91-sir william success ? "[936-i]

[She]936-i shook [her]936-i head . " [I]936-i do not get on at all . [I]936-i hear such different accounts of [you]91-sir william as puzzle [me]936-i exceedingly . "[936-i]

" [I]91-sir william can readily believe , "[91-sir william] answered [he]91-sir william gravely , " that report may vary greatly with respect to [me]91-sir william ; and [I]91-sir william could wish , [Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth , that [you]936-i were not to sketch [my]91-sir william character at the present moment , as there is reason to fear that the performance would reflect no credit on either . "[91-sir william]

" But if [I]936-i do not take [your]936-i likeness now , [I]936-i may never have another opportunity . "[936-i]

" [I]91-sir william would by no means suspend any pleasure of [yours]936-i , "[91-sir william] [he]91-sir william coldly replied . [She]936-i said no more , and [they]937-they went down the other dance and parted in silence ; on each side dissatisfied , though not to an equal degree , for in [Darcy]100-mr. darcy 's breast there was a tolerable powerful feeling towards [her]936-i , which soon procured [her]936-i pardon , and directed all [his]100-mr. darcy anger against another .

[They]937-they had not long separated when [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley came towards [her]936-i , and with an expression of civil disdain thus accosted [her]936-i ,

" So , [Miss Eliza]93-elizabeth , [I]100-mr. darcy hear [you]93-elizabeth are quite delighted with [[George Wickham!--Your]164-george wickham!--your sister]3616-george wickham!--your sister has been talking to [me]100-mr. darcy about [him]164-george wickham!--your , and asking [me]100-mr. darcy a thousand questions ; and [I]100-mr. darcy find that [the young man]787-the young man forgot to tell [you]93-elizabeth , among [his]787-the young man other communications , that [he]787-the young man was [the son of [old Wickham]156-wickham]3618-the son of old wickham , [[the late Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy 's steward]3619-the late mr. darcy 's steward . Let [me]100-mr. darcy recommend [you]93-elizabeth , however , as [a friend]3351-a friend , not to give implicit confidence to all [his]164-george wickham!--your assertions ; for as to [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy 's using [him]100-mr. darcy ill , it is perfectly false ; for , on the contrary , [he]100-mr. darcy has been always remarkably kind to [him]100-mr. darcy , though [George Wickham]165-george wickham has treated [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy in a most infamous manner . [I]100-mr. darcy do not know the particulars , but [I]100-mr. darcy know very well that [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy is not in the least to blame , that [he]100-mr. darcy can not bear to hear [George Wickham]165-george wickham mentioned , and that though [[my]100-mr. darcy brother]3216-my brother thought [he]100-mr. darcy could not well avoid including [him]100-mr. darcy in [his]100-mr. darcy invitation to [the officers]466-the officers , [he]100-mr. darcy was excessively glad to find that [he]100-mr. darcy had taken [himself]100-mr. darcy out of the way . [His]100-mr. darcy coming into [the country]460-the country at all , is a most insolent thing indeed , and [I]100-mr. darcy wonder how [he]100-mr. darcy could presume to do it . [I]100-mr. darcy pity [you]93-elizabeth , [Miss Eliza]93-elizabeth , for this discovery of [your]93-elizabeth favourite 's guilt ; but really considering [his]100-mr. darcy descent , one could not expect much better . "[100-mr. darcy]

" [His]100-mr. darcy guilt and [his]100-mr. darcy descent appear by [your]93-elizabeth account to be the same , "[93-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth angrily ; " for [I]93-elizabeth have heard [you]93-elizabeth accuse [him]100-mr. darcy of nothing worse than of being [the son of [[Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy 's steward]3625-mr. darcy 's steward]3624-the son of mr. darcy 's steward , and of _ that _ , [I]93-elizabeth can assure [you]93-elizabeth , [he]100-mr. darcy informed [me]93-elizabeth [himself]100-mr. darcy . "[93-elizabeth]

" [I]102-miss bingley beg [your]93-elizabeth pardon , "[102-miss bingley] replied [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley , turning away with a sneer . " Excuse [my]102-miss bingley interference.--It was kindly meant . "[102-miss bingley]

" [Insolent girl]3626-insolent girl ! "[93-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth to herself.--"You are much mistaken if [you]93-elizabeth expect to influence [me]102-miss bingley by such a paltry attack as this . [I]102-miss bingley see nothing in it but [your]93-elizabeth own wilful ignorance and the malice of [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy . "[102-miss bingley] [She]93-elizabeth then sought [[her]93-elizabeth eldest sister]938-her eldest sister , who had undertaken to make inquiries on the same subject of [Bingley]102-miss bingley . [Jane]94-jane met [her]94-jane with a smile of such sweet complacency , a glow of such happy expression , as sufficiently marked how well [she]94-jane was satisfied with the occurrences of [the evening.--Elizabeth]939-the evening.--elizabeth instantly read [her]94-jane feelings , and at that moment solicitude for [Wickham]156-wickham , resentment against [[his]156-wickham enemies]940-his enemies , and every thing else gave way before the hope of [Jane]94-jane 's being in the fairest way for happiness .

" [I]93-elizabeth want to know , "[93-elizabeth] said [she]93-elizabeth , with a countenance no less smiling than [[her]93-elizabeth sister]348-her sister 's , " what [you]93-elizabeth have learnt about [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham . But perhaps [you]93-elizabeth have been too pleasantly engaged to think of [any third person]3627-any third person ; in which case [you]93-elizabeth may be sure of [my]93-elizabeth pardon . "[93-elizabeth]

" No , "[94-jane] replied [Jane]94-jane , " [I]94-jane have not forgotten [him]156-wickham ; but [I]94-jane have nothing satisfactory to tell [you]93-elizabeth . [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley does not know the whole of [his]90-mr. bingley history , and is quite ignorant of the circumstances which have principally offended [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy ; but [he]90-mr. bingley will vouch for the good conduct , the probity and honour of [[his]90-mr. bingley friend]307-his friend , and is perfectly convinced that [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham has deserved much less attention from [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy than [he]90-mr. bingley has received ; and [I]94-jane am sorry to say that by [his]90-mr. bingley account as well as [[his]90-mr. bingley sister]569-his sister 's , [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham is by no means [a respectable young man]3630-a respectable young man . [I]94-jane am afraid [he]156-wickham has been very imprudent , and has deserved to lose [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy 's regard . "[94-jane]

" [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley does not know [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham [himself]90-mr. bingley ? "[93-elizabeth]

" No ; [he]90-mr. bingley never saw [him]156-wickham till the other morning at [Meryton]9-meryton . "[94-jane]

" This account then is what [he]90-mr. bingley has received from [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy . [I]93-elizabeth am perfectly satisfied . But what does [he]90-mr. bingley say of [the living]3631-the living ? "[93-elizabeth]

" [He]90-mr. bingley does not exactly recollect the circumstances , though [he]90-mr. bingley has heard them from [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy more than once , but [he]90-mr. bingley believes that it was left to [him]90-mr. bingley _ conditionally _ only . "[94-jane]

" [I]93-elizabeth have not a doubt of [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley 's sincerity , "[93-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth warmly ; " but [you]90-mr. bingley must excuse [my]93-elizabeth not being convinced by assurances only . [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley 's defence of [[his]90-mr. bingley friend]307-his friend was a very able one [I]93-elizabeth dare say , but since [he]90-mr. bingley is unacquainted with several parts of the story , and has learnt the rest from [that friend]3633-that friend [himself]90-mr. bingley , [I]93-elizabeth shall venture still to think of [both gentlemen]3634-both gentlemen as [I]93-elizabeth did before . "[93-elizabeth]

[She]93-elizabeth then changed the discourse to one more gratifying to each , and on which there could be no difference of sentiment . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth listened with delight to the happy , though modest hopes which [Jane]94-jane entertained of [Bingley]90-mr. bingley 's regard , and said all in [her]94-jane power to heighten [her]94-jane confidence in it . On [their]942-their being joined by [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley [himself]90-mr. bingley , [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth withdrew to [Miss Lucas]103-miss lucas ; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of [[her]93-elizabeth last partner]943-her last partner [she]93-elizabeth had scarcely replied , before [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins came up to [them]942-their and told [her]93-elizabeth with great exultation that [he]149-mr. collins had just been so fortunate as to make a most important discovery .

" [I]149-mr. collins have found out , "[149-mr. collins] said [he]149-mr. collins , " by a singular accident , that there is now in [the room]271-the room a near relation of [[my]149-mr. collins patroness]3636-my patroness . [I]149-mr. collins happened to overhear [the gentleman]306-the gentleman [himself]306-the gentleman mentioning to [the young lady who does the honours of [this house]3413-this house]3638-the young lady who does the honours of this house the names of [[his]306-the gentleman cousin]727-his cousin [Miss de Bourgh]152-miss de bourgh , and of [[her]3638-the young lady who does the honours of this house mother]261-her mother [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine . How wonderfully these sort of things occur ! Who would have thought of [my]149-mr. collins meeting with -- perhaps -- [a nephew of [Lady Catherine de Bourgh]97-lady catherine]3642-a nephew of lady catherine de bourgh in [this assembly!--I]3643-this assembly!--i am most thankful that the discovery is made in time for [me]149-mr. collins to pay [my]149-mr. collins respects to [him]3642-a nephew of lady catherine de bourgh , which [I]149-mr. collins am now going to do , and trust [he]3642-a nephew of lady catherine de bourgh will excuse [my]149-mr. collins not having done it before . [My]149-mr. collins total ignorance of the connection must plead [my]149-mr. collins apology . "[149-mr. collins]

" [You]149-mr. collins are not going to introduce [yourself]149-mr. collins to [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy ? "[944-him]

" Indeed [I]149-mr. collins am . [I]149-mr. collins shall intreat [his]3642-a nephew of lady catherine de bourgh pardon for not having done it earlier . [I]149-mr. collins believe [him]3642-a nephew of lady catherine de bourgh to be [[Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine 's _ nephew]3644-lady catherine 's _ nephew _ . "[149-mr. collins]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth tried hard to dissuade [him]944-him from such a scheme ; assuring [him]944-him that [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy would consider [his]944-him addressing [him]944-him without introduction as an impertinent freedom , rather than a compliment to [[his]944-him aunt]945-his aunt ; that it was not in the least necessary there should be any notice on either side , and that if it were , it must belong to [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , the superior in consequence , to begin the acquaintance.--Mr . [Collins]149-mr. collins listened to [her]93-elizabeth with the determined air of following [his]149-mr. collins own inclination , and when [she]93-elizabeth ceased speaking , replied thus ,

" [[My]946-me dear]3018-my dear [Miss Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , [I]946-me have the highest opinion in [the world]323-the world of [your]93-elizabeth excellent judgment in all matters within the scope of [your]93-elizabeth understanding , but permit [me]946-me to say that there must be a wide difference between the established forms of ceremony amongst [the laity]3648-the laity , and those which regulate [the clergy]3649-the clergy ; for give [me]946-me leave to observe that [I]946-me consider the clerical office as equal in point of dignity with the highest rank in [the kingdom]3650-the kingdom -- provided that a proper humility of behaviour is at the same time maintained . [You]93-elizabeth must therefore allow [me]946-me to follow the dictates of [my]946-me conscience on this occasion , which leads [me]946-me to perform what [I]946-me look on as a point of duty . Pardon [me]946-me for neglecting to profit by [your]93-elizabeth advice , which on every other subject shall be [my]946-me constant guide , though in the case before [us]3651-us [I]946-me consider [myself]946-me more fitted by education and habitual study to decide on what is right than [a young lady like [yourself]93-elizabeth]3652-a young lady like yourself . "[946-me] And with a low bow [he]946-me left [her]947-her to attack [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , whose reception of [his]946-me advances [she]947-her eagerly watched , and whose astonishment at being so addressed was very evident . [[Her]947-her cousin]3565-her cousin prefaced [his]946-me speech with a solemn bow , and though [she]947-her could not hear a word of it , [she]947-her felt as if hearing it all , and saw in the motion of [his]946-me lips the words " apology , "[946-me] " [Hunsford]16-hunsford , "[946-me] and " [Lady Catherine de Bourgh]97-lady catherine . "--It[946-me] vexed [her]947-her to see [him]946-me expose [himself]946-me to [such a man]245-such a man . [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy was eyeing [him]946-me with unrestrained wonder , and when at last [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins allowed [him]100-mr. darcy time to speak , replied with an air of distant civility . [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins , however , was not discouraged from speaking again , and [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy 's contempt seemed abundantly increasing with the length of [his]100-mr. darcy second speech , and at the end of it [he]100-mr. darcy only made [him]100-mr. darcy a slight bow , and moved another way . [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins then returned to [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth .

" [I]149-mr. collins have no reason , [I]149-mr. collins assure [you]93-elizabeth , "[149-mr. collins] said [he]149-mr. collins , " to be dissatisfied with [my]149-mr. collins reception . [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy seemed much pleased with the attention . [He]100-mr. darcy answered [me]149-mr. collins with the utmost civility , and even paid [me]149-mr. collins the compliment of saying , that [he]100-mr. darcy was so well convinced of [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine 's discernment as to be certain [she]97-lady catherine could never bestow a favour unworthily . It was really a very handsome thought . Upon the whole , [I]149-mr. collins am much pleased with [him]100-mr. darcy . "[149-mr. collins]

As [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth had no longer any interest of [her]93-elizabeth own to pursue , [she]93-elizabeth turned [her]93-elizabeth attention almost entirely on [[her]93-elizabeth sister]348-her sister and [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley , and the train of agreeable reflections which [her]93-elizabeth observations gave birth to , made [her]93-elizabeth perhaps almost as happy as [Jane]94-jane . [She]93-elizabeth saw [her]93-elizabeth in idea settled in [that very house]951-that very house in all the felicity which a marriage of true affection could bestow ; and [she]93-elizabeth felt capable under such circumstances , of endeavouring even to like [[Bingley]90-mr. bingley 's two sisters]952-bingley 's two sisters . [[Her]93-elizabeth mother]261-her mother 's thoughts [she]93-elizabeth plainly saw were bent the same way , and [she]93-elizabeth determined not to venture near [her]261-her mother , lest [she]93-elizabeth might hear too much . When [they]954-them sat down to supper , therefore , [she]93-elizabeth considered it a most unlucky perverseness which placed [them]954-them within one of [each other]3157-each other ; and deeply was [she]93-elizabeth vexed to find that [[her]93-elizabeth mother]261-her mother was talking to [that one person]957-that one person ( [Lady Lucas]92-lady lucas ) freely , openly , and of nothing else but of [her]261-her mother expectation that [Jane]94-jane would be soon married to [Mr. Bingley.--It]167-mr. bingley.--it was an animating subject , and [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet seemed incapable of fatigue while enumerating the advantages of the match . [His]958-his being such [a charming young man]959-a charming young man , and so rich , and living but three miles from [them]954-them , were the first points of self - gratulation ; and then it was such a comfort to think how fond [the two sisters]960-the two sisters were of [Jane]94-jane , and to be certain that [they]960-the two sisters must desire the connection as much as [she]94-jane could do . It was , moreover , such a promising thing for [[her]94-jane younger daughters]961-her younger daughters , as [Jane]94-jane 's marrying so greatly must throw [them]961-her younger daughters in the way of [other rich men]962-other rich men ; and lastly , it was so pleasant at [her]94-jane time of life to be able to consign [[her]94-jane single daughters]963-her single daughters to the care of [[their]963-her single daughters sister]964-their sister , that [she]94-jane might not be obliged to go into company more than [she]94-jane liked . It was necessary to make this circumstance a matter of pleasure , because on such occasions it is the etiquette ; but [no one]3275-no one was less likely than [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet to find comfort in staying at [home]3223-home at any period of [her]94-jane life . [She]94-jane concluded with many good wishes that [Lady Lucas]92-lady lucas might soon be equally fortunate , though evidently and triumphantly believing there was no chance of it .

In vain did [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth endeavour to check the rapidity of [[her]93-elizabeth mother]261-her mother 's words , or persuade [her]261-her mother to describe [her]94-jane felicity in a less audible whisper ; for to [her]93-elizabeth inexpressible vexation , [she]93-elizabeth could perceive that [the chief of it]968-the chief of it was overheard by [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , who sat opposite to [them]969-them . [[Her]93-elizabeth mother]261-her mother only scolded [her]93-elizabeth for being nonsensical .

" What is [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy to [me]261-her mother , pray , that [I]261-her mother should be afraid of [him]100-mr. darcy ? [I]261-her mother am sure [we]969-them owe [him]100-mr. darcy no such particular civility as to be obliged to say nothing _ [he]100-mr. darcy _ may not like to hear . "[261-her mother]

" For heaven 's sake , [madam]3285-madam , speak lower.--What advantage can it be to [you]3285-madam to offend [Mr. Darcy?--You]168-mr. darcy?--you will never recommend [yourself]3285-madam to [[his]100-mr. darcy friend]307-his friend by so doing . "[261-her mother]

Nothing that [she]93-elizabeth could say , however , had any influence . [[Her]93-elizabeth mother]261-her mother would talk of [her]261-her mother views in the same intelligible tone . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth blushed and blushed again with shame and vexation . [She]93-elizabeth could not help frequently glancing [her]93-elizabeth eye at [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , though every glance convinced [her]93-elizabeth of what [she]93-elizabeth dreaded ; for though [he]100-mr. darcy was not always looking at [[her]93-elizabeth mother]261-her mother , [she]93-elizabeth was convinced that [his]100-mr. darcy attention was invariably fixed by [her]93-elizabeth . The expression of [his]100-mr. darcy face changed gradually from indignant contempt to a composed and steady gravity .

At length however [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet had no more to say ; and [Lady Lucas]92-lady lucas , who had been long yawning at the repetition of delights which [she]92-lady lucas saw no likelihood of sharing , was left to the comforts of cold ham and chicken . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth now began to revive . But not long was the interval of tranquillity ; for when supper was over , singing was talked of , and [she]93-elizabeth had the mortification of seeing [Mary]98-mary , after very little entreaty , preparing to oblige [the company]973-the company . By many significant looks and silent entreaties , did [she]93-elizabeth endeavour to prevent such a proof of complaisance,--but in vain ; [Mary]98-mary would not understand [them]974-them ; such an opportunity of exhibiting was delightful to [her]98-mary , and [she]98-mary began [her]98-mary song . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth 's eyes were fixed on [her]93-elizabeth with most painful sensations ; and [she]93-elizabeth watched [her]93-elizabeth progress through the several stanzas with an impatience which was very ill rewarded at their close ; for [Mary]98-mary , on receiving amongst the thanks of the table , the hint of a hope that [she]98-mary might be prevailed on to favour [them]974-them again , after the pause of half a minute began another . [Mary]98-mary 's powers were by no means fitted for such a display ; [her]98-mary voice was weak , and [her]98-mary manner affected.--Elizabeth was in agonies . [She]98-mary looked at [Jane]94-jane , to see how [she]94-jane bore it ; but [Jane]94-jane was very composedly talking to [Bingley]90-mr. bingley . [She]98-mary looked at [[his]90-mr. bingley two sisters]299-his two sisters , and saw [them]299-his two sisters making signs of derision at [each other]3157-each other , and at [Darcy]100-mr. darcy , who continued however impenetrably grave . [She]98-mary looked at [[her]98-mary father]264-her father to entreat [his]264-her father interference , lest [Mary]98-mary should be singing all night . [He]264-her father took the hint , and when [Mary]98-mary had finished [her]98-mary second song , said aloud ,

" That will do extremely well , [child]3655-child . [You]3655-child have delighted [us]3656-us long enough . Let [the other young ladies]3657-the other young ladies have time to exhibit . "[98-mary]

[Mary]98-mary , though pretending not to hear , was somewhat disconcerted ; and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth sorry for [her]98-mary , and sorry for [[her]93-elizabeth father]264-her father 's speech , was afraid [her]93-elizabeth anxiety had done no good.--Others of [the party]3034-the party were now applied to .

" If [I]149-mr. collins , "[149-mr. collins] said [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins , " were so fortunate as to be able to sing , [I]149-mr. collins should have great pleasure , [I]149-mr. collins am sure , in obliging [the company]973-the company with an air ; for [I]149-mr. collins consider music as a very innocent diversion , and perfectly compatible with the profession of [a clergyman.--I]3659-a clergyman.--i do not mean however to assert that [we]3656-us can be justified in devoting too much of [our]3656-us time to music , for there are certainly other things to be attended to . [The rector of [a parish]3661-a parish]3660-the rector of a parish has much to do.--In the first place , [he]3660-the rector of a parish must make such an agreement for tythes as may be beneficial to [himself]3660-the rector of a parish and not offensive to [[his]3660-the rector of a parish patron]3662-his patron . [He]3660-the rector of a parish must write [his]3660-the rector of a parish own sermons ; and the time that remains will not be too much for [his]3660-the rector of a parish parish duties , and the care and improvement of [[his]3660-the rector of a parish dwelling]3663-his dwelling , which [he]3660-the rector of a parish can not be excused from making as comfortable as possible . And [I]149-mr. collins do not think it of light importance that [he]3660-the rector of a parish should have attentive and conciliatory manners towards every body , especially towards those to whom [he]3660-the rector of a parish owes [his]3660-the rector of a parish preferment . [I]149-mr. collins can not acquit [him]3660-the rector of a parish of that duty ; nor could [I]149-mr. collins think well of [the man who should omit an occasion of testifying [his]3660-the rector of a parish respect towards any body connected with [the family]432-the family]3664-the man who should omit an occasion of testifying his respect towards any body connected with the family . "[149-mr. collins] And with a bow to [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , [he]100-mr. darcy concluded [his]100-mr. darcy speech , which had been spoken so loud as to be heard by [half the room.--Many stared.--Many]980-half the room.--many stared.--many smiled ; but [no one]3275-no one looked more amused than [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet [himself]86-mr. bennet , while [[his]100-mr. darcy wife]251-his wife seriously commended [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins for having spoken so sensibly , and observed in a half - whisper to [Lady Lucas]92-lady lucas , that [he]149-mr. collins was [a remarkably clever , good kind of young man]983-a remarkably clever , good kind of young man .

To [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth it appeared , that had [[her]93-elizabeth family]905-her family made an agreement to expose [themselves]905-her family as much as [they]905-her family could during the evening , it would have been impossible for [them]905-her family to play [their]905-her family parts with more spirit , or finer success ; and happy did [she]93-elizabeth think it for [Bingley]90-mr. bingley and [[her]93-elizabeth sister]348-her sister that some of the exhibition had escaped [his]100-mr. darcy notice , and that [his]100-mr. darcy feelings were not of a sort to be much distressed by the folly which [he]100-mr. darcy must have witnessed . That [[his]100-mr. darcy two sisters]299-his two sisters and [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , however , should have such an opportunity of ridiculing [her]93-elizabeth relations was bad enough , and [she]93-elizabeth could not determine whether the silent contempt of [the gentleman]306-the gentleman , or the insolent smiles of [the ladies]269-the ladies , were more intolerable .

The rest of the evening brought [her]93-elizabeth little amusement . [She]93-elizabeth was teazed by [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins , who continued most perseveringly by [her]93-elizabeth side , and though [he]149-mr. collins could not prevail with [her]93-elizabeth to dance with [him]149-mr. collins again , put it out of [her]93-elizabeth power to dance with [others]3123-others . In vain did [she]93-elizabeth entreat [him]149-mr. collins to stand up with [somebody else]3067-somebody else , and offer to introduce [him]149-mr. collins to [any young lady in [the room]271-the room]991-any young lady in the room . [He]149-mr. collins assured [her]93-elizabeth that as to dancing , [he]149-mr. collins was perfectly indifferent to it ; that [his]149-mr. collins chief object was by delicate attentions to recommend [himself]149-mr. collins to [her]93-elizabeth , and that [he]149-mr. collins should therefore make a point of remaining close to [her]93-elizabeth the whole evening . There was no arguing upon such a project . [She]93-elizabeth owed [her]93-elizabeth greatest relief to [[her]93-elizabeth friend]418-her friend [Miss Lucas]103-miss lucas , who often joined [them]994-their , and good - naturedly engaged [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins 's conversation to [herself]93-elizabeth .

[She]93-elizabeth was at least free from the offence of [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy 's farther notice ; though often standing within a very short distance of [her]93-elizabeth , quite disengaged , [he]149-mr. collins never came near enough to speak . [She]93-elizabeth felt it to be the probable consequence of [her]93-elizabeth allusions to [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham , and rejoiced in it .

The Longbourn party were the last of all [the company]973-the company to depart ; and by a manoeuvre of [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet had to wait for [[their]994-their carriages]996-their carriages a quarter of an hour after every body else was gone , which gave [them]994-their time to see how heartily [they]994-their were wished away by [some of [the family]432-the family]997-some of the family . [Mrs. Hurst]101-mrs. hurst and [[her]101-mrs. hurst sister]348-her sister scarcely opened [their]994-their mouths except to complain of fatigue , and were evidently impatient to have [the house]3026-the house to [themselves]994-their . [They]994-their repulsed every attempt of [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet at conversation , and by so doing , threw a languor over [the whole party]531-the whole party , which was very little relieved by the long speeches of [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins , who was complimenting [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley and [[his]90-mr. bingley sisters]303-his sisters on the elegance of [their]994-their entertainment , and the hospitality and politeness which had marked [their]994-their behaviour to [[their]994-their guests]1003-their guests . [Darcy]100-mr. darcy said nothing at all . [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet , in equal silence , was enjoying the scene . [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley and [Jane]94-jane were standing together , a little detached from the rest , and talked only to [each other]3157-each other . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth preserved as steady a silence as either [Mrs. Hurst]101-mrs. hurst or [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley ; and even [Lydia]95-lydia was too much fatigued to utter more than the occasional exclamation of " [Lord]3666-lord , how tired [I]95-lydia am ! "[95-lydia] accompanied by a violent yawn .

When at length [they]1005-them arose to take leave , [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet was most pressingly civil in [her]96-mrs. bennet hope of seeing [the whole family]331-the whole family soon at [Longbourn]7-longbourn ; and addressed [herself]96-mrs. bennet particularly to [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley , to assure [him]90-mr. bingley how happy [he]90-mr. bingley would make [them]1005-them , by eating a family dinner with [them]1005-them at any time , without the ceremony of a formal invitation . [Bingley]90-mr. bingley was all grateful pleasure , and [he]90-mr. bingley readily engaged for taking the earliest opportunity of waiting on [her]96-mrs. bennet , after [his]90-mr. bingley return from [London]5-london , whither [he]90-mr. bingley was obliged to go the next day for a short time .

[Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet was perfectly satisfied ; and quitted [the house]3026-the house under the delightful persuasion that , allowing for the necessary preparations of settlements , new carriages and wedding clothes , [she]96-mrs. bennet should undoubtedly see [[her]96-mrs. bennet daughter]475-her daughter settled at [Netherfield]2-netherfield , in the course of three or four months . Of having [another daughter]1009-another daughter married to [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins , [she]96-mrs. bennet thought with equal certainty , and with considerable , though not equal , pleasure . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was the least dear to [her]96-mrs. bennet of all [[her]96-mrs. bennet children]1010-her children ; and though [the man]3112-the man and the match were quite good enough for _ [her]96-mrs. bennet _ , the worth of each was eclipsed by [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley and [Netherfield]2-netherfield .

CHAPTER XIX .

The next day opened a new scene at [Longbourn]7-longbourn . [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins made [his]149-mr. collins declaration in form . Having resolved to do it without loss of time , as [his]149-mr. collins leave of absence extended only to the following Saturday , and having no feelings of diffidence to make it distressing to [himself]149-mr. collins even at the moment , [he]149-mr. collins set about it in a very orderly manner , with all the observances which [he]149-mr. collins supposed a regular part of the business . On finding [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet , [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , and [one of [the younger girls]3371-the younger girls]1012-one of the younger girls together , soon after breakfast , [he]149-mr. collins addressed [the mother]412-the mother in these words ,

" May [I]149-mr. collins hope , [Madam]3285-madam , for [your]412-the mother interest with [[your]412-the mother fair daughter]3668-your fair daughter [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , when [I]149-mr. collins solicit for the honour of a private audience with [her]93-elizabeth in the course of this morning ? "[149-mr. collins]

Before [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth had time for any thing but a blush of surprise , [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet instantly answered ,

" Oh dear!--Yes -- certainly.--I am sure [Lizzy]93-elizabeth will be very happy -- [I]93-elizabeth am sure [she]93-elizabeth can have no objection.--Come , [Kitty]97-lady catherine , [I]93-elizabeth want [you]97-lady catherine up [stairs]529-stairs . "[93-elizabeth] And gathering [her]93-elizabeth work together , [she]93-elizabeth was hastening away , when [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth called out ,

" [Dear Ma'am]120-ma'am , do not go.--I beg [you]120-ma'am will not go.--Mr . [Collins]149-mr. collins must excuse me.--He can have nothing to say to [me]93-elizabeth that [any body]3670-any body need not hear . [I]93-elizabeth am going away [myself]93-elizabeth . "[93-elizabeth]

" No , no , nonsense , [Lizzy.--I]169-lizzy.--i desire [you]120-ma'am will stay where [you]120-ma'am are . "--And[93-elizabeth] upon [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth 's seeming really , with vexed and embarrassed looks , about to escape , [she]93-elizabeth added , " [Lizzy]93-elizabeth , [I]93-elizabeth _ insist _ upon [your]120-ma'am staying and hearing [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins . "[93-elizabeth]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth would not oppose such an injunction -- and a moment 's consideration making [her]93-elizabeth also sensible that it would be wisest to get it over as soon and as quietly as possible , [she]93-elizabeth sat down again , and tried to conceal by incessant employment the feelings which were divided between distress and diversion . [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet and [Kitty]97-lady catherine walked off , and as soon as [they]1015-they were gone [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins began .

" Believe [me]149-mr. collins , [[my]149-mr. collins dear]3018-my dear [Miss Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , that [your]120-ma'am modesty , so far from doing [you]120-ma'am any disservice , rather adds to [your]120-ma'am other perfections . [You]120-ma'am would have been less amiable in [my]149-mr. collins eyes had there _ not _ been this little unwillingness ; but allow [me]149-mr. collins to assure [you]120-ma'am that [I]149-mr. collins have [[your]120-ma'am respected mother]3672-your respected mother 's permission for this address . [You]120-ma'am can hardly doubt the purport of [my]149-mr. collins discourse , however [your]120-ma'am natural delicacy may lead [you]120-ma'am to dissemble ; [my]149-mr. collins attentions have been too marked to be mistaken . Almost as soon as [I]149-mr. collins entered [the house]3026-the house [I]149-mr. collins singled [you]120-ma'am out as the companion of [my]149-mr. collins future life . But before [I]149-mr. collins am run away with by [my]149-mr. collins feelings on this subject , perhaps it will be advisable for [me]149-mr. collins to state [my]149-mr. collins reasons for marrying -- and moreover for coming into [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire with the design of selecting [a wife]244-a wife , as [I]149-mr. collins certainly did . "[149-mr. collins]

The idea of [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins , with all [his]149-mr. collins solemn composure , being run away with by [his]149-mr. collins feelings , made [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth so near laughing that [she]93-elizabeth could not use the short pause [he]149-mr. collins allowed in any attempt to stop [him]149-mr. collins farther , and [he]149-mr. collins continued :

" [My]149-mr. collins reasons for marrying are , first , that [I]149-mr. collins think it a right thing for [every clergyman in easy circumstances ( like [myself]149-mr. collins ) to set the example of matrimony in [[his]3675-every clergyman in easy circumstances ( like myself ) to set the example of matrimony in his parish parish]723-his parish]3675-every clergyman in easy circumstances ( like myself ) to set the example of matrimony in his parish . Secondly , that [I]149-mr. collins am convinced it will add very greatly to [my]149-mr. collins happiness ; and thirdly -- which perhaps [I]149-mr. collins ought to have mentioned earlier , that it is the particular advice and recommendation of [the very noble lady whom [I]149-mr. collins have the honour of calling [patroness]3678-patroness]3677-the very noble lady whom i have the honour of calling patroness . Twice has [she]3677-the very noble lady whom i have the honour of calling patroness condescended to give [me]149-mr. collins [her]3677-the very noble lady whom i have the honour of calling patroness opinion ( unasked too ! ) on this subject ; and it was but the very Saturday night before [I]149-mr. collins left [Hunsford]16-hunsford -- between [[our]3679-our pools at [quadrille]7-longbourn]3680-our pools at quadrille , while [Mrs. Jenkinson]170-mrs. jenkinson was arranging [Miss de Bourgh]152-miss de bourgh 's foot - stool , that [she]170-mrs. jenkinson said , ' [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins , [you]149-mr. collins must marry . [A clergyman like [you]149-mr. collins]3681-a clergyman like you must marry.--Chuse properly , chuse [a gentlewoman]3682-a gentlewoman for _ [my]149-mr. collins _ sake ; and for [your]149-mr. collins _ own _ , let [her]3682-a gentlewoman be [an active , useful sort of person , not brought up high]3683-an active , useful sort of person , not brought up high , but able to make a small income go a good way . This is [my]149-mr. collins advice . Find [such a woman]3278-such a woman as soon as [you]149-mr. collins can , bring [her]3278-such a woman to [Hunsford]16-hunsford , and [I]149-mr. collins will visit [her]3278-such a woman . ' Allow [me]149-mr. collins , by the way , to observe , [[my]149-mr. collins fair cousin]3685-my fair cousin , that [I]149-mr. collins do not reckon the notice and kindness of [Lady Catherine de Bourgh]97-lady catherine as among the least of the advantages in [my]149-mr. collins power to offer . [You]149-mr. collins will find [her]97-lady catherine manners beyond any thing [I]149-mr. collins can describe ; and [your]149-mr. collins wit and vivacity [I]149-mr. collins think must be acceptable to [her]97-lady catherine , especially when tempered with the silence and respect which [her]97-lady catherine rank will inevitably excite . Thus much for [my]149-mr. collins general intention in favour of matrimony ; it remains to be told why [my]149-mr. collins views were directed to [Longbourn]7-longbourn instead of [[my]149-mr. collins own neighbourhood]3686-my own neighbourhood , where [I]149-mr. collins assure [you]149-mr. collins there are many [amiable young women]3687-amiable young women . But the fact is , that being , as [I]149-mr. collins am , to inherit [this estate]3429-this estate after the death of [[your]149-mr. collins honoured father]3689-your honoured father , ( who , however , may live many years longer , ) [I]149-mr. collins could not satisfy [myself]149-mr. collins without resolving to chuse [a wife from among [[his]3689-your honoured father daughters]443-his daughters]3690-a wife from among his daughters , that the loss to [them]443-his daughters might be as little as possible , when the melancholy event takes place -- which , however , as [I]149-mr. collins have already said , may not be for several years . This has been [my]149-mr. collins motive , [[my]149-mr. collins fair cousin]3685-my fair cousin , and [I]149-mr. collins flatter [myself]149-mr. collins it will not sink [me]149-mr. collins in [your]149-mr. collins esteem . And now nothing remains for [me]149-mr. collins but to assure [you]149-mr. collins in the most animated language of the violence of [my]149-mr. collins affection . To [fortune]3693-fortune [I]149-mr. collins am perfectly indifferent , and shall make no demand of that nature on [[your]149-mr. collins father]3227-your father , since [I]149-mr. collins am well aware that it could not be complied with ; and that one thousand pounds in the 4 per cents . which will not be [yours]149-mr. collins till after [[your]149-mr. collins mother]3695-your mother 's decease , is all that [you]149-mr. collins may ever be entitled to . On that head , therefore , [I]149-mr. collins shall be uniformly silent ; and [you]149-mr. collins may assure [yourself]149-mr. collins that no ungenerous reproach shall ever pass [my]149-mr. collins lips when [we]3696-we are married . "[149-mr. collins]

It was absolutely necessary to interrupt [him]1016-you now .

" [You]1016-you are too hasty , [Sir]3172-sir , "[1017-me] [she]1017-me cried . " [You]1016-you forget that [I]1017-me have made no answer . Let [me]1017-me do it without farther loss of time . Accept [my]1017-me thanks for the compliment [you]1016-you are paying [me]1017-me . [I]1017-me am very sensible of the honour of [your]1016-you proposals , but it is impossible for [me]1017-me to do otherwise than decline them . "[1017-me]

" [I]149-mr. collins am not now to learn , "[149-mr. collins] replied [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins , with a formal wave of the hand , " that it is usual with [young ladies]3267-young ladies to reject the addresses of [the man whom [they]3267-young ladies secretly mean to accept , when [he]3699-the man whom they secretly mean to accept , when he first applies for their favour first applies for [their]3267-young ladies favour]3699-the man whom they secretly mean to accept , when he first applies for their favour ; and that sometimes the refusal is repeated a second or even a third time . [I]149-mr. collins am therefore by no means discouraged by what [you]1016-you have just said , and shall hope to lead [you]1016-you to the altar ere long . "[149-mr. collins]

" Upon [my]93-elizabeth word , [Sir]3172-sir , "[93-elizabeth] cried [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , " [your]3172-sir hope is rather an extraordinary one after [my]93-elizabeth declaration . [I]93-elizabeth do assure [you]1016-you that [I]93-elizabeth am [not one of [those young ladies ( if such [young ladies there]3703-young ladies there are ) who are so daring as to risk [their]3267-young ladies happiness on the chance of being asked a second time]3702-those young ladies ( if such young ladies there are ) who are so daring as to risk their happiness on the chance of being asked a second time . [I]93-elizabeth am perfectly serious in [my]93-elizabeth refusal.--You could not make _ [me]93-elizabeth _ happy , and [I]93-elizabeth am convinced that [I]93-elizabeth am [the last woman in [the world]323-the world who would make _ [you]1016-you _ so.--Nay]3704-the last woman in the world who would make _ you _ so.--nay , were [[your]1016-you friend]3063-your friend [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine to know [me]93-elizabeth , [I]93-elizabeth am persuaded [she]97-lady catherine would find [me]93-elizabeth in every respect ill qualified for the situation]3701-not one of those young ladies ( if such young ladies there are ) who are so daring as to risk their happiness on the chance of being asked a second time . i am perfectly serious in my refusal.--you could not make _ me _ happy , and i am convinced that i am the last woman in the world who would make _ you _ so.--nay , were your friend lady catherine to know me , i am persuaded she would find me in every respect ill qualified for the situation . "[93-elizabeth]

" Were it certain that [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine would think so , "[149-mr. collins] said [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins very gravely--"but [I]93-elizabeth can not imagine that [[her]97-lady catherine ladyship]677-her ladyship would at all disapprove of [you]1016-you . And [you]1016-you may be certain that when [I]93-elizabeth have the honour of seeing [her]97-lady catherine again [I]93-elizabeth shall speak in the highest terms of [your]1016-you modesty , economy , and other amiable qualifications . "[93-elizabeth]

" Indeed , [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins , all praise of [me]93-elizabeth will be unnecessary . [You]149-mr. collins must give [me]93-elizabeth leave to judge for [myself]93-elizabeth , and pay [me]93-elizabeth the compliment of believing what [I]93-elizabeth say . [I]93-elizabeth wish [you]1016-you very happy and very rich , and by refusing [your]1016-you hand , do all in [my]93-elizabeth power to prevent [your]1016-you being otherwise . In making [me]93-elizabeth the offer , [you]1016-you must have satisfied the delicacy of [your]1016-you feelings with regard to [[my]93-elizabeth family]3708-my family , and may take possession of [Longbourn estate]681-longbourn estate whenever it falls , without any self - reproach . This matter may be considered , therefore , as finally settled . "[93-elizabeth] And rising as [she]1018-you thus spoke , [she]1018-you would have quitted [the room]271-the room , had not [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins thus addressed [her]1018-you ,

" When [I]93-elizabeth do [myself]93-elizabeth the honour of speaking to [you]1018-you next on this subject [I]93-elizabeth shall hope to receive a more favourable answer than [you]1018-you have now given [me]93-elizabeth ; though [I]93-elizabeth am far from accusing [you]1018-you of cruelty at present , because [I]93-elizabeth know it to be the established custom of [your]1018-you sex to reject [a man]3065-a man on the first application , and perhaps [you]1018-you have even now said as much to encourage [my]93-elizabeth suit as would be consistent with the true delicacy of [the female character]3711-the female character . "[93-elizabeth]

" Really , [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins , "[93-elizabeth] cried [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth with some warmth , " [you]149-mr. collins puzzle [me]93-elizabeth exceedingly . If what [I]93-elizabeth have hitherto said can appear to [you]1018-you in the form of encouragement , [I]93-elizabeth know not how to express [my]93-elizabeth refusal in such a way as may convince [you]1018-you of its being one . "[93-elizabeth]

" [You]1018-you must give [me]93-elizabeth leave to flatter [myself]93-elizabeth , [[my]93-elizabeth dear cousin]3712-my dear cousin , that [your]1018-you refusal of [my]93-elizabeth addresses is merely words of course . [My]93-elizabeth reasons for believing it are briefly these:--It does not appear to [me]93-elizabeth that [my]93-elizabeth hand is unworthy [your]1018-you acceptance , or that the establishment [I]93-elizabeth can offer would be any other than highly desirable . [My]93-elizabeth situation in life , [my]93-elizabeth connections with [the family of [De Bourgh]152-miss de bourgh]874-the family of de bourgh , and [my]93-elizabeth relationship to [your]1018-you own , are circumstances highly in [my]93-elizabeth favour ; and [you]1018-you should take it into farther consideration that in spite of [your]1018-you manifold attractions , it is by no means certain that another offer of marriage may ever be made [you]1018-you . [Your]1018-you portion is unhappily so small that it will in all likelihood undo the effects of [your]1018-you loveliness and amiable qualifications . As [I]93-elizabeth must therefore conclude that [you]1018-you are not serious in [your]1018-you rejection of [me]93-elizabeth , [I]93-elizabeth shall chuse to attribute it to [your]1018-you wish of increasing [my]93-elizabeth love by suspense , according to the usual practice of [elegant females]3714-elegant females . "[93-elizabeth]

" [I]93-elizabeth do assure [you]1018-you , [Sir]3172-sir , that [I]93-elizabeth have no pretension whatever to that kind of elegance which consists in tormenting [a respectable man]3716-a respectable man . [I]93-elizabeth would rather be paid the compliment of being believed sincere . [I]93-elizabeth thank [you]1018-you again and again for the honour [you]1018-you have done [me]93-elizabeth in [your]1018-you proposals , but to accept them is absolutely impossible . [My]93-elizabeth feelings in every respect forbid it . Can [I]93-elizabeth speak plainer ? Do not consider [me]93-elizabeth now as [an elegant female]3717-an elegant female intending to plague [you]1018-you , but as [a rational creature speaking the truth]3718-a rational creature speaking the truth from [her]3717-an elegant female heart . "[93-elizabeth]

" [You]93-elizabeth are uniformly charming ! "[1020-he] cried [he]1020-he , with an air of awkward gallantry ; " and [I]1020-he am persuaded that when sanctioned by the express authority of both [[your]93-elizabeth excellent parents]3719-your excellent parents , [my]1020-he proposals will not fail of being acceptable . "[1020-he]

To such perseverance in wilful self - deception [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth would make no reply , and immediately and in silence withdrew ; determined , if [he]1020-he persisted in considering [her]93-elizabeth repeated refusals as flattering encouragement , to apply to [[her]93-elizabeth father]264-her father , whose negative might be uttered in such a manner as must be decisive , and whose behaviour at least could not be mistaken for the affectation and coquetry of [an elegant female]3717-an elegant female .

CHAPTER XX .

[Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins was not left long to the silent contemplation of [his]149-mr. collins successful love ; for [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet , having dawdled about in [the vestibule]1023-the vestibule to watch for the end of the conference , no sooner saw [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth open the door and with quick step pass [her]93-elizabeth towards the staircase , than [she]93-elizabeth entered [the breakfast - room]1024-the breakfast - room , and congratulated both [him]1020-he and [herself]93-elizabeth in warm terms on the happy prospect of [their]1025-their nearer connection . [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins received and returned these felicitations with equal pleasure , and then proceeded to relate the particulars of [their]1025-their interview , with the result of which [he]149-mr. collins trusted [he]149-mr. collins had every reason to be satisfied , since the refusal which [[his]149-mr. collins cousin]727-his cousin had steadfastly given [him]149-mr. collins would naturally flow from [her]727-his cousin bashful modesty and the genuine delicacy of [her]727-his cousin character .
