This information , however , startled [Mrs. Bennet;--she]171-mrs. bennet;--she would have been glad to be equally satisfied that [[her]171-mrs. bennet;--she daughter]475-her daughter had meant to encourage [him]149-mr. collins by protesting against [his]149-mr. collins proposals , but [she]171-mrs. bennet;--she dared not to believe it , and could not help saying so .

" But depend upon it , [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins , "[171-mrs. bennet;--she] [she]171-mrs. bennet;--she added , " that [Lizzy]93-elizabeth shall be brought to reason . [I]171-mrs. bennet;--she will speak to [her]93-elizabeth about it [myself]171-mrs. bennet;--she directly . [She]93-elizabeth is [a very headstrong foolish girl]3720-a very headstrong foolish girl , and does not know [her]93-elizabeth own interest ; but [I]171-mrs. bennet;--she will _ make _ [her]93-elizabeth know it . "[171-mrs. bennet;--she]

" Pardon [me]149-mr. collins for interrupting [you]171-mrs. bennet;--she , [Madam]3285-madam , "[149-mr. collins] cried [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins ; " but if [she]93-elizabeth is really headstrong and foolish , [I]149-mr. collins know not whether [she]93-elizabeth would altogether be [a very desirable wife to [a man in [my]149-mr. collins situation , who naturally looks for happiness in the marriage state]3723-a man in my situation , who naturally looks for happiness in the marriage state]3722-a very desirable wife to a man in my situation , who naturally looks for happiness in the marriage state . If therefore [she]93-elizabeth actually persists in rejecting [my]149-mr. collins suit , perhaps it were better not to force [her]93-elizabeth into accepting [me]149-mr. collins , because if liable to such defects of temper , [she]93-elizabeth could not contribute much to [my]149-mr. collins felicity . "[149-mr. collins]

" [Sir]3172-sir , [you]3172-sir quite misunderstand [me]96-mrs. bennet , "[96-mrs. bennet] said [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet , alarmed . " [Lizzy]93-elizabeth is only headstrong in such matters as these . In every thing else [she]93-elizabeth is as good natured [a girl as ever lived]3725-a girl as ever lived . [I]96-mrs. bennet will go directly to [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet , and [we]3726-we shall very soon settle it with [her]93-elizabeth , [I]96-mrs. bennet am sure . "[96-mrs. bennet]

[She]96-mrs. bennet would not give [him]1028-him time to reply , but hurrying instantly to [[her]96-mrs. bennet husband]276-her husband , called out as [she]96-mrs. bennet entered [the library]1030-the library ,

" Oh ! [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet , [you]86-mr. bennet are wanted immediately ; [we]3726-we are all in an uproar . [You]86-mr. bennet must come and make [Lizzy]93-elizabeth marry [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins , for [she]93-elizabeth vows [she]93-elizabeth will not have [him]149-mr. collins , and if [you]86-mr. bennet do not make haste [he]149-mr. collins will change [his]149-mr. collins mind and not have _ [her]93-elizabeth _ . "[86-mr. bennet]

[Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet raised [his]86-mr. bennet eyes from [his]86-mr. bennet book as [she]96-mrs. bennet entered , and fixed them on [her]96-mrs. bennet face with a calm unconcern which was not in the least altered by [her]96-mrs. bennet communication .

" [I]86-mr. bennet have not the pleasure of understanding [you]96-mrs. bennet , "[86-mr. bennet] said [he]86-mr. bennet , when [she]96-mrs. bennet had finished [her]96-mrs. bennet speech . " Of what are [you]96-mrs. bennet talking ? "[86-mr. bennet]

" Of [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins and [Lizzy]93-elizabeth . [Lizzy]93-elizabeth declares [she]93-elizabeth will not have [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins , and [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins begins to say that [he]149-mr. collins will not have [Lizzy]93-elizabeth . "[96-mrs. bennet]

" And what am [I]86-mr. bennet to do on the occasion?--It seems an hopeless business . "[86-mr. bennet]

" Speak to [Lizzy]93-elizabeth about it [yourself]86-mr. bennet . Tell [her]93-elizabeth that [you]86-mr. bennet insist upon [her]93-elizabeth marrying [him]149-mr. collins . "[96-mrs. bennet]

" Let [her]93-elizabeth be called down . [She]93-elizabeth shall hear [my]86-mr. bennet opinion . "[86-mr. bennet]

[Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet rang the bell , and [Miss Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was summoned to [the library]1030-the library .

" Come here , [child]3655-child , "[264-her father] cried [[her]93-elizabeth father]264-her father as [she]93-elizabeth appeared . " [I]93-elizabeth have sent for [you]93-elizabeth on an affair of importance . [I]93-elizabeth understand that [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins has made [you]93-elizabeth an offer of marriage . Is it true ? "[93-elizabeth] [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth replied that it was . " Very well -- and this offer of marriage [you]264-her father have refused ? "[93-elizabeth]

" [I]86-mr. bennet have , [Sir]3172-sir . "[86-mr. bennet]

" Very well . [We]3729-we now come to the point . [[Your]93-elizabeth mother]3695-your mother insists upon [your]93-elizabeth accepting it . Is not it so , [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet ? "[93-elizabeth]

" Yes , or [I]86-mr. bennet will never see [her]3695-your mother again . "[86-mr. bennet]

" An unhappy alternative is before [you]93-elizabeth , [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth . From this day [you]93-elizabeth must be [a stranger to one of [[your]93-elizabeth parents.--Your mother]3732-your parents.--your mother]3731-a stranger to one of your parents.--your mother will never see [you]93-elizabeth again if [you]93-elizabeth do _ not _ marry [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins , and [I]93-elizabeth will never see [you]93-elizabeth again if [you]93-elizabeth _ do _ . "[93-elizabeth]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth could not but smile at such a conclusion of such a beginning ; but [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet , who had persuaded [herself]96-mrs. bennet that [[her]96-mrs. bennet husband]276-her husband regarded the affair as [she]96-mrs. bennet wished , was excessively disappointed .

" What do [you]276-her husband mean , [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet , by talking in this way ? [You]276-her husband promised [me]93-elizabeth to _ insist _ upon [her]96-mrs. bennet marrying [him]276-her husband . "[93-elizabeth]

" [[My]276-her husband dear]3018-my dear , "[276-her husband] replied [[her]96-mrs. bennet husband]276-her husband , " [I]276-her husband have two small favours to request . First , that [you]93-elizabeth will allow [me]276-her husband the free use of [my]276-her husband understanding on the present occasion ; and secondly , of [[my]276-her husband room]3734-my room . [I]276-her husband shall be glad to have [the library]1030-the library to [myself]276-her husband as soon as may be . "[276-her husband]

Not yet , however , in spite of [her]96-mrs. bennet disappointment in [[her]96-mrs. bennet husband]276-her husband , did [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet give up the point . [She]96-mrs. bennet talked to [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth again and again ; coaxed and threatened [her]93-elizabeth by turns . [She]96-mrs. bennet endeavoured to secure [Jane]94-jane in [her]96-mrs. bennet interest , but [Jane]94-jane with all possible mildness declined interfering;--and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth sometimes with real earnestness and sometimes with playful gaiety replied to [her]96-mrs. bennet attacks . Though [her]96-mrs. bennet manner varied however , [her]96-mrs. bennet determination never did .

[Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins , meanwhile , was meditating in solitude on what had passed . [He]149-mr. collins thought too well of [himself]149-mr. collins to comprehend on what motive [[his]149-mr. collins cousin]727-his cousin could refuse [him]149-mr. collins ; and though [his]149-mr. collins pride was hurt , [he]149-mr. collins suffered in no other way . [His]149-mr. collins regard for [her]727-his cousin was quite imaginary ; and the possibility of [her]727-his cousin deserving [[her]727-his cousin mother]261-her mother 's reproach prevented [his]149-mr. collins feeling any regret .

While [the family]432-the family were in this confusion , [Charlotte Lucas]114-charlotte came to spend the day with [them]432-the family . [She]114-charlotte was met in [the vestibule]1023-the vestibule by [Lydia]95-lydia , who , flying to [her]114-charlotte , cried in a half whisper , " [I]95-lydia am glad [you]114-charlotte are come , for there is such fun here!--What do [you]114-charlotte think has happened this morning?--Mr . [Collins]149-mr. collins has made an offer to [Lizzy]93-elizabeth , and [she]97-lady catherine will not have [him]149-mr. collins . "[95-lydia]

[Charlotte]114-charlotte had hardly time to answer , before [they]432-the family were joined by [Kitty]97-lady catherine , who came to tell the same news , and no sooner had [they]432-the family entered [the breakfast - room]1024-the breakfast - room , where [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet was alone , than [she]97-lady catherine likewise began on the subject , calling on [Miss Lucas]103-miss lucas for [her]103-miss lucas compassion , and entreating [her]103-miss lucas to persuade [[her]97-lady catherine friend]418-her friend [Lizzy]93-elizabeth to comply with the wishes of all [[her]97-lady catherine family]905-her family . " Pray do , [[my]97-lady catherine dear]3018-my dear [Miss Lucas]103-miss lucas , "[97-lady catherine] [she]97-lady catherine added in a melancholy tone , " for [nobody]3098-nobody is on [my]97-lady catherine side , [nobody]3098-nobody takes part with [me]97-lady catherine , [I]97-lady catherine am cruelly used , [nobody]3098-nobody feels for [my]97-lady catherine poor nerves . "[97-lady catherine]

[Charlotte]114-charlotte 's reply was spared by the entrance of [Jane]94-jane and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth .

" Aye , there [she]97-lady catherine comes , "[96-mrs. bennet] continued [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet , " looking as unconcerned as may be , and caring no more for [us]3740-us than if [we]3740-us were at [York]28-york , provided [she]97-lady catherine can have [her]97-lady catherine own way.--But [I]96-mrs. bennet tell [you]103-miss lucas what , [Miss Lizzy]93-elizabeth , if [you]103-miss lucas take it into [your]103-miss lucas head to go on refusing every offer of marriage in this way , [you]103-miss lucas will never get [a husband]3741-a husband at all -- and [I]96-mrs. bennet am sure [I]96-mrs. bennet do not know who is to maintain [you]103-miss lucas when [[your]103-miss lucas father]3227-your father is dead.--_I _ shall not be able to keep [you]103-miss lucas -- and so [I]96-mrs. bennet warn you.--I have done with [you]103-miss lucas from this very day.--I told [you]103-miss lucas in [the library]1030-the library , [you]103-miss lucas know , that [I]96-mrs. bennet should never speak to [you]103-miss lucas again , and [you]103-miss lucas will find [me]96-mrs. bennet as good as [my]96-mrs. bennet word . [I]96-mrs. bennet have no pleasure in talking to undutiful children.--Not that [I]96-mrs. bennet have much pleasure indeed in talking to any body . [People who suffer as [I]96-mrs. bennet do from nervous complaints]3744-people who suffer as i do from nervous complaints can have no great inclination for talking . [Nobody]3098-nobody can tell what [I]96-mrs. bennet suffer!--But it is always so . [Those who do not complain]3746-those who do not complain are never pitied . "[96-mrs. bennet]

[[Her]1043-her daughters]257-her daughters listened in silence to this effusion , sensible that any attempt to reason with or sooth [her]1043-her would only increase the irritation . [She]1043-her talked on , therefore , without interruption from any of [them]257-her daughters till [they]257-her daughters were joined by [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins , who entered with an air more stately than usual , and on perceiving whom , [she]1043-her said to [the girls]3033-the girls ,

" Now , [I]1043-her do insist upon it , that [you]3033-the girls , all of [you]3033-the girls , hold [your]3033-the girls tongues , and let [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins and [me]1043-her have a little conversation together . "[1043-her]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth passed quietly out of [the room]271-the room , [Jane]94-jane and [Kitty]97-lady catherine followed , but [Lydia]95-lydia stood [her]95-lydia ground , determined to hear all [she]95-lydia could ; and [Charlotte]114-charlotte , detained first by the civility of [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins , whose inquiries after [herself]114-charlotte and all [[her]114-charlotte family]905-her family were very minute , and then by a little curiosity , satisfied [herself]114-charlotte with walking to the window and pretending not to hear . In a doleful voice [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet thus began the projected conversation.--"Oh ! [Mr. Collins!"--]172-mr. collins!"--[96-mrs. bennet]

" [[My]149-mr. collins dear]3018-my dear Madam , "[149-mr. collins] replied [he]149-mr. collins , " let [us]3748-us be for ever silent on this point . Far be it from [me]149-mr. collins , "[149-mr. collins] [he]149-mr. collins presently continued in a voice that marked [his]149-mr. collins displeasure , " to resent the behaviour of [[your]3018-my dear daughter]3235-your daughter . Resignation to inevitable evils is the duty of [us]3748-us all ; the peculiar duty of [a young man who has been so fortunate as [I]149-mr. collins have been in early preferment]3750-a young man who has been so fortunate as i have been in early preferment ; and [I]149-mr. collins trust [I]149-mr. collins am resigned . Perhaps not the less so from feeling a doubt of [my]149-mr. collins positive happiness had [[my]149-mr. collins fair cousin]3685-my fair cousin honoured [me]149-mr. collins with [her]3685-my fair cousin hand ; for [I]149-mr. collins have often observed that resignation is never so perfect as when the blessing denied begins to lose somewhat of its value in [our]3748-us estimation . [You]3018-my dear will not , [I]149-mr. collins hope , consider [me]149-mr. collins as [shewing]3752-shewing any disrespect to [[your]3018-my dear family]685-your family , [[my]149-mr. collins dear Madam]3754-my dear madam , by thus withdrawing [my]149-mr. collins pretensions to [[your]3018-my dear daughter]3235-your daughter 's favour , without having paid [yourself]3018-my dear and [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet the compliment of requesting [you]3018-my dear to interpose [your]3018-my dear authority in [my]149-mr. collins behalf . [My]149-mr. collins conduct may [I]149-mr. collins fear be objectionable in having accepted [my]149-mr. collins dismission from [[your]3018-my dear daughter]3235-your daughter 's lips instead of [your]3018-my dear own . But [we]3757-we are all liable to error . [I]149-mr. collins have certainly meant well through the whole affair . [My]149-mr. collins object has been to secure an amiable companion for [myself]149-mr. collins , with due consideration for the advantage of all [[your]3018-my dear family]685-your family , and if [my]149-mr. collins _ manner _ has been at all reprehensible , [I]149-mr. collins here beg leave to apologise . "[149-mr. collins]

CHAPTER XXI .

The discussion of [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins 's offer was now nearly at an end , and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth had only to suffer from the uncomfortable feelings necessarily attending it , and occasionally from some peevish allusion of [[her]93-elizabeth mother]261-her mother . As for [the gentleman]306-the gentleman [himself]306-the gentleman , [_]1050-_ [his]306-the gentleman _ feelings were chiefly expressed , not by embarrassment or dejection , or by trying to avoid [her]261-her mother , but by stiffness of manner and resentful silence . [He]306-the gentleman scarcely ever spoke to [her]261-her mother , and the assiduous attentions which [he]306-the gentleman had been so sensible of [himself]306-the gentleman , were transferred for the rest of the day to [Miss Lucas]103-miss lucas , whose civility in listening to [him]306-the gentleman , was a seasonable relief to [them]1051-them all , and especially to [[her]103-miss lucas friend]418-her friend .

The morrow produced no abatement of [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet 's ill humour or ill health . [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins was also in the same state of angry pride . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth had hoped that [his]306-the gentleman resentment might shorten [his]306-the gentleman visit , but [his]306-the gentleman plan did not appear in the least affected by it . [He]306-the gentleman was always to have gone on Saturday , and to [Saturday]173-saturday [he]306-the gentleman still meant to stay .

After breakfast , [the girls]3033-the girls walked to [Meryton]9-meryton to inquire if [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham were returned , and to lament over [his]306-the gentleman absence from the [Netherfield]2-netherfield ball . [He]306-the gentleman joined [them]3033-the girls on [their]3033-the girls entering [the town]1054-the town and attended [them]3033-the girls to [[their]3033-the girls aunt]455-their aunt 's , where [his]306-the gentleman regret and vexation , and the concern of [every body]324-every body was well talked over.--To [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , however , [he]306-the gentleman voluntarily acknowledged that the necessity of [his]306-the gentleman absence _ had _ been self imposed .

" [I]306-the gentleman found , "[306-the gentleman] said [he]306-the gentleman , " as the time drew near , that [I]306-the gentleman had better not meet [Mr. Darcy;--that]174-mr. darcy;--that to be in [the same room]3759-the same room , the same party with [him]306-the gentleman for so many hours together , might be more than [I]306-the gentleman could bear , and that scenes might arise unpleasant to more than [myself]306-the gentleman . "[306-the gentleman]

[She]93-elizabeth highly approved [his]306-the gentleman forbearance , and [they]1057-they had leisure for a full discussion of it , and for all the commendation which [they]1057-they civilly bestowed on [each other]3157-each other , as [Wickham]156-wickham and [another officer]1059-another officer walked back with [them]1057-they to [Longbourn]7-longbourn , and during the walk , [he]306-the gentleman particularly attended to [her]93-elizabeth . [His]306-the gentleman accompanying [them]1057-they was a double advantage ; [she]93-elizabeth felt all the compliment it offered to [herself]93-elizabeth , and it was most acceptable as an occasion of introducing [him]306-the gentleman to [[her]93-elizabeth father]264-her father and [mother]3249-mother .

Soon after [their]1057-they return , a letter was delivered to [Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth ; it came from [Netherfield]2-netherfield , and was opened immediately . The envelope contained a sheet of elegant , little , hot pressed paper , well covered with [a lady]3166-a lady 's fair , flowing hand ; and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth saw [[her]93-elizabeth sister]348-her sister 's countenance change as [she]93-elizabeth read it , and saw [her]93-elizabeth dwelling intently on some particular passages . [Jane]94-jane recollected [herself]94-jane soon , and putting the letter away , tried to join with [her]94-jane usual cheerfulness in the general conversation ; but [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth felt an anxiety on the subject which drew off [her]93-elizabeth attention even from [Wickham]156-wickham ; and no sooner had [he]156-wickham and [[his]156-wickham companion]437-his companion taken leave , than a glance from [Jane]94-jane invited [her]93-elizabeth to follow [her]93-elizabeth up [stairs]529-stairs . When [they]1066-their had gained [[their]1066-their own room]1067-their own room , [Jane]94-jane taking out the letter , said ,

" This is from [Caroline Bingley]133-caroline ; what it contains , has surprised [me]94-jane a good deal . [The whole party]531-the whole party have left [Netherfield]2-netherfield by this time , and are on [their]1066-their way to [town]285-town ; and without any intention of coming back again . [You]3762-you shall hear what [she]133-caroline says . "[94-jane]

[She]94-jane then read the first sentence aloud , which comprised the information of [their]1066-their having just resolved to follow [[their]1066-their brother]359-their brother to [town]285-town directly , and of [their]1066-their meaning to dine that day in [[Grosvenor]29-grosvenor street]1070-grosvenor street , where [Mr. Hurst]99-mr. hurst had [a house]1071-a house . The next was in these words . " [I]1066-their do not pretend to regret any thing [I]1066-their shall leave in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire , except [[your]3762-you society]3763-your society , [[my]1066-their dearest friend]3764-my dearest friend ; but [we]1066-their will hope at some future period , to enjoy many returns of the delightful intercourse [we]1066-their have known , and in the mean while may lessen the pain of separation by a very frequent and most unreserved correspondence . [I]1066-their depend on [you]3762-you for that . "[1066-their] To these high flown expressions , [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth listened with all the insensibility of distrust ; and though the suddenness of [their]1066-their removal surprised [her]93-elizabeth , [she]93-elizabeth saw nothing in it really to lament ; it was not to be supposed that [their]1066-their absence from [Netherfield]2-netherfield would prevent [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley 's being [there]325-there ; and as to the loss of [their]1066-their society , [she]93-elizabeth was persuaded that [Jane]94-jane must soon cease to regard it , in the enjoyment of [his]90-mr. bingley .

" It is unlucky , "[93-elizabeth] said [she]93-elizabeth , after a short pause , " that [you]3762-you should not be able to see [[your]3762-you friends]3765-your friends before [they]3765-your friends leave [the country]460-the country . But may [we]1066-their not hope that the period of future happiness to which [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley looks forward , may arrive earlier than [she]102-miss bingley is aware , and that the delightful intercourse [you]3762-you have known as [friends]3767-friends , will be renewed with yet greater satisfaction as sisters?--Mr . [Bingley]90-mr. bingley will not be detained in [London]5-london by [them]3765-your friends . "[93-elizabeth]

" [Caroline]133-caroline decidedly says that [none of the party]3768-none of the party will return into [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire this winter . [I]93-elizabeth will read it to [you--]3762-you "[93-elizabeth]

" When [[my]93-elizabeth brother]3216-my brother left [us]1066-their yesterday , [he]3216-my brother imagined that the business which took [him]3216-my brother to [London]5-london , might be concluded in three or four days , but as [we]1066-their are certain it can not be so , and at the same time convinced that when [Charles]137-charles gets to [town]285-town , [he]137-charles will be in no hurry to leave it again , [we]1066-their have determined on following [him]137-charles thither , that [he]137-charles may not be obliged to spend [his]137-charles vacant hours in [a comfortless hotel]3771-a comfortless hotel . Many of [my]93-elizabeth acquaintance are already there for the winter ; [I]93-elizabeth wish [I]93-elizabeth could hear that [you]3762-you , [[my]93-elizabeth dearest friend]3764-my dearest friend , had any intention of making one in the croud , but of that [I]93-elizabeth despair . [I]93-elizabeth sincerely hope [your]3762-you Christmas in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire may abound in the gaieties which that season generally brings , and that [[your]3762-you beaux]3773-your beaux will be so numerous as to prevent [your]3762-you feeling the loss of the three , of whom [we]1066-their shall deprive [you]3762-you . "[93-elizabeth]

" It is evident by this , "[94-jane] added [Jane]94-jane , " that [he]137-charles comes back no more this winter . "[94-jane]

" It is only evident that [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley does not mean [he]137-charles _ should _ . "[93-elizabeth]

" Why will [you]3762-you think so ? It must be [his]137-charles own doing.--He is [[his]137-charles own master]3774-his own master . But [you]3762-you do not know _ all _ . [I]94-jane _ will _ read [you]3762-you the passage which particularly hurts [me]94-jane . [I]94-jane will have no reserves from _ [you]3762-you _ . "[94-jane] " [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy is impatient to see [[his]100-mr. darcy sister]569-his sister , and to confess the truth , _ [we]1066-their _ are scarcely less eager to meet [her]569-his sister again . [I]93-elizabeth really do not think [Georgiana Darcy]175-georgiana has [her]175-georgiana equal for beauty , elegance , and accomplishments ; and the affection [she]175-georgiana inspires in [Louisa]132-louisa and [myself]93-elizabeth , is heightened into something still more interesting , from the hope [we]1066-their dare to entertain of [her]175-georgiana being hereafter [[our]1066-their sister]3776-our sister . [I]93-elizabeth do not know whether [I]93-elizabeth ever before mentioned to [you]3762-you [my]93-elizabeth feelings on this subject , but [I]93-elizabeth will not leave [the country]460-the country without confiding them , and [I]93-elizabeth trust [you]3762-you will not esteem [them]3778-them unreasonable . [[My]93-elizabeth brother]3216-my brother admires [her]175-georgiana greatly already , [he]3216-my brother will have frequent opportunity now of seeing [her]175-georgiana on the most intimate footing , [her]175-georgiana relations all wish the connection as much as [his]3216-my brother own , and [a sister]449-a sister 's partiality is not misleading [me]93-elizabeth , [I]93-elizabeth think , when [I]93-elizabeth call [Charles]137-charles most capable of engaging [any woman]3781-any woman 's heart . With all these circumstances to favour an attachment and nothing to prevent it , am [I]93-elizabeth wrong , [[my]93-elizabeth dearest]3231-my dearest [Jane]94-jane , in indulging the hope of an event which will secure the happiness of [so many]3783-so many ? "[93-elizabeth]

" What think [you]94-jane of _ this _ sentence , [[my]94-jane dear]3018-my dear Lizzy?"--said[94-jane] [Jane]94-jane as [she]94-jane finished it . " Is it not clear enough?--Does it not expressly declare that [Caroline]133-caroline neither expects nor wishes [me]94-jane to be [[her]133-caroline sister]348-her sister ; that [she]133-caroline is perfectly convinced of [[her]133-caroline brother]3126-her brother 's indifference , and that if [she]133-caroline suspects the nature of [my]94-jane feelings for [him]3126-her brother , [she]133-caroline means ( most kindly ! ) to put [me]94-jane on [my]94-jane guard ? Can there be any other opinion on the subject ? "[94-jane]

" Yes , there can ; for [mine]94-jane is totally different.--Will [you]94-jane hear it ? "[94-jane]

" Most willingly . "[94-jane]

" [You]94-jane shall have it in few words . [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley sees that [[her]102-miss bingley brother]3126-her brother is in love with [you]94-jane , and wants [him]3126-her brother to marry [Miss Darcy]139-miss darcy . [She]102-miss bingley follows [him]3126-her brother to [town]285-town in the hope of keeping [him]3126-her brother [there]325-there , and tries to persuade [you]94-jane that [he]3126-her brother does not care about [you]94-jane . "[94-jane]

[Jane]94-jane shook [her]94-jane head .

" Indeed , [Jane]94-jane , [you]94-jane ought to believe [me.--No one who has ever seen [you]94-jane together]3790-me.--no one who has ever seen you together , can doubt [his]3126-her brother affection . [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley [I]94-jane am sure can not . [She]102-miss bingley is not such [a simpleton]3153-a simpleton . Could [she]102-miss bingley have seen half as much love in [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy for [herself]102-miss bingley , [she]102-miss bingley would have ordered [her]102-miss bingley wedding clothes . But the case is this . [We]3792-we are not rich enough , or grand enough for [them]3792-we ; and [she]102-miss bingley is the more anxious to get [Miss Darcy]139-miss darcy for [[her]102-miss bingley brother]3126-her brother , from the notion that when there has been _ one _ intermarriage , [she]102-miss bingley may have less trouble in achieving a second ; in which there is certainly some ingenuity , and [I]94-jane dare say it would succeed , if [Miss de Bourgh]152-miss de bourgh were out of the way . But , [[my]94-jane dearest]3231-my dearest [Jane]94-jane , [you]94-jane can not seriously imagine that because [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley tells [you]94-jane [[her]102-miss bingley brother]3126-her brother greatly admires [Miss Darcy]139-miss darcy , [he]3126-her brother is in the smallest degree less sensible of _ [your]94-jane _ merit than when [he]3126-her brother took leave of [you]94-jane on Tuesday , or that it will be in [her]102-miss bingley power to persuade [him]3126-her brother that instead of being in love with [you]94-jane , [he]3126-her brother is very much in love with [[her]102-miss bingley friend]418-her friend . "[94-jane]

" If [we]3797-we thought alike of [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley , "[94-jane] replied [Jane]94-jane , " [your]102-miss bingley representation of all this , might make [me]94-jane quite easy . But [I]94-jane know the foundation is unjust . [Caroline]133-caroline is incapable of wilfully deceiving [any one]3122-any one ; and all that [I]94-jane can hope in this case is , that [she]133-caroline is deceived [herself]133-caroline . "[94-jane]

" That is right.--You could not have started a more happy idea , since [you]102-miss bingley will not take comfort in [mine]94-jane . Believe [her]133-caroline to be deceived by all means . [You]102-miss bingley have now done [your]102-miss bingley duty by [her]133-caroline , and must fret no longer . "[1073-he]

" But , [[my]94-jane dear sister]3799-my dear sister , can [I]94-jane be happy , even supposing the best , in accepting [a man whose [sisters]3563-sisters and [friends]3767-friends are all wishing [him]3800-a man whose sisters and friends are all wishing him to marry elsewhere to marry elsewhere]3800-a man whose sisters and friends are all wishing him to marry elsewhere ? "[94-jane]

" [You]102-miss bingley must decide for [yourself]102-miss bingley , "[93-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , " and if upon mature deliberation , [you]102-miss bingley find that the misery of disobliging [[his]3800-a man whose sisters and friends are all wishing him to marry elsewhere two sisters]299-his two sisters is more than equivalent to the happiness of being [[his]3800-a man whose sisters and friends are all wishing him to marry elsewhere wife]251-his wife , [I]93-elizabeth advise [you]102-miss bingley by all means to refuse [him]3800-a man whose sisters and friends are all wishing him to marry elsewhere . "[93-elizabeth]

" How can [you]102-miss bingley talk so?"--said[94-jane] [Jane]94-jane faintly smiling,--"You must know that though [I]93-elizabeth should be exceedingly grieved at [their]299-his two sisters disapprobation , [I]93-elizabeth could not hesitate . "[93-elizabeth]

" [I]94-jane did not think [you]102-miss bingley would;--and that being the case , [I]94-jane can not consider [your]102-miss bingley situation with much compassion . "[94-jane]

" But if [he]1073-he returns no more this winter , [my]93-elizabeth choice will never be required . A thousand things may arise in six months ! "[93-elizabeth]

The idea of [his]1073-he returning no more [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth treated with the utmost contempt . It appeared to [her]93-elizabeth merely the suggestion of [Caroline]133-caroline 's interested wishes , and [she]93-elizabeth could not for a moment suppose that those wishes , however openly or artfully spoken , could influence [a young man so totally independent of every one]1074-a young man so totally independent of every one .

[She]93-elizabeth represented to [[her]93-elizabeth sister]348-her sister as forcibly as possible what [she]93-elizabeth felt on the subject , and had soon the pleasure of seeing its happy effect . [Jane]94-jane 's temper was not desponding , and [she]94-jane was gradually led to hope , though the diffidence of affection sometimes overcame the hope , that [Bingley]102-miss bingley would return to [Netherfield]2-netherfield and answer every wish of [her]94-jane heart .

[They]1076-they agreed that [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet should only hear of the departure of [the family]432-the family , without being alarmed on the score of [the gentleman]306-the gentleman 's conduct ; but even this partial communication gave [her]93-elizabeth a great deal of concern , and [she]93-elizabeth bewailed it as exceedingly unlucky that [the ladies]269-the ladies should happen to go away , just as [they]269-the ladies were all getting so intimate together . After lamenting it however at some length , [she]93-elizabeth had the consolation of thinking that [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley would be soon down again and soon dining at [Longbourn]7-longbourn , and the conclusion of all was the comfortable declaration that , though [he]90-mr. bingley had been invited only to a family dinner , [she]93-elizabeth would take care to have two full courses .

CHAPTER XXII .

[The Bennets]111-the bennets were engaged to dine with [the Lucases]113-the lucases , and again during the chief of the day , was [Miss Lucas]103-miss lucas so kind as to listen to [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth took an opportunity of thanking [her]103-miss lucas . " It keeps [him]90-mr. bingley in good humour , "[93-elizabeth] said [she]93-elizabeth , " and [I]93-elizabeth am more obliged to [you]418-her friend than [I]93-elizabeth can express . "[93-elizabeth] [Charlotte]114-charlotte assured [[her]114-charlotte friend]418-her friend of [her]114-charlotte satisfaction in being useful , and that it amply repaid [her]114-charlotte for the little sacrifice of [her]114-charlotte time . This was very amiable , but [Charlotte]114-charlotte 's kindness extended farther than [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth had any conception of;--its object was nothing less , than to secure [her]93-elizabeth from any return of [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins 's addresses , by engaging [them]1081-them towards [herself]93-elizabeth . Such was [Miss Lucas]103-miss lucas 's scheme ; and appearances were so favourable that when [they]1082-they parted at night , [she]93-elizabeth would have felt almost sure of success if [he]1083-he had not been to leave [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire so very soon . But here , [she]93-elizabeth did injustice to the fire and independence of [his]1083-he character , for it led [him]1083-he to escape out of [Longbourn House]25-longbourn house the next morning with admirable slyness , and hasten to [Lucas Lodge]10-lucas lodge to throw [himself]1083-he at [her]93-elizabeth feet . [He]1083-he was anxious to avoid the notice of [[his]1083-he cousins]769-his cousins , from a conviction that if [they]769-his cousins saw [him]1083-he depart , [they]769-his cousins could not fail to conjecture [his]1083-he design , and [he]1083-he was not willing to have the attempt known till [its]1085-its success could be known likewise ; for though feeling almost secure , and with reason , for [Charlotte]114-charlotte had been tolerably encouraging , [he]1083-he was comparatively diffident since the adventure of [Wednesday]177-wednesday . [His]1083-he reception however was of the most flattering kind . [Miss Lucas]103-miss lucas perceived [him]1083-he from an upper window as [he]1083-he walked towards [the house]3026-the house , and instantly set out to meet [him]1083-he accidentally in [the lane]1087-the lane . But little had [she]103-miss lucas dared to hope that so much love and eloquence awaited [her]103-miss lucas [there]325-there .

In as short a time as [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins 's long speeches would allow , every thing was settled between [them]1089-their to the satisfaction of [both]796-both ; and as [they]1089-their entered [the house]3026-the house , [he]1083-he earnestly entreated [her]103-miss lucas to name the day that was to make [him]1083-he [the happiest of [men]3391-men]1092-the happiest of men ; and though such a solicitation must be waved for the present , [the lady]595-the lady felt no inclination to trifle with [his]1083-he happiness . The stupidity with which [he]1083-he was favoured by nature , must guard [his]1083-he courtship from any charm that could make [a woman]3036-a woman wish for its continuance ; and [Miss Lucas]103-miss lucas , who accepted [him]1083-he solely from the pure and disinterested desire of an establishment , cared not how soon that establishment were gained .

[Sir William]91-sir william and [Lady Lucas]92-lady lucas were speedily applied to for [their]1089-their consent ; and it was bestowed with a most joyful alacrity . [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins 's present circumstances made it a most eligible match for [[their]1089-their daughter]1096-their daughter , to whom [they]1089-their could give little fortune ; and [his]149-mr. collins prospects of future wealth were exceedingly fair . [Lady Lucas]92-lady lucas began directly to calculate with more interest than the matter had ever excited before , how many years longer [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet was likely to live ; and [Sir William]91-sir william gave it as [his]91-sir william decided opinion , that whenever [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins should be in possession of [the Longbourn estate]1097-the longbourn estate , it would be highly expedient that both [he]149-mr. collins and [[his]149-mr. collins wife]251-his wife should make [their]1089-their appearance at [[St. James]11-st. james 's]397-st. james 's . [The whole family]331-the whole family in short were properly overjoyed on the occasion . [The younger girls]3371-the younger girls formed hopes of _ coming out _ a year or two sooner than [they]3371-the younger girls might otherwise have done ; and [the boys]1102-the boys were relieved from [their]1102-the boys apprehension of [Charlotte]114-charlotte 's dying [an old maid]1103-an old maid . [Charlotte]114-charlotte [herself]114-charlotte was tolerably composed . [She]114-charlotte had gained [her]114-charlotte point , and had time to consider of it . [Her]114-charlotte reflections were in general satisfactory . [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins to be sure was neither sensible nor agreeable ; [his]149-mr. collins society was irksome , and [his]149-mr. collins attachment to [her]114-charlotte must be imaginary . But still [he]149-mr. collins would be [her]114-charlotte husband.--Without thinking highly either of [men]3391-men or of matrimony , marriage had always been [her]114-charlotte object ; it was the only honourable provision for [well - educated young women of small fortune , and however uncertain of giving happiness]1105-well - educated young women of small fortune , and however uncertain of giving happiness , must be [their]1105-well - educated young women of small fortune , and however uncertain of giving happiness pleasantest preservative from want . This preservative [she]114-charlotte had now obtained ; and at the age of twenty - seven , without having ever been handsome , [she]114-charlotte felt all the good luck of it . The least agreeable circumstance in the business , was the surprise it must occasion to [Elizabeth Bennet]93-elizabeth , whose friendship [she]93-elizabeth valued beyond that of [any other person]1106-any other person . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth would wonder , and probably would blame [her]93-elizabeth ; and though [her]93-elizabeth resolution was not to be shaken , [her]93-elizabeth feelings must be hurt by such disapprobation . [She]93-elizabeth resolved to give [her]93-elizabeth the information [herself]93-elizabeth , and therefore charged [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins when [he]149-mr. collins returned to [Longbourn]7-longbourn to dinner , to drop no hint of what had passed before [any of [the family]432-the family]1107-any of the family . A promise of secrecy was of course very dutifully given , but it could not be kept without difficulty ; for the curiosity excited by [his]149-mr. collins long absence , burst forth in such very direct questions on [his]149-mr. collins return , as required some ingenuity to evade , and [he]149-mr. collins was at the same time exercising great self - denial , for [he]149-mr. collins was longing to publish [his]149-mr. collins prosperous love .

As [he]149-mr. collins was to begin [his]149-mr. collins journey too early on the morrow to see [any of [the family]432-the family]1107-any of the family , the ceremony of leave - taking was performed when [the ladies]269-the ladies moved for the night ; and [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet with great politeness and cordiality said how happy [they]269-the ladies should be to see [him]149-mr. collins at [Longbourn]7-longbourn again , whenever [his]149-mr. collins other engagements might allow [him]149-mr. collins to visit [them]269-the ladies .

" [[My]149-mr. collins dear]3018-my dear Madam , "[149-mr. collins] [he]149-mr. collins replied , " this invitation is particularly gratifying , because it is what [I]149-mr. collins have been hoping to receive ; and [you]3018-my dear may be very certain that [I]149-mr. collins shall avail [myself]149-mr. collins of it as soon as possible . "[149-mr. collins]

[They]269-the ladies were all astonished ; and [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet , who could by no means wish for so speedy a return , immediately said ,

" But is there not danger of [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine 's disapprobation here , [[my]86-mr. bennet good sir?--You]3806-my good sir?--you had better neglect [your]3018-my dear relations , than run the risk of offending [[your]3018-my dear patroness]3807-your patroness . "[86-mr. bennet]

" [[My]149-mr. collins dear sir]3808-my dear sir , "[149-mr. collins] replied [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins , " [I]149-mr. collins am particularly obliged to [you]3808-my dear sir for this friendly caution , and [you]3808-my dear sir may depend upon [my]149-mr. collins not taking so material a step without [[her]97-lady catherine ladyship]677-her ladyship 's concurrence . "[149-mr. collins]

" [You]3808-my dear sir can not be too much on [your]3808-my dear sir guard . Risk any thing rather than [her]97-lady catherine displeasure ; and if [you]3808-my dear sir find it likely to be raised by [your]3808-my dear sir coming to [us]3810-us again , which [I]86-mr. bennet should think exceedingly probable , stay quietly at [home]3223-home , and be satisfied that _ [we]3810-us _ shall take no offence . "[86-mr. bennet]

" Believe [me]269-the ladies , [[my]269-the ladies dear sir]3808-my dear sir , [my]269-the ladies gratitude is warmly excited by such affectionate attention ; and depend upon it , [you]3808-my dear sir will speedily receive from [me]269-the ladies a letter of thanks for this , as well as for every other mark of [your]3808-my dear sir regard during [my]269-the ladies stay in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire . As for [[my]269-the ladies fair cousins]3590-my fair cousins , though [my]269-the ladies absence may not be long enough to render it necessary , [I]269-the ladies shall now take the liberty of wishing [them]3590-my fair cousins health and happiness , not excepting [[my]269-the ladies cousin]3411-my cousin [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth . "[269-the ladies]

With proper civilities [the ladies]269-the ladies then withdrew ; all of [them]269-the ladies equally surprised to find that [he]1113-he meditated a quick return . [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet wished to understand by it that [he]1113-he thought of paying [his]1113-he addresses to [one of [[her]96-mrs. bennet younger girls]1115-her younger girls]1114-one of her younger girls , and [Mary]98-mary might have been prevailed on to accept [him]1113-he . [She]96-mrs. bennet rated [his]1113-he abilities much higher than any of the others ; there was a solidity in [his]1113-he reflections which often struck [her]96-mrs. bennet , and though by no means so clever as [herself]96-mrs. bennet , [she]96-mrs. bennet thought that if encouraged to read and improve [himself]1113-he by such an example as [her]96-mrs. bennet 's , [he]1113-he might become [a very agreeable companion]1116-a very agreeable companion . But on the following morning , every hope of this kind was done away . [Miss Lucas]103-miss lucas called soon after breakfast , and in a private conference with [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth related the event of the day before .

The possibility of [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins 's fancying [himself]1113-he in love with [[her]96-mrs. bennet friend]418-her friend had once occurred to [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth within the last day or two ; but that [Charlotte]114-charlotte could encourage [him]1113-he , seemed almost as far from possibility as that [she]114-charlotte could encourage [him]1113-he [herself]114-charlotte , and [her]114-charlotte astonishment was consequently so great as to overcome at first the bounds of decorum , and [she]114-charlotte could not help crying out ,

" Engaged to [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins ! [[my]114-charlotte dear]3018-my dear Charlotte,--impossible ! "[114-charlotte]

The steady countenance which [Miss Lucas]103-miss lucas had commanded in telling [her]103-miss lucas story , gave way to a momentary confusion here on receiving so direct a reproach ; though , as it was no more than [she]103-miss lucas expected , [she]103-miss lucas soon regained [her]103-miss lucas composure , and calmly replied ,

" Why should [you]114-charlotte be surprised , [[my]103-miss lucas dear]3018-my dear Eliza?--Do [you]114-charlotte think it incredible that [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins should be able to procure [any woman]3781-any woman 's good opinion , because [he]149-mr. collins was not so happy as to succeed with [you]114-charlotte ? "[103-miss lucas]

But [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth had now recollected [herself]93-elizabeth , and making a strong effort for it , was able to assure [her]114-charlotte with tolerable firmness that the prospect of [their]1118-their relationship was highly grateful to [her]114-charlotte , and that [she]114-charlotte wished [her]114-charlotte all imaginable happiness .

" [I]103-miss lucas see what [you]114-charlotte are feeling , "[103-miss lucas] replied [Charlotte,--"you]3818-charlotte,--"you must be surprised , very much surprised,--so lately as [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins was wishing to marry [you]114-charlotte . But when [you]114-charlotte have had time to think it all over , [I]894-the rest of the family hope [you]114-charlotte will be satisfied with what [I]894-the rest of the family have done . [I]894-the rest of the family am not romantic [you]114-charlotte know . [I]894-the rest of the family never was . [I]894-the rest of the family ask only a comfortable home ; and considering [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins 's character , connections , and situation in life , [I]894-the rest of the family am convinced that [my]894-the rest of the family chance of happiness with [him]149-mr. collins is as fair , as [most people]3819-most people can boast on entering the marriage state . "[894-the rest of the family]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth quietly answered " Undoubtedly;"--and[93-elizabeth] after an awkward pause , [they]1119-they returned to [the rest of [the family]432-the family]894-the rest of the family . [Charlotte]114-charlotte did not stay much longer , and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was then left to reflect on what [she]93-elizabeth had heard . It was a long time before [she]93-elizabeth became at all reconciled to the idea of so unsuitable a match . The strangeness of [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins 's making two offers of marriage within three days , was nothing in comparison of [his]149-mr. collins being now accepted . [She]93-elizabeth had always felt that [Charlotte]114-charlotte 's opinion of matrimony was not exactly like [her]93-elizabeth own , but [she]93-elizabeth could not have supposed it possible that when called into action , [she]93-elizabeth would have sacrificed every better feeling to worldly advantage . [Charlotte]114-charlotte [the wife of [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins]1122-the wife of mr. collins , was a most humiliating picture!--And to the pang of [a friend]3351-a friend disgracing [herself]114-charlotte and sunk in [her]114-charlotte esteem , was added the distressing conviction that it was impossible for [that friend]3633-that friend to be tolerably happy in the lot [she]114-charlotte had chosen .

CHAPTER XXIII .

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was sitting with [[her]93-elizabeth mother]261-her mother and [sisters]3563-sisters , reflecting on what [she]93-elizabeth had heard , and doubting whether [she]93-elizabeth were authorised to mention it , when [Sir William Lucas]91-sir william [himself]91-sir william appeared , sent by [[his]91-sir william daughter]1127-his daughter to announce [her]1127-his daughter engagement to [the family]432-the family . With many compliments to [them]432-the family , and much self - gratulation on the prospect of a connection between [the houses]1129-the houses , [he]91-sir william unfolded the matter,--to an audience not merely wondering , but incredulous ; for [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet , with more perseverance than politeness , protested [he]91-sir william must be entirely mistaken , and [Lydia]95-lydia , always unguarded and often uncivil , boisterously exclaimed ,

" [Good Lord]3820-good lord ! [Sir William]91-sir william , how can [you]91-sir william tell such a story?--Do not [you]91-sir william know that [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins wants to marry [Lizzy]93-elizabeth ? "[95-lydia]

Nothing less than the complaisance of [a courtier]1130-a courtier could have borne without anger such treatment ; but [Sir William]91-sir william 's good breeding carried [him]91-sir william through it all ; and though [he]91-sir william begged leave to be positive as to the truth of [his]91-sir william information , [he]91-sir william listened to all [their]432-the family impertinence with the most forbearing courtesy .

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , feeling it incumbent on [her]93-elizabeth to relieve [him]91-sir william from so unpleasant a situation , now put [herself]93-elizabeth forward to confirm [his]91-sir william account , by mentioning [her]93-elizabeth prior knowledge of it from [Charlotte]114-charlotte [herself]114-charlotte ; and endeavoured to put a stop to the exclamations of [[her]93-elizabeth mother]261-her mother and [sisters]3563-sisters , by the earnestness of [her]93-elizabeth congratulations to [Sir William]91-sir william , in which [she]93-elizabeth was readily joined by [Jane]94-jane , and by making a variety of remarks on the happiness that might be expected from the match , the excellent character of [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins , and the convenient distance of [Hunsford]16-hunsford from [London]5-london .

[Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet was in fact too much overpowered to say a great deal while [Sir William]91-sir william remained ; but no sooner had [he]91-sir william left [them]1133-them than [her]96-mrs. bennet feelings found a rapid vent . In the first place , [she]96-mrs. bennet persisted in disbelieving the whole of the matter ; secondly , [she]96-mrs. bennet was very sure that [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins had been taken in ; thirdly , [she]96-mrs. bennet trusted that [they]1134-them would never be happy together ; and fourthly , that the match might be broken off . Two inferences , however , were plainly deduced from the whole ; one , that [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was the real cause of all the mischief ; and the other , that [she]93-elizabeth [herself]93-elizabeth had been barbarously used by [them]1134-them all ; and on these two points [she]93-elizabeth principally dwelt during the rest of the day . Nothing could console and nothing appease her.--Nor did that day wear out [her]93-elizabeth resentment . A week elapsed before [she]93-elizabeth could see [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth without scolding [her]93-elizabeth , a month passed away before [she]93-elizabeth could speak to [Sir William]91-sir william or [Lady Lucas]92-lady lucas without being rude , and many months were gone before [she]93-elizabeth could at all forgive [[their]1134-them daughter]1096-their daughter .

[Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet 's emotions were much more tranquil on the occasion , and such as [he]86-mr. bennet did experience [he]86-mr. bennet pronounced to be of a most agreeable sort ; for it gratified [him]86-mr. bennet , [he]86-mr. bennet said , to discover that [Charlotte Lucas]114-charlotte , whom [he]86-mr. bennet had been used to think tolerably sensible , was as foolish as [[his]86-mr. bennet wife]251-his wife , and more foolish than [[his]86-mr. bennet daughter]1127-his daughter !

[Jane]94-jane confessed [herself]94-jane a little surprised at the match ; but [she]94-jane said less of [her]94-jane astonishment than of [her]94-jane earnest desire for [their]1134-them happiness ; nor could [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth persuade [her]94-jane to consider it as improbable . [Kitty]97-lady catherine and [Lydia]95-lydia were far from envying [Miss Lucas]103-miss lucas , for [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins was only [a clergyman]679-a clergyman ; and it affected [them]1134-them in no other way than as a piece of news to spread at [Meryton]9-meryton .

[Lady Lucas]92-lady lucas could not be insensible of triumph on being able to retort on [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet the comfort of having [a daughter]1139-a daughter well married ; and [she]92-lady lucas called at [Longbourn]7-longbourn rather oftener than usual to say how happy [she]92-lady lucas was , though [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet 's sour looks and ill - natured remarks might have been enough to drive happiness away .

Between [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth and [Charlotte]114-charlotte there was a restraint which kept [them]1134-them mutually silent on the subject ; and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth felt persuaded that no real confidence could ever subsist between [them]1134-them again . [Her]93-elizabeth disappointment in [Charlotte]114-charlotte made [her]93-elizabeth turn with fonder regard to [[her]93-elizabeth sister]348-her sister , of whose rectitude and delicacy [she]93-elizabeth was sure [her]93-elizabeth opinion could never be shaken , and for whose happiness [she]93-elizabeth grew daily more anxious , as [Bingley]90-mr. bingley had now been gone a week , and nothing was heard of [his]90-mr. bingley return .

[Jane]94-jane had sent [Caroline]133-caroline an early answer to [her]94-jane letter , and was counting the days till [she]133-caroline might reasonably hope to hear again . The promised letter of thanks from [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins arrived on Tuesday , addressed to [[their]1134-them father]267-their father , and written with all the solemnity of gratitude which [a twelvemonth]1142-a twelvemonth 's abode in [the family]432-the family might have prompted . After discharging [his]149-mr. collins conscience on that head , [he]149-mr. collins proceeded to inform [them]1134-them , with many rapturous expressions , of [his]149-mr. collins happiness in having obtained the affection of [[their]1134-them amiable neighbour]1144-their amiable neighbour , [Miss Lucas]103-miss lucas , and then explained that it was merely with the view of enjoying [her]103-miss lucas society that [he]149-mr. collins had been so ready to close with [their]1134-them kind wish of seeing [him]149-mr. collins again at [Longbourn]7-longbourn , whither [he]149-mr. collins hoped to be able to return on Monday fortnight ; for [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine , [he]149-mr. collins added , so heartily approved [his]149-mr. collins marriage , that [she]97-lady catherine wished it to take place as soon as possible , which [he]149-mr. collins trusted would be an unanswerable argument with [his]149-mr. collins amiable [Charlotte]114-charlotte to name an early day for making [him]149-mr. collins [the happiest of [men]3391-men]1092-the happiest of men .

[Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins 's return into [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire was no longer a matter of pleasure to [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet . On the contrary [she]97-lady catherine was as much disposed to complain of it as [her]97-lady catherine husband.--It was very strange that [he]149-mr. collins should come to [Longbourn]7-longbourn instead of to [Lucas Lodge]10-lucas lodge ; it was also very inconvenient and exceedingly troublesome.--She hated having [visitors]1147-visitors in [the house]3026-the house while [her]97-lady catherine health was so indifferent , and [lovers]1149-lovers were of [all people]1150-all people the most disagreeable . Such were the gentle murmurs of [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet , and they gave way only to the greater distress of [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley 's continued absence .

Neither [Jane]94-jane nor [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth were comfortable on this subject . Day after day passed away without bringing any other tidings of [him]90-mr. bingley than the report which shortly prevailed in [Meryton]9-meryton of [his]90-mr. bingley coming no more to [Netherfield]2-netherfield the whole winter ; a report which highly incensed [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet , and which [she]96-mrs. bennet never failed to contradict as a most scandalous falsehood .

Even [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth began to fear -- not that [Bingley]90-mr. bingley was indifferent -- but that [[his]90-mr. bingley sisters]303-his sisters would be successful in keeping [him]90-mr. bingley away . Unwilling as [she]93-elizabeth was to admit an idea so destructive of [Jane]94-jane 's happiness , and so dishonourable to the stability of [[her]93-elizabeth lover]1152-her lover , [she]93-elizabeth could not prevent its frequently recurring . The united efforts of [[his]90-mr. bingley two unfeeling sisters]1153-his two unfeeling sisters and of [[his]90-mr. bingley overpowering friend]1154-his overpowering friend , assisted by the attractions of [Miss Darcy]139-miss darcy and the amusements of [London]5-london , might be too much , [she]93-elizabeth feared , for the strength of [his]90-mr. bingley attachment .

As for [Jane]94-jane , _ [her]94-jane _ anxiety under this suspence was , of course , more painful than [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth 's ; but whatever [she]94-jane felt [she]94-jane was desirous of concealing , and between [herself]94-jane and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , therefore , the subject was never alluded to . But as no such delicacy restrained [[her]94-jane mother]261-her mother , an hour seldom passed in which [she]261-her mother did not talk of [Bingley]90-mr. bingley , express [her]261-her mother impatience for [his]90-mr. bingley arrival , or even require [Jane]94-jane to confess that if [he]90-mr. bingley did not come back , [she]94-jane should think [herself]94-jane very ill used . It needed all [Jane]94-jane 's steady mildness to bear these attacks with tolerable tranquillity .

[Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins returned most punctually on the Monday fortnight , but [his]149-mr. collins reception at [Longbourn]7-longbourn was not quite so gracious as it had been on [his]149-mr. collins first introduction . [He]90-mr. bingley was too happy , however , to need much attention ; and luckily for [the others]517-the others , the business of love - making relieved [them]517-the others from a great deal of [his]90-mr. bingley company . [The chief of every day]1157-the chief of every day was spent by [him]90-mr. bingley at [Lucas Lodge]10-lucas lodge , and [he]90-mr. bingley sometimes returned to [Longbourn]7-longbourn only in time to make an apology for [his]90-mr. bingley absence before [the family]432-the family went to bed .

[Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet was really in a most pitiable state . The very mention of any thing concerning the match threw [her]96-mrs. bennet into an agony of ill humour , and wherever [she]96-mrs. bennet went [she]96-mrs. bennet was sure of hearing it talked of . The sight of [Miss Lucas]103-miss lucas was odious to [her]96-mrs. bennet . As [[her]96-mrs. bennet successor in [that house]1160-that house]1159-her successor in that house , [she]96-mrs. bennet regarded [her]96-mrs. bennet with jealous abhorrence . Whenever [Charlotte]114-charlotte came to see [them]1161-them [she]114-charlotte concluded [her]114-charlotte to be anticipating the hour of possession ; and whenever [she]114-charlotte spoke in a low voice to [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins , was convinced that [they]1161-them were talking of [the Longbourn estate]1097-the longbourn estate , and resolving to turn [herself]114-charlotte and [[her]114-charlotte daughters]257-her daughters out of [the house]3026-the house , as soon as [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet were dead . [She]114-charlotte complained bitterly of all this to [[her]114-charlotte husband]276-her husband .

" Indeed , [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet , "[114-charlotte] said [she]114-charlotte , " it is very hard to think that [Charlotte Lucas]114-charlotte should ever be [mistress of [this house]3413-this house]3821-mistress of this house , that [I]114-charlotte should be forced to make way for _ [her]114-charlotte _ , and live to see [her]114-charlotte take [my]114-charlotte place in it ! "[114-charlotte]

" [[My]114-charlotte dear]3018-my dear , do not give way to such gloomy thoughts . Let [us]3824-us hope for better things . Let [us]3824-us flatter [ourselves]3824-us that _ [I]114-charlotte _ may be [the survivor]3825-the survivor . "[114-charlotte]

This was not very consoling to [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet , and , therefore , instead of making any answer , [she]114-charlotte went on as before ,

" [I]114-charlotte can not bear to think that [they]3826-they should have all [this estate]3429-this estate . If it was not for the entail [I]114-charlotte should not mind it . "[114-charlotte]

" What should not [you]114-charlotte mind ? "[114-charlotte]

" [I]114-charlotte should not mind any thing at all . "[114-charlotte]

" Let [us]3824-us be thankful that [you]114-charlotte are preserved from a state of such insensibility . "[114-charlotte]

" [I]114-charlotte never can be thankful , [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet , for any thing about the entail . How [any one]3122-any one could have the conscience to entail away an estate from [[one]3064-one 's own daughters]3830-one 's own daughters [I]114-charlotte can not understand ; and all for the sake of [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins too!--Why should _ [he]149-mr. collins _ have it more than [anybody else]3831-anybody else ? "[114-charlotte]

" [I]86-mr. bennet leave it to [yourself]86-mr. bennet to determine , "[86-mr. bennet] said [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet .

END OF VOL . I.

[ Illustration : [A VICARAGE HOUSE]1166-a vicarage house . ]

[PRIDE AND PREJUDICE]178-matlock :

A Novel .

In Three Volumes .

By [the Author of " Sense and Sensibility]3832-the author of " sense and sensibility . "[3832-the author of " sense and sensibility]

VOL . II .

[London]5-london : Printed for T. [Egerton]31-egerton , [Military Library]1167-military library , [Whitehall]32-whitehall . 1813 .

PRIDE & PREJUDICE .

CHAPTER I.

[Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley 's letter arrived , and put an end to doubt . The very first sentence conveyed the assurance of [their]1168-their being all settled in [London]5-london for the winter , and concluded with [[her]102-miss bingley brother]3126-her brother 's regret at not having had time to pay [his]3126-her brother respects to [[his]3126-her brother friends]423-his friends in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire before [he]3126-her brother left [the country]460-the country .

[Hope]179-hope was over , entirely over ; and when [Jane]94-jane could attend to the rest of the letter , [she]94-jane found little , except the professed affection of [the writer]1172-the writer , that could give [her]94-jane any comfort . [Miss Darcy]139-miss darcy 's praise occupied [the chief of it]968-the chief of it . [Her]139-miss darcy many attractions were again dwelt on , and [Caroline]133-caroline boasted joyfully of [their]1168-their increasing intimacy , and ventured to predict the accomplishment of the wishes which had been unfolded in [her]139-miss darcy former letter . [She]139-miss darcy wrote also with great pleasure of [[her]139-miss darcy brother]3126-her brother 's being [an inmate of [[Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy 's house]1176-mr. darcy 's house]1175-an inmate of mr. darcy 's house , and mentioned with raptures , some plans of the latter with regard to new furniture .

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , to whom [Jane]94-jane very soon communicated [the chief of all this]1177-the chief of all this , heard it in silent indignation . [Her]94-jane heart was divided between concern for [[her]94-jane sister]348-her sister , and resentment against [all the others]1179-all the others . To [Caroline]133-caroline 's assertion of [[her]139-miss darcy brother]3126-her brother 's being partial to [Miss Darcy]139-miss darcy [she]94-jane paid no credit . That [he]3126-her brother was really fond of [Jane]94-jane , [she]139-miss darcy doubted no more than [she]139-miss darcy had ever done ; and much as [she]139-miss darcy had always been disposed to like [him]3126-her brother , [she]139-miss darcy could not think without anger , hardly without contempt , on that easiness of temper , that want of proper resolution which now made [him]3126-her brother [the slave of [[his]3126-her brother designing friends]1182-his designing friends]1181-the slave of his designing friends , and led [him]3126-her brother to sacrifice [his]3126-her brother own happiness to the caprice of [their]1182-his designing friends inclinations . Had [his]3126-her brother own happiness , however , been the only sacrifice , [he]3126-her brother might have been allowed to sport with it in what ever manner [he]3126-her brother thought best ; but [[her]139-miss darcy sister]348-her sister 's was involved in it , as [she]139-miss darcy thought [he]3126-her brother must be sensible [himself]3126-her brother . It was a subject , in short , on which reflection would be long indulged , and must be unavailing . [She]139-miss darcy could think of nothing else , and yet whether [Bingley]102-miss bingley 's regard had really died away , or were suppressed by [[his]3126-her brother friends]423-his friends ' interference ; whether [he]3126-her brother had been aware of [Jane]94-jane 's attachment , or whether it had escaped [his]3126-her brother observation ; whichever were the case , though [her]139-miss darcy opinion of [him]3126-her brother must be materially affected by the difference , [[her]139-miss darcy sister]348-her sister 's situation remained the same , [her]348-her sister peace equally wounded .

A day or two passed before [Jane]94-jane had courage to speak of [her]94-jane feelings to [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth ; but at last on [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet 's leaving [them]1186-we together , after a longer irritation than usual about [Netherfield]2-netherfield and [its master]1187-its master , [she]94-jane could not help saying ,

" Oh ! that [[my]94-jane dear mother]3833-my dear mother had more command over [herself]3833-my dear mother ; [she]3833-my dear mother can have no idea of the pain [she]3833-my dear mother gives [me]94-jane by [her]3833-my dear mother continual reflections on [him]1187-its master . But [I]94-jane will not repine . It can not last long . [He]1187-its master will be forgot , and [we]1186-we shall all be as [we]1186-we were before . "[94-jane]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth looked at [[her]93-elizabeth sister]348-her sister with incredulous solicitude , but said nothing .

" [You]93-elizabeth doubt [me]94-jane , "[94-jane] cried [Jane]94-jane , slightly colouring ; " indeed [you]93-elizabeth have no reason . [He]1187-its master may live in [my]94-jane memory as [the most amiable man of [my]94-jane acquaintance]3834-the most amiable man of my acquaintance , but that is all . [I]94-jane have nothing either to hope or fear , and nothing to reproach [him]1187-its master with . Thank [God]107-god ! [I]94-jane have not _ that _ pain . A little time [therefore.--I]94-jane shall certainly try to get the better . "[94-jane]

With a stronger voice [she]94-jane soon added , " [I]94-jane have this comfort immediately , that it has not been more than an error of fancy on [my]94-jane side , and that it has done no harm to [any one]3122-any one but [myself]94-jane . "[94-jane]

" [[My]93-elizabeth dear]3018-my dear [Jane]94-jane ! "[93-elizabeth] exclaimed [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , " [you]94-jane are too good . [Your]94-jane sweetness and disinterestedness are really angelic ; [I]93-elizabeth do not know what to say to [you]94-jane . [I]93-elizabeth feel as if [I]93-elizabeth had never done [you]94-jane justice , or loved [you]94-jane as [you]94-jane deserve . "[93-elizabeth]

[Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth eagerly disclaimed all extraordinary merit , and threw back the praise on [[her]93-elizabeth sister]348-her sister 's warm affection .

" Nay , "[93-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , " this is not fair . _ [You]94-jane _ wish to think all [the world]323-the world respectable , and are hurt if [I]93-elizabeth speak ill of any body . _ [I]93-elizabeth _ only want to think _ [you]94-jane _ perfect , and [you]94-jane set [yourself]94-jane against it . Do not be afraid of [my]93-elizabeth running into any excess , of [my]93-elizabeth encroaching on [your]94-jane privilege of universal good will . [You]94-jane need not . There are [few people whom [I]93-elizabeth really love]3838-few people whom i really love , and still fewer of whom [I]93-elizabeth think well . The more [I]93-elizabeth see of [the world]323-the world , the more am [I]93-elizabeth dissatisfied with it ; and every day confirms [my]93-elizabeth belief of the inconsistency of [all human characters]3840-all human characters , and of the little dependence that can be placed on the appearance of either merit or sense . [I]93-elizabeth have met with two instances lately ; one [I]93-elizabeth will not mention ; the other is [Charlotte]114-charlotte 's marriage . It is unaccountable ! in every view it is unaccountable ! "[93-elizabeth]

" [[My]348-her sister dear]3018-my dear [Lizzy]93-elizabeth , do not give way to such feelings as these . They will ruin [your]93-elizabeth happiness . [You]93-elizabeth do not make allowance enough for difference of situation and temper . Consider [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins 's respectability , and [Charlotte]114-charlotte 's prudent , steady character . Remember that [she]114-charlotte is [one of [a large family]3843-a large family]3842-one of a large family ; that as to fortune , it is a most eligible match ; and be ready to believe , for every body 's sake , that [she]114-charlotte may feel something like regard and esteem for [[our]3844-our cousin]3845-our cousin . "[348-her sister]

" To oblige [you]93-elizabeth , [I]93-elizabeth would try to believe almost any thing , but [no one else]3846-no one else could be benefited by such a belief as this ; for were [I]93-elizabeth persuaded that [Charlotte]114-charlotte had any regard for [him]149-mr. collins , [I]93-elizabeth should only think worse of [her]114-charlotte understanding , than [I]93-elizabeth now do of [her]114-charlotte heart . [[My]93-elizabeth dear]3018-my dear [Jane]94-jane , [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins is [a conceited , pompous , narrow - minded , silly man]3848-a conceited , pompous , narrow - minded , silly man ; [you]94-jane know [he]149-mr. collins is , as well as [I]93-elizabeth do ; and [you]94-jane must feel , as well as [I]93-elizabeth do , that [the woman who marries [him]149-mr. collins]3849-the woman who marries him , can not have a proper way of thinking . [You]94-jane shall not defend [her]114-charlotte , though it is [Charlotte Lucas]114-charlotte . [You]94-jane shall not , for the sake of [one individual]3850-one individual , change the meaning of principle and integrity , nor endeavour to persuade [yourself]94-jane or [me]93-elizabeth , that selfishness is prudence , and insensibility of danger , security for happiness . "[93-elizabeth]

" [I]94-jane must think [your]94-jane language too strong in speaking of both , "[94-jane] replied [Jane]94-jane , " and [I]94-jane hope [you]94-jane will be convinced of it , by seeing [them]3851-them happy together . But enough of this . [You]94-jane alluded to something else . [You]94-jane mentioned _ two _ instances . [I]94-jane can not misunderstand [you]94-jane , but [I]94-jane intreat [you]94-jane , [dear Lizzy]93-elizabeth , not to pain [me]94-jane by thinking _ [that person]3852-that person _ to blame , and saying [your]94-jane opinion of [him]3852-that person is sunk . [We]3853-we must not be so ready to fancy [ourselves]3853-we intentionally injured . [We]3853-we must not expect [a lively young man]3854-a lively young man to be always so guarded and circumspect . It is very often nothing but [our]3853-we own vanity that deceives [us]3853-we . [Women]3855-women fancy admiration means more than it does . "[94-jane]

" And [men]3391-men take care that [they]3391-men should . "[93-elizabeth]

" If it is designedly done , [they]3391-men can not be justified ; but [I]94-jane have no idea of there being so much design in [the world]323-the world as [some persons]3858-some persons imagine . "[94-jane]

" [I]93-elizabeth am far from attributing any part of [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley 's conduct to design , "[93-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth ; " but without scheming to do wrong , or to make [others]3123-others unhappy , there may be error , and there may be misery . Thoughtlessness , want of attention to [other people]3860-other people 's feelings , and want of resolution , will do the business . "[93-elizabeth]

" And do [you]94-jane impute it to either of those ? "[93-elizabeth]

" Yes ; to the last . But if [I]93-elizabeth go on , [I]93-elizabeth shall displease [you]94-jane by saying what [I]93-elizabeth think of persons [you]94-jane esteem . Stop [me]93-elizabeth whilst [you]94-jane can . "[93-elizabeth]

" [You]94-jane persist , then , in supposing [[his]90-mr. bingley sisters]303-his sisters influence [him]90-mr. bingley . "[93-elizabeth]

" Yes , in conjunction with [[his]90-mr. bingley friend]307-his friend . "[93-elizabeth]

" [I]93-elizabeth can not believe it . Why should [they]303-his sisters try to influence [him]90-mr. bingley ? [They]303-his sisters can only wish [his]90-mr. bingley happiness , and if [he]90-mr. bingley is attached to [me]93-elizabeth , [no other woman]3863-no other woman can secure it . "[93-elizabeth]

" [Your]94-jane first position is false . [They]303-his sisters may wish many things besides [his]90-mr. bingley happiness ; [they]303-his sisters may wish [his]90-mr. bingley increase of wealth and consequence ; [they]303-his sisters may wish [him]90-mr. bingley to marry [a girl who has all the importance of money , great connections , and pride]3864-a girl who has all the importance of money , great connections , and pride . "[93-elizabeth]

" Beyond a doubt , [they]303-his sisters _ do _ wish [him]90-mr. bingley to chuse [Miss Darcy]139-miss darcy , "[94-jane] replied [Jane]94-jane ; " but this may be from better feelings than [you]94-jane are supposing . [They]303-his sisters have known [her]139-miss darcy much longer than [they]303-his sisters have known [me]94-jane ; no wonder if [they]303-his sisters love [her]139-miss darcy better . But , whatever may be [their]303-his sisters own wishes , it is very unlikely [they]303-his sisters should have opposed [[their]303-his sisters brother]359-their brother 's . What [sister]3866-sister would think [herself]3866-sister at liberty to do it , unless there were something very objectionable ? If [they]303-his sisters believed [him]90-mr. bingley attached to [me]94-jane , [they]303-his sisters would not try to part [us]3867-us ; if [he]90-mr. bingley were so , [they]303-his sisters could not succeed . By supposing such an affection , [you]3868-you make every body acting unnaturally and wrong , and [me]94-jane most unhappy . Do not distress [me]94-jane by the idea . [I]94-jane am not ashamed of having been mistaken -- or , at least , it is slight , it is nothing in comparison of what [I]94-jane should feel in thinking ill of [him]90-mr. bingley or [[his]90-mr. bingley sisters]303-his sisters . Let [me]94-jane take it in the best light , in the light in which it may be understood . "[94-jane]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth could not oppose such a wish ; and from this time [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley 's name was scarcely ever mentioned between [them]1190-them .

[Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet still continued to wonder and repine at [his]90-mr. bingley returning no more , and though a day seldom passed in which [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth did not account for it clearly , there seemed little chance of [her]93-elizabeth ever considering it with less perplexity . [[Her]96-mrs. bennet daughter]475-her daughter endeavoured to convince [her]93-elizabeth of what [she]93-elizabeth did not believe [herself]93-elizabeth , that [his]90-mr. bingley attentions to [Jane]94-jane had been merely the effect of a common and transient liking , which ceased when [he]90-mr. bingley saw [her]94-jane no more ; but though the probability of the statement was admitted at the time , [she]93-elizabeth had the same story to repeat every day . [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet 's best comfort was , that [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley must be down again in the summer .

[Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet treated the matter differently . " So , [Lizzy]93-elizabeth , "[86-mr. bennet] said [he]86-mr. bennet one day , " [[your]93-elizabeth sister]3152-your sister is crossed in love [I]86-mr. bennet find . [I]86-mr. bennet congratulate [her]3152-your sister . Next to being married , [a girl]3548-a girl likes to be crossed in love a little now and then . It is something to think of , and gives [her]3152-your sister a sort of distinction among [[her]3152-your sister companions]3872-her companions . When is [your]93-elizabeth turn to come ? [You]93-elizabeth will hardly bear to be long outdone by [Jane]94-jane . Now is [your]93-elizabeth time . Here are officers enough at [Meryton]9-meryton to disappoint [all the young ladies in [the country]460-the country]3873-all the young ladies in the country . Let [Wickham]156-wickham be _ [[your]93-elizabeth _ man]3875-your _ man . [He]156-wickham is [a pleasant fellow]3876-a pleasant fellow , and would jilt [you]93-elizabeth creditably . "[86-mr. bennet]

" Thank [you]156-wickham , [Sir]3172-sir , but [a less agreeable man]3878-a less agreeable man would satisfy [me]1194-general unreserve . [We]1192-many of the longbourn family must not all expect [Jane]94-jane 's good fortune . "[1194-general unreserve]

" True , "[86-mr. bennet] said [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet , " but it is a comfort to think that , whatever of that kind may befal [you]93-elizabeth , [you]93-elizabeth have [an affectionate mother who will always make the most of it . "[86-mr. bennet]

[Mr. Wickham]156-wickham 's society]3879-an affectionate mother who will always make the most of it . " mr. wickham 's society was of material service in dispelling the gloom , which the late perverse occurrences had thrown on [many of [the Longbourn family]748-the longbourn family]1192-many of the longbourn family . [They]1192-many of the longbourn family saw [him]156-wickham often , and to [his]156-wickham other recommendations was now added that of [general unreserve]1194-general unreserve . The whole of what [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth had already heard , [his]156-wickham claims on [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , and all that [he]156-wickham had suffered from [him]156-wickham , was now openly acknowledged and publicly canvassed ; and [every body]324-every body was pleased to think how much [they]324-every body had always disliked [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy before [they]324-every body had known any thing of the matter .
