[Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth was [the only creature who could suppose there might be any extenuating circumstances in the case]1196-the only creature who could suppose there might be any extenuating circumstances in the case , unknown to [the society of [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire]1197-the society of hertfordshire ; [her]93-elizabeth mild and steady candour always pleaded for allowances , and urged the possibility of mistakes -- but by [everybody else]1198-everybody else [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy was condemned as the worst of [men]3391-men .

CHAPTER II .

After a week spent in professions of love and schemes of felicity , [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins was called from [his]149-mr. collins amiable Charlotte by the arrival of Saturday . The pain of separation , however , might be alleviated on [his]149-mr. collins side , by preparations for the reception of [[his]149-mr. collins bride]1200-his bride , as [he]149-mr. collins had reason to hope , that shortly after [his]149-mr. collins next return into [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire , the day would be fixed that was to make [him]149-mr. collins [the happiest of [men]3391-men]1092-the happiest of men . [He]149-mr. collins took leave of [[his]149-mr. collins relations]724-his relations at [Longbourn]7-longbourn with as much solemnity as before ; wished [[his]149-mr. collins fair cousins]711-his fair cousins health and happiness again , and promised [[their]711-his fair cousins father]267-their father another letter of thanks .

On the following Monday , [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet had the pleasure of receiving [[her]96-mrs. bennet brother]3126-her brother and [[his]3126-her brother wife]251-his wife , who came as usual to spend the Christmas at [Longbourn]7-longbourn . [Mr. Gardiner]180-mr. gardiner was [a sensible , gentleman - like man , greatly superior to [[his]180-mr. gardiner sister]569-his sister , as well by nature as education]1208-a sensible , gentleman - like man , greatly superior to his sister , as well by nature as education . [The Netherfield ladies]1210-the netherfield ladies would have had difficulty in believing that [a man who lived by trade]1211-a man who lived by trade , and within view of [[his]180-mr. gardiner own warehouses]1212-his own warehouses , could have been so well bred and agreeable . [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner , who was several years younger than [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet and [Mrs. Philips]127-mrs. philips , was [an amiable , intelligent , elegant woman]1213-an amiable , intelligent , elegant woman , and a great favourite with all [[her]141-mrs. gardiner Longbourn nieces]1214-her longbourn nieces . Between [the two eldest]414-the two eldest and [herself]141-mrs. gardiner especially , there subsisted a very particular regard . [They]414-the two eldest had frequently been staying with [her]141-mrs. gardiner in [town]285-town .

The first part of [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner 's business on [her]141-mrs. gardiner arrival , was to distribute [her]141-mrs. gardiner presents and describe the newest fashions . When this was done , [she]141-mrs. gardiner had a less active part to play . It became [her]141-mrs. gardiner turn to listen . [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet had many grievances to relate , and much to complain of . [They]1217-they had all been very ill - used since [she]141-mrs. gardiner last saw [[her]141-mrs. gardiner sister]348-her sister . [Two of [[her]141-mrs. gardiner girls]1220-her girls]1219-two of her girls had been on the point of marriage , and after all there was nothing in it .

" [I]141-mrs. gardiner do not blame [Jane]94-jane , "[141-mrs. gardiner] [she]141-mrs. gardiner continued , " for [Jane]94-jane would have got [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley , if [she]94-jane could . But , [Lizzy]93-elizabeth ! Oh , [sister]3866-sister ! it is very hard to think that [she]94-jane might have been [[Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins 's wife]3881-mr. collins 's wife by this time , had not it been for [her]94-jane own perverseness . [He]90-mr. bingley made [her]94-jane an offer in [this very room]3882-this very room , and [she]94-jane refused [him]90-mr. bingley . The consequence of it is , that [Lady Lucas]92-lady lucas will have [a daughter]1139-a daughter married before [I]141-mrs. gardiner have , and that [Longbourn]7-longbourn estate is just as much entailed as ever . [The Lucases]113-the lucases are [very artful people]3884-very artful people indeed , [sister]3866-sister . [They]113-the lucases are all for what [they]113-the lucases can get . [I]141-mrs. gardiner am sorry to say it of [them]113-the lucases , but so it is . It makes [me]141-mrs. gardiner very nervous and poorly , to be thwarted so in [[my]141-mrs. gardiner own family]3886-my own family , and to have [[neighbours]3887-neighbours who think of [themselves]3888-neighbours who think of themselves before anybody else before [anybody else]3831-anybody else]3888-neighbours who think of themselves before anybody else . However , [your]3866-sister coming just at this time is the greatest of comforts , and [I]141-mrs. gardiner am very glad to hear what [you]3866-sister tell [us]3890-us , of long sleeves . "[141-mrs. gardiner]

[Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner , to whom [the chief of this news]1221-the chief of this news had been given before , in the course of [Jane]94-jane and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth 's correspondence with [her]141-mrs. gardiner , made [[her]141-mrs. gardiner sister]348-her sister a slight answer , and in compassion to [[her]141-mrs. gardiner nieces]3068-her nieces turned the conversation .

When alone with [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth afterwards , [she]141-mrs. gardiner spoke more on the subject . " It seems likely to have been a desirable match for [Jane]94-jane , "[141-mrs. gardiner] said [she]141-mrs. gardiner . " [I]141-mrs. gardiner am sorry it went off . But these things happen so often ! [A young man]3113-a young man , such as [you]3866-sister describe [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley , so easily falls in love with [a pretty girl]3892-a pretty girl for a few weeks , and when accident separates [them]3893-them , so easily forgets [her]3892-a pretty girl , that these sort of inconstancies are very frequent . "[141-mrs. gardiner]

" An excellent consolation in its way , "[93-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , " but it will not do for _ [us]3894-us _ . [We]3894-us do not suffer by _ accident _ . It does not often happen that the interference of [friends]3767-friends will persuade [a young man of independent fortune]3896-a young man of independent fortune to think no more of [a girl]3548-a girl , whom [he]3896-a young man of independent fortune was violently in love with only a few days before . "[93-elizabeth]

" But that expression of ' violently in love ' is so hackneyed , so doubtful , so indefinite , that it gives [me]141-mrs. gardiner very little idea . It is as often applied to feelings which arise from an half - hour 's acquaintance , as to a real , strong attachment . Pray , how _ violent was _ [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley 's love ? "[141-mrs. gardiner]

" [I]93-elizabeth never saw a more promising inclination . [He]90-mr. bingley was growing quite inattentive to [other people]3860-other people , and wholly engrossed by [her]3892-a pretty girl . Every time [they]3893-them met , it was more decided and remarkable . At [his]90-mr. bingley own ball [he]90-mr. bingley offended [two or three young ladies]3899-two or three young ladies , by not asking [them]3899-two or three young ladies to dance , and [I]93-elizabeth spoke to [him]90-mr. bingley twice [myself]93-elizabeth , without receiving an answer . Could there be finer symptoms ? Is not general incivility the very essence of love ? "[93-elizabeth]

" Oh , yes!--of that kind of love which [I]141-mrs. gardiner suppose [him]90-mr. bingley to have felt . Poor [Jane]94-jane ! [I]141-mrs. gardiner am sorry for [her]94-jane , because , with [her]94-jane disposition , [she]94-jane may not get over it immediately . It had better have happened to _ [you]93-elizabeth _ , [Lizzy]93-elizabeth ; [you]93-elizabeth would have laughed [yourself]93-elizabeth out of it sooner . But do [you]93-elizabeth think [she]94-jane would be prevailed on to go back with [us]3900-we ? Change of scene might be of service -- and perhaps a little relief from [home]3223-home , may be as useful as anything . "[141-mrs. gardiner]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was exceedingly pleased with this proposal , and felt persuaded of [[her]93-elizabeth sister]348-her sister 's ready acquiescence .

" [I]141-mrs. gardiner hope , "[141-mrs. gardiner] added [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner , " that no consideration with regard to [this young man]3902-this young man will influence [her]94-jane . [We]3900-we live in so different [a part of [town]285-town]3903-a part of town , all [our]3900-we connections are so different , and , as [you]93-elizabeth well know , [we]3900-we go out so little , that it is very improbable [they]3900-we should meet at all , unless [he]3902-this young man really comes to see [her]94-jane . "[141-mrs. gardiner]

" And _ that _ is quite impossible ; for [he]3902-this young man is now in the custody of [[his]3902-this young man friend]307-his friend , and [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy would no more suffer [him]3902-this young man to call on [Jane]94-jane in [such a part of [London]5-london]3906-such a part of london ! [[My]348-her sister dear aunt]3907-my dear aunt , how could [you]93-elizabeth think of it ? [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy may perhaps have _ heard _ of [such a place as [Gracechurch Street]33-gracechurch street]3908-such a place as gracechurch street , but [he]3902-this young man would hardly think a month 's ablution enough to cleanse [him]3902-this young man from its impurities , were [he]3902-this young man once to enter [it]3908-such a place as gracechurch street ; and depend upon it , [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley never stirs without [him]3902-this young man . "[348-her sister]

" So much the better . [I]141-mrs. gardiner hope [they]3909-they will not meet at all . But does not [Jane]3910-jane correspond with [the sister]3911-the sister ? _ [She]3910-jane _ will not be able to help calling . "[141-mrs. gardiner]

" [She]3910-jane will drop the acquaintance entirely . "[348-her sister]

But in spite of the certainty in which [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth affected to place this point , as well as the still more interesting one of [Bingley]90-mr. bingley 's being withheld from seeing [Jane]94-jane , [she]93-elizabeth felt a solicitude on the subject which convinced [her]93-elizabeth , on examination , that [she]93-elizabeth did not consider it entirely hopeless . It was possible , and sometimes [she]93-elizabeth thought it probable , that [his]90-mr. bingley affection might be re - animated , and the influence of [[his]90-mr. bingley friends]423-his friends successfully combated by the more natural influence of [Jane]94-jane 's attractions .

[Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth accepted [[her]93-elizabeth aunt]1226-her aunt 's invitation with pleasure ; and [the Bingleys]181-the bingleys were no otherwise in [her]93-elizabeth thoughts at the time , than as [she]93-elizabeth hoped that , by [Caroline]133-caroline 's not living in [the same house]3481-the same house with [[her]133-caroline brother]3126-her brother , [she]133-caroline might occasionally spend a morning with [her]133-caroline , without any danger of seeing [him]3126-her brother .

[The Gardiners]182-the gardiners staid a week at [Longbourn]7-longbourn ; and what with [the Philipses]157-the philipses , [the Lucases]113-the lucases , and [the officers]466-the officers , there was not a day without its engagement . [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet had so carefully provided for the entertainment of [[her]96-mrs. bennet brother]3126-her brother and [sister]3866-sister , that [they]1232-they did not once sit down to a family dinner . When the engagement was for [home]3223-home , [some of [the officers]466-the officers]1234-some of the officers always made part of it , of which [officers]470-officers [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham was sure to be one ; and on these occasions , [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner , rendered suspicious by [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth 's warm commendation of [him]3126-her brother , narrowly observed [them]1232-they both . Without supposing [them]1232-they , from what [she]93-elizabeth saw , to be very seriously in love , [their]1232-they preference of each other was plain enough to make [her]93-elizabeth a little uneasy ; and [she]93-elizabeth resolved to speak to [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth on the subject before [she]93-elizabeth left [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire , and represent to [her]93-elizabeth the imprudence of encouraging such an attachment .

To [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner , [Wickham]156-wickham had one means of affording pleasure , unconnected with [his]156-wickham general powers . About ten or a dozen years ago , before [her]93-elizabeth marriage , [she]93-elizabeth had spent a considerable time in [that very part of [Derbyshire]6-derbyshire]1237-that very part of derbyshire , to which [he]156-wickham belonged . [They]1232-they had , therefore , many acquaintance in common ; and , though [Wickham]156-wickham had been little there since the death of [[Darcy]100-mr. darcy 's father]1238-darcy 's father , five years before , it was yet in [his]156-wickham power to give [her]93-elizabeth fresher intelligence of [[her]93-elizabeth former friends]1239-her former friends , than [she]93-elizabeth had been in the way of procuring .

[Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner had seen [Pemberley]12-pemberley , and known [the late Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy by character perfectly well . Here consequently was an inexhaustible subject of discourse . In comparing [her]93-elizabeth recollection of [Pemberley]12-pemberley , with the minute description which [Wickham]156-wickham could give , and in bestowing [her]93-elizabeth tribute of praise on the character of [its late possessor]1240-its late possessor , [she]93-elizabeth was delighting both [him]156-wickham and [herself]93-elizabeth . On being made acquainted with the present [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy 's treatment of [him]100-mr. darcy , [she]93-elizabeth tried to remember something of [that gentleman]3311-that gentleman 's reputed disposition when quite [a lad]1242-a lad , which might agree with it , and was confident at last , that [she]93-elizabeth recollected having heard [Mr. Fitzwilliam Darcy]100-mr. darcy formerly spoken of as [a very proud , ill - natured boy]1243-a very proud , ill - natured boy .

CHAPTER III .

[Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner 's caution to [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was punctually and kindly given on the first favourable opportunity of speaking to [her]93-elizabeth alone ; after honestly telling [her]93-elizabeth what [she]141-mrs. gardiner thought , [she]141-mrs. gardiner thus went on :

" [You]93-elizabeth are too sensible [a girl]3548-a girl , [Lizzy]93-elizabeth , to fall in love merely because [you]93-elizabeth are warned against it ; and , therefore , [I]141-mrs. gardiner am not afraid of speaking openly . Seriously , [I]141-mrs. gardiner would have [you]93-elizabeth be on [your]93-elizabeth guard . Do not involve [yourself]93-elizabeth , or endeavour to involve [him]3311-that gentleman in an affection which the want of fortune would make so very imprudent . [I]141-mrs. gardiner have nothing to say against _ [him]3311-that gentleman _ ; [he]3311-that gentleman is [a most interesting young man]3913-a most interesting young man ; and if [he]3311-that gentleman had the fortune [he]3311-that gentleman ought to have , [I]141-mrs. gardiner should think [you]93-elizabeth could not do better . But as it is -- [you]93-elizabeth must not let [your]93-elizabeth fancy run away with [you]93-elizabeth . [You]93-elizabeth have sense , and [we]3914-we all expect [you]93-elizabeth to use it . [[Your]93-elizabeth father]3227-your father would depend on _ [your]93-elizabeth _ resolution and good conduct , [I]141-mrs. gardiner am sure . [You]93-elizabeth must not disappoint [[your]93-elizabeth father]3227-your father . "[141-mrs. gardiner]

" [[My]141-mrs. gardiner dear aunt]3907-my dear aunt , this is being serious indeed . "[141-mrs. gardiner]

" Yes , and [I]141-mrs. gardiner hope to engage [you]93-elizabeth to be serious likewise . "[141-mrs. gardiner]

" Well , then , [you]93-elizabeth need not be under any alarm . [I]141-mrs. gardiner will take care of [myself]141-mrs. gardiner , and of [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham too . [He]156-wickham shall not be in love with [me]141-mrs. gardiner , if [I]141-mrs. gardiner can prevent it . "[141-mrs. gardiner]

" [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , [you]93-elizabeth are not serious now . "[141-mrs. gardiner]

" [I]141-mrs. gardiner beg [your]93-elizabeth pardon . [I]141-mrs. gardiner will try again . At present [I]141-mrs. gardiner am not in love with [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham ; no , [I]141-mrs. gardiner certainly am not . But [he]156-wickham is , beyond all comparison , [the most agreeable man [I]141-mrs. gardiner ever saw]3918-the most agreeable man i ever saw -- and if [he]156-wickham becomes really attached to [me]141-mrs. gardiner -- [I]141-mrs. gardiner believe it will be better that [he]156-wickham should not . [I]141-mrs. gardiner see the imprudence of it.--Oh ! _ that _ abominable Mr. [Darcy!--My father]3919-darcy!--my father 's opinion of [me]141-mrs. gardiner does [me]141-mrs. gardiner the greatest honour ; and [I]141-mrs. gardiner should be miserable to forfeit it . [[My]141-mrs. gardiner father]3259-my father , however , is partial to [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham . In short , [[my]141-mrs. gardiner dear aunt]3907-my dear aunt , [I]141-mrs. gardiner should be very sorry to be the means of making any of [you]3907-my dear aunt unhappy ; but since [we]3922-we see every day that where there is affection , [young people]3169-young people are seldom withheld by immediate want of fortune , from entering into engagements with [each other]3157-each other , how can [I]141-mrs. gardiner promise to be wiser than so many of [[my]141-mrs. gardiner fellow creatures]3925-my fellow creatures if [I]141-mrs. gardiner am tempted , or how am [I]141-mrs. gardiner even to know that it would be wisdom to resist ? All that [I]141-mrs. gardiner can promise [you]3907-my dear aunt , therefore , is not to be in a hurry . [I]141-mrs. gardiner will not be in a hurry to believe [myself]141-mrs. gardiner [his]156-wickham first object . When [I]141-mrs. gardiner am in company with [him]156-wickham , [I]141-mrs. gardiner will not be wishing . In short , [I]141-mrs. gardiner will do [my]141-mrs. gardiner best . "[141-mrs. gardiner]

" Perhaps it will be as well , if [you]3907-my dear aunt discourage [his]156-wickham coming [here]3019-here so very often . At least , [you]3907-my dear aunt should not _ remind _ [[your]3907-my dear aunt Mother]3695-your mother of inviting [him]156-wickham . "[93-elizabeth]

" As [I]93-elizabeth did the other day , "[93-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , with a conscious smile ; " very true , it will be wise in [me]93-elizabeth to refrain from _ that _ . But do not imagine that [he]156-wickham is always here so often . It is on [your]3907-my dear aunt account that [he]156-wickham has been so frequently invited this week . [You]3907-my dear aunt know [[my]93-elizabeth mother]3230-my mother 's ideas as to the necessity of constant company for [[her]3230-my mother friends]330-her friends . But really , and upon [my]93-elizabeth honour , [I]93-elizabeth will try to do what [I]93-elizabeth think to be wisest ; and now , [I]93-elizabeth hope [you]3907-my dear aunt are satisfied . "[93-elizabeth]

[[Her]93-elizabeth aunt]1226-her aunt assured [her]93-elizabeth that [she]93-elizabeth was ; and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth having thanked [her]1226-her aunt for the kindness of [her]1226-her aunt hints , [they]1245-they parted ; a wonderful instance of advice being given on such a point , without being resented .

[Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins returned into [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire soon after [it]4-hertfordshire had been quitted by [the Gardiners]182-the gardiners and [Jane]94-jane ; but as [he]149-mr. collins took up [his]149-mr. collins abode with [the Lucases]113-the lucases , [his]149-mr. collins arrival was no great inconvenience to [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet . [His]149-mr. collins marriage was now fast approaching , and [she]96-mrs. bennet was at length so far resigned as to think it inevitable , and even repeatedly to say in an ill - natured tone that [she]96-mrs. bennet " _ wished _ [they]1248-they might be happy . "[96-mrs. bennet] Thursday was to be the wedding day , and on Wednesday [Miss Lucas]103-miss lucas paid [her]103-miss lucas farewell visit ; and when [she]103-miss lucas rose to take leave , [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , ashamed of [[her]93-elizabeth mother]261-her mother 's ungracious and reluctant good wishes , and sincerely affected [herself]93-elizabeth , accompanied [her]103-miss lucas out of [the room]271-the room . As [they]1248-they went down [stairs]529-stairs together , [Charlotte]114-charlotte said ,

" [I]261-her mother shall depend on hearing from [you]93-elizabeth very often , [Eliza]93-elizabeth . "[261-her mother]

" _ That _ [you]93-elizabeth certainly shall . "[261-her mother]

" And [I]261-her mother have another favour to ask . Will [you]93-elizabeth come and see [me]261-her mother ? "[261-her mother]

" [We]1248-they shall often meet , [I]261-her mother hope , in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire . "[261-her mother]

" [I]261-her mother am not likely to leave [Kent]18-kent for some time . Promise [me]261-her mother , therefore , to come to [Hunsford]16-hunsford . "[261-her mother]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth could not refuse , though [she]93-elizabeth foresaw little pleasure in the visit .

" [[My]114-charlotte father]3259-my father and [Maria]105-maria are to come to [me]114-charlotte in March , "[114-charlotte] added [Charlotte]114-charlotte , " and [I]114-charlotte hope [you]93-elizabeth will consent to be of [the party]3034-the party . Indeed , [Eliza]93-elizabeth , [you]93-elizabeth will be as welcome to [me]114-charlotte as either of [them]1255-them . "[114-charlotte]

The wedding took place ; [the bride]1250-the bride and [bridegroom]1251-bridegroom set off for [Kent]18-kent from [the church]3507-the church door , and [every body]324-every body had as much to say or to hear on the subject as usual . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth soon heard from [[her]93-elizabeth friend]418-her friend ; and [their]1255-them correspondence was as regular and frequent as it had ever been ; that it should be equally unreserved was impossible . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth could never address [her]418-her friend without feeling that all the comfort of intimacy was over , and , though determined not to slacken as [a correspondent]1256-a correspondent , it was for the sake of what had been , rather than what was . [Charlotte]114-charlotte 's first letters were received with a good deal of eagerness ; there could not but be curiosity to know how [she]114-charlotte would speak of [[her]114-charlotte new home]1257-her new home , how [she]114-charlotte would like [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine , and how happy [she]114-charlotte would dare pronounce [herself]114-charlotte to be ; though , when the letters were read , [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth felt that [Charlotte]114-charlotte expressed [herself]114-charlotte on every point exactly as [she]114-charlotte might have foreseen . [She]114-charlotte wrote cheerfully , seemed surrounded with comforts , and mentioned nothing which [she]114-charlotte could not praise . [The house]3026-the house , furniture , [neighbourhood]1259-neighbourhood , and [roads]1260-roads , were all to [her]114-charlotte taste , and [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine 's behaviour was most friendly and obliging . It was [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins 's picture of [Hunsford]16-hunsford and [Rosings]22-rosings rationally softened ; and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth perceived that [she]93-elizabeth must wait for [her]93-elizabeth own visit [there]325-there , to know the rest .

[Jane]94-jane had already written a few lines to [[her]94-jane sister]348-her sister to announce [their]1263-their safe arrival in [London]5-london ; and when [she]94-jane wrote again , [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth hoped it would be in [her]93-elizabeth power to say something of [the Bingleys]181-the bingleys .

[Her]93-elizabeth impatience for this second letter was as well rewarded as impatience generally is . [Jane]94-jane had been a week in [town]285-town , without either seeing or hearing from [Caroline]133-caroline . [She]94-jane accounted for it , however , by supposing that [her]94-jane last letter to [[her]94-jane friend from [Longbourn]7-longbourn]1265-her friend from longbourn , had by some accident been lost .

" [[My]94-jane aunt]3208-my aunt , "[94-jane] [she]94-jane continued , " is going to - morrow into [that part of [the town]1054-the town]3933-that part of the town , and [I]94-jane shall take the opportunity of calling in [Grosvenor]29-grosvenor - street . "[94-jane]

[She]94-jane wrote again when the visit was paid , and [she]94-jane had seen [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley . " [I]94-jane did not think [Caroline]133-caroline in spirits , "[94-jane] were [her]94-jane words , " but [she]133-caroline was very glad to see [me]94-jane , and reproached [me]94-jane for giving [her]133-caroline no notice of [my]94-jane coming to [London]5-london . [I]94-jane was right , therefore ; [my]94-jane last letter had never reached [her]133-caroline . [I]94-jane enquired after [[their]3935-their brother]359-their brother , of course . [He]359-their brother was well , but so much engaged with [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , that [they]3935-their scarcely ever saw [him]359-their brother . [I]94-jane found that [Miss Darcy]139-miss darcy was expected to dinner . [I]94-jane wish [I]94-jane could see [her]139-miss darcy . [My]94-jane visit was not long , as [Caroline]133-caroline and [Mrs. Hurst]101-mrs. hurst were going out . [I]94-jane dare say [I]94-jane shall soon see [them]3937-them here . "[94-jane]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth shook [her]93-elizabeth head over this letter . It convinced [her]93-elizabeth , that accident only could discover to [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley [[her]93-elizabeth sister]348-her sister 's being in [town]285-town .

Four weeks passed away , and [Jane]94-jane saw nothing of [him]90-mr. bingley . [She]94-jane endeavoured to persuade [herself]94-jane that [she]94-jane did not regret it ; but [she]94-jane could no longer be blind to [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley 's inattention . After waiting at [home]3223-home every morning for a fortnight , and inventing every evening a fresh excuse for [her]94-jane , [the visitor]1269-the visitor did at last appear ; but the shortness of [her]94-jane stay , and yet more , the alteration of [her]94-jane manner , would allow [Jane]94-jane to deceive [herself]94-jane no longer . The letter which [she]94-jane wrote on this occasion to [[her]94-jane sister]348-her sister , will prove what [she]94-jane felt .

" [[My]94-jane dearest]3231-my dearest [Lizzy]93-elizabeth will , [I]94-jane am sure , be incapable of triumphing in [her]93-elizabeth better judgment , at [my]94-jane expence , when [I]94-jane confess [myself]94-jane to have been entirely deceived in [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley 's regard for [me]94-jane . But , [[my]94-jane dear sister]3799-my dear sister , though the event has proved [you]3799-my dear sister right , do not think [me]94-jane obstinate if [I]94-jane still assert , that , considering what [her]93-elizabeth behaviour was , [my]94-jane confidence was as natural as [your]3799-my dear sister suspicion . [I]94-jane do not at all comprehend [her]93-elizabeth reason for wishing to be intimate with [me]94-jane , but if the same circumstances were to happen again , [I]94-jane am sure [I]94-jane should be deceived again . [Caroline]133-caroline did not return [my]94-jane visit till yesterday ; and not a note , not a line , did [I]94-jane receive in the mean time . When [she]93-elizabeth did come , it was very evident that [she]93-elizabeth had no pleasure in it ; [she]93-elizabeth made a slight , formal , apology , for not calling before , said not a word of wishing to see [me]94-jane again , and was in every respect so altered [a creature]3940-a creature , that when [she]93-elizabeth went away , [I]94-jane was perfectly resolved to continue the acquaintance no longer . [I]94-jane pity , though [I]94-jane can not help blaming [her]93-elizabeth . [She]93-elizabeth was very wrong in singling [me]94-jane out as [she]93-elizabeth did ; [I]94-jane can safely say , that every advance to intimacy began on [her]93-elizabeth side . But [I]94-jane pity [her]93-elizabeth , because [she]93-elizabeth must feel that [she]93-elizabeth has been acting wrong , and because [I]94-jane am very sure that anxiety for [[her]93-elizabeth brother]3126-her brother is the cause of it . [I]94-jane need not explain [myself]94-jane farther ; and though _ [we]3942-we _ know this anxiety to be quite needless , yet if [she]93-elizabeth feels it , it will easily account for [her]93-elizabeth behaviour to [me]94-jane ; and so deservedly dear as [he]3126-her brother is to [[his]3126-her brother sister]569-his sister , whatever anxiety [she]93-elizabeth may feel on [his]3126-her brother behalf , is natural and amiable . [I]94-jane can not but wonder , however , at [her]93-elizabeth having any such fears now , because , if [he]3126-her brother had at all cared about [me]94-jane , [we]3942-we must have met long , long ago . [He]3126-her brother knows of [my]94-jane being in [town]285-town , [I]94-jane am certain , from something [she]93-elizabeth said [herself]93-elizabeth ; and yet it should seem by [her]93-elizabeth manner of talking , as if [she]93-elizabeth wanted to persuade [herself]93-elizabeth that [he]3126-her brother is really partial to [Miss Darcy]139-miss darcy . [I]94-jane can not understand it . If [I]94-jane were not afraid of judging harshly , [I]94-jane should be almost tempted to say , that there is a strong appearance of duplicity in all this . But [I]94-jane will endeavour to banish every painful thought , and think only of what will make [me]94-jane happy , [your]3945-you affection , and the invariable kindness of [[my]94-jane dear uncle]3946-my dear uncle and [aunt]3947-aunt . Let [me]94-jane hear from [you]3945-you very soon . [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley said something of [his]3126-her brother never returning to [Netherfield]2-netherfield again , of giving up [the house]3026-the house , but not with any certainty . [We]3949-we had better not mention it . [I]94-jane am extremely glad that [you]3945-you have such pleasant accounts from [[our]3949-we friends]3950-our friends at [Hunsford]16-hunsford . Pray go to see [them]3950-our friends , with [Sir William]91-sir william and [Maria]105-maria . [I]94-jane am sure [you]3945-you will be very comfortable [there]325-there . "[94-jane]

" [Your]93-elizabeth 's , & c. "[94-jane]

This letter gave [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth some pain ; but [her]93-elizabeth spirits returned as [she]93-elizabeth considered that [Jane]94-jane would no longer be duped , by [the sister]3911-the sister at least . All expectation from [the brother]1272-the brother was now absolutely over . [She]93-elizabeth would not even wish for any renewal of [his]1272-the brother attentions . [His]1272-the brother character sunk on every review of it ; and as a punishment for [him]1272-the brother , as well as a possible advantage to [Jane]94-jane , [she]93-elizabeth seriously hoped [he]1272-the brother might really soon marry [[Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy 's sister]1273-mr. darcy 's sister , as , by [Wickham]156-wickham 's account , [she]93-elizabeth would make [him]1272-the brother abundantly regret what [he]1272-the brother had thrown away .

[Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner about this time reminded [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth of [her]141-mrs. gardiner promise concerning [that gentleman]3311-that gentleman , and required information ; and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth had such to send as might rather give contentment to [[her]93-elizabeth aunt]1226-her aunt than to [herself]93-elizabeth . [His]1272-the brother apparent partiality had subsided , [his]1272-the brother attentions were over , [he]1272-the brother was [the admirer of [some one else]1277-some one else]1276-the admirer of some one else . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was watchful enough to see it all , but [she]93-elizabeth could see it and write of it without material pain . [Her]93-elizabeth heart had been but slightly touched , and [her]93-elizabeth vanity was satisfied with believing that _ [she]93-elizabeth _ would have been [his]1272-the brother only choice , had fortune permitted it . The sudden acquisition of ten thousand pounds was the most remarkable charm of [the young lady]1278-the young lady , to whom [he]1272-the brother was now rendering [himself]1272-the brother agreeable ; but [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , less clear - sighted perhaps in [his]1272-the brother case than in [Charlotte]114-charlotte 's , did not quarrel with [him]1272-the brother for [his]1272-the brother wish of independence . Nothing , on the contrary , could be more natural ; and while able to suppose that it cost [him]1272-the brother a few struggles to relinquish [her]93-elizabeth , [she]93-elizabeth was ready to allow it a wise and desirable measure for both , and could very sincerely wish [him]1272-the brother happy .

All this was acknowledged to [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner ; and after relating the circumstances , [she]141-mrs. gardiner thus went on:--"I am now convinced , [[my]141-mrs. gardiner dear aunt]3907-my dear aunt , that [I]141-mrs. gardiner have never been much in love ; for had [I]141-mrs. gardiner really experienced that pure and elevating passion , [I]141-mrs. gardiner should at present detest [his]1272-the brother very name , and wish [him]1272-the brother all manner of evil . But [my]141-mrs. gardiner feelings are not only cordial towards _ [him]1272-the brother _ ; they are even impartial towards [Miss King]104-miss king . [I]141-mrs. gardiner can not find out that [I]141-mrs. gardiner hate [her]93-elizabeth at all , or that [I]141-mrs. gardiner am in the least unwilling to think [her]93-elizabeth [a very good sort of girl]3953-a very good sort of girl . There can be no love in all this . [My]141-mrs. gardiner watchfulness has been effectual ; and though [I]141-mrs. gardiner should certainly be a more interesting object to all [my]141-mrs. gardiner acquaintance , were [I]141-mrs. gardiner distractedly in love with [him]1272-the brother , [I]141-mrs. gardiner can not say that [I]141-mrs. gardiner regret [my]141-mrs. gardiner comparative insignificance . Importance may sometimes be purchased too dearly . [Kitty]97-lady catherine and [Lydia]95-lydia take [his]1272-the brother defection much more to heart than [I]141-mrs. gardiner do . [They]3954-they are young in the ways of [the world]323-the world , and not yet open to the mortifying conviction that [handsome young men]3956-handsome young men must have something to live on , as well as the plain . "[141-mrs. gardiner]

CHAPTER IV .

With no greater events than these in [the Longbourn family]748-the longbourn family , and otherwise diversified by little beyond the walks to [Meryton]9-meryton , sometimes dirty and sometimes cold , did January and [February]184-february pass away . March was to take [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth to [Hunsford]16-hunsford . [She]93-elizabeth had not at first thought very seriously of going thither ; but [Charlotte]114-charlotte , [she]93-elizabeth soon found , was depending on the plan , and [she]93-elizabeth gradually learned to consider it [herself]93-elizabeth with greater pleasure as well as greater certainty . [Absence]185-absence had increased [her]93-elizabeth desire of seeing [Charlotte]114-charlotte again , and weakened [her]93-elizabeth disgust of [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins . There was novelty in the scheme , and as , with [such a mother]1280-such a mother and [such uncompanionable sisters]1281-such uncompanionable sisters , [home]3223-home could not be faultless , a little change was not unwelcome for its own sake . The journey would moreover give [her]93-elizabeth a peep at [Jane]94-jane ; and , in short , as the time drew near , [she]93-elizabeth would have been very sorry for any delay . Every thing , however , went on smoothly , and was finally settled according to [Charlotte]114-charlotte 's first sketch . [She]114-charlotte was to accompany [Sir William]91-sir william and [[his]91-sir william second daughter]260-his second daughter . The improvement of spending a night in [London]5-london was added in time , and the plan became perfect as plan could be .

The only pain was in leaving [[her]114-charlotte father]264-her father , who would certainly miss [her]114-charlotte , and who , when it came to the point , so little liked [her]114-charlotte going , that [he]264-her father told [her]114-charlotte to write to [him]264-her father , and almost promised to answer [her]114-charlotte letter .

The farewell between [herself]114-charlotte and [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham was perfectly friendly ; on [his]156-wickham side even more . [His]156-wickham present pursuit could not make [him]156-wickham forget that [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth had been the first to excite and to deserve [his]156-wickham attention , the first to listen and to pity , the first to be admired ; and in [his]156-wickham manner of bidding [her]93-elizabeth adieu , wishing [her]93-elizabeth every enjoyment , reminding [her]93-elizabeth of what [she]93-elizabeth was to expect in [Lady Catherine de Bourgh]97-lady catherine , and trusting [their]1285-their opinion of [her]93-elizabeth -- [their]1285-their opinion of every body -- would always coincide , there was a solicitude , an interest which [she]114-charlotte felt must ever attach [her]114-charlotte to [him]156-wickham with a most sincere regard ; and [she]114-charlotte parted from [him]156-wickham convinced , that whether married or single , [he]156-wickham must always be [[her]114-charlotte model of the amiable and pleasing]1286-her model of the amiable and pleasing .

[[Her]114-charlotte fellow - travellers]1287-her fellow - travellers the next day , were not of a kind to make [her]114-charlotte think [him]156-wickham less agreeable . [Sir William Lucas]91-sir william , and [[his]91-sir william daughter]1127-his daughter [Maria]105-maria , [a good humoured girl]1289-a good humoured girl , but as empty - headed as [himself]91-sir william , had nothing to say that could be worth hearing , and were listened to with about as much delight as the rattle of the chaise . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth loved absurdities , but [she]93-elizabeth had known [Sir William]91-sir william 's too long . [He]91-sir william could tell [her]93-elizabeth nothing new of the wonders of [his]91-sir william presentation and knighthood ; and [his]91-sir william civilities were worn out like [his]91-sir william information .

It was a journey of only twenty - four miles , and [they]1290-they began it so early as to be in [Gracechurch - street]1291-gracechurch - street by noon . As [they]1290-they drove to [Mr. Gardiner]180-mr. gardiner 's door , [Jane]94-jane was at a drawing - room window watching [their]1290-they arrival ; when [they]1290-they entered [the passage]1292-the passage [she]94-jane was there to welcome [them]1290-they , and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , looking earnestly in [her]94-jane face , was pleased to see it healthful and lovely as ever . On the stairs were [a troop of [little boys]1294-little boys and [girls]3074-girls , whose eagerness for [[their]1293-a troop of little boys and girls , whose eagerness for their cousin 's appearance would not allow them to wait in the drawing - room , and whose shyness , as they had not seen her for a twelvemonth , prevented their coming lower cousin]694-their cousin 's appearance would not allow [them]1293-a troop of little boys and girls , whose eagerness for their cousin 's appearance would not allow them to wait in the drawing - room , and whose shyness , as they had not seen her for a twelvemonth , prevented their coming lower to wait in [the drawing - room]530-the drawing - room , and whose shyness , as [they]1293-a troop of little boys and girls , whose eagerness for their cousin 's appearance would not allow them to wait in the drawing - room , and whose shyness , as they had not seen her for a twelvemonth , prevented their coming lower had not seen [her]94-jane for a twelvemonth , prevented [their]1293-a troop of little boys and girls , whose eagerness for their cousin 's appearance would not allow them to wait in the drawing - room , and whose shyness , as they had not seen her for a twelvemonth , prevented their coming lower coming lower]1293-a troop of little boys and girls , whose eagerness for their cousin 's appearance would not allow them to wait in the drawing - room , and whose shyness , as they had not seen her for a twelvemonth , prevented their coming lower . All was joy and kindness . The day passed most pleasantly away ; the morning in bustle and shopping , and the evening at [one of [the theatres]1299-the theatres]1298-one of the theatres .

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth then contrived to sit by [[her]93-elizabeth aunt]1226-her aunt . [Their]1290-they first subject was [[her]93-elizabeth sister]348-her sister ; and [she]93-elizabeth was more grieved than astonished to hear , in reply to [her]93-elizabeth minute enquiries , that though [Jane]94-jane always struggled to support [her]94-jane spirits , there were periods of dejection . It was reasonable , however , to hope , that [they]1290-they would not continue long . [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner gave [her]94-jane the particulars also of [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley 's visit in [Gracechurch - street]1291-gracechurch - street , and repeated conversations occurring at different times between [Jane]94-jane and [herself]94-jane , which proved that [the former]347-the former had , from [her]347-the former heart , given up the acquaintance .

[Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner then rallied [[her]141-mrs. gardiner niece]1304-her niece on [Wickham]156-wickham 's desertion , and complimented [her]1304-her niece on bearing it so well .

" But , [[my]141-mrs. gardiner dear]3018-my dear [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , "[141-mrs. gardiner] [she]141-mrs. gardiner added , " what sort of [girl]3958-girl is [Miss King]104-miss king ? [I]141-mrs. gardiner should be sorry to think [[our]3959-our friend]3960-our friend mercenary . "[141-mrs. gardiner]

" Pray , [[my]1304-her niece dear aunt]3907-my dear aunt , what is the difference in matrimonial affairs , between [the mercenary]3962-the mercenary and the prudent motive ? Where does discretion end , and avarice begin ? Last Christmas [you]3907-my dear aunt were afraid of [his]3960-our friend marrying [me]1304-her niece , because it would be imprudent ; and now , because [he]3960-our friend is trying to get [a girl with only ten thousand pounds]3963-a girl with only ten thousand pounds , [you]3907-my dear aunt want to find out that [he]3960-our friend is [mercenary]3964-mercenary . "[1304-her niece]

" If [you]3907-my dear aunt will only tell [me]141-mrs. gardiner what sort of girl [Miss King]104-miss king is , [I]141-mrs. gardiner shall know what to think . "[141-mrs. gardiner]

" [She]104-miss king is [a very good kind of girl]3965-a very good kind of girl , [I]1304-her niece believe . [I]1304-her niece know no harm of [her]104-miss king . "[1304-her niece]

" But [he]3960-our friend paid [her]104-miss king not the smallest attention , till [[her]104-miss king grandfather]3966-her grandfather 's death made [her]104-miss king mistress of this fortune . "[141-mrs. gardiner]

" No -- why should [he]3960-our friend ? If it was not allowable for [him]3960-our friend to gain _ [my]1304-her niece _ affections , because [I]1304-her niece had no money , what occasion could there be for making love to [a girl whom [he]3960-our friend did not care about]3967-a girl whom he did not care about , and who was equally poor ? "[1304-her niece]

" But there seems indelicacy in directing [his]3960-our friend attentions towards [her]104-miss king , so soon after this event . "[141-mrs. gardiner]

" [A man in distressed circumstances]3968-a man in distressed circumstances has not time for all those elegant decorums which [other people]3860-other people may observe . If _ [she]104-miss king _ does not object to it , why should _ [we]3970-we _ ? "[1304-her niece]

" _ [Her]104-miss king _ not objecting , does not justify _ [him]3960-our friend _ . It only shews [her]104-miss king being deficient in something [herself]104-miss king -- sense or feeling . "[141-mrs. gardiner]

" Well , "[93-elizabeth] cried [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , " have it as [you]3960-our friend choose . _ [He]3960-our friend _ shall be [mercenary]3964-mercenary , and _ [she]104-miss king _ shall be foolish . "[93-elizabeth]

" No , [Lizzy]93-elizabeth , that is what [I]141-mrs. gardiner do _ not _ choose . [I]141-mrs. gardiner should be sorry , [you]93-elizabeth know , to think ill of [a young man who has lived so long in [Derbyshire]6-derbyshire]3972-a young man who has lived so long in derbyshire . "[141-mrs. gardiner]

" Oh ! if that is all , [I]93-elizabeth have a very poor opinion of [young men who live in [Derbyshire]6-derbyshire]3973-young men who live in derbyshire ; and [[their]3973-young men who live in derbyshire intimate friends who live in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire]3974-their intimate friends who live in hertfordshire are not much better . [I]93-elizabeth am sick of [them]3973-young men who live in derbyshire all . Thank Heaven ! [I]93-elizabeth am going to - morrow where [I]93-elizabeth shall find [a man who has not one agreeable quality]3975-a man who has not one agreeable quality , who has neither manner nor sense to recommend [him]3975-a man who has not one agreeable quality . [Stupid men]3976-stupid men are [the only ones worth knowing]3977-the only ones worth knowing , after all . "[93-elizabeth]

" Take care , [Lizzy]93-elizabeth ; that speech savours strongly of disappointment . "[141-mrs. gardiner]

Before [they]1305-we were separated by the conclusion of the play , [she]1306-she had the unexpected happiness of an invitation to accompany [[her]1306-she uncle]583-her uncle and [aunt]3947-aunt in a tour of pleasure which [they]1305-we proposed taking in the summer .

" [We]1305-we have not quite determined how far it shall carry [us]1305-we , "[141-mrs. gardiner] said [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner , " but perhaps to [the Lakes]34-the lakes . "[141-mrs. gardiner]

No scheme could have been more agreeable to [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , and [her]93-elizabeth acceptance of the invitation was most ready and grateful . " [[My]1306-she dear]3018-my dear , [dear aunt]3979-dear aunt , "[1306-she] [she]1306-she rapturously cried , " what delight ! what felicity ! [You]3979-dear aunt give [me]1306-she fresh life and vigour . Adieu to disappointment and spleen . What are [men]3391-men to rocks and [mountains]3981-mountains ? Oh ! what hours of transport [we]1305-we shall spend ! And when [we]1305-we _ do _ return , it shall not be like [other travellers]3982-other travellers , without being able to give one accurate idea of any thing . [We]1305-we _ will _ know where [we]1305-we have gone -- [we]1305-we _ will _ recollect what [we]1305-we have seen . [Lakes]3983-lakes , [mountains]3981-mountains , and [rivers]3985-rivers , shall not be jumbled together in [our]1305-we imaginations ; nor , when [we]1305-we attempt to describe any particular scene , will [we]1305-we begin quarrelling about its relative situation . Let _ [our]1305-we _ first effusions be less insupportable than those of the generality of [travellers]3986-travellers . "[1306-she]

CHAPTER V.

Every object in the next day 's journey was new and interesting to [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth ; and [her]93-elizabeth spirits were in a state for enjoyment ; for [she]93-elizabeth had seen [[her]93-elizabeth sister]348-her sister looking so well as to banish all fear for [her]93-elizabeth health , and the prospect of [her]93-elizabeth northern tour was a constant source of delight .

When [they]1310-they left [the high road]1311-the high road for [the lane]1087-the lane to [Hunsford]16-hunsford , every eye was in search of [the Parsonage]1313-the parsonage , and every turning expected to bring [it]1313-the parsonage in view . The paling of [Rosings Park]21-rosings park was [their]1310-they boundary on one side . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth smiled at the recollection of all that [she]93-elizabeth had heard of [[its]1313-the parsonage inhabitants]1314-its inhabitants .

At length [the Parsonage]1313-the parsonage was discernible . [The garden]1316-the garden sloping to [the road]1317-the road , [the house]3026-the house standing in [it]1316-the garden , the green pales and the laurel hedge , every thing declared [they]1310-they were arriving . [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins and [Charlotte]114-charlotte appeared at the door , and [the carriage]3221-the carriage stopped at the small gate , which led by a short gravel walk to [the house]3026-the house , amidst the nods and smiles of [the whole party]531-the whole party . In a moment [they]1310-they were all out of the chaise , rejoicing at the sight of [each other]3157-each other . [Mrs. Collins]186-mrs. collins welcomed [[her]186-mrs. collins friend]418-her friend with the liveliest pleasure , and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was more and more satisfied with coming , when [she]93-elizabeth found [herself]93-elizabeth so affectionately received . [She]93-elizabeth saw instantly that [[her]93-elizabeth cousin]3565-her cousin 's manners were not altered by [his]3565-her cousin marriage ; [his]3565-her cousin formal civility was just what it had been , and [he]3565-her cousin detained [her]93-elizabeth some minutes at the gate to hear and satisfy [his]3565-her cousin enquiries after all [[her]93-elizabeth family]905-her family . [They]1310-they were then , with no other delay than [his]3565-her cousin pointing out the neatness of the entrance , taken into [the house]3026-the house ; and as soon as [they]1310-they were in [the parlour]1327-the parlour , [he]3565-her cousin welcomed [them]1310-they a second time with ostentatious formality to [[his]3565-her cousin humble abode]1328-his humble abode , and punctually repeated all [[his]3565-her cousin wife]251-his wife 's offers of refreshment .

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was prepared to see [him]3565-her cousin in [his]3565-her cousin glory ; and [she]93-elizabeth could not help fancying that in displaying the good proportion of [the room]271-the room , [its]271-the room aspect and [its]271-the room furniture , [he]3565-her cousin addressed [himself]3565-her cousin particularly to [her]93-elizabeth , as if wishing to make [her]93-elizabeth feel what [she]93-elizabeth had lost in refusing [him]3565-her cousin . But though every thing seemed neat and comfortable , [she]93-elizabeth was not able to gratify [him]3565-her cousin by any sigh of repentance ; and rather looked with wonder at [[her]93-elizabeth friend]418-her friend that [she]93-elizabeth could have so cheerful an air , with such [a companion]1332-a companion . When [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins said any thing of which [[his]149-mr. collins wife]251-his wife might reasonably be ashamed , which certainly was not unseldom , [she]93-elizabeth involuntarily turned [her]93-elizabeth eye on [Charlotte]114-charlotte . Once or twice [she]93-elizabeth could discern a faint blush ; but in general [Charlotte]114-charlotte wisely did not hear . After sitting long enough to admire every article of furniture in [the room]271-the room , from the sideboard to the fender , to give an account of [their]1335-them journey and of all that had happened in [London]5-london , [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins invited [them]1335-them to take a stroll in [the garden]1316-the garden , which was large and well laid out , and to the cultivation of which [he]149-mr. collins attended [himself]149-mr. collins . To work in [[his]149-mr. collins garden]1337-his garden was one of [his]149-mr. collins most respectable pleasures ; and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth admired the command of countenance with which [Charlotte]114-charlotte talked of the healthfulness of the exercise , and owned [she]93-elizabeth encouraged it as much as possible . Here , leading the way through every walk and cross walk , and scarcely allowing [them]1335-them an interval to utter the praises [he]149-mr. collins asked for , every view was pointed out with a minuteness which left beauty entirely behind . [He]149-mr. collins could number [the fields]1338-the fields in every direction , and could tell how many trees there were in the most distant clump . But of all the views which [[his]149-mr. collins garden]1337-his garden , or which [the country]460-the country , or [the kingdom]3650-the kingdom could boast , none were to be compared with the prospect of Rosings , afforded by an opening in the trees that bordered [the park]1342-the park nearly opposite the front of [[his]149-mr. collins house]3127-his house . [It]1344-it was [a handsome modern building , well situated on rising ground]1345-a handsome modern building , well situated on rising ground .

From [[his]149-mr. collins garden]1337-his garden , [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins would have led [them]1335-them round [[his]149-mr. collins two meadows]1347-his two meadows , but [the ladies]269-the ladies not having shoes to encounter the remains of a white frost , turned back ; and while [Sir William]91-sir william accompanied [him]149-mr. collins , [Charlotte]114-charlotte took [[her]114-charlotte sister]348-her sister and [friend]3360-friend over [the house]3026-the house , extremely well pleased , probably , to have the opportunity of shewing [it]1337-his garden without [[her]114-charlotte husband]276-her husband 's help . [It]1337-his garden was rather small , but well built and convenient ; and every thing was fitted up and arranged with a neatness and consistency of which [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth gave [Charlotte]114-charlotte all the credit . When [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins could be forgotten , there was really a great air of comfort throughout , and by [Charlotte]114-charlotte 's evident enjoyment of it , [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth supposed [he]149-mr. collins must be often forgotten .

[She]93-elizabeth had already learnt that [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine was still in [the country]460-the country . It was spoken of again while [they]1354-us were at dinner , when [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins joining in , observed ,

" Yes , [Miss Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , [you]93-elizabeth will have the honour of seeing [Lady Catherine de Bourgh]97-lady catherine on the ensuing Sunday at [church]3987-church , and [I]149-mr. collins need not say [you]93-elizabeth will be delighted with [her]97-lady catherine . [She]97-lady catherine is all affability and condescension , and [I]149-mr. collins doubt not but [you]93-elizabeth will be honoured with some portion of [her]97-lady catherine notice when service is over . [I]149-mr. collins have scarcely any hesitation in saying that [she]97-lady catherine will include [you]93-elizabeth and [[my]149-mr. collins sister]3284-my sister [Maria]105-maria in every invitation with which [she]97-lady catherine honours [us]1354-us during [your]93-elizabeth stay [here]3019-here . [Her]97-lady catherine behaviour to [[my]149-mr. collins dear]3018-my dear [Charlotte]114-charlotte is charming . [We]1354-us dine at Rosings twice every week , and are never allowed to walk [home]3223-home . [[Her]97-lady catherine ladyship]677-her ladyship 's carriage is regularly ordered for [us]1354-us . [I]149-mr. collins _ should _ say , one of [[[her]97-lady catherine ladyship]677-her ladyship 's carriages]3994-her ladyship 's carriages , for [she]97-lady catherine has several . "[149-mr. collins]

" [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine is [a very respectable , sensible woman]3995-a very respectable , sensible woman indeed , "[114-charlotte] added [Charlotte]114-charlotte , " and [a most attentive neighbour]3996-a most attentive neighbour . "[114-charlotte]

" Very true , [[my]149-mr. collins dear]3018-my dear , that is exactly what [I]149-mr. collins say . [She]97-lady catherine is [the sort of woman whom one]3998-the sort of woman whom one can not regard with too much deference . "[149-mr. collins]

The evening was spent chiefly in talking over Hertfordshire news , and telling again what had been already written ; and when it closed , [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth in the solitude of [[her]93-elizabeth chamber]1355-her chamber had to meditate upon [Charlotte]114-charlotte 's degree of contentment , to understand [her]114-charlotte address in guiding , and composure in bearing with [[her]114-charlotte husband]276-her husband , and to acknowledge that it was all done very well . [She]93-elizabeth had also to anticipate how [her]114-charlotte visit would pass , the quiet tenor of [their]1357-their usual employments , the vexatious interruptions of [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins , and the gaieties of [their]1357-their intercourse with Rosings . A lively imagination soon settled it all .

About the middle of the next day , as [she]93-elizabeth was in [[her]93-elizabeth room]501-her room getting ready for a walk , a sudden noise below seemed to speak [the whole house]1359-the whole house in confusion ; and after listening a moment , [she]93-elizabeth heard [somebody]3579-somebody running up [stairs]529-stairs in a violent hurry , and calling loudly after [her]93-elizabeth . [She]93-elizabeth opened the door , and met [Maria]105-maria in [the landing place]1362-the landing place , who , breathless with agitation , cried out ,

" Oh , [my]3579-somebody dear [Eliza]93-elizabeth ! pray make haste and come into [the dining - room]709-the dining - room , for there is such a sight to be seen ! [I]3579-somebody will not tell [you]93-elizabeth what it is . Make haste , and come down this moment . "[3579-somebody]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth asked questions in vain ; [Maria]105-maria would tell [her]93-elizabeth nothing more , and down [they]1357-their ran into [the dining - room]709-the dining - room , which fronted [the lane]1087-the lane , in quest of this wonder ; it was [two ladies]1365-two ladies stopping in a low phaeton at the garden gate .

" And is this all ? "[93-elizabeth] cried [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth . " [I]93-elizabeth expected at least that the pigs were got into [the garden]1316-the garden , and here is nothing but [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine and [[her]97-lady catherine daughter]475-her daughter ! "[93-elizabeth]

" La ! [[my]105-maria dear]3018-my dear , "[105-maria] said [Maria]105-maria quite shocked at the mistake , " it is not [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine . [The old lady]4003-the old lady is [Mrs. Jenkinson]170-mrs. jenkinson , who lives with [them]1357-their . The other is [Miss De Bourgh]152-miss de bourgh . Only look at [her]152-miss de bourgh . [She]152-miss de bourgh is quite a little creature . Who would have thought [she]152-miss de bourgh could be so thin and small ! "[105-maria]

" [She]152-miss de bourgh is abominably rude to keep [Charlotte]114-charlotte out of doors in all this wind . Why does [she]152-miss de bourgh not come in ? "[93-elizabeth]

" Oh ! [Charlotte]114-charlotte says , [she]114-charlotte hardly ever does . It is the greatest of favours when [Miss De Bourgh]152-miss de bourgh comes in . "[105-maria]

" [I]93-elizabeth like [her]152-miss de bourgh appearance , "[93-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , struck with other ideas . " [She]152-miss de bourgh looks sickly and cross.--Yes , [she]152-miss de bourgh will do for [him]91-sir william very well . [She]152-miss de bourgh will make [him]91-sir william [a very proper wife]4004-a very proper wife . "[93-elizabeth]

[Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins and [Charlotte]114-charlotte were both standing at the gate in conversation with [the ladies]269-the ladies ; and [Sir William]91-sir william , to [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth 's high diversion , was stationed in the doorway , in earnest contemplation of the greatness before [him]91-sir william , and constantly bowing whenever [Miss De Bourgh]152-miss de bourgh looked that way .

At length there was nothing more to be said ; [the ladies]269-the ladies drove on , and [the others]517-the others returned into [the house]3026-the house . [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins no sooner saw [the two girls]575-the two girls than [he]149-mr. collins began to congratulate [them]575-the two girls on [their]575-the two girls good fortune , which [Charlotte]114-charlotte explained by letting [them]575-the two girls know that [the whole party]531-the whole party was asked to dine at Rosings the next day .

[CHAPTER VI .

Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins 's triumph in consequence of this invitation was complete . The power of displaying the grandeur of [[his]149-mr. collins patroness]717-his patroness to [[his]149-mr. collins wondering visitors]1373-his wondering visitors , and of letting [them]1373-his wondering visitors see [her]717-his patroness civility towards [himself]149-mr. collins and [[his]149-mr. collins wife]251-his wife , was exactly what [he]149-mr. collins had wished for ; and that an opportunity of doing it should be given so soon , was such an instance of [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine 's condescension as [he]149-mr. collins knew not how to admire enough .

" [I]149-mr. collins confess , "[149-mr. collins] said [he]149-mr. collins , " that [I]149-mr. collins should not have been at all surprised by [[her]97-lady catherine Ladyship]677-her ladyship 's asking [us]4006-us on Sunday to drink tea and spend the evening at Rosings . [I]149-mr. collins rather expected , from [my]149-mr. collins knowledge of [her]97-lady catherine affability , that it would happen . But who could have foreseen such an attention as this ? Who could have imagined that [we]4006-us should receive an invitation to dine [there]325-there ( an invitation moreover including [the whole party]531-the whole party ) so immediately after [your]1375-they arrival ! "[149-mr. collins]

" [I]91-sir william am the less surprised at what has happened , "[91-sir william] replied [Sir William]91-sir william , " from that knowledge of what the manners of the great really are , which [my]91-sir william situation in life has allowed [me]91-sir william to acquire . About [the Court]4009-the court , such instances of elegant breeding are not uncommon . "[91-sir william]

Scarcely any thing was talked of the whole day or next morning , but [their]1375-they visit to Rosings . [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins was carefully instructing [them]1375-they in what [they]1375-they were to expect , that the sight of [such rooms]1376-such rooms , so many [servants]1377-servants , and so splendid a dinner might not wholly overpower [them]1375-they .

When [the ladies]269-the ladies were separating for the toilette , [he]149-mr. collins said to [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth ,

" Do not make [yourself]93-elizabeth uneasy , [[my]149-mr. collins dear cousin]3712-my dear cousin , about [your]93-elizabeth apparel . [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine is far from requiring that elegance of dress in [us]1375-they , which becomes [herself]97-lady catherine and [daughter]4011-daughter . [I]149-mr. collins would advise [you]93-elizabeth merely to put on whatever of [your]93-elizabeth clothes is superior to the rest , there is no occasion for any thing more . [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine will not think the worse of [you]93-elizabeth for being simply dressed . [She]97-lady catherine likes to have the distinction of rank preserved . "[149-mr. collins]

While [they]1375-they were dressing , [he]149-mr. collins came two or three times to [their]1375-they different doors , to recommend [their]1375-they being quick , as [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine very much objected to be kept waiting for [her]97-lady catherine dinner.--Such formidable accounts of [[her]97-lady catherine Ladyship]677-her ladyship , and [her]97-lady catherine manner of living , quite frightened [Maria Lucas]105-maria , who had been little used to company , and [she]97-lady catherine looked forward to [her]97-lady catherine introduction at Rosings , with as much apprehension , as [[her]97-lady catherine father]264-her father had done to [his]264-her father presentation at [St. James]11-st. james 's .

As the weather was fine , [they]1375-they had a pleasant walk of about half a mile across [the park.--Every park]1381-the park.--every park has [its]1381-the park.--every park beauty and [its]1381-the park.--every park prospects ; and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth saw much to be pleased with , though [she]93-elizabeth could not be in such raptures as [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins expected the scene to inspire , and was but slightly affected by [his]149-mr. collins enumeration of the windows in front of [the house]3026-the house , and [his]149-mr. collins relation of what the glazing altogether had originally cost [Sir Lewis De Bourgh]150-sir lewis de bourgh .

When [they]1375-they ascended the steps to [the hall]708-the hall , [Maria]105-maria 's alarm was every moment increasing , and even [Sir William]91-sir william did not look perfectly calm.--Elizabeth 's courage did not fail [her]105-maria . [She]105-maria had heard nothing of [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine that spoke [her]97-lady catherine awful from any extraordinary talents or miraculous virtue , and the mere stateliness of money and rank , [she]105-maria thought [she]105-maria could witness without trepidation .

From [the entrance hall]1384-the entrance hall , of which [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins pointed out , with a rapturous air , the fine proportion and finished ornaments , [they]1375-they followed [the servants]715-the servants through [an anti - chamber]1386-an anti - chamber , to [the room where [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine]1387-the room where lady catherine , [[her]97-lady catherine daughter]475-her daughter , and [Mrs. Jenkinson]170-mrs. jenkinson were [sitting.--Her Ladyship]187-sitting.--her ladyship , with great condescension , arose to receive [them]1375-they ; and as [Mrs. Collins]186-mrs. collins had settled it with [[her]186-mrs. collins husband]276-her husband that the office of introduction should be [her]186-mrs. collins 's , it was performed in a proper manner , without any of those apologies and thanks which [he]276-her husband would have thought necessary .

In spite of having been at [[St. James]11-st. james 's]397-st. james 's , [Sir William]91-sir william was so completely awed , by the grandeur surrounding [him]91-sir william , that [he]91-sir william had but just courage enough to make a very low bow , and take [his]91-sir william seat without saying a word ; and [[his]91-sir william daughter]1127-his daughter , frightened almost out of [her]1127-his daughter senses , sat on the edge of [her]1127-his daughter chair , not knowing which way to look . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth found [herself]93-elizabeth quite equal to the scene , and could observe [the three ladies]1392-the three ladies before [her]93-elizabeth composedly.--Lady [Catherine]97-lady catherine was [a tall , large woman]1393-a tall , large woman , with strongly - marked features , which might once have been handsome . [Her]97-lady catherine air was not conciliating , nor was [her]97-lady catherine manner of receiving them , such as to make [[her]97-lady catherine visitors]1394-her visitors forget [their]1394-her visitors inferior rank . [She]97-lady catherine was not rendered formidable by silence ; but whatever [she]97-lady catherine said , was spoken in so authoritative a tone , as marked [her]97-lady catherine self - importance , and brought [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham immediately to [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth 's mind ; and from the observation of the day altogether , [she]93-elizabeth believed [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine to be exactly what [he]156-wickham had represented .

When , after examining [the mother]412-the mother , in whose countenance and deportment [she]93-elizabeth soon found some resemblance of [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , [she]93-elizabeth turned [her]93-elizabeth eyes on [the daughter]1396-the daughter , [she]93-elizabeth could almost have joined in [Maria]105-maria 's astonishment , at [her]1396-the daughter being so thin , and so small . There was neither in figure nor face , any likeness between [the ladies]269-the ladies . [Miss De Bourgh]152-miss de bourgh was pale and sickly ; [her]152-miss de bourgh features , though not plain , were insignificant ; and [she]152-miss de bourgh spoke very little , except in a low voice , to [Mrs. Jenkinson]170-mrs. jenkinson , in whose appearance there was nothing remarkable , and who was entirely engaged in listening to what [she]152-miss de bourgh said , and placing a screen in the proper direction before [her]152-miss de bourgh eyes .

After sitting a few minutes , [they]269-the ladies were all sent to one of the windows , to admire the view , [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins attending [them]269-the ladies to point out [its]1398-its beauties , and [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine kindly informing [them]269-the ladies that it was much better worth looking at in the summer .

The dinner was exceedingly handsome , and there were [all the servants]1399-all the servants , and all the articles of plate which [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins had promised ; and , as [he]149-mr. collins had likewise foretold , [he]149-mr. collins took [his]149-mr. collins seat at the bottom of the table , by [[her]97-lady catherine ladyship]677-her ladyship 's desire , and looked as if [he]149-mr. collins felt that life could furnish nothing greater.--He carved , and ate , and praised with delighted alacrity ; and every dish was commended , first by [him]149-mr. collins , and then by [Sir William]91-sir william , who was now enough recovered to echo whatever [[his]91-sir william son in law]1401-his son in law said , in a manner which [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth wondered [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine could bear . But [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine seemed gratified by [their]269-the ladies excessive admiration , and gave most gracious smiles , especially when any dish on the table proved a novelty to [them]269-the ladies . The party did not supply much conversation . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was ready to speak whenever there was an opening , but [she]93-elizabeth was seated between [Charlotte]114-charlotte and [Miss De Bourgh]152-miss de bourgh -- the former of whom was engaged in listening to [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine , and [the latter]499-the latter said not a word to [her]93-elizabeth all dinner time . [Mrs. Jenkinson]170-mrs. jenkinson was chiefly employed in watching how little [Miss De Bourgh]152-miss de bourgh ate , pressing [her]93-elizabeth to try some other dish , and fearing [she]93-elizabeth were indisposed . [Maria]105-maria thought speaking out of the question , and [the gentlemen]311-the gentlemen did nothing but eat and admire .

When [the ladies]269-the ladies returned to [the drawing - room]530-the drawing - room , there was little to be done but to hear [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine talk , which [she]97-lady catherine did without any intermission till coffee came in , delivering [her]97-lady catherine opinion on every subject in so decisive a manner as proved that [she]97-lady catherine was not used to have [her]97-lady catherine judgment controverted . [She]93-elizabeth enquired into [Charlotte]114-charlotte 's domestic concerns familiarly and minutely , and gave [her]114-charlotte a great deal of advice , as to the management of [them]1406-them all ; told [her]114-charlotte how every thing ought to be regulated in [so small a family as [[her]114-charlotte 's]1408-her 's]1407-so small a family as her 's , and instructed [her]114-charlotte as to the care of [her]114-charlotte cows and [[her]114-charlotte poultry]1409-her poultry . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth found that nothing was beneath [this great Lady]1410-this great lady 's attention , which could furnish [her]114-charlotte with an occasion of dictating to [others]3123-others . In the intervals of [her]97-lady catherine discourse with [Mrs. Collins]186-mrs. collins , [she]97-lady catherine addressed a variety of questions to [Maria]105-maria and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , but especially to [the latter , of whose connections [she]97-lady catherine knew the least , and who [she]97-lady catherine observed to [Mrs. Collins]186-mrs. collins]1412-the latter , of whose connections she knew the least , and who she observed to mrs. collins , was [a very genteel , pretty kind of girl]1413-a very genteel , pretty kind of girl . [She]97-lady catherine asked [her]114-charlotte at different times , how many [sisters]3563-sisters [she]97-lady catherine had , whether [they]3563-sisters were older or younger than [herself]97-lady catherine , whether any of [them]3563-sisters were likely to be married , whether [they]3563-sisters were handsome , where [they]3563-sisters had been educated , what carriage [[her]97-lady catherine father]264-her father kept , and what had been [[her]97-lady catherine mother]261-her mother 's maiden name?--Elizabeth felt all the impertinence of [her]97-lady catherine questions , but answered them very composedly.--Lady [Catherine]97-lady catherine then observed ,

" [[Your]97-lady catherine father]3227-your father 's estate is entailed on [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins , [I]97-lady catherine think . For [your]97-lady catherine sake , "[97-lady catherine] turning to [Charlotte]114-charlotte , " [I]97-lady catherine am glad of it ; but otherwise [I]97-lady catherine see no occasion for entailing estates from the female line.--It was not thought necessary in [Sir Lewis de Bourgh]150-sir lewis de bourgh 's family.--Do [you]97-lady catherine play and sing , [Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth ? "[97-lady catherine]

" A little . "[261-her mother]

" Oh ! then -- some time or other [we]4013-we shall be happy to hear [you]97-lady catherine . [Our]4013-we instrument is a capital one , probably superior to----You shall try it some day.--Do [[your]97-lady catherine sisters]3082-your sisters play and sing ? "[97-lady catherine]

" [One of [them]3082-your sisters]3042-one of them does . "[261-her mother]

" Why did not [you]97-lady catherine all learn?--You ought all to have learned . [The Miss Webbs]188-the miss webbs all play , and [[their]188-the miss webbs father]267-their father has not so good an income as your's.--Do [you]97-lady catherine draw ? "[97-lady catherine]

" No , not at all . "[261-her mother]

" What , none of [you]97-lady catherine ? "[97-lady catherine]

" Not one . "[261-her mother]

" That is very strange . But [I]97-lady catherine suppose [you]97-lady catherine had no opportunity . [[Your]97-lady catherine mother]3695-your mother should have taken [you]97-lady catherine to [town]285-town every spring for the benefit of [masters]4019-masters . "[97-lady catherine]

" [[My]261-her mother mother]3230-my mother would have had no objection , but [[my]261-her mother father]3259-my father hates [London]5-london . "[261-her mother]

" Has [[your]97-lady catherine governess]4022-your governess left [you]97-lady catherine ? "[97-lady catherine]

" [We]4023-we never had [any governess]4024-any governess . "[261-her mother]

" [No governess]4025-no governess ! How was that possible ? [Five daughters brought up at [home]3223-home without [a governess!--I]4028-a governess!--i]4026-five daughters brought up at home without a governess!--i never heard of such a thing . [[Your]97-lady catherine mother]3695-your mother must have been quite a slave to [your]97-lady catherine education . "[97-lady catherine]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth could hardly help smiling , as [she]93-elizabeth assured [her]93-elizabeth that had not been the case .

" Then , who taught [you]97-lady catherine ? who attended to [you]97-lady catherine ? Without [a governess]4030-a governess [you]97-lady catherine must have been neglected . "[97-lady catherine]

" Compared with [some families]4031-some families , [I]97-lady catherine believe [we]4023-we were ; but such of [us]4023-we as wished to learn , never wanted the means . [We]4023-we were always encouraged to read , and had all [the masters that were necessary]4032-the masters that were necessary . [Those who chose to be idle]4033-those who chose to be idle , certainly might . "[97-lady catherine]

" Aye , no doubt ; but that is what [a governess]4030-a governess will prevent , and if [I]97-lady catherine had known [[your]97-lady catherine mother]3695-your mother , [I]97-lady catherine should have advised [her]3695-your mother most strenuously to engage one . [I]97-lady catherine always say that nothing is to be done in education without steady and regular instruction , and [nobody]3098-nobody but [a governess]4030-a governess can give it . It is wonderful how many families [I]97-lady catherine have been the means of supplying in that way . [I]97-lady catherine am always glad to get [a young person]4038-a young person well placed out . [Four nieces of [Mrs. Jenkinson]170-mrs. jenkinson]4039-four nieces of mrs. jenkinson are most delightfully situated through [my]97-lady catherine means ; and it was but the other day , that [I]97-lady catherine recommended [another young person]4040-another young person , who was merely accidentally mentioned to [me]97-lady catherine , and [the family]432-the family are quite delighted with [her]4040-another young person . [Mrs. Collins]186-mrs. collins , did [I]97-lady catherine tell [you]186-mrs. collins of [Lady Metcalfe]189-lady metcalfe 's calling yesterday to thank [me]97-lady catherine ? [She]189-lady metcalfe finds [Miss Pope]190-miss pope a treasure . ' [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine , ' said [she]97-lady catherine , ' [you]97-lady catherine have given [me]97-lady catherine a treasure . ' Are any of [[your]97-lady catherine younger sisters]4042-your younger sisters out , [Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth ? "[97-lady catherine]

" Yes , [Ma'am]4043-ma'am , all . "[97-lady catherine]

" All!--What , [all five]4044-all five out at once ? Very odd!--And [you]4043-ma'am only [the second.--The younger ones]4045-the second.--the younger ones out before [the elder]4046-the elder are [married!--Your younger sisters]4047-married!--your younger sisters must be very young ? "[97-lady catherine]

" Yes , [[my]97-lady catherine youngest]4048-my youngest is not sixteen . Perhaps _ [she]4048-my youngest _ is full young to be much in company . But really , [Ma'am]120-ma'am , [I]97-lady catherine think it would be very hard upon [younger sisters]4049-younger sisters , that [they]4049-younger sisters should not have [their]4049-younger sisters share of society and amusement because [the elder]4046-the elder may not have the means or inclination to marry [early.--The last born]4051-early.--the last born has as good a right to the pleasures of youth , as the first . And to be kept back on _ such _ a motive!--I think it would not be very likely to promote sisterly affection or delicacy of mind . "[97-lady catherine]

" Upon [my]677-her ladyship word , "[677-her ladyship] said [[her]1417-her Ladyship]677-her ladyship , " [you]4043-ma'am give [your]4043-ma'am opinion very decidedly for [so young a person.--Pray]4052-so young a person.--pray , what is [your]4043-ma'am age ? "[677-her ladyship]
