" With [three younger sisters]4053-three younger sisters grown up , "[93-elizabeth] replied [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth smiling , " [[your]4043-ma'am Ladyship]4054-your ladyship can hardly expect [me]93-elizabeth to own it . "[93-elizabeth]

[Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine seemed quite astonished at not receiving a direct answer ; and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth suspected [herself]93-elizabeth to be the first creature who had ever dared to trifle with so much dignified impertinence .

" [You]97-lady catherine can not be more than twenty , [I]311-the gentlemen am sure,--therefore [you]97-lady catherine need not conceal [your]97-lady catherine age . "[311-the gentlemen]

" [I]311-the gentlemen am not one and twenty . "[311-the gentlemen]

When [the gentlemen]311-the gentlemen had joined [them]311-the gentlemen , and tea was over , the card tables were placed . [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine , [Sir William]91-sir william , and [Mr.]1420-mr. and [Mrs. Collins]186-mrs. collins sat down to quadrille ; and as [Miss De Bourgh]152-miss de bourgh chose to play at cassino , [the two girls]575-the two girls had the honour of assisting [Mrs. Jenkinson]170-mrs. jenkinson to make up [her]170-mrs. jenkinson party . [Their]575-the two girls table was superlatively stupid . Scarcely a syllable was uttered that did not relate to the game , except when [Mrs. Jenkinson]170-mrs. jenkinson expressed [her]170-mrs. jenkinson fears of [Miss De Bourgh]152-miss de bourgh 's being too hot or too cold , or having too much or too little light . A great deal more passed at the other table . [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine was generally speaking -- stating the mistakes of [the three others]1422-the three others , or relating some anecdote of [herself]97-lady catherine . [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins was employed in agreeing to every thing [[her]97-lady catherine Ladyship]677-her ladyship said , thanking [her]97-lady catherine for every fish [he]149-mr. collins won , and apologising if [he]149-mr. collins thought [he]149-mr. collins won too many . [Sir William]91-sir william did not say much . [He]91-sir william was storing [his]91-sir william memory with anecdotes and noble names .

When [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine and [[her]97-lady catherine daughter]475-her daughter had played as long as [they]575-the two girls chose , the tables were broke up , [the carriage]3221-the carriage was offered to [Mrs. Collins]186-mrs. collins , gratefully accepted , and immediately ordered . [The party]3034-the party then gathered round the fire to hear [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine determine what weather [they]3034-the party were to have on the morrow . From these instructions [they]3034-the party were summoned by the arrival of [the coach]3225-the coach , and with many speeches of thankfulness on [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins 's side , and as many bows on [Sir William]91-sir william 's , [they]3034-the party departed . As soon as [they]3034-the party had driven from the door , [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was called on by [[her]93-elizabeth cousin]3565-her cousin , to give [her]93-elizabeth opinion of all that [she]93-elizabeth had seen at Rosings , which , for [Charlotte]114-charlotte 's sake , [she]93-elizabeth made more favourable than it really was . But [her]93-elizabeth commendation , though costing [her]93-elizabeth some trouble , could by no means satisfy [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins , and [he]149-mr. collins was very soon obliged to take [her]93-elizabeth [Ladyship]187-sitting.--her ladyship 's praise into [his]149-mr. collins own hands .

CHAPTER VII .

[Sir William]91-sir william staid only a week at [Hunsford]16-hunsford ; but [his]91-sir william visit was long enough to convince [him]91-sir william of [[his]91-sir william daughter]1127-his daughter 's being most comfortably settled , and of [her]1127-his daughter possessing such [a husband]3741-a husband and such [a neighbour]1431-a neighbour as were not often met with . While [Sir William]91-sir william was with [them]1432-them , [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins devoted [his]149-mr. collins mornings to driving [him]91-sir william out in [[his]149-mr. collins gig]1433-his gig , and shewing [him]91-sir william [the country]460-the country ; but when [he]149-mr. collins went away , [the whole family]331-the whole family returned to [their]331-the whole family usual employments , and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was thankful to find that [they]1432-them did not see more of [[her]93-elizabeth cousin]3565-her cousin by the alteration , for the chief of the time between breakfast and dinner was now passed by [him]3565-her cousin either at work in [the garden]1316-the garden , or in reading and writing , and looking out of window in [[his]3565-her cousin own book room]1438-his own book room , which fronted [the road]1317-the road . [The room in which [the ladies]269-the ladies sat]1440-the room in which the ladies sat was backwards . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth at first had rather wondered that [Charlotte]114-charlotte should not prefer [the dining - parlour]528-the dining - parlour for common use ; it was [a better sized room]1443-a better sized room , and had a pleasanter aspect ; but [she]93-elizabeth soon saw that [[her]93-elizabeth friend]418-her friend had an excellent reason for what [she]93-elizabeth did , for [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins would undoubtedly have been much less in [[his]149-mr. collins own apartment]1445-his own apartment , had [they]1446-they sat in one equally lively ; and [she]93-elizabeth gave [Charlotte]114-charlotte credit for the arrangement .

From [the drawing - room]530-the drawing - room [they]1446-they could distinguish nothing in [the lane]1087-the lane , and were indebted to [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins for the knowledge of what carriages went along , and how often especially [Miss De Bourgh]152-miss de bourgh drove by in [her]152-miss de bourgh phaeton , which [he]149-mr. collins never failed coming to inform [them]1446-they of , though it happened almost every day . [She]93-elizabeth not unfrequently stopped at [the Parsonage]1313-the parsonage , and had a few minutes ' conversation with [Charlotte]114-charlotte , but was scarcely ever prevailed on to get out .

Very few days passed in which [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins did not walk to [Rosings]22-rosings , and not many in which [[his]149-mr. collins wife]251-his wife did not think it necessary to go likewise ; and till [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth recollected that there might be other family livings to be disposed of , [she]93-elizabeth could not understand the sacrifice of so many hours . Now and then , [they]1446-they were honoured with a call from [[her]93-elizabeth Ladyship]677-her ladyship , and nothing escaped [her]93-elizabeth observation that was passing in [the room]271-the room during these visits . [She]93-elizabeth examined into [their]1446-they employments , looked at [their]1446-they work , and advised [them]1446-they to do it differently ; found fault with the arrangement of the furniture , or detected [the housemaid]1453-the housemaid in negligence ; and if [she]93-elizabeth accepted any refreshment , seemed to do it only for the sake of finding out that [Mrs. Collins]186-mrs. collins 's joints of meat were too large for [[her]93-elizabeth family]905-her family .

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth soon perceived that though [this great lady]1410-this great lady was not in the commission of the peace for [the county]1456-the county , [she]1410-this great lady was [a most active magistrate in [[her]1410-this great lady own parish]1458-her own parish]1457-a most active magistrate in her own parish , the minutest concerns of which were carried to [her]1410-this great lady by [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins ; and whenever [any of [the cottagers]1460-the cottagers]1459-any of the cottagers were disposed to be quarrelsome , discontented or too poor , [she]93-elizabeth sallied forth into [the village]339-the village to settle [their]1459-any of the cottagers differences , silence [their]1459-any of the cottagers complaints , and scold [them]1459-any of the cottagers into harmony and plenty .

The entertainment of dining at [Rosings]22-rosings was repeated about twice a week ; and , allowing for the loss of [Sir William]91-sir william , and there being only one card table in the evening , every such entertainment was the counterpart of the first . [Their]1462-their other engagements were few ; as the style of living of [the neighbourhood]3040-the neighbourhood in general , was beyond [the Collinses]191-the collinses ' reach . This however was no evil to [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , and upon the whole [she]93-elizabeth spent [her]93-elizabeth time comfortably enough ; there were half hours of pleasant conversation with [Charlotte]114-charlotte , and the weather was so fine for the time of year , that [she]93-elizabeth had often great enjoyment out of doors . [Her]93-elizabeth favourite walk , and where [she]93-elizabeth frequently went while [the others]517-the others were calling on [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine , was along [the open grove which edged that side of [the park]1342-the park]1465-the open grove which edged that side of the park , where there was [a nice sheltered path]1467-a nice sheltered path , which [no one]3275-no one seemed to value but [herself]93-elizabeth , and where [she]93-elizabeth felt beyond the reach of [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine 's curiosity .

In this quiet way , the first fortnight of [her]93-elizabeth visit soon passed away . Easter was approaching , and the week preceding it , was to bring an addition to [the family]432-the family at [Rosings]22-rosings , which in so small a circle must be important . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth had heard soon after [her]93-elizabeth arrival , that [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy was expected [there]325-there in the course of a few weeks , and though there were not many of [her]93-elizabeth acquaintance whom [she]93-elizabeth did not prefer , [his]100-mr. darcy coming would furnish one comparatively new to look at in [their]1471-their Rosings parties , and [she]93-elizabeth might be amused in seeing how hopeless [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley 's designs on [him]100-mr. darcy were , by [his]100-mr. darcy behaviour to [[his]100-mr. darcy cousin]727-his cousin , for whom [he]100-mr. darcy was evidently destined by [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine ; who talked of [his]100-mr. darcy coming with the greatest satisfaction , spoke of [him]100-mr. darcy in terms of the highest admiration , and seemed almost angry to find that [he]100-mr. darcy had already been frequently seen by [Miss Lucas]103-miss lucas and [herself]97-lady catherine .

[His]100-mr. darcy arrival was soon known at [the Parsonage]1313-the parsonage , for [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins was walking the whole morning within view of [the lodges]1474-the lodges opening into [Hunsford Lane]35-hunsford lane , in order to have the earliest assurance of [it]1475-it ; and after making [his]149-mr. collins bow as [the carriage]3221-the carriage turned into [the Park]1342-the park , hurried [home]3223-home with the great intelligence . On the following morning [he]149-mr. collins hastened to [Rosings]22-rosings to pay [his]149-mr. collins respects . There were [two nephews of [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine]1479-two nephews of lady catherine to require [them]1479-two nephews of lady catherine , for [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy had brought with [him]100-mr. darcy [a Colonel Fitzwilliam , the younger son of [[his]100-mr. darcy uncle]1481-his uncle]1480-a colonel fitzwilliam , the younger son of his uncle , [Lord ----]1482-lord ---- and to the great surprise of [all the party]1483-all the party , when [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins returned [the gentlemen]311-the gentlemen accompanied [him]100-mr. darcy . [Charlotte]114-charlotte had seen [them]311-the gentlemen from [[[her]114-charlotte husband]276-her husband 's room]1486-her husband 's room , crossing [the road]1317-the road , and immediately running into the other , told [the girls]3033-the girls what an honour [they]3033-the girls might expect , adding ,

" [I]1491-colonel fitzwilliam , who led the way may thank [you]3033-the girls , [Eliza]93-elizabeth , for this piece of civility . [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy would never have come so soon to wait upon [me]1491-colonel fitzwilliam , who led the way . "[1491-colonel fitzwilliam , who led the way]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth had scarcely time to disclaim all right to the compliment , before [their]311-the gentlemen approach was announced by the door - bell , and shortly afterwards [the three gentlemen]1489-the three gentlemen entered [the room]271-the room . [Colonel Fitzwilliam , who led the way]1491-colonel fitzwilliam , who led the way , was about thirty , not handsome , but in person and address most truly [the gentleman]306-the gentleman . [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy looked just as [he]100-mr. darcy had been used to look in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire , paid [his]100-mr. darcy compliments , with [his]100-mr. darcy usual reserve , to [Mrs. Collins]186-mrs. collins ; and whatever might be [his]100-mr. darcy feelings towards [[her]186-mrs. collins friend]418-her friend , met [her]186-mrs. collins with every appearance of composure . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth merely curtseyed to [him]100-mr. darcy , without saying a word .

[Colonel Fitzwilliam]192-colonel fitzwilliam entered into conversation directly with the readiness and ease of [a well - bred man]1494-a well - bred man , and talked very pleasantly ; but [[his]192-colonel fitzwilliam cousin]727-his cousin , after having addressed a slight observation on [the house]3026-the house and [garden]1497-garden to [Mrs. Collins]186-mrs. collins , sat for some time without speaking to [any body]3670-any body . At length , however , [his]100-mr. darcy civility was so far awakened as to enquire of [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth after the health of [[her]93-elizabeth family]905-her family . [She]93-elizabeth answered [him]100-mr. darcy in the usual way , and after a moment 's pause , added ,

" [[My]93-elizabeth eldest sister]4055-my eldest sister has been in [town]285-town these three months . Have [you]100-mr. darcy never happened to see [her]4055-my eldest sister [there]325-there ? "[93-elizabeth]

[She]93-elizabeth was perfectly sensible that [he]100-mr. darcy never had ; but [she]93-elizabeth wished to see whether [he]100-mr. darcy would betray any consciousness of what had passed between [the Bingleys]181-the bingleys and [Jane]94-jane ; and [she]93-elizabeth thought [he]100-mr. darcy looked a little confused as [he]100-mr. darcy answered that [he]100-mr. darcy had never been so fortunate as to meet [Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth . The subject was pursued no farther , and [the gentlemen]311-the gentlemen soon afterwards went away .

CHAPTER VIII .

[Colonel Fitzwilliam]192-colonel fitzwilliam 's manners were very much admired at [the parsonage]1313-the parsonage , and [the ladies]269-the ladies all felt that [he]192-colonel fitzwilliam must add considerably to the pleasure of [their]269-the ladies engagements at Rosings . It was some days , however , before [they]269-the ladies received any invitation thither , for while there were [visitors]1147-visitors in [the house]3026-the house , [they]269-the ladies could not be necessary ; and it was not till Easter - day , almost a week after [the gentlemen]311-the gentlemen 's arrival , that [they]269-the ladies were honoured by such an attention , and then [they]269-the ladies were merely asked on leaving [church]3987-church to come [there]325-there in the evening . For the last week [they]269-the ladies had seen very little of either [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine or [[her]97-lady catherine daughter]475-her daughter . [Colonel Fitzwilliam]192-colonel fitzwilliam had called at [the parsonage]1313-the parsonage more than once during the time , but [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy [they]269-the ladies had only seen at [church]3987-church .

The invitation was accepted of course , and at a proper hour [they]269-the ladies joined the party in [[Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine 's drawing - room]1511-lady catherine 's drawing - room . [[Her]97-lady catherine ladyship]677-her ladyship received [them]269-the ladies civilly , but it was plain that [their]269-the ladies company was by no means so acceptable as when [she]677-her ladyship could get [nobody else]1513-nobody else ; and [she]677-her ladyship was , in fact , almost engrossed by [[her]677-her ladyship nephews]1514-her nephews , speaking to [them]1514-her nephews , especially to [Darcy]100-mr. darcy , much more than to [any other person in [the room]271-the room]1515-any other person in the room .

[Colonel Fitzwilliam]192-colonel fitzwilliam seemed really glad to see [them]269-the ladies ; any thing was a welcome relief to [him]192-colonel fitzwilliam at Rosings ; and [[Mrs. Collins]186-mrs. collins 's pretty friend]1517-mrs. collins 's pretty friend had moreover caught [his]192-colonel fitzwilliam fancy very much . [He]192-colonel fitzwilliam now seated [himself]192-colonel fitzwilliam by [her]677-her ladyship , and talked so agreeably of [Kent]18-kent and [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire , of travelling and staying at [home]3223-home , of new books and music , that [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth had never been half so well entertained in [that room]1519-that room before ; and [they]269-the ladies conversed with so much spirit and flow , as to draw the attention of [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine [herself]97-lady catherine , as well as of [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy . _ [His]192-colonel fitzwilliam _ eyes had been soon and repeatedly turned towards [them]269-the ladies with a look of curiosity ; and that [[her]677-her ladyship ladyship]677-her ladyship after a while shared the feeling , was more openly acknowledged , for [she]677-her ladyship did not scruple to call out ,

" What is that [you]100-mr. darcy are saying , [Fitzwilliam]192-colonel fitzwilliam ? What is it [you]100-mr. darcy are talking of ? What are [you]100-mr. darcy telling [Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth ? Let [me]677-her ladyship hear what it is . "[677-her ladyship]

" [We]269-the ladies are speaking of music , [Madam]3285-madam , "[100-mr. darcy] said [he]100-mr. darcy , when no longer able to avoid a reply .

" Of music ! Then pray speak aloud . It is of all subjects [my]677-her ladyship delight . [I]677-her ladyship must have [my]677-her ladyship share in the conversation , if [you]100-mr. darcy are speaking of music . There are [few people in [England]3-england]4059-few people in england , [I]677-her ladyship suppose , who have more true enjoyment of music than [myself]677-her ladyship , or a better natural taste . If [I]677-her ladyship had ever learnt , [I]677-her ladyship should have been [a great proficient]4060-a great proficient . And so would [Anne]160-anne , if [her]160-anne health had allowed [her]160-anne to apply . [I]677-her ladyship am confident that [she]160-anne would have performed delightfully . How does [Georgiana]175-georgiana get on , [Darcy]175-georgiana ? "[677-her ladyship]

[Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy spoke with affectionate praise of [[his]100-mr. darcy sister]569-his sister 's proficiency .

" [I]97-lady catherine am very glad to hear such a good account of [her]175-georgiana , "[97-lady catherine] said [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine ; " and pray tell [her]175-georgiana from [me]97-lady catherine , that [she]175-georgiana can not expect to excel , if [she]175-georgiana does not practise a great deal . "[97-lady catherine]

" [I]100-mr. darcy assure [you]97-lady catherine , [Madam]193-madam , "[100-mr. darcy] [he]100-mr. darcy replied , " that [she]175-georgiana does not need such advice . [She]175-georgiana practises very constantly . "[100-mr. darcy]

" So much the better . It can not be done too much ; and when [I]97-lady catherine next write to [her]175-georgiana , [I]97-lady catherine shall charge [her]175-georgiana not to neglect it on any account . [I]97-lady catherine often tell [young ladies]3267-young ladies , that no excellence in music is to be acquired , without constant practice . [I]97-lady catherine have told [Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth several times , that [she]175-georgiana will never play really well , unless [she]175-georgiana practises more ; and though [Mrs. Collins]186-mrs. collins has no instrument , [she]175-georgiana is very welcome , as [I]97-lady catherine have often told [her]175-georgiana , to come to Rosings every day , and play on the piano - forte in [[Mrs. Jenkinson]170-mrs. jenkinson 's room]4062-mrs. jenkinson 's room . [She]175-georgiana would be in [nobody]3098-nobody 's way , [you]4064-you know , in [that part of [the house]3026-the house]4065-that part of the house . "[97-lady catherine]

[Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy looked a little ashamed of [[his]100-mr. darcy aunt]945-his aunt 's ill breeding , and made no answer .

When coffee was over , [Colonel Fitzwilliam]192-colonel fitzwilliam reminded [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth of having promised to play to [him]100-mr. darcy ; and [she]93-elizabeth sat down directly to the instrument . [He]100-mr. darcy drew a chair near [her]93-elizabeth . [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine listened to half a song , and then talked , as before , to [[her]97-lady catherine other nephew]1523-her other nephew ; till [the latter]499-the latter walked away from [her]97-lady catherine , and moving with [his]100-mr. darcy usual deliberation towards the piano - forte , stationed [himself]100-mr. darcy so as to command a full view of [the fair performer]1525-the fair performer 's countenance . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth saw what [he]100-mr. darcy was doing , and at the first convenient pause , turned to [him]100-mr. darcy with an arch smile , and said ,

" [You]100-mr. darcy mean to frighten [me]100-mr. darcy , [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , by coming in all this state to hear [me]100-mr. darcy ? But [I]100-mr. darcy will not be alarmed though [[your]100-mr. darcy sister]3152-your sister _ does _ play so well . There is a stubbornness about [me]100-mr. darcy that never can bear to be frightened at the will of [others]3123-others . [My]100-mr. darcy courage always rises with every attempt to intimidate [me]100-mr. darcy . "[100-mr. darcy]

" [I]100-mr. darcy shall not say that [you]93-elizabeth are mistaken , "[100-mr. darcy] [he]100-mr. darcy replied , " because [you]93-elizabeth could not really believe [me]100-mr. darcy to entertain any design of alarming [you]93-elizabeth ; and [I]100-mr. darcy have had the pleasure of [your]93-elizabeth acquaintance long enough to know , that [you]93-elizabeth find great enjoyment in occasionally professing opinions which in fact are not [your]93-elizabeth own . "[100-mr. darcy]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth laughed heartily at this picture of [herself]93-elizabeth , and said to [Colonel Fitzwilliam]192-colonel fitzwilliam , " [[Your]100-mr. darcy cousin]4069-your cousin will give [you]100-mr. darcy a very pretty notion of [me]93-elizabeth , and teach [you]100-mr. darcy not to believe a word [I]93-elizabeth say . [I]93-elizabeth am particularly unlucky in meeting with [a person so well able to expose [my]93-elizabeth real character , in [a part of [the world]323-the world]4071-a part of the world , where [I]93-elizabeth had hoped to pass [myself]93-elizabeth off with some degree of credit]4070-a person so well able to expose my real character , in a part of the world , where i had hoped to pass myself off with some degree of credit . Indeed , [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , it is very ungenerous in [you]100-mr. darcy to mention all that [you]100-mr. darcy knew to [my]93-elizabeth disadvantage in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire -- and , give [me]93-elizabeth leave to say , very impolitic too -- for it is provoking [me]93-elizabeth to retaliate , and such things may come out , as will shock [[your]100-mr. darcy relations]4073-your relations to hear . "[93-elizabeth]

" [I]1526-he am not afraid of [you]100-mr. darcy , "[1526-he] said [he]1526-he , smilingly .

" Pray let [me]192-colonel fitzwilliam hear what [you]100-mr. darcy have to accuse [him]1526-he of , "[192-colonel fitzwilliam] cried [Colonel Fitzwilliam]192-colonel fitzwilliam . " [I]192-colonel fitzwilliam should like to know how [he]1526-he behaves among [strangers]4074-strangers . "[192-colonel fitzwilliam]

" [You]100-mr. darcy shall hear then -- but prepare [yourself]100-mr. darcy for something very dreadful . The first time of [my]93-elizabeth ever seeing [him]1526-he in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire , [you]100-mr. darcy must know , was at a ball -- and at this ball , what do [you]100-mr. darcy think [he]1526-he did ? [He]1526-he danced only four dances ! [I]93-elizabeth am sorry to pain [you]100-mr. darcy -- but so it was . [He]1526-he danced only four dances , though [gentlemen]328-gentlemen were scarce ; and , to [my]93-elizabeth certain knowledge , [more than one young lady]4076-more than one young lady was sitting down in want of [a partner]3183-a partner . [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , [you]100-mr. darcy can not deny the fact . "[93-elizabeth]

" [I]192-colonel fitzwilliam had not at that time the honour of knowing [any lady in the assembly]4078-any lady in the assembly beyond [[my]192-colonel fitzwilliam own party]4079-my own party . "[192-colonel fitzwilliam]

" True ; and [nobody]3098-nobody can ever be introduced in [a ball room]4081-a ball room . Well , [Colonel Fitzwilliam]192-colonel fitzwilliam , what do [I]93-elizabeth play next ? [My]93-elizabeth fingers wait [your]100-mr. darcy orders . "[93-elizabeth]

" Perhaps , "[100-mr. darcy] said [Darcy]100-mr. darcy , " [I]100-mr. darcy should have judged better , had [I]100-mr. darcy sought an introduction , but [I]100-mr. darcy am ill qualified to recommend [myself]100-mr. darcy to [strangers]4074-strangers . "[100-mr. darcy]

" Shall [we]4083-we ask [[your]93-elizabeth cousin]4069-your cousin the reason of this ? "[93-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , still addressing [Colonel Fitzwilliam]192-colonel fitzwilliam . " Shall [we]4083-we ask [him]4069-your cousin why [a man of sense and education]4085-a man of sense and education , and who has lived in [the world]323-the world , is ill qualified to recommend [himself]4069-your cousin to [strangers]4074-strangers ? "[93-elizabeth]

" [I]192-colonel fitzwilliam can answer [your]93-elizabeth question , "[192-colonel fitzwilliam] said [Fitzwilliam]192-colonel fitzwilliam , " without applying to [him]4069-your cousin . It is because [he]4069-your cousin will not give [himself]4069-your cousin the trouble . "[192-colonel fitzwilliam]

" [I]100-mr. darcy certainly have not the talent which [some people]4088-some people possess , "[100-mr. darcy] said [Darcy]100-mr. darcy , " of conversing easily with those [I]100-mr. darcy have never seen before . [I]100-mr. darcy can not catch [their]4088-some people tone of conversation , or appear interested in [their]4088-some people concerns , as [I]100-mr. darcy often see done . "[100-mr. darcy]

" [My]93-elizabeth fingers , "[93-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , " do not move over this instrument in the masterly manner which [I]93-elizabeth see [so many women]4089-so many women 's do . [They]4088-some people have not the same force or rapidity , and do not produce the same expression . But then [I]93-elizabeth have always supposed it to be [my]93-elizabeth own fault -- because [I]93-elizabeth would not take the trouble of practising . It is not that [I]93-elizabeth do not believe _ [my]93-elizabeth _ fingers as capable as [any other woman]4090-any other woman 's of superior execution . "[93-elizabeth]

[Darcy]100-mr. darcy smiled and said , " [You]93-elizabeth are perfectly right . [You]93-elizabeth have employed [your]93-elizabeth time much better . [No one]3275-no one admitted to the privilege of hearing [you]93-elizabeth , can think any thing wanting . [We]1527-they neither of [us]1527-they perform to [strangers]4074-strangers . "[100-mr. darcy]

Here [they]1527-they were interrupted by [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine , who called out to know what [they]1527-they were talking of . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth immediately began playing again . [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine approached , and , after listening for a few minutes , said to [Darcy]100-mr. darcy ,

" [Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth would not play at all amiss , if [she]93-elizabeth practised more , and could have the advantage of [a London master]4093-a london master . [She]93-elizabeth has a very good notion of fingering , though [her]93-elizabeth taste is not equal to [Anne]160-anne 's . [Anne]160-anne would have been [a delightful performer]4094-a delightful performer , had [her]93-elizabeth health allowed [her]93-elizabeth to learn . "[97-lady catherine]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth looked at [Darcy]160-anne to see how cordially [he]100-mr. darcy assented to [[his]100-mr. darcy cousin]727-his cousin 's praise ; but neither at that moment nor at any other could [she]93-elizabeth discern any symptom of love ; and from the whole of [his]100-mr. darcy behaviour to [Miss De Bourgh]152-miss de bourgh [she]93-elizabeth derived this comfort for [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley , that [he]100-mr. darcy might have been just as likely to marry _ [her]102-miss bingley _ , had [she]102-miss bingley been [[his]100-mr. darcy relation]1529-his relation .

[Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine continued [her]97-lady catherine remarks on [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth 's performance , mixing with [them]1530-them many instructions on execution and taste . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth received them with all the forbearance of civility ; and at the request of [the gentlemen]311-the gentlemen remained at the instrument till [[her]93-elizabeth Ladyship]677-her ladyship 's carriage was ready to take [them]311-the gentlemen all [home]3223-home .

CHAPTER IX .

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was sitting by [herself]93-elizabeth the next morning , and writing to [Jane]94-jane , while [Mrs. Collins]186-mrs. collins and [Maria]105-maria were gone on business into [the village]339-the village , when [she]93-elizabeth was startled by a ring at the door , the certain signal of [a visitor]1535-a visitor . As [she]93-elizabeth had heard [no carriage]1536-no carriage , [she]93-elizabeth thought it not unlikely to be [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine , and under that apprehension was putting away [her]93-elizabeth half - finished letter that [she]93-elizabeth might escape all impertinent questions , when the door opened , and to [her]93-elizabeth very great surprise , [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , and [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy only , entered [the room]271-the room .

[He]100-mr. darcy seemed astonished too on finding [her]93-elizabeth alone , and apologised for [his]100-mr. darcy intrusion , by letting [her]93-elizabeth know that [he]100-mr. darcy had understood all [the ladies]269-the ladies to be within .

[They]1539-they then sat down , and when [her]93-elizabeth enquiries after Rosings were made , seemed in danger of sinking into total silence . It was absolutely necessary , therefore , to think of something , and in this emergence recollecting _ when _ [she]93-elizabeth had seen [him]100-mr. darcy last in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire , and feeling curious to know what [he]100-mr. darcy would say on the subject of [their]1539-they hasty departure , [she]93-elizabeth observed ,

" How very suddenly [you]100-mr. darcy all quitted [Netherfield]2-netherfield last November , [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy ! It must have been a most agreeable surprise to [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley to see [you]100-mr. darcy all after [him]100-mr. darcy so soon ; for , if [I]93-elizabeth recollect right , [he]100-mr. darcy went but the day before . [He]100-mr. darcy and [[his]100-mr. darcy sisters]303-his sisters were well , [I]93-elizabeth hope , when [you]100-mr. darcy left [London]5-london . "[93-elizabeth]

" Perfectly so -- [I]93-elizabeth thank [you]100-mr. darcy . "[93-elizabeth]

[She]93-elizabeth found that [she]93-elizabeth was to receive no other answer -- and , after a short pause , added ,

" [I]93-elizabeth think [I]93-elizabeth have understood that [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley has not much idea of ever returning to [Netherfield]2-netherfield again ? "[93-elizabeth]

" [I]93-elizabeth have never heard [him]90-mr. bingley say so ; but it is probable that [he]90-mr. bingley may spend very little of [his]90-mr. bingley time [there]325-there in future . [He]90-mr. bingley has [many friends]4097-many friends , and [he]90-mr. bingley is at a time of life when [friends]3767-friends and engagements are continually increasing . "[93-elizabeth]

" If [he]90-mr. bingley means to be but little at [Netherfield]2-netherfield , it would be better for [the neighbourhood]3040-the neighbourhood that [he]90-mr. bingley should give up [the place]3023-the place entirely , for then [we]4101-we might possibly get [a settled family]4102-a settled family [there]325-there . But perhaps [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley did not take [the house]3026-the house so much for the convenience of [the neighbourhood]3040-the neighbourhood as for [his]90-mr. bingley own , and [we]4101-we must expect [him]90-mr. bingley to keep or quit [it]3026-the house on the same principle . "[93-elizabeth]

" [I]100-mr. darcy should not be surprised , "[100-mr. darcy] said [Darcy]100-mr. darcy , " if [he]90-mr. bingley were to give it up , as soon as any eligible purchase offers . "[100-mr. darcy]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth made no answer . [She]93-elizabeth was afraid of talking longer of [[his]1540-i friend]307-his friend ; and , having nothing else to say , was now determined to leave the trouble of finding a subject to [him]1540-i .

[He]1540-i took the hint , and soon began with , " [This]4106-this seems [a very comfortable house]4107-a very comfortable house . [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine , [I]1540-i believe , did a great deal to [it]4106-this when [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins first came to [Hunsford]16-hunsford . "[1540-i]

" [I]100-mr. darcy believe [she]97-lady catherine did -- and [I]100-mr. darcy am sure [she]97-lady catherine could not have bestowed [her]97-lady catherine kindness on a more grateful object . "[100-mr. darcy]

" [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins appears very fortunate in [his]149-mr. collins choice of [a wife]244-a wife . "[1540-i]

" Yes , indeed ; [[his]149-mr. collins friends]423-his friends may well rejoice in [his]149-mr. collins having met with [one of [the very few sensible women who would have accepted [him]149-mr. collins , or have made [him]149-mr. collins happy if [they]423-his friends had]4111-the very few sensible women who would have accepted him , or have made him happy if they had . [[My]100-mr. darcy friend]3352-my friend]4110-one of the very few sensible women who would have accepted him , or have made him happy if they had . my friend has an excellent understanding -- though [I]100-mr. darcy am not certain that [I]100-mr. darcy consider [her]3352-my friend marrying [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins as the wisest thing [she]3352-my friend ever did . [She]3352-my friend seems perfectly happy , however , and in a prudential light , it is certainly a very good match for [her]3352-my friend . "[100-mr. darcy]

" It must be very agreeable to [her]3352-my friend to be settled within so easy a distance of [[her]3352-my friend own family]4113-her own family and [friends]3767-friends . "[1540-i]

" An easy distance do [you]100-mr. darcy call it ? It is nearly fifty miles . "[100-mr. darcy]

" And what is fifty miles of [good road]4115-good road ? Little more than half a day 's journey . Yes , [I]1540-i call [it]4116-it [a _ very _ easy distance]4117-a _ very _ easy distance . "[1540-i]

" [I]93-elizabeth should never have considered the distance as one of the _ advantages _ of the match , "[93-elizabeth] cried [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth . " [I]93-elizabeth should never have said [Mrs. Collins]186-mrs. collins was settled _ near _ [[her]186-mrs. collins family]905-her family . "[93-elizabeth]

" It is a proof of [your]100-mr. darcy own attachment to [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire . Any thing beyond [the very neighbourhood of [Longbourn]7-longbourn]4119-the very neighbourhood of longbourn , [I]1542-he suppose , would appear far . "[1542-he]

As [he]1542-he spoke there was a sort of smile , which [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth fancied [she]93-elizabeth understood ; [he]1542-he must be supposing [her]93-elizabeth to be thinking of [Jane]94-jane and [Netherfield]2-netherfield , and [she]93-elizabeth blushed as [she]93-elizabeth answered ,

" [I]93-elizabeth do not mean to say that [a woman]3036-a woman may not be settled too near [[her]3036-a woman family]905-her family . The far and the near must be relative , and depend on many varying circumstances . Where there is fortune to make the expence of travelling unimportant , distance becomes no evil . But that is not the case _ here _ . [Mr.]4122-mr. and [Mrs. Collins]186-mrs. collins have a comfortable income , but not such a one as will allow of frequent journeys -- and [I]93-elizabeth am persuaded [[my]93-elizabeth friend]3352-my friend would not call [herself]3352-my friend _ near _ [[her]3352-my friend family]905-her family under less than _ half _ the present distance . "[93-elizabeth]

[Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy drew [his]100-mr. darcy chair a little towards [her]93-elizabeth , and said , " _ [You]93-elizabeth _ can not have a right to such very strong local attachment . _ [You]93-elizabeth _ can not have been always at [Longbourn]7-longbourn . "[100-mr. darcy]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth looked surprised . [The gentleman]306-the gentleman experienced some change of feeling ; [he]100-mr. darcy drew back [his]100-mr. darcy chair , took a newspaper from the table , and , glancing over it , said , in a colder voice ,

" Are [you]93-elizabeth pleased with [Kent]18-kent ? "[100-mr. darcy]

A short dialogue on the subject of [the country]460-the country ensued , on either side calm and concise -- and soon put an end to by the entrance of [Charlotte]114-charlotte and [[her]114-charlotte sister]348-her sister , just returned from [their]1546-their walk . [The t?te-?-t?te]1547-the t?te-?-t?te surprised [them]1546-their . [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy related the mistake which had occasioned [his]100-mr. darcy intruding on [Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth , and after sitting a few minutes longer without saying much to any body , went away .

" What can be the meaning of this ! "[114-charlotte] said [Charlotte]114-charlotte , as soon as [he]100-mr. darcy was gone . " [[My]114-charlotte dear]3018-my dear [Eliza]93-elizabeth [he]100-mr. darcy must be in love with [you]3018-my dear , or [he]100-mr. darcy would never have called on [us]1546-their in this familiar way . "[114-charlotte]

But when [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth told of [his]100-mr. darcy silence , it did not seem very likely , even to [Charlotte]114-charlotte 's wishes , to be the case ; and after various conjectures , [they]1546-their could at last only suppose [his]100-mr. darcy visit to proceed from the difficulty of finding any thing to do , which was the more probable from the time of year . All field sports were over . Within doors there was [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine , books , and a billiard table , but [gentlemen]328-gentlemen can not be always within doors ; and in the nearness of [the Parsonage]1313-the parsonage , or the pleasantness of the walk to [it]1313-the parsonage , or of [the people who lived in [it]1313-the parsonage]1550-the people who lived in it , [the two cousins]1551-the two cousins found a temptation from this period of walking thither almost every day . [They]1551-the two cousins called at various times of the morning , sometimes separately , sometimes together , and now and then accompanied by [[their]1551-the two cousins aunt]455-their aunt . It was plain to [them]1551-the two cousins all that [Colonel Fitzwilliam]192-colonel fitzwilliam came because [he]192-colonel fitzwilliam had pleasure in [their]1551-the two cousins society , a persuasion which of course recommended [him]192-colonel fitzwilliam still more ; and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was reminded by [her]93-elizabeth own satisfaction in being with [him]192-colonel fitzwilliam , as well as by [his]192-colonel fitzwilliam evident admiration of [her]93-elizabeth , of [[her]93-elizabeth former favourite]1553-her former favourite [George Wickham]165-george wickham ; and though , in comparing [them]1551-the two cousins , [she]93-elizabeth saw there was less captivating softness in [Colonel Fitzwilliam]192-colonel fitzwilliam 's manners , [she]93-elizabeth believed [he]192-colonel fitzwilliam might have the best informed mind .

But why [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy came so often to [the Parsonage]1313-the parsonage , it was more difficult to understand . It could not be for [society]1555-society , as [he]100-mr. darcy frequently sat there ten minutes together without opening [his]100-mr. darcy lips ; and when [he]100-mr. darcy did speak , it seemed the effect of necessity rather than of choice -- a sacrifice to propriety , not a pleasure to [himself]100-mr. darcy . [He]100-mr. darcy seldom appeared really animated . [Mrs. Collins]186-mrs. collins knew not what to make of [him]100-mr. darcy . [Colonel Fitzwilliam]192-colonel fitzwilliam 's occasionally laughing at [his]100-mr. darcy stupidity , proved that [he]100-mr. darcy was generally different , which [her]93-elizabeth own knowledge of [him]100-mr. darcy could not have told [her]93-elizabeth ; and as [she]93-elizabeth would have liked to believe this change the effect of love , and the object of that love , [[her]93-elizabeth friend]418-her friend [Eliza]93-elizabeth , [she]93-elizabeth sat [herself]93-elizabeth seriously to work to find it out.--She watched [him]100-mr. darcy whenever [they]1557-they were at Rosings , and whenever [he]100-mr. darcy came to [Hunsford]16-hunsford ; but without much success . [He]100-mr. darcy certainly looked at [[her]93-elizabeth friend]418-her friend a great deal , but the expression of that look was disputable . It was an earnest , steadfast gaze , but [she]93-elizabeth often doubted whether there were much admiration in it , and sometimes it seemed nothing but absence of mind .

[She]93-elizabeth had once or twice suggested to [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth the possibility of [his]100-mr. darcy being partial to [her]93-elizabeth , but [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth always laughed at the idea ; and [Mrs. Collins]186-mrs. collins did not think it right to press the subject , from the danger of raising expectations which might only end in disappointment ; for in [her]186-mrs. collins opinion it admitted not of a doubt , that all [[her]186-mrs. collins friend]418-her friend 's dislike would vanish , if [she]186-mrs. collins could suppose [him]100-mr. darcy to be in [her]186-mrs. collins power .

In [her]186-mrs. collins kind schemes for [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , [she]186-mrs. collins sometimes planned [her]93-elizabeth marrying [Colonel Fitzwilliam]192-colonel fitzwilliam . [He]100-mr. darcy was beyond comparison [the pleasantest man]1560-the pleasantest man ; [he]100-mr. darcy certainly admired [her]93-elizabeth , and [his]100-mr. darcy situation in life was most eligible ; but , to counterbalance these advantages , [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy had considerable patronage in [the church]3507-the church , and [[his]100-mr. darcy cousin]727-his cousin could have none at all .

[[CHAPTER X.]195-chapter x.]1563-chapter x.

More than once did [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth in [her]93-elizabeth ramble within [the Park]1342-the park , unexpectedly meet [Mr. Darcy.--She]196-mr. darcy.--she felt all the perverseness of the mischance that should bring [him]100-mr. darcy where [no one else]3846-no one else was brought ; and to prevent its ever happening again , took care to inform [him]100-mr. darcy at first , that it was a favourite haunt of hers.--How it could occur a second time therefore was very odd!--Yet it did , and even a third . It seemed like wilful ill - nature , or a voluntary penance , for on these occasions it was not merely a few formal enquiries and an awkward pause and then away , but [he]100-mr. darcy actually thought it necessary to turn back and walk with [her]93-elizabeth . [He]100-mr. darcy never said a great deal , nor did [she]93-elizabeth give [herself]93-elizabeth the trouble of talking or of listening much ; but it struck [her]93-elizabeth in the course of [their]1566-their third rencontre that [he]100-mr. darcy was asking some odd unconnected questions -- about [her]93-elizabeth pleasure in being at [Hunsford]16-hunsford , [her]93-elizabeth love of solitary walks , and [her]93-elizabeth opinion of [Mr.]1567-mr. and [Mrs. Collins]186-mrs. collins 's happiness ; and that in speaking of [Rosings]22-rosings and [her]93-elizabeth not perfectly understanding [the house]3026-the house , [he]100-mr. darcy seemed to expect that whenever [she]93-elizabeth came into [Kent]18-kent again [she]93-elizabeth would be staying _ [there]325-there _ too . [His]100-mr. darcy words seemed to imply it . Could [he]100-mr. darcy have [Colonel Fitzwilliam]192-colonel fitzwilliam in [his]100-mr. darcy thoughts ? [She]93-elizabeth supposed , if [he]100-mr. darcy meant any thing , [he]100-mr. darcy must mean an allusion to what might arise in that quarter . It distressed [her]93-elizabeth a little , and [she]93-elizabeth was quite glad to find [herself]93-elizabeth at the gate in [the pales opposite [the Parsonage]1313-the parsonage]1570-the pales opposite the parsonage .

[She]93-elizabeth was engaged one day as [she]93-elizabeth walked , in re - perusing [Jane]94-jane 's last letter , and dwelling on some passages which proved that [Jane]94-jane had not written in spirits , when , instead of being again surprised by [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , [she]93-elizabeth saw on looking up that [Colonel Fitzwilliam]192-colonel fitzwilliam was meeting [her]93-elizabeth . Putting away the letter immediately and forcing a smile , [she]93-elizabeth said ,

" [I]93-elizabeth did not know before that [you]100-mr. darcy ever walked this way . "[93-elizabeth]

" [I]100-mr. darcy have been making the tour of [the Park]1342-the park , "[100-mr. darcy] [he]100-mr. darcy replied , " as [I]100-mr. darcy generally do every year , and intend to close it with a call at [the Parsonage]1313-the parsonage . Are [you]93-elizabeth going much farther ? "[100-mr. darcy]

" No , [I]93-elizabeth should have turned in a moment . "[93-elizabeth]

And accordingly [she]93-elizabeth did turn , and [they]1572-they walked towards [the Parsonage]1313-the parsonage together .

" Do [you]100-mr. darcy certainly leave [Kent]18-kent on Saturday ? "[93-elizabeth] said [she]93-elizabeth .

" Yes -- if [Darcy]100-mr. darcy does not put it off again . But [I]93-elizabeth am at [his]100-mr. darcy disposal . [He]100-mr. darcy arranges the business just as [he]100-mr. darcy pleases . "[93-elizabeth]

" And if not able to please [himself]100-mr. darcy in the arrangement , [he]100-mr. darcy has at least great pleasure in the power of choice . [I]93-elizabeth do not know any body who seems more to enjoy the power of doing what [he]100-mr. darcy likes than [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy . "[93-elizabeth]

" [He]100-mr. darcy likes to have [his]100-mr. darcy own way very well , "[192-colonel fitzwilliam] replied [Colonel Fitzwilliam]192-colonel fitzwilliam . " But so [we]1572-they all do . It is only that [he]100-mr. darcy has better means of having it than [many others]4128-many others , because [he]100-mr. darcy is rich , and [many others]4128-many others are poor . [I]192-colonel fitzwilliam speak feelingly . [A younger son]4130-a younger son , [you]192-colonel fitzwilliam know , must be inured to self - denial and dependence . "[192-colonel fitzwilliam]

" In [my]93-elizabeth opinion , [the younger son of [an Earl]4132-an earl]4131-the younger son of an earl can know very little of either . "[93-elizabeth]

" These are [home]3223-home questions -- and perhaps [I]192-colonel fitzwilliam can not say that [I]192-colonel fitzwilliam have experienced many hardships of that nature . "[192-colonel fitzwilliam]

" [Our]4136-our habits of expence make [us]4136-our too dependant , and there are not many in [my]192-colonel fitzwilliam rank of life who can [afford to marry without some attention to money]4137-afford to marry without some attention to money . "[192-colonel fitzwilliam]

" Is this , "[93-elizabeth] thought [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , " meant for [me]93-elizabeth ? "[93-elizabeth] and [she]93-elizabeth coloured at the idea ; but , recovering [herself]93-elizabeth , said in a lively tone , " And pray , what is the usual price of [[an Earl]4132-an earl 's younger son]4139-an earl 's younger son ? "[93-elizabeth]

" [You]192-colonel fitzwilliam need not be frightened . "[192-colonel fitzwilliam]

" Oh ! yes , "[192-colonel fitzwilliam] said [Elizabeth drily--"Mr]93-elizabeth . [Darcy]139-miss darcy is uncommonly kind to [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley , and takes a prodigious deal of care of [him]90-mr. bingley . "[192-colonel fitzwilliam]

" Care of him!--Yes , [I]192-colonel fitzwilliam really believe [Darcy]139-miss darcy _ does _ take care of [him]90-mr. bingley in those points where [he]90-mr. bingley most wants care . " What is it [you]192-colonel fitzwilliam mean ? "[192-colonel fitzwilliam]

"[192-colonel fitzwilliam]

" Did [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy give [you]100-mr. darcy [his]100-mr. darcy reasons for this interference ? "[192-colonel fitzwilliam]

" [He]100-mr. darcy did not talk to [me]100-mr. darcy of [his]100-mr. darcy own arts , "[100-mr. darcy] said [Fitzwilliam]100-mr. darcy smiling . " [He]100-mr. darcy only told [me]100-mr. darcy , what [I]100-mr. darcy have now told [you]93-elizabeth . "[100-mr. darcy]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth made no answer , and walked on , [her]93-elizabeth heart swelling with indignation . After watching [her]93-elizabeth a little , [Fitzwilliam]100-mr. darcy asked [her]93-elizabeth why [she]93-elizabeth was so thoughtful .

" [I]93-elizabeth am thinking of what [you]100-mr. darcy have been telling [me]93-elizabeth , "[93-elizabeth] said [she]93-elizabeth . " [[Your]93-elizabeth cousin]4069-your cousin 's conduct does not suit [my]93-elizabeth feelings . Why was [he]100-mr. darcy to be [the judge]3377-the judge ? "[93-elizabeth]

" [You]100-mr. darcy are rather disposed to call [his]100-mr. darcy interference officious ? "[93-elizabeth]

" [I]93-elizabeth do not see what right [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy had to decide on the propriety of [[his]100-mr. darcy friend]307-his friend 's inclination , or why , upon [his]100-mr. darcy own judgment alone , [he]100-mr. darcy was to determine and direct in what manner [that friend]3633-that friend was to be happy . "[93-elizabeth] " But , "[93-elizabeth] [she]93-elizabeth continued , recollecting [herself]93-elizabeth , " as [we]1577-them know none of the particulars , it is not fair to condemn [him]100-mr. darcy . It is not to be supposed that there was much affection in the case . "[93-elizabeth]

" That is not an unnatural surmise , "[100-mr. darcy] said [Fitzwilliam]100-mr. darcy , " but it is lessening the honour of [[my]100-mr. darcy cousin]3411-my cousin 's triumph very sadly . "[100-mr. darcy]

This was spoken jestingly , but it appeared to [her]93-elizabeth so just a picture of [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , that [she]93-elizabeth would not trust [herself]93-elizabeth with an answer ; and , therefore , abruptly changing the conversation , talked on indifferent matters till [they]1577-them reached [the parsonage]1313-the parsonage . [There]325-there , shut into [[her]93-elizabeth own room]1580-her own room , as soon as [[their]1577-them visitor]1581-their visitor left [them]1577-them , [she]93-elizabeth could think without interruption of all that [she]93-elizabeth had heard . It was not to be supposed that [any other people]1582-any other people could be meant than those with whom [she]93-elizabeth was connected . There could not exist in [the world]323-the world _ two _ men , over whom [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy could have such boundless influence . That [he]100-mr. darcy had been concerned in the measures taken to separate [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley and [Jane]94-jane , [she]93-elizabeth had never doubted ; but [she]93-elizabeth had always attributed to [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley the principal design and arrangement of [them]1577-them . If [his]100-mr. darcy own vanity , however , did not mislead [him]100-mr. darcy , _ [he]100-mr. darcy _ was the cause , [his]100-mr. darcy pride and caprice were the cause of all that [Jane]94-jane had suffered , and still continued to suffer . [He]100-mr. darcy had ruined for a while every hope of happiness for the most affectionate , generous heart in [the world]323-the world ; and [no one]3275-no one could say how lasting an evil [he]100-mr. darcy might have inflicted .

" There were some very strong objections against [the lady]595-the lady , "[192-colonel fitzwilliam] were [Colonel Fitzwilliam]192-colonel fitzwilliam 's words , and these strong objections probably were , [her]93-elizabeth having [one uncle who was [a country attorney]1587-a country attorney , and another who was in business in [London]5-london]1586-one uncle who was a country attorney , and another who was in business in london .

" To [Jane]94-jane [herself]94-jane , "[93-elizabeth] [she]93-elizabeth exclaimed , " there could be no possibility of objection . All loveliness and goodness as [she]595-the lady is ! [Her]595-the lady understanding excellent , [her]595-the lady mind improved , and [her]595-the lady manners captivating . Neither could any thing be urged against [[my]93-elizabeth father]3259-my father , who , though with some peculiarities , has abilities which [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy [himself]100-mr. darcy need not disdain , and respectability which [he]100-mr. darcy will probably never reach . "[93-elizabeth] When [she]93-elizabeth thought of [[her]93-elizabeth mother]261-her mother indeed , [her]93-elizabeth confidence gave way a little , but [she]93-elizabeth would not allow that any objections _ there _ had material weight with [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , whose pride , [she]93-elizabeth was convinced , would receive a deeper wound from the want of importance in [[his]100-mr. darcy friend]307-his friend 's connections , than from [their]1590-their want of sense ; and [she]93-elizabeth was quite decided at last , that [he]100-mr. darcy had been partly governed by this worst kind of pride , and partly by the wish of retaining [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley for [[his]100-mr. darcy sister]569-his sister .

The agitation and tears which the subject occasioned , brought on a headache ; and it grew so much worse towards the evening that , added to [her]93-elizabeth unwillingness to see [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , it determined [her]93-elizabeth not to attend [[her]93-elizabeth cousins]1592-her cousins to Rosings , where [they]1592-her cousins were engaged to drink tea . [Mrs. Collins]186-mrs. collins , seeing that [she]93-elizabeth was really unwell , did not press [her]93-elizabeth to go , and as much as possible prevented [[her]93-elizabeth husband]276-her husband from pressing [her]93-elizabeth , but [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins could not conceal [his]149-mr. collins apprehension of [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine 's being rather displeased by [her]93-elizabeth staying at [home]3223-home .

CHAPTER XI .

When [they]1592-her cousins were gone , [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , as if intending to exasperate [herself]93-elizabeth as much as possible against [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , chose for [her]93-elizabeth employment the examination of all the letters which [Jane]94-jane had written to [her]93-elizabeth since [her]93-elizabeth being in [Kent]18-kent . They contained no actual complaint , nor was there any revival of past occurrences , or any communication of present suffering . But in all , and in almost every line of each , there was a want of that cheerfulness which had been used to characterize [her]93-elizabeth style , and which , proceeding from the serenity of a mind at ease with itself , and kindly disposed towards every one , had been scarcely ever clouded . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth noticed every sentence conveying the idea of uneasiness , with an attention which it had hardly received on the first perusal . [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy 's shameful boast of what misery [he]100-mr. darcy had been able to inflict , gave [her]93-elizabeth a keener sense of [[her]93-elizabeth sister]348-her sister 's sufferings . It was some consolation to think that [his]100-mr. darcy visit to [Rosings]22-rosings was to end on the day after the next , and a still greater , that in less than a fortnight [she]93-elizabeth should [herself]93-elizabeth be with [Jane]94-jane again , and enabled to contribute to the recovery of [her]93-elizabeth spirits , by all that affection could do .

[She]93-elizabeth could not think of [Darcy]100-mr. darcy 's leaving [Kent]18-kent , without remembering that [[his]100-mr. darcy cousin]727-his cousin was to go with [him]100-mr. darcy ; but [Colonel Fitzwilliam]192-colonel fitzwilliam had made it clear that [he]100-mr. darcy had no intentions at all , and agreeable as [he]100-mr. darcy was , [she]93-elizabeth did not mean to be unhappy about [him]100-mr. darcy .

While settling this point , [she]93-elizabeth was suddenly roused by the sound of the door bell , and [her]93-elizabeth spirits were a little fluttered by the idea of its being [Colonel Fitzwilliam]192-colonel fitzwilliam [himself]100-mr. darcy , who had once before called late in the evening , and might now come to enquire particularly after [her]93-elizabeth . But this idea was soon banished , and [her]93-elizabeth spirits were very differently affected , when , to [her]93-elizabeth utter amazement , [she]93-elizabeth saw [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy walk into [the room]271-the room . In an hurried manner [he]100-mr. darcy immediately began an enquiry after [her]93-elizabeth health , imputing [his]100-mr. darcy visit to a wish of hearing that [she]93-elizabeth were better . [She]93-elizabeth answered [him]100-mr. darcy with cold civility . [He]100-mr. darcy sat down for a few moments , and then getting up walked about [the room]271-the room . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was surprised , but said not a word . After a silence of several minutes [he]100-mr. darcy came towards [her]93-elizabeth in an agitated manner , and thus began ,

" In vain have [I]100-mr. darcy struggled . It will not do . [My]100-mr. darcy feelings will not be repressed . [You]93-elizabeth must allow [me]100-mr. darcy to tell [you]93-elizabeth how ardently [I]100-mr. darcy admire and love [you]93-elizabeth . "[100-mr. darcy]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth 's astonishment was beyond expression . [She]93-elizabeth stared , coloured , doubted , and was silent . This [he]100-mr. darcy considered sufficient encouragement , and the avowal of all that [he]100-mr. darcy felt and had long felt for [her]93-elizabeth , immediately followed . [He]100-mr. darcy spoke well , but there were feelings besides those of the heart to be detailed , and [he]100-mr. darcy was not more eloquent on the subject of tenderness than of pride . [His]100-mr. darcy sense of [her]93-elizabeth inferiority -- of its being a degradation -- of [the family]432-the family obstacles which judgment had always opposed to inclination , were dwelt on with a warmth which seemed due to the consequence [he]100-mr. darcy was wounding , but was very unlikely to recommend [his]100-mr. darcy suit .

In spite of [her]93-elizabeth deeply - rooted dislike , [she]93-elizabeth could not be insensible to the compliment of [such a man]245-such a man 's affection , and though [her]93-elizabeth intentions did not vary for an instant , [she]93-elizabeth was at first sorry for the pain [he]100-mr. darcy was to receive ; till , roused to resentment by [his]100-mr. darcy subsequent language , [she]93-elizabeth lost all compassion in anger . [She]93-elizabeth tried , however , to compose [herself]93-elizabeth to answer [him]100-mr. darcy with patience , when [he]100-mr. darcy should have done . [He]100-mr. darcy concluded with representing to [her]93-elizabeth the strength of that attachment which , in spite of all [his]100-mr. darcy endeavours , [he]100-mr. darcy had found impossible to conquer ; and with expressing [his]100-mr. darcy hope that it would now be rewarded by [her]93-elizabeth acceptance of [his]100-mr. darcy hand . As [he]100-mr. darcy said this , [she]93-elizabeth could easily see that [he]100-mr. darcy had no doubt of a favourable answer . [He]100-mr. darcy _ spoke _ of apprehension and anxiety , but [his]100-mr. darcy countenance expressed real security . Such a circumstance could only exasperate farther , and when [he]100-mr. darcy ceased , the colour rose into [her]93-elizabeth cheeks , and [she]93-elizabeth said ,

" In such cases as this , it is , [I]93-elizabeth believe , the established mode to express a sense of obligation for the sentiments avowed , however unequally they may be returned . It is natural that obligation should be felt , and if [I]93-elizabeth could _ feel _ gratitude , [I]93-elizabeth would now thank [you]100-mr. darcy . But [I]93-elizabeth cannot -- [I]93-elizabeth have never desired [your]100-mr. darcy good opinion , and [you]100-mr. darcy have certainly bestowed it most unwillingly . [I]93-elizabeth am sorry to have occasioned pain to [any one]3122-any one . It has been most unconsciously done , however , and [I]93-elizabeth hope will be of short duration . The feelings which , [you]100-mr. darcy tell [me]93-elizabeth , have long prevented the acknowledgment of [your]100-mr. darcy regard , can have little difficulty in overcoming it after this explanation . "[93-elizabeth]

[Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , who was leaning against the mantle - piece with [his]100-mr. darcy eyes fixed on [her]93-elizabeth face , seemed to catch [her]93-elizabeth words with no less resentment than surprise . [His]100-mr. darcy complexion became pale with anger , and the disturbance of [his]100-mr. darcy mind was visible in every feature . [He]100-mr. darcy was struggling for the appearance of composure , and would not open [his]100-mr. darcy lips , till [he]100-mr. darcy believed [himself]100-mr. darcy to have attained it . The pause was to [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth 's feelings dreadful . At length , in a voice of forced calmness , [he]100-mr. darcy said ,

" And this is all the reply which [I]100-mr. darcy am to have the honour of expecting ! [I]100-mr. darcy might , perhaps , wish to be informed why , with so little _ endeavour _ at civility , [I]100-mr. darcy am thus rejected . But it is of small importance . "[100-mr. darcy]

" [I]93-elizabeth might as well enquire , "[93-elizabeth] replied [she]93-elizabeth , " why with so evident a design of offending and insulting [me]93-elizabeth , [you]100-mr. darcy chose to tell [me]93-elizabeth that [you]100-mr. darcy liked [me]93-elizabeth against [your]100-mr. darcy will , against [your]100-mr. darcy reason , and even against [your]100-mr. darcy character ? Was not this some excuse for incivility , if [I]93-elizabeth _ was _ uncivil ? But [I]93-elizabeth have other provocations . [You]100-mr. darcy know [I]93-elizabeth have . Had not [my]93-elizabeth own feelings decided against [you]100-mr. darcy , had [they]4166-they been indifferent , or had they even been favourable , do [you]100-mr. darcy think that any consideration would tempt [me]93-elizabeth to accept [the man , who has been the means of ruining , perhaps for ever , the happiness of a most beloved sister]4167-the man , who has been the means of ruining , perhaps for ever , the happiness of a most beloved sister ? "[93-elizabeth]

As [she]93-elizabeth pronounced these words , [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy changed colour ; but the emotion was short , and [he]100-mr. darcy listened without attempting to interrupt [her]93-elizabeth while [she]93-elizabeth continued .

" [I]93-elizabeth have every reason in [the world]323-the world to think ill of [you]100-mr. darcy . No motive can excuse the unjust and ungenerous part [you]100-mr. darcy acted _ there _ . [You]100-mr. darcy dare not , [you]100-mr. darcy can not deny that [you]100-mr. darcy have been [the principal]4169-the principal , if not the only means of dividing [them]4170-them from [each other]3157-each other , of exposing one to the censure of [the world]323-the world for caprice and instability , the other to its derision for disappointed hopes , and involving [them]4170-them both in misery of the acutest kind . "[93-elizabeth]

[She]93-elizabeth paused , and saw with no slight indignation that [he]100-mr. darcy was listening with an air which proved [him]100-mr. darcy wholly unmoved by any feeling of remorse . [He]100-mr. darcy even looked at [her]93-elizabeth with a smile of affected incredulity .

" Can [you]100-mr. darcy deny that [you]100-mr. darcy have done it ? "[93-elizabeth] [she]93-elizabeth repeated .

With assumed tranquillity [he]100-mr. darcy then replied , " [I]100-mr. darcy have no wish of denying that [I]100-mr. darcy did every thing in [my]100-mr. darcy power to separate [[my]100-mr. darcy friend]3352-my friend from [[your]93-elizabeth sister]3152-your sister , or that [I]100-mr. darcy rejoice in [my]100-mr. darcy success . Towards _ [him]3352-my friend _ [I]100-mr. darcy have been kinder than towards [myself]100-mr. darcy . "[100-mr. darcy]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth disdained the appearance of noticing this civil reflection , but its meaning did not escape , nor was it likely to conciliate [her]93-elizabeth .

" But it is not merely this affair , "[93-elizabeth] [she]93-elizabeth continued , " on which [my]93-elizabeth dislike is founded . Long before it had taken place , [my]93-elizabeth opinion of [you]100-mr. darcy was decided . [Your]100-mr. darcy character was unfolded in the recital which [I]93-elizabeth received many months ago from [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham . On this subject , what can [you]100-mr. darcy have to say ? In what imaginary act of friendship can [you]100-mr. darcy here defend [yourself]100-mr. darcy ? or under what misrepresentation , can [you]100-mr. darcy here impose upon [others]3123-others ? "[93-elizabeth]

" [You]100-mr. darcy take an eager interest in [that gentleman]3311-that gentleman 's concerns , "[100-mr. darcy] said [Darcy]100-mr. darcy in a less tranquil tone , and with a heightened colour .

" Who that knows what [his]3311-that gentleman misfortunes have been , can help feeling an interest in [him]3311-that gentleman ? "[93-elizabeth]

" [His]3311-that gentleman misfortunes ! "[100-mr. darcy] repeated [Darcy]100-mr. darcy contemptuously ; " yes , [his]3311-that gentleman misfortunes have been great indeed . "[100-mr. darcy]

" And of [your]100-mr. darcy infliction , "[93-elizabeth] cried [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth with energy . " [You]100-mr. darcy have reduced [him]3311-that gentleman to [his]3311-that gentleman present state of poverty , comparative poverty . [You]100-mr. darcy have withheld the advantages , which [you]100-mr. darcy must know to have been designed for [him]3311-that gentleman . [You]100-mr. darcy have deprived the best years of [his]3311-that gentleman life , of that independence which was no less [his]3311-that gentleman due than [his]3311-that gentleman desert . [You]100-mr. darcy have done all this ! and yet [you]100-mr. darcy can treat the mention of [his]3311-that gentleman misfortunes with contempt and ridicule . "[93-elizabeth]

" And this , "[100-mr. darcy] cried [Darcy]100-mr. darcy , as [he]100-mr. darcy walked with quick steps across [the room]271-the room , " is [your]1602-you opinion of [me]100-mr. darcy ! This is the estimation in which [you]1602-you hold [me]100-mr. darcy ! [I]100-mr. darcy thank [you]1602-you for explaining it so fully . [My]100-mr. darcy faults , according to this calculation , are heavy indeed ! But perhaps , "[100-mr. darcy] added [he]100-mr. darcy , stopping in [his]100-mr. darcy walk , and turning towards [her]1602-you , " these offences might have been overlooked , had not [your]1602-you pride been hurt by [my]100-mr. darcy honest confession of the scruples that had long prevented [my]100-mr. darcy forming any serious design . These bitter accusations might have been suppressed , had [I]100-mr. darcy with greater policy concealed [my]100-mr. darcy struggles , and flattered [you]1602-you into the belief of [my]100-mr. darcy being impelled by unqualified , unalloyed inclination ; by reason , by reflection , by every thing . But disguise of every sort is [my]100-mr. darcy abhorrence . Nor am [I]100-mr. darcy ashamed of the feelings [I]100-mr. darcy related . They were natural and just . Could [you]1602-you expect [me]100-mr. darcy to rejoice in the inferiority of [your]1602-you connections ? To congratulate [myself]100-mr. darcy on the hope of relations , whose condition in life is so decidedly beneath [my]100-mr. darcy own ? "[100-mr. darcy]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth felt [herself]93-elizabeth growing more angry every moment ; yet [she]93-elizabeth tried to the utmost to speak with composure when [she]93-elizabeth said ,

" [You]1602-you are mistaken , [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , if [you]1602-you suppose that the mode of [your]1602-you declaration affected [me]93-elizabeth in any other way , than as it spared [me]93-elizabeth the concern which [I]93-elizabeth might have felt in refusing [you]1602-you , had [you]1602-you behaved in a more gentleman - like manner . "[93-elizabeth]

[She]93-elizabeth saw [him]1603-your start at this , but [he]1603-your said nothing , and [she]93-elizabeth continued ,

" [You]1603-your could not have made [me]93-elizabeth the offer of [your]1603-your hand in any possible way that would have tempted [me]93-elizabeth to accept it . "[93-elizabeth]

Again [his]1603-your astonishment was obvious ; and [he]1603-your looked at [her]93-elizabeth with an expression of mingled incredulity and mortification . [She]93-elizabeth went on .

" From the very beginning , from the first moment [I]1603-your may almost say , of [my]1603-your acquaintance with [you]1603-your , [your]1603-your manners impressing [me]1603-your with the fullest belief of [your]1603-your arrogance , [your]1603-your conceit , and [your]1603-your selfish disdain of the feelings of [others]3123-others , were such as to form that ground - work of disapprobation , on which succeeding events have built so immoveable a dislike ; and [I]1603-your had not known [you]1603-your a month before [I]1603-your felt that [you]1603-your were [the last man in [the world]323-the world whom [I]1603-your could ever be prevailed on to marry]4178-the last man in the world whom i could ever be prevailed on to marry . "[1603-your]

" [You]1603-your have said quite enough , [madam]3285-madam . [I]1603-your perfectly comprehend [your]1603-your feelings , and have now only to be ashamed of what [my]1603-your own have been . Forgive [me]1603-your for having taken up so much of [your]1603-your time , and accept [my]1603-your best wishes for [your]1603-your health and happiness . "[1603-your]

And with these words [he]1604-he hastily left [the room]271-the room , and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth heard [him]1604-he the next moment open the front door and quit [the house]3026-the house .

The tumult of [her]93-elizabeth mind was now painfully great . [She]93-elizabeth knew not how to support [herself]93-elizabeth , and from actual weakness sat down and cried for half an hour . [Her]93-elizabeth astonishment , as [she]93-elizabeth reflected on what had passed , was increased by every review of it . That [she]93-elizabeth should receive an offer of marriage from [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy ! that [he]100-mr. darcy should have been in love with [her]93-elizabeth for so many months ! so much in love as to wish to marry [her]93-elizabeth in spite of all the objections which had made [him]100-mr. darcy prevent [[his]100-mr. darcy friend]307-his friend 's marrying [[her]93-elizabeth sister]348-her sister , and which must appear at least with equal force in [his]100-mr. darcy own case , was almost incredible ! it was gratifying to have inspired unconsciously so strong an affection . But [his]100-mr. darcy pride , [his]100-mr. darcy abominable pride , [his]100-mr. darcy shameless avowal of what [he]100-mr. darcy had done with respect to [Jane]94-jane , [his]100-mr. darcy unpardonable assurance in acknowledging , though [he]100-mr. darcy could not justify it , and the unfeeling manner in which [he]100-mr. darcy had mentioned [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham , [his]100-mr. darcy cruelty towards whom [he]100-mr. darcy had not attempted to deny , soon overcame the pity which the consideration of [his]100-mr. darcy attachment had for a moment excited .

[She]93-elizabeth continued in very agitating reflections till the sound of [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine 's carriage made [her]93-elizabeth feel how unequal [she]93-elizabeth was to encounter [Charlotte]114-charlotte 's observation , and hurried [her]93-elizabeth away to [[her]93-elizabeth room]501-her room .

CHAPTER XII .

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth awoke the next morning to the same thoughts and meditations which had at length closed [her]93-elizabeth eyes . [She]93-elizabeth could not yet recover from the surprise of what had happened ; it was impossible to think of any thing else , and totally indisposed for employment , [she]93-elizabeth resolved soon after breakfast to indulge [herself]93-elizabeth in air and exercise . [She]93-elizabeth was proceeding directly to [her]93-elizabeth favourite walk , when the recollection of [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy 's sometimes coming [there]325-there stopped [her]93-elizabeth , and instead of entering [the park]1342-the park , [she]93-elizabeth turned up [the lane]1087-the lane , which led [her]93-elizabeth farther from [the turnpike road]1613-the turnpike road . [The park paling]1614-the park paling was still the boundary on one side , and [she]93-elizabeth soon passed one of the gates into the ground .

After walking two or three times along that part of [the lane]1087-the lane , [she]93-elizabeth was tempted , by the pleasantness of the morning , to stop at the gates and look into [the park]1342-the park . The five weeks which [she]93-elizabeth had now passed in [Kent]18-kent , had made a great difference in [the country]460-the country , and every day was adding to the verdure of the early trees . [She]93-elizabeth was on the point of continuing [her]93-elizabeth walk , when [she]93-elizabeth caught a glimpse of [a gentleman within the sort of grove which edged [the park]1342-the park]1618-a gentleman within the sort of grove which edged the park ; [he]1618-a gentleman within the sort of grove which edged the park was moving that way ; and fearful of its being [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , [she]93-elizabeth was directly retreating . But [the person who advanced]1620-the person who advanced , was now near enough to see [her]93-elizabeth , and stepping forward with eagerness , pronounced [her]93-elizabeth name . [She]93-elizabeth had turned away , but on hearing [herself]93-elizabeth called , though in a voice which proved it to be [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , [she]93-elizabeth moved again towards the gate . [He]1618-a gentleman within the sort of grove which edged the park had by that time reached it also , and holding out a letter , which [she]93-elizabeth instinctively took , said with a look of haughty composure , " [I]93-elizabeth have been walking in [the grove]4181-the grove some time in the hope of meeting [you]93-elizabeth . Will [you]93-elizabeth do [me]93-elizabeth the honour of reading that letter?"--And[93-elizabeth] then , with a slight bow , turned again into [the plantation]1621-the plantation , and was soon out of sight .

With no expectation of pleasure , but with the strongest curiosity , [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth opened the letter , and to [her]93-elizabeth still increasing wonder , perceived an envelope containing two sheets of letter paper , written quite through , in a very close hand.--The envelope itself was likewise full.--Pursuing [her]93-elizabeth way along [the lane]1087-the lane , [she]93-elizabeth then began it . It was dated from Rosings , at eight o'clock in the morning , and was as follows:--

" Be not alarmed , [Madam]193-madam , on receiving this letter , by the apprehension of its containing any repetition of those sentiments , or renewal of those offers , which were last night so disgusting to [you]93-elizabeth . [I]93-elizabeth write without any intention of paining [you]93-elizabeth , or humbling [myself]93-elizabeth , by dwelling on wishes , which , for the happiness of both , can not be too soon forgotten ; and the effort which the formation , and the perusal of this letter must occasion , should have been spared , had not [my]93-elizabeth character required it to be written and read . [You]93-elizabeth must , therefore , pardon the freedom with which [I]93-elizabeth demand [your]93-elizabeth attention ; [your]93-elizabeth feelings , [I]93-elizabeth know , will bestow it unwillingly , but [I]93-elizabeth demand it of [your]93-elizabeth justice . "[93-elizabeth]

" Two offences of a very different nature , and by no means of equal magnitude , [you]93-elizabeth last night laid to [my]93-elizabeth charge . The first mentioned was , that , regardless of the sentiments of either , [I]93-elizabeth had detached [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley from [your]93-elizabeth sister,--and the other , that [I]93-elizabeth had , in defiance of various claims , in defiance of honour and humanity , ruined the immediate prosperity , and blasted the prospects of [Mr. Wickham.--Wilfully]4182-mr. wickham.--wilfully and wantonly to have thrown off [the companion of [my]93-elizabeth youth]4183-the companion of my youth , [the acknowledged favourite of [[my]93-elizabeth father]3259-my father]4184-the acknowledged favourite of my father , [a young man who had scarcely any other dependence than on [our]4187-our patronage]4186-a young man who had scarcely any other dependence than on our patronage , and [who had been brought up to expect its exertion]4188-who had been brought up to expect its exertion , would be a depravity , to which the separation of [two young persons , whose affection could be the growth of only a few weeks]4189-two young persons , whose affection could be the growth of only a few weeks , could bear no comparison.--But from the severity of that blame which was last night so liberally bestowed , respecting each circumstance , [I]93-elizabeth shall hope to be in future secured , when the following account of [my]93-elizabeth actions and [their]4190-their motives has been read.--If , in the explanation of them which is due to [myself]93-elizabeth , [I]93-elizabeth am under the necessity of relating feelings which may be offensive to [your]93-elizabeth 's , [I]93-elizabeth can only say that [I]93-elizabeth am sorry.--The necessity must be obeyed -- and farther apology would be absurd.--I had not been long in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire , before [I]93-elizabeth saw , in common with [others]3123-others , that [Bingley]90-mr. bingley preferred [[your]93-elizabeth eldest sister]4192-your eldest sister , to [any other young woman in the country.--But]4193-any other young woman in the country.--but it was not till the evening of the dance at [Netherfield]2-netherfield that [I]93-elizabeth had any apprehension of [his]90-mr. bingley feeling a serious attachment.--I had often
