seen [him]90-mr. bingley in love before.--At that ball , while [I]93-elizabeth had the honour of dancing with [you]93-elizabeth , [I]93-elizabeth was first made acquainted , by [Sir William Lucas]91-sir william 's accidental information , that [Bingley]90-mr. bingley 's attentions to [[your]93-elizabeth sister]3152-your sister had given rise to a general expectation of [their]4195-their marriage . [He]90-mr. bingley spoke of it as a certain event , of which the time alone could be undecided . From that moment [I]93-elizabeth observed [[my]93-elizabeth friend]3352-my friend 's behaviour attentively ; and [I]93-elizabeth could then perceive that [his]90-mr. bingley partiality for [Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth was beyond what [I]93-elizabeth had ever witnessed in [him]90-mr. bingley . [[Your]93-elizabeth sister]3152-your sister [I]93-elizabeth also watched.--Her look and manners were open , cheerful and engaging as ever , but without any symptom of peculiar regard , and [I]93-elizabeth remained convinced from the evening 's scrutiny , that though [she]3152-your sister received [his]90-mr. bingley attentions with pleasure , [she]3152-your sister did not invite [them]4195-their by any participation of sentiment.--If _ [you]93-elizabeth _ have not been mistaken here , _ [I]93-elizabeth _ must have been in an error . [Your]93-elizabeth superior knowledge of [[your]93-elizabeth sister]3152-your sister must make the latter probable.--If it be so , if [I]93-elizabeth have been misled by such error , to inflict pain on [her]3152-your sister , [your]93-elizabeth resentment has not been unreasonable . But [I]93-elizabeth shall not scruple to assert , that the serenity of [[your]93-elizabeth sister]3152-your sister 's countenance and air was such , as might have given [the most acute observer]4200-the most acute observer , a conviction that , however amiable [her]3152-your sister temper , [her]3152-your sister heart was not likely to be easily touched.--That [I]93-elizabeth was desirous of believing [her]3152-your sister indifferent is certain,--but [I]93-elizabeth will venture to say that [my]93-elizabeth investigations and decisions are not usually influenced by [my]93-elizabeth hopes or fears.--I did not believe [her]3152-your sister to be indifferent because [I]93-elizabeth wished it;--I believed it on impartial conviction , as truly as [I]93-elizabeth wished it in reason.--My objections to the marriage were not merely those , which [I]93-elizabeth last night acknowledged to have required the utmost force of passion to put aside , in [my]93-elizabeth own case ; the want of connection could not be so great an evil to [[my]93-elizabeth friend]3352-my friend as to me.--But there were other causes of repugnance;--causes which , though still existing , and existing to an equal degree in both instances , [I]93-elizabeth had [myself]93-elizabeth endeavoured to forget , because they were not immediately before me.--These causes must be stated , though briefly.--The situation of [[[your]93-elizabeth mother]3695-your mother 's family]4203-your mother 's family , though objectionable , was nothing in comparison of that total want of propriety so frequently , so almost uniformly betrayed by [herself]3152-your sister , by [[your]93-elizabeth three younger sisters]4204-your three younger sisters , and occasionally even by [your]93-elizabeth father.--Pardon me.--It pains [me]93-elizabeth to offend [you]93-elizabeth . But amidst [your]93-elizabeth concern for the defects of [[your]93-elizabeth nearest relations]4205-your nearest relations , and [your]93-elizabeth displeasure at this representation of [them]4205-your nearest relations , let it give [you]93-elizabeth consolation to consider that , to have conducted [yourselves]93-elizabeth so as to avoid any share of the like censure , is praise no less generally bestowed on [you]93-elizabeth and [[your]93-elizabeth eldest sister]4192-your eldest sister , than it is honourable to the sense and disposition of both.--I will only say farther , that from what passed that evening , [my]93-elizabeth opinion of all parties was confirmed , and every inducement heightened , which could have led [me]93-elizabeth before , to preserve [[my]93-elizabeth friend]3352-my friend from what [I]93-elizabeth esteemed a most unhappy connection.--He left [Netherfield]2-netherfield for [London]5-london , on the day following , as [you]93-elizabeth , [I]93-elizabeth am certain , remember , with the design of soon returning.--The part which [I]93-elizabeth acted , is now to be [explained.--His sisters]4208-explained.--his sisters ' uneasiness had been equally excited with [my]93-elizabeth own ; [our]4209-our coincidence of feeling was soon discovered ; and , alike sensible that no time was to be lost in detaching [[their]4208-explained.--his sisters brother]359-their brother , [we]4209-our shortly resolved on joining [him]359-their brother directly in [London.--We]36-london.--we accordingly went -- and there [I]93-elizabeth readily engaged in the office of pointing out to [[my]93-elizabeth friend]3352-my friend , the certain evils of such a choice.--I described , and enforced [them]4212-them earnestly.--But , however this remonstrance might have staggered or delayed [his]359-their brother determination , [I]93-elizabeth do not suppose that it would ultimately have prevented the marriage , had it not been seconded by the assurance which [I]93-elizabeth hesitated not in giving , of [[your]93-elizabeth sister]3152-your sister 's indifference . [He]359-their brother had before believed [her]359-their brother to return [his]359-their brother affection with sincere , if not with equal regard.--But [Bingley]90-mr. bingley has great natural modesty , with a stronger dependence on [my]93-elizabeth judgment than on [his]90-mr. bingley own.--To convince [him]90-mr. bingley , therefore , that [he]90-mr. bingley had deceived [himself]90-mr. bingley , was no very difficult point . To persuade [him]90-mr. bingley against returning into [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire , when that conviction had been given , was scarcely the work of [a moment.--I]4214-a moment.--i can not blame [myself]93-elizabeth for having done thus much . There is but one part of [my]93-elizabeth conduct in the whole affair , on which [I]93-elizabeth do not reflect with satisfaction ; it is that [I]93-elizabeth condescended to adopt the measures of art so far as to conceal from [him]90-mr. bingley [[your]93-elizabeth sister]3152-your sister 's being in [town]285-town . [I]93-elizabeth knew it [myself]93-elizabeth , as it was known to [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley , but [[her]102-miss bingley brother]3126-her brother is even yet ignorant of it.--That [they]4218-they might have met without ill consequence , is perhaps probable;--but [his]3126-her brother regard did not appear to [me]93-elizabeth enough extinguished for [him]3126-her brother to see [her]102-miss bingley without some danger.--Perhaps this concealment , this disguise , was beneath me.--It is done , however , and it was done for the best.--On this subject [I]93-elizabeth have nothing more to say , no other apology to offer . If [I]93-elizabeth have wounded [[your]93-elizabeth sister]3152-your sister 's feelings , it was unknowingly done ; and though the motives which governed [me]93-elizabeth may to [you]93-elizabeth very naturally appear insufficient , [I]93-elizabeth have not yet learnt to condemn them.--With respect to that other , more weighty accusation , of having injured [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham , [I]93-elizabeth can only refute it by laying before [you]93-elizabeth the whole of [his]156-wickham connection with [[my]93-elizabeth family]3708-my family . Of what [he]156-wickham has _ particularly _ accused [me]93-elizabeth [I]93-elizabeth am ignorant ; but of the truth of what [I]93-elizabeth shall relate , [I]93-elizabeth can summon more than one witness of undoubted veracity . [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham is [the son of [a very respectable man]4222-a very respectable man , who had for many years the management of all [the Pemberley estates]4223-the pemberley estates]4221-the son of a very respectable man , who had for many years the management of all the pemberley estates ; and whose good conduct in the discharge of [his]156-wickham trust , naturally inclined [[my]93-elizabeth father]3259-my father to be of service to [him]156-wickham , and on [George Wickham]165-george wickham , who was [[his]3259-my father god - son]4225-his god - son , [his]165-george wickham kindness was therefore liberally bestowed . [[My]93-elizabeth father]3259-my father supported [him]165-george wickham at [school]4227-school , and afterwards at Cambridge;--most important assistance , as [[his]165-george wickham own father]4228-his own father , always poor from the extravagance of [[his]165-george wickham wife]251-his wife , would have been unable to give [him]165-george wickham [a gentleman]3404-a gentleman 's education . [[My]93-elizabeth father]3259-my father was not only fond of [this young man]3902-this young man 's society , whose manners were always engaging ; [he]3259-my father had also the highest opinion of [him]3902-this young man , and hoping the church would be [his]3902-this young man profession , intended to provide for [him]3902-this young man in it . As for [myself]93-elizabeth , it is many , many years since [I]93-elizabeth first began to think of [him]3902-this young man in a very different manner . The vicious propensities -- the want of principle which [he]3902-this young man was careful to guard from the knowledge of [[his]3902-this young man best friend]3536-his best friend , could not escape the observation of [a young man of nearly the same age]4234-a young man of nearly the same age with [himself]3902-this young man , and who had opportunities of seeing [him]3902-this young man in unguarded moments , which [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy could not have . Here again [I]93-elizabeth shall give [you]4235-you pain -- to what degree [you]4235-you only can tell . But whatever may be the sentiments which [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham has created , a suspicion of their nature shall not prevent [me]93-elizabeth from unfolding [his]156-wickham real character . It adds even another motive . [[My]93-elizabeth excellent father]4236-my excellent father died about five years ago ; and [his]3902-this young man attachment to [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham was to the last so steady , that in [his]3902-this young man will [he]3902-this young man particularly recommended it to [me]93-elizabeth , to promote [his]3902-this young man advancement in the best manner that [his]3902-this young man profession might allow , and if [he]3902-this young man took orders , desired that [a valuable family]4237-a valuable family living might be [his]3902-this young man as soon as soon as [it]4237-a valuable family became vacant . There was also a legacy of one thousand pounds . [[His]156-wickham own father]4228-his own father did not long survive [mine]93-elizabeth , and within half a year from these events , [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham wrote to inform [me]93-elizabeth that , having finally resolved against taking orders , [he]156-wickham hoped [I]93-elizabeth should not think it unreasonable for [him]156-wickham to expect some more immediate pecuniary advantage , in lieu of the preferment , by which [he]156-wickham could not be benefited . [He]156-wickham had some intention , [he]156-wickham added , of studying the law , and [I]93-elizabeth must be aware that the interest of one thousand pounds would be a very insufficient support therein . [I]93-elizabeth rather wished , than believed [him]156-wickham to be sincere ; but at any rate , was perfectly ready to accede to [his]156-wickham proposal . [I]93-elizabeth knew that [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham ought not to be [a clergyman]679-a clergyman . The business was therefore soon settled . [He]156-wickham resigned all claim to assistance in the church , were it possible that [he]156-wickham could ever be in a situation to receive it , and accepted in return three thousand pounds . All connection between [us]4240-us seemed now dissolved . [I]93-elizabeth thought too ill of [him]156-wickham , to invite [him]156-wickham to [Pemberley]12-pemberley , or admit [his]156-wickham society in [town]285-town . In [town]285-town [I]93-elizabeth believe [he]156-wickham chiefly lived , but [his]156-wickham studying the law was a mere pretence , and being now free from all restraint , [his]156-wickham life was a life of idleness and dissipation . For about three years [I]93-elizabeth heard little of [him]156-wickham ; but on the decease of [the incumbent of the living]4243-the incumbent of the living which had been designed for [him]156-wickham , [he]156-wickham applied to [me]93-elizabeth again by letter for the presentation . [His]156-wickham circumstances , [he]156-wickham assured [me]93-elizabeth , and [I]93-elizabeth had no difficulty in believing it , were exceedingly bad . [He]156-wickham had found the law a most unprofitable study , and was now absolutely resolved on being ordained , if [I]93-elizabeth would present [him]156-wickham to [the living in question]4244-the living in question -- of which [he]156-wickham trusted there could be little doubt , as [he]156-wickham was well assured that [I]93-elizabeth had [no other person]4245-no other person to provide for , and [I]93-elizabeth could not have forgotten [[my]93-elizabeth revered father]4246-my revered father 's intentions . [You]4247-you will hardly blame [me]93-elizabeth for refusing to comply with this entreaty , or for resisting every repetition of it . [His]156-wickham resentment was in proportion to the distress of [his]156-wickham circumstances -- and [he]156-wickham was doubtless as violent in [his]156-wickham abuse of [me]93-elizabeth to [others]3123-others , as in [his]156-wickham reproaches to [myself]93-elizabeth . After this period , every appearance of acquaintance was dropt . How [he]156-wickham lived [I]93-elizabeth know not . But last summer [he]156-wickham was again most painfully obtruded on [my]93-elizabeth notice . [I]93-elizabeth must now mention a circumstance which [I]93-elizabeth would wish to forget [myself]93-elizabeth , and which no obligation less than the present should induce [me]93-elizabeth to unfold to [any human being]4249-any human being . Having said thus much , [I]93-elizabeth feel no doubt of [your]4247-you secrecy . [[My]93-elizabeth sister]3284-my sister , who is more than ten years [my]93-elizabeth junior , was left to the guardianship of [[[my]93-elizabeth mother]3230-my mother 's nephew]4252-my mother 's nephew , [Colonel Fitzwilliam]192-colonel fitzwilliam , and [myself]93-elizabeth . About a year ago , [she]3284-my sister was taken from [school]4227-school , and [an establishment formed for [her]3284-my sister in [London]5-london]4254-an establishment formed for her in london ; and last summer [she]3284-my sister went with [the lady who presided over it]4255-the lady who presided over it , to [Ramsgate]37-ramsgate ; and thither also went [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham , undoubtedly by design ; for there proved to have been a prior acquaintance between [him]156-wickham and [Mrs. Younge]139-miss darcy , in whose character [we]4256-we were most unhappily deceived ; and by [her]139-miss darcy connivance and aid , [he]156-wickham so far recommended [himself]156-wickham to [Georgiana]175-georgiana , whose affectionate heart retained a strong impression of [his]156-wickham kindness to [her]175-georgiana as [a child]3550-a child , that [she]175-georgiana was persuaded to believe [herself]175-georgiana in love , and to consent to an elopement . [She]175-georgiana was then but fifteen , which must be [her]175-georgiana excuse ; and after stating [her]175-georgiana imprudence , [I]93-elizabeth am happy to add , that [I]93-elizabeth owed the knowledge of it to [herself]175-georgiana . [I]93-elizabeth joined [them]4258-them unexpectedly a day or two before the intended elopement , and then [Georgiana]175-georgiana , unable to support the idea of grieving and offending [a brother whom [she]175-georgiana almost looked up to as [a father]3248-a father]4259-a brother whom she almost looked up to as a father , acknowledged the whole to [me]93-elizabeth . [You]4261-you may imagine what [I]93-elizabeth felt and how [I]93-elizabeth acted . Regard for [[my]93-elizabeth sister]3284-my sister 's credit and feelings prevented any public exposure , but [I]93-elizabeth wrote to [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham , who left [the place]3023-the place immediately , and [Mrs. Younge]139-miss darcy was of course removed from [her]139-miss darcy charge . [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham 's chief object was unquestionably [[my]93-elizabeth sister]3284-my sister 's fortune , which is thirty thousand pounds ; but [I]93-elizabeth can not help supposing that the hope of revenging [himself]156-wickham on [me]93-elizabeth , was a strong inducement . [His]156-wickham revenge would have been complete indeed . This , [madam]3285-madam , is a faithful narrative of every event in which [we]4266-we have been concerned together ; and if [you]4261-you do not absolutely reject it as false , [you]4261-you will , [I]93-elizabeth hope , acquit [me]93-elizabeth henceforth of cruelty towards [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham . [I]93-elizabeth know not in what manner , under what form of falsehood [he]156-wickham has imposed on [you]4261-you ; but [his]156-wickham success is not perhaps to be wondered at . Ignorant as [you]4261-you previously were of every thing concerning either , detection could not be in [your]4261-you power , and suspicion certainly not in [your]4261-you inclination . [You]4261-you may possibly wonder why all this was not told [you]4261-you last night . But [I]93-elizabeth was not then master enough of [myself]93-elizabeth to know what could or ought to be revealed . For the truth of every thing here related , [I]93-elizabeth can appeal more particularly to the testimony of [Colonel Fitzwilliam]192-colonel fitzwilliam , who from [our]4266-we near relationship and constant intimacy , and still more as one of [the executors of [[my]93-elizabeth father]3259-my father 's will]4267-the executors of my father 's will , has been unavoidably acquainted with every particular of these transactions . If [your]4261-you abhorrence of _ [me]93-elizabeth _ should make _ [my]93-elizabeth _ assertions valueless , [you]4261-you can not be prevented by the same cause from confiding in [[my]93-elizabeth cousin]3411-my cousin ; and that there may be the possibility of consulting [him]3411-my cousin , [I]93-elizabeth shall endeavour to find some opportunity of putting this letter in [your]4261-you hands in the course of the morning . [I]93-elizabeth will only add , [God]107-god bless [you]4261-you . "[93-elizabeth]

" [FITZWILLIAM DARCY]100-mr. darcy . "[93-elizabeth]

CHAPTER XIII .

If [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , when [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy gave [her]93-elizabeth the letter , did not expect it to contain a renewal of [his]100-mr. darcy offers , [she]93-elizabeth had formed no expectation at all of its contents . But such as they were , it may be well supposed how eagerly [she]93-elizabeth went through them , and what a contrariety of emotion [they]1623-they excited . [Her]93-elizabeth feelings as [she]93-elizabeth read were scarcely to be defined . With amazement did [she]93-elizabeth first understand that [he]100-mr. darcy believed any apology to be in [his]100-mr. darcy power ; and steadfastly was [she]93-elizabeth persuaded that [he]100-mr. darcy could have no explanation to give , which a just sense of shame would not conceal . With a strong prejudice against every thing [he]100-mr. darcy might say , [she]93-elizabeth began [his]100-mr. darcy account of what had happened at [Netherfield]2-netherfield . [She]93-elizabeth read , with an eagerness which hardly left [her]93-elizabeth power of comprehension , and from impatience of knowing what the next sentence might bring , was incapable of attending to the sense of the one before [her]93-elizabeth eyes . [His]100-mr. darcy belief of [[her]93-elizabeth sister]348-her sister 's insensibility , [she]93-elizabeth instantly resolved to be false , and [his]100-mr. darcy account of the real , the worst objections to the match , made [her]93-elizabeth too angry to have any wish of doing [him]100-mr. darcy justice . [He]100-mr. darcy expressed no regret for what [he]100-mr. darcy had done which satisfied [her]93-elizabeth ; [his]100-mr. darcy style was not penitent , but haughty . It was all pride and insolence .

But when this subject was succeeded by [his]100-mr. darcy account of [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham , when [she]93-elizabeth read with somewhat clearer attention , a relation of events , which , if true , must overthrow every cherished opinion of [his]100-mr. darcy worth , and which bore so alarming an affinity to [his]100-mr. darcy own history of [himself]100-mr. darcy , [her]93-elizabeth feelings were yet more acutely painful and more difficult of definition . Astonishment , apprehension , and even horror , oppressed [her]93-elizabeth . [She]93-elizabeth wished to discredit it entirely , repeatedly exclaiming , " This must be false ! This can not be ! This must be the grossest falsehood!"--and[93-elizabeth] when [she]93-elizabeth had gone through the whole letter , though scarcely knowing any thing of the last page or two , put it hastily away , protesting that [she]93-elizabeth would not regard it , that [she]93-elizabeth would never look in it again .

In this perturbed state of mind , with thoughts that could rest on nothing , [she]93-elizabeth walked on ; but it would not do ; in half a minute the letter was unfolded again , and collecting [herself]93-elizabeth as well as [she]93-elizabeth could , [she]93-elizabeth again began the mortifying perusal of all that related to [Wickham]156-wickham , and commanded [herself]93-elizabeth so far as to examine the meaning of every sentence . The account of [his]100-mr. darcy connection with [the Pemberley family]1625-the pemberley family , was exactly what [he]100-mr. darcy had related [himself]100-mr. darcy ; and the kindness of [the late Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , though [she]93-elizabeth had not before known its extent , agreed equally well with [his]100-mr. darcy own words . So far each recital confirmed the other : but when [she]93-elizabeth came to the will , the difference was great . What [Wickham]156-wickham had said of [the living]3631-the living was fresh in [her]93-elizabeth memory , and as [she]93-elizabeth recalled [his]156-wickham very words , it was impossible not to feel that there was gross duplicity on one side or the other ; and , for a few moments , [she]93-elizabeth flattered [herself]93-elizabeth that [her]93-elizabeth wishes did not err . But when [she]93-elizabeth read , and re - read with the closest attention , the particulars immediately following of [Wickham]156-wickham 's resigning all pretensions to the living , of [his]156-wickham receiving in lieu , so considerable a sum as three thousand pounds , again was [she]93-elizabeth forced to hesitate . [She]93-elizabeth put down the letter , weighed every circumstance with what [she]93-elizabeth meant to be impartiality -- deliberated on the probability of each statement -- but with little success . On both sides it was only assertion . Again [she]93-elizabeth read on . But every line proved more clearly that the affair , which [she]93-elizabeth had believed it impossible that any contrivance could so represent , as to render [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy 's conduct in it less than infamous , was capable of a turn which must make [him]100-mr. darcy entirely blameless throughout the whole .

The extravagance and general profligacy which [he]100-mr. darcy scrupled not to lay to [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham 's charge , exceedingly shocked [her]93-elizabeth ; the more so , as [she]93-elizabeth could bring no proof of its injustice . [She]93-elizabeth had never heard of [him]100-mr. darcy before [his]100-mr. darcy entrance into the ----shire Militia , in which [he]100-mr. darcy had engaged at the persuasion of [the young man]787-the young man , who , on meeting [him]100-mr. darcy accidentally in [town]285-town , had there renewed a slight acquaintance . Of [his]100-mr. darcy former way of life , nothing had been known in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire but what [he]100-mr. darcy told [himself]100-mr. darcy . As to [his]100-mr. darcy real character , had information been in [her]93-elizabeth power , [she]93-elizabeth had never felt a wish of enquiring . [His]100-mr. darcy countenance , voice , and manner , had established [him]100-mr. darcy at once in the possession of every virtue . [She]93-elizabeth tried to recollect some instance of goodness , some distinguished trait of integrity or benevolence , that might rescue [him]100-mr. darcy from the attacks of [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy ; or at least , by the predominance of virtue , atone for those casual errors , under which [she]93-elizabeth would endeavour to class , what [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy had described as the idleness and vice of many years continuance . But no such recollection befriended [her]93-elizabeth . [She]93-elizabeth could see [him]100-mr. darcy instantly before [her]93-elizabeth , in every charm of air and address ; but [she]93-elizabeth could remember no more substantial good than the general approbation of [the neighbourhood]3040-the neighbourhood , and the regard which [his]100-mr. darcy social powers had gained [him]100-mr. darcy in the mess . After pausing on this point a considerable while , [she]93-elizabeth once more continued to read . But , alas ! the story which followed of [his]100-mr. darcy designs on [Miss Darcy]139-miss darcy , received some confirmation from what had passed between [Colonel Fitzwilliam]192-colonel fitzwilliam and [herself]93-elizabeth only the morning before ; and at last [she]93-elizabeth was referred for the truth of every particular to [Colonel Fitzwilliam]192-colonel fitzwilliam [himself]192-colonel fitzwilliam -- from whom [she]93-elizabeth had previously received the information of [his]192-colonel fitzwilliam near concern in all [[his]192-colonel fitzwilliam cousin]727-his cousin 's affairs , and whose character [she]93-elizabeth had no reason to question . At one time [she]93-elizabeth had almost resolved on applying to [him]100-mr. darcy , but the idea was checked by the awkwardness of the application , and at length wholly banished by the conviction that [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy would never have hazarded such a proposal , if [he]100-mr. darcy had not been well assured of [[his]100-mr. darcy cousin]727-his cousin 's corroboration .

[She]93-elizabeth perfectly remembered every thing that had passed in conversation between [Wickham]156-wickham and [herself]93-elizabeth , in [their]1632-their first evening at [Mr. Philips]126-philips 's . Many of [his]100-mr. darcy expressions were still fresh in [her]93-elizabeth memory . [She]93-elizabeth was _ now _ struck with the impropriety of such communications to [a stranger]3405-a stranger , and wondered it had escaped [her]93-elizabeth before . [She]93-elizabeth saw the indelicacy of putting [himself]100-mr. darcy forward as [he]100-mr. darcy had done , and the inconsistency of [his]100-mr. darcy professions with [his]100-mr. darcy conduct . [She]93-elizabeth remembered that [he]100-mr. darcy had boasted of having no fear of seeing [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy -- that [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy might leave [the country]460-the country , but that _ [he]100-mr. darcy _ should stand [his]100-mr. darcy ground ; yet [he]100-mr. darcy had avoided the Netherfield ball the very next week . [She]93-elizabeth remembered also , that till [the Netherfield family]1635-the netherfield family had quitted [the country]460-the country , [he]100-mr. darcy had told [his]100-mr. darcy story to [no one]3275-no one but [herself]93-elizabeth ; but that after [their]1635-the netherfield family removal , it had been every where discussed ; that [he]100-mr. darcy had then no reserves , no scruples in sinking [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy 's character , though [he]100-mr. darcy had assured [her]93-elizabeth that respect for [the father]282-the father , would always prevent [his]100-mr. darcy exposing [the son]1639-the son .

How differently did every thing now appear in which [he]100-mr. darcy was concerned ! [His]100-mr. darcy attentions to [Miss King]104-miss king were now the consequence of views solely and hatefully mercenary ; and the mediocrity of [her]104-miss king fortune proved no longer the moderation of [his]100-mr. darcy wishes , but [his]100-mr. darcy eagerness to grasp at any thing . [His]100-mr. darcy behaviour to [herself]93-elizabeth could now have had no tolerable motive ; [he]100-mr. darcy had either been deceived with regard to [her]104-miss king fortune , or had been gratifying [his]100-mr. darcy vanity by encouraging the preference which [she]93-elizabeth believed [she]93-elizabeth had most incautiously shewn . Every lingering struggle in [his]100-mr. darcy favour grew fainter and fainter ; and in farther justification of [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , [she]93-elizabeth could not but allow that [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley , when questioned by [Jane]94-jane , had long ago asserted [his]90-mr. bingley blamelessness in the affair ; that proud and repulsive as were [his]100-mr. darcy manners , [she]93-elizabeth had never , in the whole course of [their]1640-their acquaintance , an acquaintance which had latterly brought [them]1640-their much together , and given [her]93-elizabeth a sort of intimacy with [his]100-mr. darcy ways , seen any thing that betrayed [him]100-mr. darcy to be unprincipled or unjust -- any thing that spoke [him]100-mr. darcy of irreligious or immoral habits . That among [his]100-mr. darcy own connections [he]100-mr. darcy was esteemed and valued -- that even [Wickham]156-wickham had allowed [him]100-mr. darcy merit as [a brother]452-a brother , and that [she]93-elizabeth had often heard [him]100-mr. darcy speak so affectionately of [[his]100-mr. darcy sister]569-his sister as to prove [him]100-mr. darcy capable of _ some _ amiable feeling . That had [his]100-mr. darcy actions been what [Wickham]156-wickham represented [them]1643-them , so gross a violation of every thing right could hardly have been concealed from [the world]323-the world ; and that friendship between [a person capable of it]1645-a person capable of it , and such [an amiable man]1646-an amiable man as [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley , was incomprehensible .

[She]93-elizabeth grew absolutely ashamed of herself.--Of neither [Darcy nor Wickham]197-darcy nor wickham could [she]93-elizabeth think , without feeling that [she]93-elizabeth had been blind , partial , prejudiced , absurd .

" How despicably have [I]93-elizabeth acted ! "[93-elizabeth] [she]93-elizabeth cried.--"I , who have prided [myself]93-elizabeth on [my]93-elizabeth discernment!--I , who have valued [myself]93-elizabeth on [my]93-elizabeth abilities ! who have often disdained the generous candour of [[my]93-elizabeth sister]3284-my sister , and gratified [my]93-elizabeth vanity , in useless or blameable distrust.--How humiliating is this discovery!--Yet , how just a humiliation!--Had [I]93-elizabeth been in love , [I]93-elizabeth could not have been more wretchedly blind . But vanity , not love , has been [my]93-elizabeth folly.--Pleased with the preference of one , and offended by the neglect of the other , on the very beginning of [our]4271-our acquaintance , [I]93-elizabeth have courted prepossession and ignorance , and driven reason away , where either were concerned . Till this moment , [I]93-elizabeth never knew [myself]93-elizabeth . "[93-elizabeth]

From [herself]93-elizabeth to [Jane]94-jane -- from [Jane]94-jane to [Bingley]90-mr. bingley , [her]93-elizabeth thoughts were in a line which soon brought to [her]93-elizabeth recollection that [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy 's explanation _ there _ , had appeared very insufficient ; and [she]93-elizabeth read it again . Widely different was the effect of a second perusal.--How could [she]93-elizabeth deny that credit to [his]90-mr. bingley assertions , in one instance , which [she]93-elizabeth had been obliged to give in the other?--He declared [himself]90-mr. bingley to have been totally unsuspicious of [[her]93-elizabeth sister]348-her sister 's attachment;--and [she]93-elizabeth could not help remembering what [Charlotte]114-charlotte 's opinion had always been.--Neither could [she]93-elizabeth deny the justice of [his]90-mr. bingley description of [Jane.--She]198-jane.--she felt that [Jane]94-jane 's feelings , though fervent , were little displayed , and that there was a constant complacency in [her]94-jane air and manner , not often united with great sensibility .

When [she]93-elizabeth came to that part of the letter in which [[her]94-jane family]905-her family were mentioned , in terms of such mortifying , yet merited reproach , [her]94-jane sense of shame was severe . The justice of the charge struck [her]93-elizabeth too forcibly for denial , and the circumstances to which [he]90-mr. bingley particularly alluded , as having passed at the Netherfield ball , and as confirming all [his]90-mr. bingley first disapprobation , could not have made a stronger impression on [his]90-mr. bingley mind than on [hers]93-elizabeth .

The compliment to [herself]94-jane and [[her]94-jane sister]348-her sister , was not unfelt . It soothed , but it could not console [her]94-jane for the contempt which had been thus self - attracted by the rest of [her]94-jane family;--and as [she]93-elizabeth considered that [Jane]94-jane 's disappointment had in fact been the work of [[her]94-jane nearest relations]1650-her nearest relations , and reflected how materially the credit of both must be hurt by such impropriety of conduct , [she]93-elizabeth felt depressed beyond any thing [she]93-elizabeth had ever known before .

After wandering along [the lane]1087-the lane for two hours , giving way to every variety of thought ; re - considering events , determining probabilities , and reconciling [herself]94-jane as well as [she]94-jane could , to a change so sudden and so important , fatigue , and a recollection of [her]94-jane long absence , made [her]94-jane at length return [home]3223-home ; and [she]94-jane entered [the house]3026-the house with the wish of appearing cheerful as usual , and the resolution of repressing such reflections as must make [her]94-jane unfit for conversation .

[She]94-jane was immediately told , that [the two gentlemen from [Rosings]22-rosings]1654-the two gentlemen from rosings had each called during [her]94-jane absence ; [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , only for a few minutes to take leave , but that [Colonel Fitzwilliam]192-colonel fitzwilliam had been sitting with [them]1654-the two gentlemen from rosings at least an hour , hoping for [her]94-jane return , and almost resolving to walk after [her]94-jane till [she]94-jane could be found.--Elizabeth could but just _ affect _ concern in missing [him]192-colonel fitzwilliam ; [she]94-jane really rejoiced at it . [Colonel Fitzwilliam]192-colonel fitzwilliam was no longer an object . [She]94-jane could think only of [her]94-jane letter .

CHAPTER XIV .

[The two gentlemen]782-the two gentlemen left [Rosings]22-rosings the next morning ; and [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins having been in waiting near [the lodges]1474-the lodges , to make [them]782-the two gentlemen [his]149-mr. collins parting obeisance , was able to bring home the pleasing intelligence , of [their]782-the two gentlemen appearing in very good health , and in as tolerable spirits as could be expected , after the melancholy scene so lately gone through at [Rosings]22-rosings . To [Rosings]22-rosings [he]192-colonel fitzwilliam then hastened to console [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine , and [[her]97-lady catherine daughter]475-her daughter ; and on [his]192-colonel fitzwilliam return , brought back , with great satisfaction , a message from [[her]97-lady catherine Ladyship]677-her ladyship , importing that [she]97-lady catherine felt [herself]97-lady catherine so dull as to make [her]97-lady catherine very desirous of having [them]782-the two gentlemen all to dine with [her]97-lady catherine .

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth could not see [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine without recollecting , that had [she]93-elizabeth chosen it , [she]93-elizabeth might by this time have been presented to [her]97-lady catherine , as [[her]93-elizabeth future niece]1659-her future niece ; nor could [she]93-elizabeth think , without a smile , of what [[her]97-lady catherine ladyship]677-her ladyship 's indignation would have been . " What would [she]97-lady catherine have said?--how would [she]97-lady catherine have behaved ? "[93-elizabeth] were questions with which [she]93-elizabeth amused [herself]93-elizabeth .

[Their]782-the two gentlemen first subject was the diminution of the Rosings party.--"I assure [you]4272-you , [I]97-lady catherine feel it exceedingly , "[97-lady catherine] said [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine ; " [I]97-lady catherine believe [nobody]3098-nobody feels the loss of [friends]3767-friends so much as [I]97-lady catherine do . But [I]97-lady catherine am particularly attached to [these young men]4275-these young men ; and know [them]4275-these young men to be so much attached to [me!--They]4275-these young men were excessively sorry to go ! But so [they]4275-these young men always are . [The dear colonel]4276-the dear colonel rallied [his]4276-the dear colonel spirits tolerably till just at last ; but [Darcy]100-mr. darcy seemed to feel it most acutely , more [I]97-lady catherine think than last year . [His]100-mr. darcy attachment to Rosings , certainly increases . "[97-lady catherine]

[Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins had a compliment , and an allusion to throw in here , which were kindly smiled on by [the mother]412-the mother and [daughter]4011-daughter .

[Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine observed , after dinner , that [Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth seemed out of spirits , and immediately accounting for it [herself]93-elizabeth , by supposing that [she]93-elizabeth did not like to go [home]3223-home again so soon , [she]97-lady catherine added ,

" But if that is the case , [you]93-elizabeth must write to [[your]93-elizabeth mother]3695-your mother to beg that [you]93-elizabeth may stay a little longer . [Mrs. Collins]186-mrs. collins will be very glad of [your]93-elizabeth company , [I]97-lady catherine am sure . "[97-lady catherine]

" [I]93-elizabeth am much obliged to [[your]93-elizabeth ladyship]4054-your ladyship for [your]93-elizabeth kind invitation , "[93-elizabeth] replied [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , " but it is not in [my]93-elizabeth power to accept it.--I must be in [town]285-town next Saturday . "[93-elizabeth]

" Why , at that rate , [you]93-elizabeth will have been [here]3019-here only six weeks . [I]97-lady catherine expected [you]93-elizabeth to stay two months . [I]97-lady catherine told [Mrs. Collins]186-mrs. collins so before [you]93-elizabeth came . There can be no occasion for [your]93-elizabeth going so soon . [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet could certainly spare [you]93-elizabeth for another fortnight . "[97-lady catherine]

" But [[my]93-elizabeth father]3259-my father cannot.--He wrote last week to hurry [my]93-elizabeth return . "[93-elizabeth]

" Oh ! [[your]93-elizabeth father]3227-your father of course may spare [you]93-elizabeth , if [[your]93-elizabeth mother]3695-your mother can.--Daughters are never of so much consequence to [a father]3248-a father . And if [you]93-elizabeth will stay another _ month _ complete , it will be in [my]97-lady catherine power to take one of [you]93-elizabeth as far as [London]5-london , for [I]97-lady catherine am going [there]325-there early in June , for a week ; and as [Dawson]199-dawson does not object to the Barouche box , there will be very good room for [one of [you]93-elizabeth]4286-one of you -- and indeed , if the weather should happen to be cool , [I]97-lady catherine should not object to taking [you]93-elizabeth both , as [you]93-elizabeth are neither of [you]93-elizabeth large . "[97-lady catherine]

" [You]93-elizabeth are all kindness , [Madam]193-madam ; but [I]93-elizabeth believe [we]4287-we must abide by [our]4287-we original plan . "[93-elizabeth]

[Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine seemed resigned .

" [Mrs. Collins]186-mrs. collins , [you]186-mrs. collins must send [a servant]510-a servant with [them]4289-them . [You]186-mrs. collins know [I]93-elizabeth always speak [my]93-elizabeth mind , and [I]93-elizabeth can not bear the idea of [two young women]4290-two young women travelling post by [themselves]4290-two young women . It is highly improper . [You]186-mrs. collins must contrive to send [somebody]3579-somebody . [I]93-elizabeth have the greatest dislike in [the world]323-the world to that sort of thing.--Young [women]3855-women should always be properly guarded and attended , according to [their]3855-women situation in life . When [[my]93-elizabeth niece]4294-my niece [Georgiana]175-georgiana went to [Ramsgate]37-ramsgate last summer , [I]93-elizabeth made a point of [her]175-georgiana having [two men servants]4295-two men servants go with [her.--Miss Darcy]175-georgiana , [the daughter of [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , of [Pemberley]12-pemberley]4296-the daughter of mr. darcy , of pemberley , and [Lady Anne]160-anne , could not have appeared with propriety in a different manner.--I am excessively attentive to all those things . [You]186-mrs. collins must send [John]200-john with [the young ladies]281-the young ladies , [Mrs. Collins]186-mrs. collins . [I]93-elizabeth am glad it occurred to [me]93-elizabeth to mention it ; for it would really be discreditable to _ [you]186-mrs. collins _ to let [them]281-the young ladies go alone . "[93-elizabeth]

" [[My]97-lady catherine uncle]3468-my uncle is to send [a servant]510-a servant for [us]1664-us . "[97-lady catherine]

" Oh!--Your uncle!--He keeps [a man - servant]4300-a man - servant , does he?--I am very glad [you]186-mrs. collins have [somebody who thinks of those things]4301-somebody who thinks of those things . Where shall [you]186-mrs. collins change horses?--Oh ! [Bromley]201-bromley , of course.--If [you]186-mrs. collins mention [my]93-elizabeth name at the Bell , [you]186-mrs. collins will be attended to . "[93-elizabeth]

[Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine had many other questions to ask respecting [their]1664-us journey , and as [she]97-lady catherine did not answer them all [herself]97-lady catherine , attention was necessary , which [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth believed to be lucky for [her]97-lady catherine ; or , with a mind so occupied , [she]97-lady catherine might have forgotten where [she]97-lady catherine was . Reflection must be reserved for solitary hours ; whenever [she]97-lady catherine was alone , [she]97-lady catherine gave way to it as the greatest relief ; and not a day went by without a solitary walk , in which [she]97-lady catherine might indulge in all the delight of unpleasant recollections .

[Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy 's letter , [she]97-lady catherine was in a fair way of soon knowing by heart . [She]97-lady catherine studied every sentence : and [her]97-lady catherine feelings towards [its writer]692-its writer were at times widely different . When [she]97-lady catherine remembered the style of [his]692-its writer address , [she]97-lady catherine was still full of indignation ; but when [she]97-lady catherine considered how unjustly [she]97-lady catherine had condemned and upbraided [him]692-its writer , [her]97-lady catherine anger was turned against [herself]97-lady catherine ; and [his]692-its writer disappointed feelings became the object of compassion . [His]692-its writer attachment excited gratitude , [his]692-its writer general character respect ; but [she]97-lady catherine could not approve [him]692-its writer ; nor could [she]97-lady catherine for a moment repent [her]97-lady catherine refusal , or feel the slightest inclination ever to see [him]692-its writer again . In [her]97-lady catherine own past behaviour , there was a constant source of vexation and regret ; and in the unhappy defects of [[her]97-lady catherine family]905-her family a subject of yet heavier chagrin . [They]905-her family were hopeless of remedy . [[Her]97-lady catherine father]264-her father , contented with laughing at [them]905-her family , would never exert [himself]264-her father to restrain the wild giddiness of [[his]264-her father youngest daughters]1668-his youngest daughters ; and [[her]97-lady catherine mother]261-her mother , with manners so far from right [herself]261-her mother , was entirely insensible of the evil . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth had frequently united with [Jane]94-jane in an endeavour to check the imprudence of [Catherine]97-lady catherine and [Lydia]95-lydia ; but while [they]905-her family were supported by [[their]905-her family mother]446-their mother 's indulgence , what chance could there be of improvement ? [Catherine]97-lady catherine , weak - spirited , irritable , and completely under [Lydia]95-lydia 's guidance , had been always affronted by [their]905-her family advice ; and [Lydia]95-lydia , self - willed and careless , would scarcely give [them]905-her family a hearing . [They]905-her family were ignorant , idle , and vain . While there was [an officer in [Meryton]9-meryton]1671-an officer in meryton , [they]905-her family would flirt with [him]1671-an officer in meryton ; and while [Meryton]9-meryton was within a walk of [Longbourn]7-longbourn , [they]905-her family would be going [there]325-there for ever .

Anxiety on [Jane]94-jane 's behalf , was another prevailing concern , and [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy 's explanation , by restoring [Bingley]90-mr. bingley to all [her]94-jane former good opinion , heightened the sense of what [Jane]94-jane had lost . [His]90-mr. bingley affection was proved to have been sincere , and [his]90-mr. bingley conduct cleared of all blame , unless any could attach to the implicitness of [his]90-mr. bingley confidence in [[his]90-mr. bingley friend]307-his friend . How grievous then was the thought that , of a situation so desirable in every respect , so replete with advantage , so promising for happiness , [Jane]94-jane had been deprived , by the folly and indecorum of [[her]94-jane own family]4113-her own family !

When to these recollections was added the developement of [Wickham]156-wickham 's character , it may be easily believed that the happy spirits which had seldom been depressed before , were now so much affected as to make it almost impossible for [her]94-jane to appear tolerably cheerful .

[Their]905-her family engagements at Rosings were as frequent during the last week of [her]94-jane stay , as they had been at first . The very last evening was spent [there]325-there ; and [[her]94-jane Ladyship]677-her ladyship again enquired minutely into the particulars of [their]905-her family journey , gave [them]905-her family directions as to the best method of packing , and was so urgent on the necessity of placing gowns in the only right way , that [Maria]105-maria thought [herself]105-maria obliged , on [her]105-maria return , to undo all the work of the morning , and pack [her]105-maria trunk afresh .

When [they]905-her family parted , [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine , with great condescension , wished [them]905-her family a good journey , and invited [them]905-her family to come to [Hunsford]16-hunsford again next year ; and [Miss De Bourgh]152-miss de bourgh exerted [herself]152-miss de bourgh so far as to curtsey and hold out [her]152-miss de bourgh hand to both .

CHAPTER XV .

On Saturday morning [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth and [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins met for breakfast a few minutes before [the others]517-the others appeared ; and [he]149-mr. collins took the opportunity of paying the parting civilities which [he]149-mr. collins deemed indispensably necessary .

" [I]149-mr. collins know not , [Miss Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , "[149-mr. collins] said [he]149-mr. collins , " whether [Mrs. Collins]186-mrs. collins has yet expressed [her]186-mrs. collins sense of [your]93-elizabeth kindness in coming to [us]905-her family , but [I]149-mr. collins am very certain [you]93-elizabeth will not leave [the house]3026-the house without receiving [her]186-mrs. collins thanks for it . The favour of [[your]93-elizabeth company]4303-your company has been much felt , [I]149-mr. collins assure [you]93-elizabeth . [We]905-her family know how little there is to tempt [any one]3122-any one to [[our]905-her family humble abode]4305-our humble abode . [Our]905-her family plain manner of living , [[our]905-her family small rooms]4306-our small rooms , and [few domestics]4307-few domestics , and the little [we]905-her family see of [the world]323-the world , must make [Hunsford]16-hunsford extremely dull to [a young lady like [yourself]93-elizabeth]3652-a young lady like yourself ; but [I]149-mr. collins hope [you]93-elizabeth will believe [us]905-her family grateful for the condescension , and that [we]905-her family have done every thing in [our]905-her family power to prevent [your]93-elizabeth spending [your]93-elizabeth time unpleasantly . "[149-mr. collins]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was eager with [her]93-elizabeth thanks and assurances of happiness . [She]93-elizabeth had spent six weeks with great enjoyment ; and the pleasure of being with [Charlotte]114-charlotte , and the kind attentions [she]114-charlotte had received , must make _ [her]93-elizabeth _ feel the obliged . [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins was gratified ; and with a more smiling solemnity replied ,

" It gives [me]149-mr. collins the greatest pleasure to hear that [you]93-elizabeth have passed [your]93-elizabeth time not disagreeably . [We]905-her family have certainly done [our]905-her family best ; and most fortunately having it in [our]905-her family power to introduce [you]93-elizabeth to very superior society , and from [our]905-her family connection with Rosings , the frequent means of varying the humble home scene , [I]149-mr. collins think [we]905-her family may flatter [ourselves]905-her family that [your]93-elizabeth Hunsford visit can not have been entirely irksome . [Our]905-her family situation with regard to [[Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine 's family]4310-lady catherine 's family is indeed the sort of extraordinary advantage and blessing which few can boast . [You]93-elizabeth see on what a footing [we]905-her family are . [You]93-elizabeth see how continually [we]905-her family are engaged [there]325-there . In truth [I]149-mr. collins must acknowledge that , with all the disadvantages of this humble parsonage , [I]149-mr. collins should not think [any one]3122-any one abiding in it an object of compassion , while [they]3122-any one are sharers of [our]905-her family intimacy at Rosings . "[149-mr. collins]

Words were insufficient for the elevation of [his]1678-my feelings ; and [he]1678-my was obliged to walk about [the room]271-the room , while [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth tried to unite civility and truth in a few short sentences .

" [You]93-elizabeth may , in fact , carry a very favourable report of [us]905-her family into [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire , [[my]1678-my dear cousin]3712-my dear cousin . [I]1678-my flatter [myself]1678-my at least that [you]93-elizabeth will be able to do so . [Lady Catherine]97-lady catherine 's great attentions to [Mrs. Collins]186-mrs. collins [you]93-elizabeth have been a daily witness of ; and altogether [I]1678-my trust it does not appear that [[your]93-elizabeth friend]3063-your friend has drawn an unfortunate -- but on this point it will be as well to be silent . Only let [me]1678-my assure [you]93-elizabeth , [[my]1678-my dear]3018-my dear [Miss Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , that [I]1678-my can from [my]1678-my heart most cordially wish [you]93-elizabeth equal felicity in marriage . [[My]1678-my dear]3018-my dear [Charlotte]114-charlotte and [I]1678-my have but one mind and one way of thinking . There is in every thing a most remarkable resemblance of character and ideas between [us]1681-their . [We]1681-their seem to have been designed for each other . "[1678-my]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth could safely say that it was a great happiness where that was the case , and with equal sincerity could add that [she]93-elizabeth firmly believed and rejoiced in [his]1680-his domestic comforts . [She]93-elizabeth was not sorry , however , to have the recital of [them]1681-their interrupted by the entrance of [the lady]595-the lady from whom [they]1681-their sprung . [Poor Charlotte!--it]202-poor charlotte!--it was melancholy to leave [her]202-poor charlotte!--it to such society!--But [she]202-poor charlotte!--it had chosen it with [her]202-poor charlotte!--it eyes open ; and though evidently regretting that [[her]202-poor charlotte!--it visitors]1394-her visitors were to go , [she]202-poor charlotte!--it did not seem to ask for compassion . [[Her]202-poor charlotte!--it home]372-her home and [[her]202-poor charlotte!--it housekeeping]284-her housekeeping , [[her]202-poor charlotte!--it parish]1686-her parish and [[her]202-poor charlotte!--it poultry]1409-her poultry , and all [their]1681-their dependent concerns , had not yet lost [their]1681-their charms .

At length the chaise arrived , the trunks were fastened on , the parcels placed within , and it was pronounced to be ready . After an affectionate parting between [the friends]1688-the friends , [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was attended to [the carriage]3221-the carriage by [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins , and as [they]1690-they walked down [the garden]1316-the garden , [he]149-mr. collins was commissioning [her]93-elizabeth with [his]149-mr. collins best respects to [all [her]93-elizabeth family]1692-all her family , not forgetting [his]149-mr. collins thanks for the kindness [he]149-mr. collins had received at [Longbourn]7-longbourn in the winter , and [his]149-mr. collins compliments to [Mr.]1693-mr. and [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner , though unknown . [He]149-mr. collins then handed [her]93-elizabeth in , [Maria]105-maria followed , and the door was on the point of being closed , when [he]149-mr. collins suddenly reminded [them]1690-they , with some consternation , that [they]1690-they had hitherto forgotten to leave any message for [the ladies of Rosings]1694-the ladies of rosings .

" But , "[149-mr. collins] [he]149-mr. collins added , " [you]93-elizabeth will of course wish to have [your]93-elizabeth humble respects delivered to [them]1694-the ladies of rosings , with [your]93-elizabeth grateful thanks for [their]1694-the ladies of rosings kindness to [you]93-elizabeth while [you]93-elizabeth have been [here]3019-here . "[149-mr. collins]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth made no objection;--the door was then allowed to be shut , and [the carriage]3221-the carriage drove off .

" [Good gracious]4318-good gracious ! "[105-maria] cried [Maria]105-maria , after a few minutes silence , " it seems but a day or two since [we]1697-we first came!--and yet how many things have happened ! "[105-maria]

" A great many indeed , "[1696-her companion] said [[her]93-elizabeth companion]1696-her companion with a sigh .

" [We]1697-we have dined nine times at [Rosings]22-rosings , besides drinking tea there twice!--How much [I]105-maria shall have to tell ! "[105-maria]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth privately added , " And how much [I]93-elizabeth shall have to conceal . "[93-elizabeth]

[Their]1697-we journey was performed without much conversation , or any alarm ; and within four hours of [their]1697-we leaving [Hunsford]16-hunsford , [they]1697-we reached [[Mr. Gardiner]180-mr. gardiner 's house]1698-mr. gardiner 's house , where [they]1697-we were to remain a few days .

[Jane]94-jane looked well , and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth had little opportunity of studying [her]94-jane spirits , amidst the various engagements which the kindness of [[her]93-elizabeth aunt]1226-her aunt had reserved for [them]1697-we . But [Jane]94-jane was to go [home]3223-home with [her]94-jane , and at [Longbourn]7-longbourn there would be leisure enough for observation .

It was not without an effort meanwhile that [she]93-elizabeth could wait even for [Longbourn]7-longbourn , before [she]93-elizabeth told [[her]93-elizabeth sister]348-her sister of [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy 's proposals . To know that [she]93-elizabeth had the power of revealing what would so exceedingly astonish [Jane]94-jane , and must , at the same time , so highly gratify whatever of [her]93-elizabeth own vanity [she]93-elizabeth had not yet been able to reason away , was such a temptation to openness as nothing could have conquered , but the state of indecision in which [she]93-elizabeth remained , as to the extent of what [she]93-elizabeth should communicate ; and [her]93-elizabeth fear , if [she]93-elizabeth once entered on the subject , of being hurried into repeating something of [Bingley]90-mr. bingley , which might only grieve [[her]93-elizabeth sister]348-her sister farther .

CHAPTER XVI .

It was the second week in May , in which [the three young ladies]486-the three young ladies set out together from [Gracechurch - street]39-gracechurch - street , for [the town of ----]1704-the town of ---- in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire ; and , as [they]486-the three young ladies drew near [the appointed inn where [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet 's carriage was to meet [them]486-the three young ladies]1705-the appointed inn where mr. bennet 's carriage was to meet them , [they]486-the three young ladies quickly perceived , in token of [the coachman]1706-the coachman 's punctuality , both [Kitty]97-lady catherine and [Lydia]95-lydia looking out of [a dining - room up stairs]1707-a dining - room up stairs . [These two girls]1708-these two girls had been above an hour in [the place]3023-the place , happily employed in visiting [an opposite milliner]1710-an opposite milliner , watching [the sentinel on guard]1711-the sentinel on guard , and dressing a sallad and cucumber .

After welcoming [[their]1708-these two girls sisters]459-their sisters , [they]1708-these two girls triumphantly displayed a table set out with such cold meat as [an inn larder]1713-an inn larder usually affords , exclaiming , " Is not this nice ? is not this an agreeable surprise ? "[1708-these two girls]

" And [we]1708-these two girls mean to treat [you]1708-these two girls all , "[95-lydia] added [Lydia]95-lydia ; " but [you]1708-these two girls must lend [us]1708-these two girls the money , for [we]1708-these two girls have just spent [ours]1708-these two girls at [the shop out there]4319-the shop out there . "[95-lydia] Then shewing [her]95-lydia purchases : " Look here , [I]95-lydia have bought this bonnet . [I]95-lydia do not think it is very pretty ; but [I]95-lydia thought [I]95-lydia might as well buy it as not . [I]95-lydia shall pull it to pieces as soon as [I]95-lydia get [home]3223-home , and see if [I]95-lydia can make it up any better . "[95-lydia]

And when [[her]95-lydia sisters]3048-her sisters abused it as ugly , [she]95-lydia added , with perfect unconcern , " Oh ! but there were two or three much uglier in [the shop]4321-the shop ; and when [I]95-lydia have bought some prettier - coloured satin to trim it with fresh , [I]95-lydia think it will be very tolerable . Besides , it will not much signify what [one]3064-one wears this summer , after the ----shire have left [Meryton]9-meryton , and [they]1708-these two girls are going in a fortnight . "[95-lydia]

" Are [they]1708-these two girls indeed ? "[93-elizabeth] cried [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , with the greatest satisfaction .

" [They]1708-these two girls are going to be encamped near [Brighton]40-brighton ; and [I]95-lydia do so want [papa]4323-papa to take [us]4324-us all there for the summer ! It would be such a delicious scheme , and [I]95-lydia dare say would hardly cost any thing at all . [Mamma]203-mamma would like to go too of all things ! Only think what a miserable summer else [we]4324-us shall have ! "[95-lydia]

" Yes , "[93-elizabeth] thought [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , " _ that _ would be a delightful scheme , indeed , and completely do for [us]4324-us at once . [Good Heaven]41-good heaven ! [Brighton]40-brighton , and [a whole campful of [soldiers]4326-soldiers]4325-a whole campful of soldiers , to [us]4324-us , who have been overset already by [one poor regiment of militia]4327-one poor regiment of militia , and the monthly balls of [Meryton]9-meryton . "[93-elizabeth]

" Now [I]95-lydia have got some news for [you]93-elizabeth , "[95-lydia] said [Lydia]95-lydia , as [they]1715-they sat down to table . " What do [you]93-elizabeth think ? It is excellent news , capital news , and about [a certain person that [we]4324-us all like]4328-a certain person that we all like . "[95-lydia]

[Jane]94-jane and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth looked at [each other]3157-each other , and [the waiter]1717-the waiter was told that [he]1717-the waiter need not stay . [Lydia]95-lydia laughed , and said ,

" Aye , that is just like [your]93-elizabeth formality and discretion . [You]93-elizabeth thought [the waiter]1717-the waiter must not hear , as if [he]1717-the waiter cared ! [I]95-lydia dare say [he]1717-the waiter often hears worse things said than [I]95-lydia am going to say . But [he]1717-the waiter is [an ugly fellow]4330-an ugly fellow ! [I]95-lydia am glad [he]1717-the waiter is gone . [I]95-lydia never saw such a long chin in [my]95-lydia life . Well , but now for [my]95-lydia news : it is about [dear Wickham]156-wickham ; too good for [the waiter]1717-the waiter , is not it ? There is no danger of [Wickham]156-wickham 's marrying [Mary King]98-mary . There 's for [you]93-elizabeth ! [She]98-mary is gone down to [[her]98-mary uncle]583-her uncle at [Liverpool]42-liverpool ; gone to stay . [Wickham]156-wickham is safe . "[95-lydia]

" And [Mary King]98-mary is safe ! "[93-elizabeth] added [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth ; " safe from a connection imprudent as to fortune . "[93-elizabeth]

" [She]98-mary is [a great fool]4333-a great fool for going away , if [she]98-mary liked [him]156-wickham . "[95-lydia]

" But [I]94-jane hope there is no strong attachment on either side , "[94-jane] said [Jane]94-jane .

" [I]95-lydia am sure there is not on _ [his]156-wickham _ . [I]95-lydia will answer for it [he]156-wickham never cared three straws about [her]98-mary . Who _ could _ about such a nasty little freckled thing ? "[95-lydia]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was shocked to think that , however incapable of such coarseness of _ expression _ [herself]93-elizabeth , the coarseness of the _ sentiment _ was little other than [her]93-elizabeth own breast had formerly harboured and fancied liberal !

As soon as [all]778-all had ate , and [the elder ones]1719-the elder ones paid , [the carriage]3221-the carriage was ordered ; and after some contrivance , [the whole party]531-the whole party , with all [their]778-all boxes , workbags , and parcels , and the unwelcome addition of [Kitty]97-lady catherine 's and [Lydia]95-lydia 's purchases , were seated in [it]531-the whole party .

" How nicely [we]778-all are crammed in ! "[95-lydia] cried [Lydia]95-lydia . " [I]95-lydia am glad [I]95-lydia bought [my]95-lydia bonnet , if it is only for the fun of having another bandbox ! Well , now let [us]778-all be quite comfortable and snug , and talk and laugh all the way [home]3223-home . And in the first place , let [us]778-all hear what has happened to [you]778-all all , since [you]778-all went away . Have [you]778-all seen [any pleasant men]4335-any pleasant men ? Have [you]778-all had any flirting ? [I]95-lydia was in great hopes that one of [you]778-all would have got [a husband]3741-a husband before [you]778-all came back . [Jane]94-jane will be quite [an old maid]1103-an old maid soon , [I]95-lydia declare . [She]94-jane is almost three and twenty ! [Lord]4338-lord , how ashamed [I]95-lydia should be of not being married before three and twenty ! [[My]95-lydia aunt]3208-my aunt [Philips]126-philips wants [you]778-all so to get [husbands]4340-husbands , [you]778-all ca n't think . [She]3208-my aunt says [Lizzy]93-elizabeth had better have taken [Mr. Collins]149-mr. collins ; but _ [I]95-lydia _ do not think there would have been any fun in it . [Lord]4341-lord ! how [I]95-lydia should like to be married before any of [you]778-all ; and then [I]95-lydia would chaperon [you]778-all about to all the balls . Dear [me]95-lydia ! [we]4342-we had such a good piece of fun the other day at [[Colonel Forster]123-colonel forster 's]4343-colonel forster 's . [Kitty]97-lady catherine and [me]95-lydia were to spend the day [there]325-there , and [Mrs. Forster]204-mrs. forster promised to have a little dance in the evening ; ( by the bye , [Mrs. Forster]204-mrs. forster and [me]95-lydia are _ [such _ friends]4345-such _ friends ! ) and so [she]3208-my aunt asked [the two Harringtons]4346-the two harringtons to come , but [Harriet]205-harriet was ill , and so [Pen]206-pen was forced to come by [herself]206-pen ; and then , what do [you]778-all think [we]4342-we did ? [We]4342-we dressed up [Chamberlayne]207-chamberlayne in [woman]4347-woman 's clothes , on purpose to pass for [a lady,--only]4348-a lady,--only think what fun ! [Not a soul]4349-not a soul knew of it , but [Col]208-col . and [Mrs. Forster]204-mrs. forster , and [Kitty]97-lady catherine and [me]95-lydia , except [[my]95-lydia aunt]3208-my aunt , for [we]4342-we were forced to borrow one of [her]3208-my aunt gowns ; and [you]778-all can not imagine how well [he]207-chamberlayne looked ! When [Denny]155-denny , and [Wickham]156-wickham , and [Pratt]209-pratt , and [two or three more of [the men]4352-the men]4351-two or three more of the men came in , [they]1722-we did not know [him]207-chamberlayne in the least . [Lord]4353-lord ! how [I]95-lydia laughed ! and so did [Mrs. Forster]204-mrs. forster . [I]95-lydia thought [I]95-lydia should have died . And _ that _ made [the men]4352-the men suspect something , and then [they]4352-the men soon found out what was the matter . "[95-lydia]

With such kind of histories of [their]1722-we parties and good jokes , did [Lydia]95-lydia , assisted by [Kitty]97-lady catherine 's hints and additions , endeavour to amuse [[her]95-lydia companions]3872-her companions all the way to [Longbourn]7-longbourn . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth listened as little as [she]93-elizabeth could , but there was no escaping the frequent mention of [Wickham]156-wickham 's name .

[Their]1722-we reception at [home]3223-home was most kind . [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet rejoiced to see [Jane]94-jane in undiminished beauty ; and more than once during dinner did [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet say voluntarily to [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth ,

" [I]86-mr. bennet am glad [you]93-elizabeth are come back , [Lizzy]93-elizabeth . "[86-mr. bennet]

[Their]1722-we party in [the dining - room]709-the dining - room was large , for almost all [the Lucases]113-the lucases came to meet [Maria]105-maria and hear the news : and various were the subjects which occupied [them]1722-we ; [lady Lucas]105-maria was enquiring of [Maria]105-maria across the table , after the welfare and poultry of [[her]105-maria eldest daughter]332-her eldest daughter ; [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet was doubly engaged , on one hand collecting an account of the present fashions from [Jane]94-jane , who sat some way below [her]96-mrs. bennet , and on the other , retailing them all to [the younger Miss Lucases]113-the lucases ; and [Lydia]95-lydia , in a voice rather louder than [any other person]1106-any other person 's , was enumerating the various pleasures of the morning to any body who would hear [her]95-lydia .

" Oh ! [Mary]98-mary , "[1728-i] said [she]1728-i , " [I]1728-i wish [you]98-mary had gone with [us]1722-we , for [we]1722-we had such fun ! as [we]1722-we went along , [Kitty]97-lady catherine and [me]1728-i drew up all the blinds , and pretended there was [nobody]3098-nobody in [the coach]3225-the coach ; and [I]1728-i should have gone so all the way , if [Kitty]97-lady catherine had not been sick ; and when [we]1722-we got to [the George]165-george wickham , [I]1728-i do think [we]1722-we behaved very handsomely , for [we]1722-we treated the other three with the nicest cold luncheon in [the world]323-the world , and if [you]98-mary would have gone , [we]1722-we would have treated [you]98-mary too . And then when [we]1722-we came away it was such fun ! [I]1728-i thought [we]1722-we never should have got into [the coach]3225-the coach . [I]1728-i was ready to die of laughter . And then [we]1722-we were so merry all the way [home]3223-home ! [we]1722-we talked and laughed so loud , that [any body]3670-any body might have heard [us]1722-we ten miles off ! "[1728-i]

To this , [Mary]98-mary very gravely replied , " Far be it from [me]98-mary , [[my]98-mary dear sister]3799-my dear sister , to depreciate such pleasures . [They]4362-they would doubtless be congenial with the generality of female minds . But [I]98-mary confess [they]4362-they would have no charms for _ [me]98-mary _ . [I]98-mary should infinitely prefer a book . "[98-mary]

But of this answer [Lydia]95-lydia heard not a word . [She]95-lydia seldom listened to any body for more than half a minute , and never attended to [Mary]98-mary at all .

In the afternoon [Lydia]95-lydia was urgent with [the rest of [the girls]3033-the girls]1729-the rest of the girls to walk to [Meryton]9-meryton and see how [every body]324-every body went on ; but [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth steadily opposed the scheme . It should not be said , that [the Miss Bennets]111-the bennets could not be at [home]3223-home half a day before [they]3033-the girls were in pursuit of [the officers]466-the officers . There was another reason too for [her]93-elizabeth opposition . [She]93-elizabeth dreaded seeing [Wickham]156-wickham again , and was resolved to avoid it as long as possible . The comfort to _ [her]93-elizabeth _ , of [the regiment]656-the regiment 's approaching removal , was indeed beyond expression . In a fortnight [they]3033-the girls were to go , and once gone , [she]93-elizabeth hoped there could be nothing more to plague [her]93-elizabeth on [his]156-wickham account .

[She]93-elizabeth had not been many hours at [home]3223-home , before [she]93-elizabeth found that the [Brighton]40-brighton scheme , of which [Lydia]95-lydia had given [them]3033-the girls a hint at [the inn]1736-the inn , was under frequent discussion between [[her]93-elizabeth parents]1737-her parents . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth saw directly that [[her]93-elizabeth father]264-her father had not the smallest intention of yielding ; but [his]264-her father answers were at the same time so vague and equivocal , that [[her]93-elizabeth mother]261-her mother , though often disheartened , had never yet despaired of succeeding at last .

CHAPTER XVII .

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth 's impatience to acquaint [Jane]94-jane with what had happened could no longer be overcome ; and at length resolving to suppress every particular in which [[her]93-elizabeth sister]348-her sister was concerned , and preparing [her]94-jane to be surprised , [she]93-elizabeth related to [her]94-jane the next morning [the chief of the scene between [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy and [herself]93-elizabeth]1741-the chief of the scene between mr. darcy and herself .

[Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth 's astonishment was soon lessened by the strong sisterly partiality which made any admiration of [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth appear perfectly natural ; and all surprise was shortly lost in other feelings . [She]93-elizabeth was sorry that [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy should have delivered [his]100-mr. darcy sentiments in a manner so little suited to recommend them ; but still more was [she]93-elizabeth grieved for the unhappiness which [[her]93-elizabeth sister]348-her sister 's refusal must have given [him]100-mr. darcy .

" [His]100-mr. darcy being so sure of succeeding , was wrong , "[93-elizabeth] said [she]93-elizabeth ; " and certainly ought not to have appeared ; but consider how much it must increase [his]100-mr. darcy disappointment . "[93-elizabeth]

" Indeed , "[93-elizabeth] replied [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , " [I]93-elizabeth am heartily sorry for [him]100-mr. darcy ; but [he]100-mr. darcy has other feelings which will probably soon drive away [his]100-mr. darcy regard for [me]93-elizabeth . [You]93-elizabeth do not blame [me]93-elizabeth , however , for refusing [him]100-mr. darcy ? "[93-elizabeth]

" Blame [you]93-elizabeth ! Oh , no . "[93-elizabeth]

" But [you]93-elizabeth blame [me]93-elizabeth for having spoken so warmly of [Wickham]156-wickham . "[93-elizabeth]

" No -- [I]93-elizabeth do not know that [you]93-elizabeth were wrong in saying what [you]93-elizabeth did . "[93-elizabeth]

" But [you]93-elizabeth _ will _ know it , when [I]93-elizabeth have told [you]93-elizabeth what happened the very next day . "[93-elizabeth]

[She]93-elizabeth then spoke of the letter , repeating the whole of its contents as far as [they]1743-them concerned [George Wickham]165-george wickham . What a stroke was this for [poor [Jane]94-jane ! who would willingly have gone through [the world]323-the world without believing that so much wickedness existed in [the whole race of mankind]1745-the whole race of mankind , as was here collected in [one individual]3850-one individual]94-jane . Nor was [Darcy]100-mr. darcy 's vindication , though grateful to [her]94-jane feelings , capable of consoling [her]94-jane for such discovery . Most earnestly did [she]94-jane labour to prove the probability of error , and seek to clear one , without involving the other .

" This will not do , "[93-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth . " [You]93-elizabeth never will be able to make both of [them]1743-them good for any thing . Take [your]93-elizabeth choice , but [you]93-elizabeth must be satisfied with only one . There is but such a quantity of merit between [them]1743-them ; just enough to make [one good sort of man]4363-one good sort of man ; and of late it has been shifting about pretty much . For [my]93-elizabeth part , [I]93-elizabeth am inclined to believe it all [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy 's , but [you]93-elizabeth shall do as [you]93-elizabeth chuse . "[93-elizabeth]

It was some time , however , before a smile could be extorted from [Jane]94-jane .

" [I]94-jane do not know when [I]94-jane have been more shocked , "[94-jane] said [she]94-jane . " [Wickham]156-wickham so very bad ! It is almost past belief . And poor [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy ! [dear Lizzy]93-elizabeth , only consider what [he]100-mr. darcy must have suffered . Such a disappointment ! and with the knowledge of [your]93-elizabeth ill opinion too ! and having to relate such a thing of [[his]100-mr. darcy sister]569-his sister ! It is really too distressing . [I]94-jane am sure [you]93-elizabeth must feel it so . "[94-jane]

" Oh ! no , [my]94-jane regret and compassion are all done away by seeing [you]93-elizabeth so full of both . [I]94-jane know [you]93-elizabeth will do [him]100-mr. darcy such ample justice , that [I]94-jane am growing every moment more unconcerned and indifferent . [Your]93-elizabeth profusion makes [me]94-jane saving ; and if [you]93-elizabeth lament over [him]100-mr. darcy much longer , [my]94-jane heart will be as light as a feather . "[94-jane]

" [Poor Wickham]210-poor wickham ; there is such an expression of goodness in [his]100-mr. darcy countenance ! such an openness and gentleness in [his]100-mr. darcy manner . "[94-jane]

" There certainly was some great mismanagement in the education of [those two young men]4365-those two young men . [One]3064-one has got all the goodness , and the other all the appearance of it . "[94-jane]

" [I]94-jane never thought [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy so deficient in the _ appearance _ of it as [you]93-elizabeth used to do . "[94-jane]

" And yet [I]94-jane meant to be uncommonly clever in taking so decided a dislike to [him]100-mr. darcy , without any reason . It is such a spur to one 's genius , such an opening for wit to have a dislike of that kind . [One]3064-one may be continually abusive without saying any thing just ; but [one]3064-one can not be always laughing at [a man]3065-a man without now and then stumbling on something witty . "[94-jane]

" [Lizzy]93-elizabeth , when [you]93-elizabeth first read that letter , [I]94-jane am sure [you]93-elizabeth could not treat the matter as [you]93-elizabeth do now . "[94-jane]

" Indeed [I]94-jane could not . [I]94-jane was uncomfortable enough . [I]94-jane was very uncomfortable , [I]94-jane may say unhappy . And with [no one]3275-no one to speak to , of what [I]94-jane felt , no [Jane]94-jane to comfort [me]94-jane and say that [I]94-jane had not been so very weak and vain and nonsensical as [I]94-jane knew [I]94-jane had ! Oh ! how [I]94-jane wanted [you]93-elizabeth ! "[94-jane]

" How unfortunate that [you]93-elizabeth should have used such very strong expressions in speaking of [Wickham]156-wickham to [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , for now [they]4371-they _ do _ appear wholly undeserved . "[94-jane]

" Certainly . But the misfortune of speaking with bitterness , is a most natural consequence of the prejudices [I]94-jane had been encouraging . There is one point , on which [I]94-jane want [your]93-elizabeth advice . [I]94-jane want to be told whether [I]94-jane ought , or ought not to make [our]4372-our acquaintance in general understand [Wickham]156-wickham 's character . "[94-jane]

[Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth paused a little and then replied , " Surely there can be no occasion for exposing [him]156-wickham so dreadfully . What is [your]93-elizabeth own opinion ? "[93-elizabeth]

" That it ought not to be attempted . [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy has not authorised [me]1747-a willing listener to make [his]100-mr. darcy communication public . On the contrary [every particular relative to [[his]100-mr. darcy sister]569-his sister]4373-every particular relative to his sister , was meant to be kept as much as possible to [myself]1747-a willing listener ; and if [I]1747-a willing listener endeavour to undeceive [people]3236-people as to the rest of [his]100-mr. darcy conduct , who will believe [me]1747-a willing listener ? The general prejudice against [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy is so violent , that it would be the death of [half the good people]4376-half the good people in [Meryton]9-meryton , to attempt to place [him]156-wickham in an amiable light . [I]1747-a willing listener am not equal to it . [Wickham]156-wickham will soon be gone ; and therefore it will not signify to [anybody here]4377-anybody here , what [he]156-wickham really is . Sometime hence it will be all found out , and then [we]4378-we may laugh at [their]3236-people stupidity in not knowing it before . At present [I]1747-a willing listener will say nothing about it . "[1747-a willing listener]

" [You]1747-a willing listener are quite right . To have [his]100-mr. darcy errors made public might ruin [him]100-mr. darcy for ever . [He]100-mr. darcy is now perhaps sorry for what [he]100-mr. darcy has done , and anxious to re - establish a character . [We]4378-we must not make [him]100-mr. darcy desperate . "[93-elizabeth]

The tumult of [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth 's mind was allayed by this conversation .
