[She]93-elizabeth had got rid of two of the secrets which had weighed on [her]93-elizabeth for a fortnight , and was certain of [a willing listener]1747-a willing listener in [Jane]94-jane , whenever [she]93-elizabeth might wish to talk again of either . But there was still something lurking behind , of which prudence forbad the disclosure . [She]93-elizabeth dared not relate the other half of [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy 's letter , nor explain to [[her]93-elizabeth sister]348-her sister how sincerely [she]348-her sister had been valued by [[his]100-mr. darcy friend]307-his friend . Here was knowledge in which [no one]3275-no one could partake ; and [she]93-elizabeth was sensible that nothing less than a perfect understanding between [the parties]3162-the parties could justify [her]93-elizabeth in throwing off this last incumbrance of mystery . " And then , "[93-elizabeth] said [she]93-elizabeth , " if that very improbable event should ever take place , [I]93-elizabeth shall merely be able to tell what [Bingley]90-mr. bingley may tell in a much more agreeable manner [himself]90-mr. bingley . The liberty of communication can not be mine till it has lost all its value ! "[93-elizabeth]

[She]93-elizabeth was now , on being settled at [home]3223-home , at leisure to observe the real state of [[her]93-elizabeth sister]348-her sister 's spirits . [Jane]94-jane was not happy . [She]94-jane still cherished a very tender affection for [Bingley]90-mr. bingley . Having never even fancied [herself]93-elizabeth in love before , [her]93-elizabeth regard had all the warmth of first attachment , and from [her]93-elizabeth age and disposition , greater steadiness than first attachments often boast ; and so fervently did [she]93-elizabeth value [his]90-mr. bingley remembrance , and prefer [him]90-mr. bingley to [every other man]1754-every other man , that all [her]93-elizabeth good sense , and all [her]93-elizabeth attention to the feelings of [[her]93-elizabeth friends]330-her friends , were requisite to check the indulgence of those regrets , which must have been injurious to [her]93-elizabeth own health and [their]330-her friends tranquillity .

" Well , [Lizzy]93-elizabeth , "[96-mrs. bennet] said [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet one day , " what is [your]93-elizabeth opinion _ now _ of this sad business of [Jane]94-jane 's ? For [my]96-mrs. bennet part , [I]96-mrs. bennet am determined never to speak of it again to [anybody]605-anybody . [I]96-mrs. bennet told [[my]96-mrs. bennet sister]3284-my sister [Philips]126-philips so the other day . But [I]96-mrs. bennet can not find out that [Jane]94-jane saw any thing of [him]4381-he in [London]5-london . Well , [he]4381-he is [a very undeserving young man]4382-a very undeserving young man -- and [I]96-mrs. bennet do not suppose there is the least chance in [the world]323-the world of [her]94-jane ever getting [him]4381-he now . There is no talk of [his]4381-he coming to [Netherfield]2-netherfield again in the summer ; and [I]96-mrs. bennet have enquired of every body too , who is likely to know . "[96-mrs. bennet]

" [I]330-her friends do not believe that [he]4381-he will ever live at [Netherfield]2-netherfield any more . "[330-her friends]

" Oh , well ! it is just as [he]4381-he chooses . [Nobody]3098-nobody wants [him]4381-he to come . Though [I]96-mrs. bennet shall always say that [he]4381-he used [[my]96-mrs. bennet daughter]4385-my daughter extremely ill ; and if [I]96-mrs. bennet was [her]4385-my daughter , [I]96-mrs. bennet would not have put up with it . Well , [my]96-mrs. bennet comfort is , [I]96-mrs. bennet am sure [Jane]94-jane will die of a broken heart , and then [he]4381-he will be sorry for what [he]4381-he has done . "[96-mrs. bennet]

But as [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth could not receive comfort from any such expectation , [she]93-elizabeth made no answer .

" Well , [Lizzy]93-elizabeth , "[261-her mother] continued [[her]93-elizabeth mother]261-her mother soon afterwards , " and so [the Collinses]4386-the collinses live very comfortable , do [they]4386-the collinses ? Well , well , [I]261-her mother only hope it will last . And what sort of table do [they]4386-the collinses keep ? [Charlotte]114-charlotte is [an excellent manager]4387-an excellent manager , [I]261-her mother dare say . If [she]114-charlotte is half as sharp as [[her]114-charlotte mother]261-her mother , [she]114-charlotte is saving enough . There is nothing extravagant in _ [[their]4386-the collinses _ housekeeping]4389-their _ housekeeping , [I]261-her mother dare say . "[261-her mother]

" No , nothing at all . "[330-her friends]

" A great deal of good management , depend upon it . Yes , yes . _ [They]4386-the collinses _ will take care not to outrun [their]4386-the collinses income . _ [They]4386-the collinses _ will never be distressed for money . Well , much good may it do [them]4386-the collinses ! And so , [I]261-her mother suppose , [they]4386-the collinses often talk of having [Longbourn]7-longbourn when [[your]4390-your father]3227-your father is dead . [They]4386-the collinses look upon it quite as [their]4386-the collinses own , [I]261-her mother dare say , whenever that happens . "[261-her mother]

" It was a subject which [they]4386-the collinses could not mention before [me]330-her friends . "[330-her friends]

" No . It would have been strange if [they]4386-the collinses had . But [I]261-her mother make no doubt , [they]4386-the collinses often talk of it between [themselves]4386-the collinses . Well , if [they]4386-the collinses can be easy with [an estate that is not lawfully [their]4386-the collinses own]4392-an estate that is not lawfully their own , so much the better . _ [I]261-her mother _ should be ashamed of having one that was only entailed on [me]261-her mother . "[261-her mother]

CHAPTER XVIII .

The first week of [their]1757-their return was soon gone . The second began . It was the last of [the regiment]656-the regiment 's stay in [Meryton]9-meryton , and [all the young ladies in [the neighbourhood]3040-the neighbourhood]1759-all the young ladies in the neighbourhood were drooping apace . The dejection was almost universal . [The elder Miss Bennets]111-the bennets alone were still able to eat , drink , and sleep , and pursue the usual course of [their]1757-their employments . Very frequently were [they]1757-their reproached for this insensibility by [Kitty]97-lady catherine and [Lydia]95-lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in [any of [the family]432-the family]1107-any of the family .

" Good Heaven ! What is to become of [us]1757-their ! What are [we]1757-their to do ! "[1757-their] would [they]1757-their often exclaim in the bitterness of woe . " How can [you]1763-their affectionate mother be smiling so , [Lizzy]93-elizabeth ? "[1757-their]

[[Their]1757-their affectionate mother]1763-their affectionate mother shared all [their]1757-their grief ; [she]1763-their affectionate mother remembered what [she]1763-their affectionate mother had [herself]1763-their affectionate mother endured on a similar occasion , five and twenty years ago .

" [I]1763-their affectionate mother am sure , "[1763-their affectionate mother] said [she]1763-their affectionate mother , " [I]1763-their affectionate mother cried for two days together when [[Colonel Millar]211-colonel millar 's regiment]4393-colonel millar 's regiment went away . [I]1763-their affectionate mother thought [I]1763-their affectionate mother should have broke [my]1763-their affectionate mother heart . "[1763-their affectionate mother]

" [I]95-lydia am sure [I]95-lydia shall break _ mine _ , "[95-lydia] said [Lydia]95-lydia .

" If [one]3064-one could but go to [Brighton]40-brighton ! "[96-mrs. bennet] observed [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet .

" Oh , [yes!--if one]4395-yes!--if one could but go to [Brighton]40-brighton ! But [papa]4396-papa is so disagreeable . "[1763-their affectionate mother]

" A little sea - bathing would set [me]1763-their affectionate mother up for ever . "[1763-their affectionate mother]

" And [[my]97-lady catherine aunt]3208-my aunt [Philips]126-philips is sure it would do _ [me]97-lady catherine _ a great deal of good , "[97-lady catherine] added [Kitty]97-lady catherine .

Such were the kind of lamentations resounding perpetually through [Longbourn - house]1764-longbourn - house . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth tried to be diverted by [them]1765-them ; but all sense of pleasure was lost in shame . [She]93-elizabeth felt anew the justice of [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy 's objections ; and never had [she]93-elizabeth before been so much disposed to pardon [his]100-mr. darcy interference in the views of [[his]100-mr. darcy friend]307-his friend .

But the gloom of [Lydia]95-lydia 's prospect was shortly cleared away ; for [she]93-elizabeth received an invitation from [Mrs. Forster]204-mrs. forster , [the wife of [the Colonel of [the regiment]656-the regiment]1768-the colonel of the regiment]1767-the wife of the colonel of the regiment , to accompany [her]93-elizabeth to [Brighton]40-brighton . [This invaluable friend]1770-this invaluable friend was [a very young woman , and very lately married]1771-a very young woman , and very lately married . A resemblance in good humour and good spirits had recommended [her]93-elizabeth and [Lydia]95-lydia to [each other]3157-each other , and out of [their]1773-their _ three _ months ' acquaintance [they]1773-their had been intimate _ two _ .

The rapture of [Lydia]95-lydia on this occasion , [her]95-lydia adoration of [Mrs. Forster]204-mrs. forster , the delight of [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet , and the mortification of [Kitty]97-lady catherine , are scarcely to be described . Wholly inattentive to [[her]95-lydia sister]348-her sister 's feelings , [Lydia]95-lydia flew about [the house]3026-the house in restless ecstacy , calling for [every one]1776-every one 's congratulations , and laughing and talking with more violence than ever ; whilst [the luckless Kitty]97-lady catherine continued in [the parlour]1327-the parlour repining at [her]97-lady catherine fate in terms as unreasonable as [her]97-lady catherine accent was peevish .

" [I]97-lady catherine can not see why [Mrs. Forster]204-mrs. forster should not ask _ [me]97-lady catherine _ as well as [Lydia]95-lydia , "[97-lady catherine] said [she]97-lady catherine , " though [I]97-lady catherine am _ not _ [[her]95-lydia particular friend]4398-her particular friend . [I]97-lady catherine have just as much right to be asked as [she]95-lydia has , and more too , for [I]97-lady catherine am two years older . "[97-lady catherine]

In vain did [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth attempt to make [her]97-lady catherine reasonable , and [Jane]94-jane to make [her]97-lady catherine resigned . As for [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth [herself]93-elizabeth , this invitation was so far from exciting in [her]93-elizabeth the same feelings as in [[her]93-elizabeth mother]261-her mother and [Lydia]95-lydia , that [she]93-elizabeth considered it as the death - warrant of all possibility of common sense for the latter ; and detestable as such a step must make [her]93-elizabeth were it known , [she]93-elizabeth could not help secretly advising [[her]93-elizabeth father]264-her father not to let [her]93-elizabeth go . [She]93-elizabeth represented to [him]264-her father all the improprieties of [Lydia]95-lydia 's general behaviour , the little advantage [she]93-elizabeth could derive from the friendship of [such a woman]3278-such a woman as [Mrs. Forster]204-mrs. forster , and the probability of [her]93-elizabeth being yet more imprudent with such a companion at [Brighton]40-brighton , where the temptations must be greater than at [home]3223-home . [He]264-her father heard [her]93-elizabeth attentively , and then said ,

" [Lydia]95-lydia will never be easy till [she]95-lydia has exposed [herself]95-lydia in some public place or other , and [we]4399-our can never expect [her]95-lydia to do it with so little expense or inconvenience to [[her]95-lydia family]905-her family as under the present circumstances . "[264-her father]

" If [you]264-her father were aware , "[93-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , " of the very great disadvantage to [us]4399-our all , which must arise from the public notice of [Lydia]95-lydia 's unguarded and imprudent manner ; nay , which has already arisen from it , [I]93-elizabeth am sure [you]264-her father would judge differently in the affair . "[93-elizabeth]

" Already arisen ! "[86-mr. bennet] repeated [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet . " What , has [she]95-lydia frightened away [some of [[your]86-mr. bennet lovers]4402-your lovers]4401-some of your lovers ? [Poor little Lizzy]93-elizabeth ! But do not be cast down . [Such squeamish youths]4403-such squeamish youths as can not bear to be connected with a little absurdity , are not worth a regret . Come , let [me]86-mr. bennet see the list of [the pitiful fellows who have been kept aloof by [Lydia]95-lydia 's folly]4404-the pitiful fellows who have been kept aloof by lydia 's folly . "[86-mr. bennet]

" Indeed [you]264-her father are mistaken . [I]264-her father have no such injuries to resent . It is not of peculiar , but of general evils , which [I]264-her father am now complaining . [Our]4399-our importance , [our]4399-our respectability in [the world]323-the world , must be affected by the wild volatility , the assurance and disdain of all restraint which mark [Lydia]95-lydia 's character . Excuse [me]264-her father -- for [I]264-her father must speak plainly . If [you]264-her father , [[my]264-her father dear father]4406-my dear father , will not take the trouble of checking [her]95-lydia exuberant spirits , and of teaching [her]95-lydia that [her]95-lydia present pursuits are not to be the business of [her]95-lydia life , [she]95-lydia will soon be beyond the reach of amendment . [Her]95-lydia character will be fixed , and [she]95-lydia will , at sixteen , be [the most determined flirt that ever made [herself]95-lydia and [[her]95-lydia family]905-her family ridiculous]4407-the most determined flirt that ever made herself and her family ridiculous . [A flirt]4409-a flirt too , in the worst and meanest degree of flirtation ; without any attraction beyond youth and [a tolerable person]4410-a tolerable person ; and from the ignorance and emptiness of [her]95-lydia mind , wholly unable to ward off any portion of that universal contempt which [her]95-lydia rage for admiration will excite . In this danger [Kitty]97-lady catherine is also comprehended . [She]97-lady catherine will follow wherever [Lydia]95-lydia leads . Vain , ignorant , idle , and absolutely uncontrouled ! Oh ! [[my]264-her father dear father]4406-my dear father , can [you]4406-my dear father suppose it possible that [they]4412-they will not be censured and despised wherever [they]4412-they are known , and that [[their]4412-they sisters]459-their sisters will not be often involved in the disgrace ? "[264-her father]

[Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet saw that [her]1782-you whole heart was in the subject ; and affectionately taking [her]1782-you hand , said in reply ,

" Do not make [yourself]1782-you uneasy , [[my]86-mr. bennet love]3076-my love . Wherever [you]1782-you and [Jane]94-jane are known , [you]1782-you must be respected and valued ; and [you]1782-you will not appear to less advantage for having a couple of -- or [I]86-mr. bennet may say , [three very silly sisters]4415-three very silly sisters . [We]4416-us shall have no peace at [Longbourn]7-longbourn if [Lydia]95-lydia does not go to [Brighton]40-brighton . Let [her]95-lydia go then . [Colonel Forster]123-colonel forster is [a sensible man]3425-a sensible man , and will keep [her]95-lydia out of any real mischief ; and [she]95-lydia is luckily too poor to be an object of prey to any body . At [Brighton]40-brighton [she]95-lydia will be of less importance even as [a common flirt]4418-a common flirt than [she]95-lydia has been [here]3019-here . [The officers]466-the officers will find [women]3855-women better worth [their]466-the officers notice . Let [us]4416-us hope , therefore , that [her]95-lydia being [there]325-there may teach [her]95-lydia [her]95-lydia own insignificance . At any rate , [she]95-lydia can not grow many degrees worse , without authorizing [us]4416-us to lock [her]95-lydia up for the rest of [her]95-lydia life . "[86-mr. bennet]

With this answer [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was forced to be content ; but [her]93-elizabeth own opinion continued the same , and [she]93-elizabeth left [him]1783-him disappointed and sorry . It was not in [her]93-elizabeth nature , however , to increase [her]93-elizabeth vexations , by dwelling on them . [She]93-elizabeth was confident of having performed [her]93-elizabeth duty , and to fret over unavoidable evils , or augment them by anxiety , was no part of [her]93-elizabeth disposition .

Had [Lydia]95-lydia and [[her]95-lydia mother]261-her mother known the substance of [her]95-lydia conference with [[her]95-lydia father]264-her father , [their]1786-their indignation would hardly have found expression in [their]1786-their united volubility . In [Lydia]95-lydia 's imagination , a visit to [Brighton]40-brighton comprised every possibility of earthly happiness . [She]95-lydia saw with the creative eye of fancy , [the streets of [that gay bathing place]1788-that gay bathing place covered with [officers]470-officers]1787-the streets of that gay bathing place covered with officers . [She]95-lydia saw [herself]95-lydia the object of attention , to tens and to scores of [them]470-officers at present unknown . [She]95-lydia saw all the glories of [the camp]1790-the camp ; [its]1790-the camp tents stretched forth in beauteous uniformity of lines , crowded with [the young]1791-the young and [the gay]1792-the gay , and dazzling with scarlet ; and to complete the view , [she]95-lydia saw [herself]95-lydia seated beneath [a tent]1793-a tent , tenderly flirting with [at least six officers]1794-at least six officers at once .

Had [she]95-lydia known that [[her]95-lydia sister]348-her sister sought to tear [her]95-lydia from such prospects and such realities as these , what would have been [her]95-lydia sensations ? They could have been understood only by [[her]95-lydia mother]261-her mother , who might have felt nearly the same . [Lydia]95-lydia 's going to [Brighton]40-brighton was all that consoled [her]95-lydia for the melancholy conviction of [[her]95-lydia husband]276-her husband 's never intending to go [there]325-there [himself]276-her husband .

But [they]1799-their were entirely ignorant of what had passed ; and [their]1799-their raptures continued with little intermission to the very day of [Lydia]95-lydia 's leaving [home]3223-home .

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was now to see [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham for the last time . Having been frequently in company with [him]156-wickham since [her]93-elizabeth return , agitation was pretty well over ; the agitations of former partiality entirely so . [She]93-elizabeth had even learnt to detect , in the very gentleness which had first delighted [her]93-elizabeth , an affectation and a sameness to disgust and weary . In [his]156-wickham present behaviour to [herself]93-elizabeth , moreover , [she]93-elizabeth had a fresh source of displeasure , for the inclination [he]156-wickham soon testified of renewing those attentions which had marked the early part of [their]1799-their acquaintance , could only serve , after what had since passed , to provoke [her]93-elizabeth . [She]93-elizabeth lost all concern for [him]156-wickham in finding [herself]93-elizabeth thus selected as the object of such idle and frivolous gallantry ; and while [she]93-elizabeth steadily repressed it , could not but feel the reproof contained in [his]156-wickham believing , that however long , and for whatever cause , [his]156-wickham attentions had been withdrawn , [her]93-elizabeth vanity would be gratified and [her]93-elizabeth preference secured at any time by [their]1799-their renewal .

On the very last day of [the regiment]656-the regiment 's remaining in [Meryton]9-meryton , [he]156-wickham dined with [others of [the officers]466-the officers at [Longbourn]7-longbourn]1802-others of the officers at longbourn ; and so little was [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth disposed to part from [him]156-wickham in good humour , that on [his]156-wickham making some enquiry as to the manner in which [her]93-elizabeth time had passed at [Hunsford]16-hunsford , [she]93-elizabeth mentioned [Colonel Fitzwilliam]192-colonel fitzwilliam 's and [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy 's having both spent three weeks at Rosings , and asked [him]156-wickham if [he]156-wickham were acquainted with [the former]347-the former .

[He]156-wickham looked surprised , displeased , alarmed ; but with a moment 's recollection and a returning smile , replied , that [he]156-wickham had formerly seen [him]156-wickham often ; and after observing that [he]156-wickham was [a very gentleman - like man]1805-a very gentleman - like man , asked [her]93-elizabeth how [she]93-elizabeth had liked [him]156-wickham . [Her]93-elizabeth answer was warmly in [his]156-wickham favour . With an air of indifference [he]156-wickham soon afterwards added , " How long did [you]93-elizabeth say that [he]156-wickham was at [Rosings]22-rosings ? "[156-wickham]

" Nearly three weeks . "[1805-a very gentleman - like man]

" And [you]93-elizabeth saw [him]156-wickham frequently ? "[156-wickham]

" Yes , almost every day . "[1805-a very gentleman - like man]

" [His]156-wickham manners are very different from [[his]156-wickham cousin]727-his cousin 's . "[156-wickham]

" Yes , very different . But [I]1805-a very gentleman - like man think [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy improves on acquaintance . "[1805-a very gentleman - like man]

" Indeed ! "[156-wickham] cried [Wickham]156-wickham with a look which did not escape [her]93-elizabeth . " And pray may [I]156-wickham ask ? "[156-wickham] but checking [himself]156-wickham , [he]156-wickham added in a gayer tone , " Is it in address that [he]156-wickham improves ? Has [he]156-wickham deigned to add ought of civility to [his]156-wickham ordinary style ? for [I]156-wickham dare not hope , "[156-wickham] [he]156-wickham continued in a lower and more serious tone , " that [he]156-wickham is improved in essentials . "[156-wickham]

" Oh , no ! "[93-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth . " In essentials , [I]93-elizabeth believe , [he]156-wickham is very much what [he]156-wickham ever was . "[93-elizabeth]

While [she]93-elizabeth spoke , [Wickham]156-wickham looked as if scarcely knowing whether to rejoice over [her]93-elizabeth words , or to distrust their meaning . There was a something in [her]93-elizabeth countenance which made [him]156-wickham listen with an apprehensive and anxious attention , while [she]93-elizabeth added ,

" When [I]93-elizabeth said that [he]156-wickham improved on acquaintance , [I]93-elizabeth did not mean that either [his]156-wickham mind or manners were in a state of improvement , but that from knowing [him]156-wickham better , [his]156-wickham disposition was better understood . "[93-elizabeth]

[Wickham]156-wickham 's alarm now appeared in a heightened complexion and agitated look ; for a few minutes [he]156-wickham was silent ; till , shaking off [his]156-wickham embarrassment , [he]156-wickham turned to [her]93-elizabeth again , and said in the gentlest of accents ,

" [You]93-elizabeth , who so well know [my]156-wickham feelings towards [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , will readily comprehend how sincerely [I]156-wickham must rejoice that [he]156-wickham is wise enough to assume even the _ appearance _ of what is right . [His]156-wickham pride , in that direction , may be of service , if not to [himself]156-wickham , to many others , for it must deter [him]156-wickham from such foul misconduct as [I]156-wickham have suffered by . [I]156-wickham only fear that the sort of cautiousness , to which [you]93-elizabeth , [I]156-wickham imagine , have been alluding , is merely adopted on [his]156-wickham visits to [[his]156-wickham aunt]945-his aunt , of whose good opinion and judgment [he]156-wickham stands much in awe . [His]156-wickham fear of [her]945-his aunt , has always operated , [I]156-wickham know , when [they]4425-they were together ; and a good deal is to be imputed to [his]156-wickham wish of forwarding the match with [Miss De Bourgh]152-miss de bourgh , which [I]156-wickham am certain [he]156-wickham has very much at heart . "[156-wickham]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth could not repress a smile at this , but [she]93-elizabeth answered only by a slight inclination of the head . [She]93-elizabeth saw that [he]1806-his wanted to engage [her]93-elizabeth on the old subject of [his]1806-his grievances , and [she]93-elizabeth was in no humour to indulge [him]1806-his . The rest of the evening passed with the _ appearance _ , on [his]1806-his side , of usual cheerfulness , but with no farther attempt to distinguish [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth ; and [they]1807-they parted at last with mutual civility , and possibly a mutual desire of never meeting again .

When the party broke up , [Lydia]95-lydia returned with [Mrs. Forster]204-mrs. forster to [Meryton]9-meryton , from whence [they]1807-they were to set out early the next morning . The separation between [her]95-lydia and [[her]95-lydia family]905-her family was rather noisy than pathetic . [Kitty]97-lady catherine was [the only one who shed tears]1809-the only one who shed tears ; but [she]97-lady catherine did weep from vexation and envy . [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet was diffuse in [her]96-mrs. bennet good wishes for the felicity of [[her]96-mrs. bennet daughter]475-her daughter , and impressive in [her]96-mrs. bennet injunctions that [she]96-mrs. bennet would not miss the opportunity of enjoying [herself]96-mrs. bennet as much as possible ; advice , which there was every reason to believe would be attended to ; and in the clamorous happiness of [Lydia]95-lydia [herself]95-lydia in bidding farewell , [the more gentle adieus of [[her]95-lydia sisters]3048-her sisters]1811-the more gentle adieus of her sisters were uttered without being heard .

CHAPTER XIX .

Had [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth 's opinion been all drawn from [[her]93-elizabeth own family]4113-her own family , [she]93-elizabeth could not have formed a very pleasing picture of conjugal felicity or domestic comfort . [[Her]93-elizabeth father]264-her father captivated by youth and beauty , and that appearance of good humour , which youth and beauty generally give , had married [a woman whose weak understanding and illiberal mind]1815-a woman whose weak understanding and illiberal mind , had very early in [their]1816-their marriage put an end to all real affection for [her]1815-a woman whose weak understanding and illiberal mind . Respect , esteem , and confidence , had vanished for ever ; and all [his]264-her father views of domestic happiness were overthrown . But [Mr. Bennet]86-mr. bennet was not of a disposition to seek comfort for the disappointment which [his]86-mr. bennet own imprudence had brought on , in any of those pleasures which too often console [the unfortunate]1817-the unfortunate for [their]1817-the unfortunate folly or [their]1817-the unfortunate vice . [He]86-mr. bennet was fond of [the country]460-the country and of books ; and from these tastes had arisen [his]86-mr. bennet principal enjoyments . To [[his]86-mr. bennet wife]251-his wife [he]86-mr. bennet was very little otherwise indebted , than as [her]251-his wife ignorance and folly had contributed to [his]86-mr. bennet amusement . This is not the sort of happiness which [a man]3065-a man would in general wish to owe to [[his]86-mr. bennet wife]251-his wife ; but where other powers of entertainment are wanting , [the true philosopher]1822-the true philosopher will derive benefit from such as are given .

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , however , had never been blind to the impropriety of [[her]93-elizabeth father]264-her father 's behaviour as [a husband]3741-a husband . [She]93-elizabeth had always seen it with pain ; but respecting [his]86-mr. bennet abilities , and grateful for [his]86-mr. bennet affectionate treatment of [herself]93-elizabeth , [she]93-elizabeth endeavoured to forget what [she]93-elizabeth could not overlook , and to banish from [her]93-elizabeth thoughts that continual breach of conjugal obligation and decorum which , in exposing [[his]86-mr. bennet wife]251-his wife to the contempt of [[her]93-elizabeth own children]1826-her own children , was so highly reprehensible . But [she]93-elizabeth had never felt so strongly as now , the disadvantages which must attend [the children of so unsuitable a marriage]1827-the children of so unsuitable a marriage , nor ever been so fully aware of the evils arising from so ill - judged a direction of talents ; talents which rightly used , might at least have preserved the respectability of [[his]86-mr. bennet daughters]443-his daughters , even if incapable of enlarging the mind of [[his]86-mr. bennet wife]251-his wife .

When [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth had rejoiced over [Wickham]156-wickham 's departure , [she]93-elizabeth found little other cause for satisfaction in the loss of [the regiment]656-the regiment . [Their]1831-their parties abroad were less varied than before ; and at [home]3223-home [she]93-elizabeth had [a mother]1833-a mother and [sister whose constant repinings at the dulness of every thing around]1834-sister whose constant repinings at the dulness of every thing around [them]1831-their , threw a real gloom over [their]1831-their domestic circle ; and , though [Kitty]97-lady catherine might in time regain [her]97-lady catherine natural degree of sense , since the disturbers of [her]97-lady catherine brain were removed , [[her]93-elizabeth other sister]1835-her other sister , from whose disposition greater evil might be apprehended , was likely to be hardened in all [her]1835-her other sister folly and assurance , by a situation of such double danger as [a watering place]1836-a watering place and [a camp]1837-a camp . Upon the whole , therefore , [she]93-elizabeth found , what has been sometimes found before , that an event to which [she]93-elizabeth had looked forward with impatient desire , did not in taking place , bring all the satisfaction [she]93-elizabeth had promised [herself]93-elizabeth . It was consequently necessary to name some other period for the commencement of actual felicity ; to have some other point on which [her]93-elizabeth wishes and hopes might be fixed , and by again enjoying the pleasure of anticipation , console [herself]93-elizabeth for the present , and prepare for another disappointment . [Her]93-elizabeth tour to [the Lakes]1838-the lakes was now the object of [her]93-elizabeth happiest thoughts ; it was [her]93-elizabeth best consolation for all the uncomfortable hours , which the discontentedness of [[her]93-elizabeth mother]261-her mother and [Kitty]97-lady catherine made inevitable ; and could [she]93-elizabeth have included [Jane]94-jane in the scheme , every part of it would have been perfect .

" But it is fortunate , "[93-elizabeth] thought [she]93-elizabeth , " that [I]93-elizabeth have something to wish for . Were the whole arrangement complete , [my]93-elizabeth disappointment would be certain . But here , by carrying with [me]93-elizabeth one ceaseless source of regret in [[my]93-elizabeth sister]3284-my sister 's absence , [I]93-elizabeth may reasonably hope to have all [my]93-elizabeth expectations of pleasure realized . A scheme of which every part promises delight , can never be successful ; and general disappointment is only warded off by the defence of some little peculiar vexation . "[93-elizabeth]

When [Lydia]95-lydia went away , [she]95-lydia promised to write very often and very minutely to [[her]95-lydia mother]261-her mother and [Kitty]97-lady catherine ; but [her]95-lydia letters were always long expected , and always very short . Those to [[her]95-lydia mother]261-her mother , contained little else , than that [they]1842-they were just returned from [the library]1030-the library , where [such and such officers]1844-such and such officers had attended [them]1842-they , and where [she]95-lydia had seen such beautiful ornaments as made [her]95-lydia quite wild ; that [she]95-lydia had a new gown , or a new parasol , which [she]95-lydia would have described more fully , but was obliged to leave off in a violent hurry , as [Mrs. Forster]204-mrs. forster called [her]95-lydia , and [they]1845-they were going to the camp;--and from [her]95-lydia correspondence with [[her]95-lydia sister]348-her sister , there was still less to be learnt -- for [her]95-lydia letters to [Kitty]97-lady catherine , though rather longer , were much too full of lines under the words to be made public .

After the first fortnight or three weeks of [her]95-lydia absence , health , good humour and cheerfulness began to re - appear at [Longbourn]7-longbourn . Everything wore a happier aspect . [The families who had been in [town]285-town for the winter]1847-the families who had been in town for the winter came back again , and summer finery and summer engagements arose . [Mrs. Bennet]96-mrs. bennet was restored to [her]96-mrs. bennet usual querulous serenity , and by the middle of June [Kitty]97-lady catherine was so much recovered as to be able to enter [Meryton]9-meryton without tears ; an event of such happy promise as to make [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth hope , that by the following Christmas , [she]93-elizabeth might be so tolerably reasonable as not to mention [an officer]922-an officer above once a day , unless by some cruel and malicious arrangement at the war - office , [another regiment]1850-another regiment should be quartered in [Meryton]9-meryton .

The time fixed for the beginning of [their]1845-they Northern tour was now fast approaching ; and a fortnight only was wanting of it , when a letter arrived from [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner , which at once delayed its commencement and curtailed its extent . [Mr. Gardiner]180-mr. gardiner would be prevented by business from setting out till a fortnight later in July , and must be in [London]5-london again within a month ; and as that left too short a period for [them]1845-they to go so far , and see so much as [they]1845-they had proposed , or at least to see it with the leisure and comfort [they]1845-they had built on , [they]1845-they were obliged to give up [the Lakes]1838-the lakes , and substitute a more contracted tour ; and , according to the present plan , were to go no farther northward than [Derbyshire]6-derbyshire . In [that county]1852-that county , there was enough to be seen , to occupy the chief of [their]1845-they three weeks ; and to [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner it had a peculiarly strong attraction . [The town where [she]141-mrs. gardiner had formerly passed some years of [her]141-mrs. gardiner life , and where [they]1845-they were now to spend a few days]1853-the town where she had formerly passed some years of her life , and where they were now to spend a few days , was probably as great an object of [her]141-mrs. gardiner curiosity , as all the celebrated beauties of [Matlock]178-matlock , [Chatsworth]45-chatsworth , [Dovedale]46-dovedale , or [the Peak]47-the peak .

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was excessively disappointed ; [she]93-elizabeth had set [her]93-elizabeth heart on seeing [the Lakes]1838-the lakes ; and still thought there might have been time enough . But it was [her]93-elizabeth business to be satisfied -- and certainly [her]93-elizabeth temper to be happy ; and all was soon right again .

With the mention of [Derbyshire]6-derbyshire , there were many ideas connected . It was impossible for [her]93-elizabeth to see the word without thinking of [Pemberley]12-pemberley and [its owner]1855-its owner . " But surely , "[93-elizabeth] said [she]93-elizabeth , " [I]93-elizabeth may enter [[his]1855-its owner county]362-his county with impunity , and rob it of a few petrified spars without [his]1855-its owner perceiving [me]93-elizabeth . "[93-elizabeth]

The period of expectation was now doubled . Four weeks were to pass away before [[her]93-elizabeth uncle]583-her uncle and [aunt]3947-aunt 's arrival . But [they]1858-they did pass away , and [Mr.]1859-mr. and [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner , with [[their]1860-their four children]1861-their four children , did at length appear at [Longbourn]7-longbourn . [The children]1862-the children , [two girls of six and eight years old]1863-two girls of six and eight years old , and [two younger boys]1864-two younger boys , were to be left under the particular care of [[their]1860-their cousin]694-their cousin [Jane]94-jane , who was [the general favourite]1866-the general favourite , and whose steady sense and sweetness of temper exactly adapted [her]94-jane for attending to [them]1862-the children in every way -- teaching [them]1862-the children , playing with [them]1862-the children , and loving [them]1862-the children .

[The Gardiners]182-the gardiners staid only one night at [Longbourn]7-longbourn , and set off the next morning with [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth in pursuit of novelty and amusement . One enjoyment was certain -- that of suitableness as [companions]1867-companions ; a suitableness which comprehended health and temper to bear inconveniences -- cheerfulness to enhance every pleasure -- and affection and intelligence , which might supply it among [themselves]182-the gardiners if there were disappointments abroad .

It is not the object of this work to give a description of [Derbyshire]6-derbyshire , nor of any of [the remarkable places through which [their]1860-their route thither]1868-the remarkable places through which their route thither lay ; [Oxford]48-oxford , [Blenheim]49-blenheim , [Warwick]50-warwick , [Kenelworth]51-kenelworth , [Birmingham]52-birmingham , & c. are sufficiently known . [A small part of [Derbyshire]6-derbyshire]1869-a small part of derbyshire is all the present concern . To [the little town of]1870-the little town of [Lambton]53-lambton , [the scene of [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner 's former residence]1871-the scene of mrs. gardiner 's former residence , and where [she]93-elizabeth had lately learned that [some acquaintance]1872-some acquaintance still remained , [they]1860-their bent [their]1860-their steps , after having seen all the principal wonders of [the country]460-the country ; and within five miles of [Lambton]53-lambton , [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth found from [[her]93-elizabeth aunt]1226-her aunt , that [Pemberley]12-pemberley was situated . [It]12-pemberley was not in [[their]1860-their direct road]1875-their direct road , nor more than a mile or two out of [it]12-pemberley . In talking over [their]1860-their route the evening before , [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner expressed an inclination to see [the place]3023-the place again . [Mr. Gardiner]180-mr. gardiner declared [his]180-mr. gardiner willingness , and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was applied to for [her]93-elizabeth approbation .

" [[My]1226-her aunt love]3076-my love , should not [you]93-elizabeth like to see [a place of which [you]93-elizabeth have heard so much]4429-a place of which you have heard so much ? "[1226-her aunt] said [[her]93-elizabeth aunt]1226-her aunt . " [A place too , with which so many of [your]93-elizabeth acquaintance]4430-a place too , with which so many of your acquaintance are connected . [Wickham]156-wickham passed all [his]156-wickham youth [there]325-there , [you]93-elizabeth know . "[1226-her aunt]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was distressed . [She]93-elizabeth felt that [she]93-elizabeth had no business at [Pemberley]12-pemberley , and was obliged to assume a disinclination for seeing [it]12-pemberley . [She]93-elizabeth must own that [she]93-elizabeth was tired of [great houses]1878-great houses ; after going over so many , [she]93-elizabeth really had no pleasure in fine carpets or satin curtains .

[Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner abused [her]141-mrs. gardiner stupidity . " If [it]12-pemberley were merely [a fine house]4432-a fine house richly furnished , "[141-mrs. gardiner] said [she]141-mrs. gardiner , " [I]141-mrs. gardiner should not care about [it]12-pemberley [myself]141-mrs. gardiner ; but [the grounds]4433-the grounds are delightful . [They]4433-the grounds have some of [the finest woods in [the country]460-the country]4434-the finest woods in the country . "[141-mrs. gardiner]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth said no more -- but [her]93-elizabeth mind could not acquiesce . The possibility of meeting [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , while viewing [the place]3023-the place , instantly occurred . It would be dreadful ! [She]93-elizabeth blushed at the very idea ; and thought it would be better to speak openly to [[her]93-elizabeth aunt]1226-her aunt , than to run such a risk . But against this , there were objections ; and [she]93-elizabeth finally resolved that it could be the last resource , if [her]93-elizabeth private enquiries as to the absence of [the family]432-the family , were unfavourably answered .

Accordingly , when [she]93-elizabeth retired at night , [she]93-elizabeth asked [the chambermaid]1882-the chambermaid whether [Pemberley]12-pemberley were not [a very fine place]1883-a very fine place , what was the name of [[its]12-pemberley proprietor]837-its proprietor , and with no little alarm , whether [the family]432-the family were down for the summer . A most welcome negative followed the last question -- and [her]93-elizabeth alarms being now removed , [she]93-elizabeth was at leisure to feel a great deal of curiosity to see [the house]3026-the house [herself]93-elizabeth ; and when the subject was revived the next morning , and [she]93-elizabeth was again applied to , could readily answer , and with a proper air of indifference , that [she]93-elizabeth had not really any dislike to the scheme .

To [Pemberley]12-pemberley , therefore , [they]1887-they were to go .

END OF THE SECOND VOLUME .

[ Illustration : [MATLOCK ]

PRIDE AND PREJUDICE]178-matlock :

A Novel .

In Three Volumes .

By [the Author of " Sense and Sensibility]3832-the author of " sense and sensibility . "[3832-the author of " sense and sensibility]

VOL . III .

[London]5-london : Printed for T. [Egerton]31-egerton , Military Library , [Whitehall]32-whitehall . 1813 .

[ Illustration : [DOVE - DALE]54-dove - dale ]

PRIDE & PREJUDICE .

CHAPTER I.

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , as [they]1887-they drove along , watched for the first appearance of [Pemberley Woods]55-pemberley woods with some perturbation ; and when at length [they]1887-they turned in at [the lodge]1888-the lodge , [her]93-elizabeth spirits were in a high flutter .

[The park]1342-the park was very large , and contained great variety of ground . [They]1887-they entered [it]1342-the park in one of [its]1342-the park lowest points , and drove for some time through [a beautiful wood]1890-a beautiful wood , stretching over a wide extent .

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth 's mind was too full for conversation , but [she]93-elizabeth saw and admired every remarkable spot and point of view . [They]1887-they gradually ascended for half a mile , and then found [themselves]1887-they at the top of a considerable eminence , where [the wood]1891-the wood ceased , and the eye was instantly caught by [Pemberley House]56-pemberley house , situated on the opposite side of [a valley]1892-a valley , into which [the road]1317-the road with some abruptness wound . [It]56-pemberley house was [a large , handsome , stone building , standing well on rising ground , and backed by [a ridge of high woody hills;--and in front , a stream of some natural importance]1895-a ridge of high woody hills;--and in front , a stream of some natural importance]1894-a large , handsome , stone building , standing well on rising ground , and backed by a ridge of high woody hills;--and in front , a stream of some natural importance was swelled into greater , but without any artificial appearance . [Its]56-pemberley house banks were neither formal , nor falsely adorned . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was delighted . [She]93-elizabeth had never seen a place for which nature had done more , or where natural beauty had been so little counteracted by an awkward taste . [They]1887-they were all of [them]1887-they warm in [their]1887-they admiration ; and at that moment [she]93-elizabeth felt , that to be [mistress of [Pemberley]12-pemberley]1896-mistress of pemberley might be something !

[They]1887-they descended [the hill]1897-the hill , crossed [the bridge]1898-the bridge , and drove to the door ; and , while examining the nearer aspect of [the house]3026-the house , all [her]93-elizabeth apprehensions of meeting [its owner]1855-its owner returned . [She]93-elizabeth dreaded lest [the chambermaid]1882-the chambermaid had been mistaken . On applying to see [the place]3023-the place , [they]1887-they were admitted into [the hall]708-the hall ; and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , as [they]1887-they waited for [the housekeeper]839-the housekeeper , had leisure to wonder at [her]839-the housekeeper being where [she]839-the housekeeper was .

[The housekeeper]839-the housekeeper came ; [a respectable - looking , elderly woman , much less fine , and more civil]1906-a respectable - looking , elderly woman , much less fine , and more civil , than [she]839-the housekeeper had any notion of finding [her]839-the housekeeper . [They]1887-they followed [her]839-the housekeeper into [the dining - parlour]528-the dining - parlour . [It]528-the dining - parlour was [a large , well - proportioned room , handsomely fitted up]1908-a large , well - proportioned room , handsomely fitted up . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , after slightly surveying [it]528-the dining - parlour , went to a window to enjoy [its]528-the dining - parlour prospect . [The hill]1897-the hill , crowned with wood , from which [they]1887-they had descended , receiving increased abruptness from the distance , was a beautiful object . Every disposition of [the ground]1910-the ground was good ; and [she]93-elizabeth looked on the whole scene , [the river]1911-the river , the trees scattered on [its]1911-the river banks , and [the winding of [the valley]1913-the valley]1912-the winding of the valley , as far as [she]93-elizabeth could trace [it]1911-the river , with delight . As [they]1887-they passed into [other rooms]1914-other rooms , these objects were taking different positions ; but from every window there were beauties to be seen . [The rooms]1915-the rooms were lofty and handsome , and [their]1915-the rooms furniture suitable to the fortune of [[their]1915-the rooms proprietor]1916-their proprietor ; but [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth saw , with admiration of [his]1916-their proprietor taste , that it was neither gaudy nor uselessly fine ; with less of splendor , and more real elegance , than the furniture of Rosings .

" And of [this place]4437-this place , "[93-elizabeth] thought [she]93-elizabeth , " [I]93-elizabeth might have been [mistress]4438-mistress ! With [these rooms]4439-these rooms [I]93-elizabeth might now have been familiarly acquainted ! Instead of viewing [them]4439-these rooms as [a stranger]3405-a stranger , [I]93-elizabeth might have rejoiced in [them]4439-these rooms as [my]93-elizabeth own , and welcomed to [them]4439-these rooms as [visitors]1147-visitors [[my]93-elizabeth uncle]3468-my uncle and aunt.--But no,"--recollecting[93-elizabeth] [herself,--"that]4443-herself,--"that could never be : [[my]93-elizabeth uncle]3468-my uncle and [aunt]3947-aunt would have been lost to [me]93-elizabeth : [I]93-elizabeth should not have been allowed to invite [them]4439-these rooms . "[93-elizabeth]

This was a lucky recollection -- it saved [her]1917-her from something like regret .

[She]1917-her longed to enquire of [the housekeeper]839-the housekeeper , whether [[her]1917-her master]1919-her master were really absent , but had not courage for it . At length , however , the question was asked by [[her]1917-her uncle]583-her uncle ; and [she]1917-her turned away with alarm , while [Mrs. Reynolds]212-mrs. reynolds replied , that [he]583-her uncle was , adding , " but [we]1921-we expect [him]583-her uncle to - morrow , with [a large party of [friends]3767-friends]4446-a large party of friends . "[583-her uncle] How rejoiced was [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth that [their]1921-we own journey had not by any circumstance been delayed a day !

[[Her]1917-her aunt]1226-her aunt now called [her]1917-her to look at a picture . [She]1917-her approached , and saw the likeness of [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham suspended , amongst several other miniatures , over the mantle - piece . [[Her]1917-her aunt]1226-her aunt asked [her]1917-her , smilingly , how [she]1917-her liked it . [The housekeeper]839-the housekeeper came forward , and told [them]1921-we it was the picture of [a young gentleman , the son of [[her]1917-her late master 's steward]1925-her late master 's steward , who had been brought up by [him]156-wickham at [[his]156-wickham own expence.--"He]4449-his own expence.--"he]4448-a young gentleman , the son of her late master 's steward , who had been brought up by him at his own expence.--"he is now gone into [the army]4450-the army , "[839-the housekeeper] [she]839-the housekeeper added , " but [I]839-the housekeeper am afraid [he]156-wickham has turned out very wild . "[839-the housekeeper]

[Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner looked at [[her]141-mrs. gardiner niece]1304-her niece with a smile , but [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth could not return it .

" And that , "[212-mrs. reynolds] said [Mrs. Reynolds]212-mrs. reynolds , pointing to another of the miniatures , " is [[my]212-mrs. reynolds master]4451-my master -- and very like [him]4451-my master . It was drawn at the same time as the other -- about eight years ago . "[212-mrs. reynolds]

" [I]141-mrs. gardiner have heard much of [[[your]93-elizabeth master]4452-your master 's fine person]4453-your master 's fine person , "[141-mrs. gardiner] said [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner , looking at the picture ; " it is a handsome face . But , [Lizzy]93-elizabeth , [you]93-elizabeth can tell [us]4454-us whether it is like or not . "[141-mrs. gardiner]

[Mrs. Reynolds]212-mrs. reynolds 's respect for [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth seemed to increase on this intimation of [her]93-elizabeth knowing [[her]93-elizabeth master]1919-her master .

" Does [that young lady]3610-that young lady know [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy ? "[212-mrs. reynolds]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth coloured , and said--"A little . "[93-elizabeth]

" And do not [you]93-elizabeth think [him]4451-my master [a very handsome gentleman]4456-a very handsome gentleman , [Ma'am]120-ma'am ? "[212-mrs. reynolds]

" Yes , very handsome . "[93-elizabeth]

" [I]212-mrs. reynolds am sure _ [I]212-mrs. reynolds _ know none so handsome ; but in [the gallery up stairs]4457-the gallery up stairs [you]93-elizabeth will see a finer , larger picture of [him]4451-my master than this . [This room]4458-this room was [[[my]212-mrs. reynolds late master]4459-my late master 's favourite room]4460-my late master 's favourite room , and these miniatures are just as they used to be then . [He]4451-my master was very fond of them . "[212-mrs. reynolds]

This accounted to [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth for [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham 's being among [them]1928-them .

[Mrs. Reynolds]212-mrs. reynolds then directed [their]1929-their attention to one of [Miss Darcy]139-miss darcy , drawn when [she]139-miss darcy was only eight years old .

" And is [Miss Darcy]139-miss darcy as handsome as [[her]139-miss darcy brother]3126-her brother ? "[180-mr. gardiner] said [Mr. Gardiner]180-mr. gardiner .

" Oh ! yes -- [the handsomest young lady that ever was seen]4462-the handsomest young lady that ever was seen ; and so accomplished!--She plays and sings all day long . In [the next room]4463-the next room is a new instrument just come down for [her]139-miss darcy -- a present from [[my]139-miss darcy master]4451-my master ; [she]139-miss darcy comes here to - morrow with [him]4451-my master . "[139-miss darcy]

[Mr. Gardiner]180-mr. gardiner , whose manners were easy and pleasant , encouraged [her]93-elizabeth communicativeness by [his]180-mr. gardiner questions and remarks ; [Mrs. Reynolds]212-mrs. reynolds , either from pride or attachment , had evidently great pleasure in talking of [[her]212-mrs. reynolds master]1919-her master and [[his]1919-her master sister]569-his sister .

" Is [[your]139-miss darcy master]4452-your master much at [Pemberley]12-pemberley in the course of the year ? "[1919-her master]

" Not so much as [I]1919-her master could wish , [Sir]3172-sir ; but [I]1919-her master dare say [he]4452-your master may spend half [his]4452-your master time [here]3019-here ; and [Miss Darcy]139-miss darcy is always down for the summer months . "[1919-her master]

" Except , "[93-elizabeth] thought [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , " when [she]139-miss darcy goes to [Ramsgate]37-ramsgate . "[93-elizabeth]

" If [[your]139-miss darcy master]4452-your master would marry , [you]139-miss darcy might see more of [him]4452-your master . "[1919-her master]

" Yes , [Sir]3172-sir ; but [I]93-elizabeth do not know when _ that _ will be . [I]93-elizabeth do not know who is good enough for [him]4452-your master . "[93-elizabeth]

[Mr.]1932-mr. and [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner smiled . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth could not help saying , " It is very much to [his]4452-your master credit , [I]93-elizabeth am sure , that [you]3172-sir should think so . "[93-elizabeth]

" [I]3363-the other say no more than the truth , and what every body will say that knows [him]4452-your master , "[3363-the other] replied [the other]3363-the other . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth thought this was going pretty far ; and [she]93-elizabeth listened with increasing astonishment as [the housekeeper]839-the housekeeper added , " [I]839-the housekeeper have never had a cross word from [him]4452-your master in [my]839-the housekeeper life , and [I]839-the housekeeper have known [him]4452-your master ever since [he]4452-your master was four years old . "[839-the housekeeper]

This was praise , of all others most extraordinary , most opposite to [her]93-elizabeth ideas . That [he]1932-mr. was not [a good - tempered man]1935-a good - tempered man , had been [her]93-elizabeth firmest opinion . [Her]93-elizabeth keenest attention was awakened ; [she]93-elizabeth longed to hear more , and was grateful to [[her]93-elizabeth uncle]583-her uncle for saying ,

" There are [very few people of whom so much]4470-very few people of whom so much can be said . [You]93-elizabeth are lucky in having such [a master]4471-a master . "[583-her uncle]

" Yes , [Sir]3172-sir , [I]1935-a good - tempered man know [I]1935-a good - tempered man am . If [I]1935-a good - tempered man was to go through [the world]323-the world , [I]1935-a good - tempered man could not meet with a better . But [I]1935-a good - tempered man have always observed , that [they]4474-they who are good - natured when [children]4475-children , are good - natured when [they]4474-they grow up ; and [he]4471-a master was always [the sweetest - tempered , most generous - hearted , boy in [the world]323-the world]4476-the sweetest - tempered , most generous - hearted , boy in the world . "[1935-a good - tempered man]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth almost stared at her.--"Can this be [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy ! "[93-elizabeth] thought [she]93-elizabeth .

" [[His]4471-a master father]360-his father was [an excellent man]4479-an excellent man , "[141-mrs. gardiner] said [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner .

" Yes , [Ma'am]120-ma'am , that [he]360-his father was indeed ; and [[his]360-his father son]3516-his son will be just like [him]360-his father -- just as affable to [the poor]3539-the poor . "[1935-a good - tempered man]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth listened , wondered , doubted , and was impatient for more . [Mrs. Reynolds]212-mrs. reynolds could interest [her]93-elizabeth on no other point . [She]93-elizabeth related the subject of the pictures , the dimensions of [the rooms]1915-the rooms , and the price of the furniture , in vain . [Mr. Gardiner]180-mr. gardiner , highly amused by the kind of family prejudice , to which [he]180-mr. gardiner attributed [her]93-elizabeth excessive commendation of [[her]93-elizabeth master]1919-her master , soon led again to the subject ; and [she]93-elizabeth dwelt with energy on [his]1919-her master many merits , as [they]1939-they proceeded together up the great staircase .

" [He]1919-her master is [the best landlord]4482-the best landlord , and [the best master]4483-the best master , "[93-elizabeth] said [she]93-elizabeth , " that ever lived . Not like [the wild young men]4484-the wild young men now - a - days , who think of nothing but [themselves]4484-the wild young men . There is not one of [[his]1919-her master tenants]3538-his tenants or [servants]1377-servants but what will give [him]1919-her master a good name . [Some people]4088-some people call [him]1919-her master proud ; but [I]93-elizabeth am sure [I]93-elizabeth never saw any thing of it . To [my]93-elizabeth fancy , it is only because [he]1919-her master does not rattle away like [other young men]4488-other young men . "[93-elizabeth]

" In what an amiable light does this place [him]1919-her master ! "[93-elizabeth] thought [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth .

" This fine account of [him]1919-her master , "[1226-her aunt] whispered [[her]93-elizabeth aunt]1226-her aunt , as [they]1941-they walked , " is not quite consistent with [his]1919-her master behaviour to [[our]1941-they poor friend]4489-our poor friend . "[1226-her aunt]

" Perhaps [we]1941-they might be deceived . "[93-elizabeth]

" That is not very likely ; [our]1941-they authority was too good . "[1226-her aunt]

On reaching [the spacious lobby above]1942-the spacious lobby above , [they]1941-they were shewn into [a very pretty sitting - room , lately fitted up with greater elegance and lightness than [the apartments below]1944-the apartments below]1943-a very pretty sitting - room , lately fitted up with greater elegance and lightness than the apartments below ; and were informed that it was but just done , to give pleasure to [Miss Darcy]139-miss darcy , who had taken a liking to [the room]271-the room , when last at [Pemberley]12-pemberley .

" [He]1919-her master is certainly [a good brother]4490-a good brother , "[93-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , as [she]93-elizabeth walked towards one of the windows .

[Mrs. Reynolds]212-mrs. reynolds anticipated [Miss Darcy]139-miss darcy 's delight , when [she]212-mrs. reynolds should enter [the room]271-the room . " And this is always the way with [him]1919-her master , "[139-miss darcy] [she]139-miss darcy added.--"Whatever can give [[his]1919-her master sister]569-his sister any pleasure , is sure to be done in a moment . There is nothing [he]1919-her master would not do for [her]569-his sister . "[139-miss darcy]

[The picture gallery]1947-the picture gallery , and two or three of [the principal bed - rooms]1948-the principal bed - rooms , were all that remained to be shewn . In the former were many good paintings ; but [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth knew nothing of the art ; and from such as had been already visible below , [she]93-elizabeth had willingly turned to look at some drawings of [Miss Darcy]139-miss darcy 's , in crayons , whose subjects were usually more interesting , and also more intelligible .

In [the gallery]1949-the gallery there were many family portraits , but they could have little to fix the attention of [a stranger]3405-a stranger . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth walked on in quest of the only face whose features would be known to [her]93-elizabeth . At last it arrested [her]93-elizabeth -- and [she]93-elizabeth beheld a striking resemblance of [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , with such a smile over the face , as [she]93-elizabeth remembered to have sometimes seen , when [he]100-mr. darcy looked at [her]93-elizabeth . [She]93-elizabeth stood several minutes before the picture in earnest contemplation , and returned to it again before [they]1951-they quitted [the gallery]1949-the gallery . [Mrs. Reynolds]212-mrs. reynolds informed [them]1951-they , that it had been taken in [[his]100-mr. darcy father]360-his father 's life time .

There was certainly at this moment , in [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth 's mind , a more gentle sensation towards the original , than [she]93-elizabeth had ever felt in the height of [their]1951-they acquaintance . The commendation bestowed on [him]100-mr. darcy by [Mrs. Reynolds]212-mrs. reynolds was of no trifling nature . What praise is more valuable than the praise of [an intelligent servant]1954-an intelligent servant ? As [a brother]452-a brother , [a landlord]1956-a landlord , [a master]4471-a master , [she]93-elizabeth considered how many [people]3236-people 's happiness were in [his]100-mr. darcy guardianship!--How much of pleasure or pain it was in [his]100-mr. darcy power to bestow!--How much of good or evil must be done by [him]100-mr. darcy ! Every idea that had been brought forward by [the housekeeper]839-the housekeeper was favourable to [his]100-mr. darcy character , and as [she]93-elizabeth stood before the canvas , on which [he]100-mr. darcy was represented , and fixed [his]100-mr. darcy eyes upon [herself]93-elizabeth , [she]93-elizabeth thought of [his]100-mr. darcy regard with a deeper sentiment of gratitude than it had ever raised before ; [she]93-elizabeth remembered its warmth , and softened its impropriety of expression .

When [all of [the house that was open to general inspection]1961-the house that was open to general inspection had been seen]1960-all of the house that was open to general inspection had been seen , [they]1962-they returned down [stairs]529-stairs , and taking leave of [the housekeeper]839-the housekeeper , were consigned over to [the gardener]1965-the gardener , who met [them]1962-they at [the hall]708-the hall door .

As [they]1962-they walked across [the lawn]1967-the lawn towards [the river]1911-the river , [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth turned back to look again ; [[her]93-elizabeth uncle]583-her uncle and [aunt]3947-aunt stopped also , and while [the former]347-the former was conjecturing as to the date of [the building]1972-the building , [the owner of [it]1972-the building [himself]1973-the owner of it himself]1973-the owner of it himself suddenly came forward from [the road]1317-the road , which led behind [it]1972-the building to [the stables]1975-the stables .

[They]1962-they were within twenty yards of [each other]3157-each other , and so abrupt was [his]1973-the owner of it himself appearance , that it was impossible to avoid [his]1973-the owner of it himself sight . [Their]1962-they eyes instantly met , and the cheeks of each were overspread with the deepest blush . [He]1973-the owner of it himself absolutely started , and for a moment seemed immoveable from surprise ; but shortly recovering [himself]1973-the owner of it himself , advanced towards [the party]3034-the party , and spoke to [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , if not in terms of perfect composure , at least of perfect civility .

[She]93-elizabeth had instinctively turned away ; but , stopping on [his]1973-the owner of it himself approach , received [his]1973-the owner of it himself compliments with an embarrassment impossible to be overcome . Had [his]1973-the owner of it himself first appearance , or [his]1973-the owner of it himself resemblance to the picture [they]1962-they had just been examining , been insufficient to assure [the other two]1978-the other two that [they]1962-they now saw [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , [the gardener]1965-the gardener 's expression of surprise , on beholding [[his]1973-the owner of it himself master]1980-his master , must immediately have told it . [They]1962-they stood a little aloof while [he]1973-the owner of it himself was talking to [[their]1962-they niece]1981-their niece , who , astonished and confused , scarcely dared lift [her]1981-their niece eyes to [his]1973-the owner of it himself face , and knew not what answer [she]1981-their niece returned to [his]1973-the owner of it himself civil enquiries after [[her]1981-their niece family]905-her family . Amazed at the alteration in [his]1973-the owner of it himself manner since [they]1962-they last parted , every sentence that [he]1973-the owner of it himself uttered was increasing [her]1981-their niece embarrassment ; and every idea of the impropriety of [her]1981-their niece being found there , recurring to [her]1981-their niece mind , the few minutes in which [they]1962-they continued together , were some of the most uncomfortable of [her]1981-their niece life . Nor did [he]1973-the owner of it himself seem much more at ease ; when [he]1973-the owner of it himself spoke , [his]1973-the owner of it himself accent had none of its usual sedateness ; and [he]1973-the owner of it himself repeated [his]1973-the owner of it himself enquiries as to the time of [her]1981-their niece having left [Longbourn]7-longbourn , and of [her]1981-their niece stay in [Derbyshire]6-derbyshire , so often , and in so hurried a way , as plainly spoke the distraction of [his]1973-the owner of it himself thoughts .

At length , every idea seemed to fail [him]1973-the owner of it himself ; and , after standing a few moments without saying a word , [he]1973-the owner of it himself suddenly recollected [himself]1973-the owner of it himself , and took leave .

[The others]517-the others then joined [her]1981-their niece , and expressed [their]517-the others admiration of [his]1973-the owner of it himself figure ; but [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth heard not a word , and , wholly engrossed by [her]93-elizabeth own feelings , followed [them]517-the others in silence . [She]93-elizabeth was overpowered by shame and vexation . [Her]93-elizabeth coming there was the most unfortunate , the most ill - judged thing in [the world]323-the world ! How strange must it appear to [him]1973-the owner of it himself ! In what a disgraceful light might it not strike so vain [a man]3065-a man ! It might seem as if [she]93-elizabeth had purposely thrown [herself]93-elizabeth in [his]1973-the owner of it himself way again ! Oh ! why did [she]93-elizabeth come ? or , why did [he]1973-the owner of it himself thus come a day before [he]1973-the owner of it himself was expected ? Had [they]1986-they been only ten minutes sooner , [they]1986-they should have been beyond the reach of [his]1973-the owner of it himself discrimination , for it was plain that [he]1973-the owner of it himself was that moment arrived , that moment alighted from [his]1973-the owner of it himself horse or [[his]1973-the owner of it himself carriage]1987-his carriage . [She]93-elizabeth blushed again and again over the perverseness of the meeting . And [his]1973-the owner of it himself behaviour , so strikingly altered,--what could it mean ? That [he]1973-the owner of it himself should even speak to [her]93-elizabeth was amazing!--but to speak with such civility , to enquire after [[her]93-elizabeth family]905-her family ! Never in [her]93-elizabeth life had [she]93-elizabeth seen [his]1973-the owner of it himself manners so little dignified , never had [he]1973-the owner of it himself spoken with such gentleness as on this unexpected meeting . What a contrast did it offer to [his]1973-the owner of it himself last address in [Rosing 's Park]1989-rosing 's park , when [he]1973-the owner of it himself put [his]1973-the owner of it himself letter into [her]93-elizabeth hand ! [She]93-elizabeth knew not what to think , nor how to account for it .

[They]1990-they had now entered a beautiful walk by the side of [the water]1991-the water , and every step was bringing forward a nobler fall of ground , or a finer reach of [the woods to which [they]1990-they were approaching]1992-the woods to which they were approaching ; but it was some time before [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was sensible of any of it ; and , though [she]93-elizabeth answered mechanically to the repeated appeals of [[her]93-elizabeth uncle]583-her uncle and [aunt]3947-aunt , and seemed to direct [her]93-elizabeth eyes to such objects as [they]1990-they pointed out , [she]93-elizabeth distinguished no part of the scene . [Her]93-elizabeth thoughts were all fixed on [that one spot of [Pemberley House]56-pemberley house]1995-that one spot of pemberley house , whichever it might be , where [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy then was . [She]93-elizabeth longed to know what at that moment was passing in [his]1973-the owner of it himself mind ; in what manner [he]1973-the owner of it himself thought of [her]93-elizabeth , and whether , in defiance of every thing , [she]93-elizabeth was still dear to [him]1973-the owner of it himself . Perhaps [he]1973-the owner of it himself had been civil , only because [he]1973-the owner of it himself felt [himself]1973-the owner of it himself at ease ; yet there had been _ that _ in [his]1973-the owner of it himself voice , which was not like ease . Whether [he]1973-the owner of it himself had felt more of pain or of pleasure in seeing [her]93-elizabeth , [she]93-elizabeth could not tell , but [he]1973-the owner of it himself certainly had not seen [her]93-elizabeth with composure .

At length , however , the remarks of [[her]93-elizabeth companions]3872-her companions on [her]93-elizabeth absence of mind roused [her]93-elizabeth , and [she]93-elizabeth felt the necessity of appearing more like [herself]93-elizabeth .

[They]1997-they entered [the woods]1998-the woods , and bidding adieu to [the river]1911-the river for a while , ascended some of [the higher grounds]2000-the higher grounds ; whence , in spots where the opening of the trees gave the eye power to wander , were many charming views of [the valley]1913-the valley , [the opposite hills]2002-the opposite hills , with [the long range of woods]2003-the long range of woods overspreading many , and occasionally part of [the stream]2004-the stream . [Mr. Gardiner]180-mr. gardiner expressed a wish of going round [the whole Park]2005-the whole park , but feared it might be beyond a walk . With a triumphant smile , [they]1997-they were told , that it was ten miles round . It settled the matter ; and [they]1997-they pursued the accustomed circuit ; which brought [them]1997-they again , after some time , in a descent among [hanging woods]2006-hanging woods , to the edge of [the water]1991-the water , in one of [its]1991-the water narrowest parts . [They]1997-they crossed [it]1991-the water by [a simple bridge]2008-a simple bridge , in character with the general air of the scene ; it was [a spot less adorned than any [they]1997-they had yet visited]2009-a spot less adorned than any they had yet visited ; and [the valley]1913-the valley , here contracted into [a glen]2011-a glen , allowed room only for [the stream]2004-the stream , and a narrow walk amidst the rough coppice - wood which bordered [it]1991-the water . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth longed to explore [its]1991-the water windings ; but when [they]1997-they had crossed the bridge , and perceived [their]1997-they distance from [the house]3026-the house , [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner , who was not [a great walker]2014-a great walker , could go no farther , and thought only of returning to [the carriage]3221-the carriage as quickly as possible . [[Her]141-mrs. gardiner niece]1304-her niece was , therefore , obliged to submit , and [they]1997-they took [their]1997-they way towards [the house]3026-the house on [the opposite side of [the river]1911-the river]2018-the opposite side of the river , in the nearest direction ; but [their]1997-they progress was slow , for [Mr. Gardiner]180-mr. gardiner , though seldom able to indulge the taste , was very fond of fishing , and was so much engaged in watching the occasional appearance of some trout in [the water]1991-the water , and talking to [the man]3112-the man about [them]2022-them , that [he]3112-the man advanced but little . Whilst wandering on in this slow manner , [they]1997-they were again surprised , and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth 's astonishment was quite equal to what it had been at first , by the sight of [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy approaching [them]1997-they , and at no great distance . The walk being [here]3019-here less sheltered than on the other side , allowed [them]1997-they to see [him]100-mr. darcy before [they]1997-they met . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , however astonished , was at least more prepared for an interview than before , and resolved to appear and to speak with calmness , if [he]100-mr. darcy really intended to meet [them]1997-they . For a few moments , indeed , [she]93-elizabeth felt that [he]100-mr. darcy would probably strike into some other path . This idea lasted while a turning in the walk concealed [him]100-mr. darcy from [their]1997-they view ; the turning past , [he]100-mr. darcy was immediately before [them]1997-they . With a glance [she]93-elizabeth saw , that [he]100-mr. darcy had lost none of [his]100-mr. darcy recent civility ; and , to imitate [his]100-mr. darcy politeness , [she]93-elizabeth began , as [they]1997-they met , to admire the beauty of [the place]3023-the place ; but [she]93-elizabeth had not got beyond the words " delightful , "[93-elizabeth] and " charming , "[93-elizabeth] when some unlucky recollections obtruded , and [she]93-elizabeth fancied that praise of [Pemberley]12-pemberley from [her]93-elizabeth , might be mischievously construed . [Her]93-elizabeth colour changed , and [she]93-elizabeth said no more .

[Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner was standing a little behind ; and on [her]93-elizabeth pausing , [he]100-mr. darcy asked [her]93-elizabeth , if [she]93-elizabeth would do [him]100-mr. darcy the honour of introducing [him]100-mr. darcy to [[her]93-elizabeth friends]330-her friends . This was a stroke of civility for which [she]93-elizabeth was quite unprepared ; and [she]93-elizabeth could hardly suppress a smile , at [his]100-mr. darcy being now seeking the acquaintance of some of [those very people]2026-those very people , against whom [his]100-mr. darcy pride had revolted , in [his]100-mr. darcy offer to [herself]93-elizabeth . " What will be [his]100-mr. darcy surprise , "[93-elizabeth] thought [she]93-elizabeth , " when [he]100-mr. darcy knows who [they]2027-them are ! [He]100-mr. darcy takes them now for [people of fashion]4492-people of fashion . "[93-elizabeth]

The introduction , however , was immediately made ; and as [she]93-elizabeth named [their]2027-them relationship to [herself]93-elizabeth , [she]93-elizabeth stole a sly look at [him]100-mr. darcy , to see how [he]100-mr. darcy bore it ; and was not without the expectation of [his]100-mr. darcy decamping as fast as [he]100-mr. darcy could from [such disgraceful companions]2028-such disgraceful companions . That [he]100-mr. darcy was _ surprised _ by the connexion was evident ; [he]100-mr. darcy sustained it however with fortitude , and so far from going away , turned back with [them]2027-them , and entered into conversation with [Mr. Gardiner]180-mr. gardiner . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth could not but be pleased , could not but triumph . It was consoling , that [he]100-mr. darcy should know [she]93-elizabeth had [some relations for whom there was no need to blush]2029-some relations for whom there was no need to blush . [She]93-elizabeth listened most attentively to all that passed between [them]2027-them , and gloried in every expression , every sentence of [[her]93-elizabeth uncle]583-her uncle , which marked [his]100-mr. darcy intelligence , [his]100-mr. darcy taste , or [his]100-mr. darcy good manners .

The conversation soon turned upon fishing , and [she]93-elizabeth heard [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy invite [him]100-mr. darcy , with the greatest civility , to fish there as often as [he]100-mr. darcy chose , while [he]100-mr. darcy continued in [the neighbourhood]3040-the neighbourhood , offering at the same time to supply [him]100-mr. darcy with fishing tackle , and pointing out [those parts of [the stream]2004-the stream]2032-those parts of the stream where there was usually most sport . [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner , who was walking arm in arm with [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , gave [her]93-elizabeth a look expressive of [her]93-elizabeth wonder . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth said nothing , but it gratified [her]93-elizabeth exceedingly ; the compliment must be all for [herself]93-elizabeth . [Her]93-elizabeth astonishment , however , was extreme ; and continually was [she]93-elizabeth repeating , " Why is [he]100-mr. darcy so altered ? From what can it proceed ? It can not be for _ [me]93-elizabeth _ , it can not be for _ [my]93-elizabeth _ sake that [his]100-mr. darcy manners are thus softened . [My]93-elizabeth reproofs at [Hunsford]16-hunsford could not work such a change as this . It is impossible that [he]100-mr. darcy should still love [me]93-elizabeth . "[93-elizabeth]

After walking some time in this way , [the two ladies in front]2034-the two ladies in front , [the two gentlemen]782-the two gentlemen behind , on resuming [their]2034-the two ladies in front places , after descending to [the brink of [the river]1911-the river]2036-the brink of the river for the better inspection of some curious water - plant , there chanced to be a little alteration . It originated in [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner , who , fatigued by the exercise of the morning , found [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth 's arm inadequate to [her]141-mrs. gardiner support , and consequently preferred [[her]141-mrs. gardiner husband]276-her husband 's . [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy took [her]141-mrs. gardiner place by [[her]141-mrs. gardiner niece]1304-her niece , and [they]2040-we walked on together . After a short silence , [the lady]595-the lady first spoke . [She]595-the lady wished [him]276-her husband to know that [she]595-the lady had been assured of [his]276-her husband absence before [she]595-the lady came to [the place]3023-the place , and accordingly began by observing , that [his]276-her husband arrival had been very unexpected--"for [[your]276-her husband housekeeper]4493-your housekeeper , "[595-the lady] [she]595-the lady added , " informed [us]2040-we that [you]276-her husband would certainly not be here till to - morrow ; and indeed , before [we]2040-we left [Bakewell]57-bakewell , [we]2040-we understood that [you]276-her husband were not immediately expected in [the country]460-the country . "[595-the lady] [He]276-her husband acknowledged the truth of it all ; and said that business with [[his]276-her husband steward]2043-his steward had occasioned [his]276-her husband coming forward a few hours before the rest of [the party with whom [he]276-her husband had been travelling]2044-the party with whom he had been travelling . " [They]4495-they will join [me]276-her husband early to - morrow , "[276-her husband] [he]276-her husband continued , " and among [them]4495-they are [some who will claim an acquaintance with you,--Mr]4496-some who will claim an acquaintance with you,--mr . [Bingley]90-mr. bingley and [[his]90-mr. bingley sisters]303-his sisters . "[276-her husband]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth answered only by a slight bow .
