[Her]93-elizabeth thoughts were instantly driven back to the time when [Mr. Bingley]90-mr. bingley 's name had been last mentioned between [them]2045-them ; and if [she]93-elizabeth might judge from [his]276-her husband complexion , _ [his]276-her husband _ mind was not very differently engaged .

" There is also [one other person in the party]4498-one other person in the party , "[276-her husband] [he]276-her husband continued after a pause , " who more particularly wishes to be known to you,--Will [you]93-elizabeth allow [me]276-her husband , or do [I]276-her husband ask too much , to introduce [[my]276-her husband sister]3284-my sister to [your]93-elizabeth acquaintance during [your]93-elizabeth stay at [Lambton]53-lambton ? "[276-her husband]

The surprise of such an application was great indeed ; it was too great for [her]93-elizabeth to know in what manner [she]93-elizabeth acceded to it . [She]93-elizabeth immediately felt that whatever desire [Miss Darcy]139-miss darcy might have of being acquainted with [her]93-elizabeth , must be the work of [[her]93-elizabeth brother]3126-her brother , and without looking farther , it was satisfactory ; it was gratifying to know that [his]276-her husband resentment had not made [him]276-her husband think really ill of [her]93-elizabeth .

[They]2047-they now walked on in silence ; each of [them]2047-they deep in thought . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was not comfortable ; that was impossible ; but [she]93-elizabeth was flattered and pleased . [His]276-her husband wish of introducing [[his]276-her husband sister]569-his sister to [her]93-elizabeth , was a compliment of the highest kind . [They]2047-they soon outstripped [the others]517-the others , and when [they]2047-they had reached [the carriage]3221-the carriage , [Mr.]2051-mr. and [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner were half a quarter of a mile behind .

[He]276-her husband then asked [her]93-elizabeth to walk into [the house]3026-the house -- but [she]93-elizabeth declared [herself]93-elizabeth not tired , and [they]2047-they stood together on [the lawn]1967-the lawn . At such a time , much might have been said , and silence was very awkward . [She]93-elizabeth wanted to talk , but there seemed an embargo on every subject . At last [she]93-elizabeth recollected that [she]93-elizabeth had been travelling , and [they]2047-they talked of [Matlock]178-matlock and [Dove Dale]213-dove dale with great perseverance . Yet time and [[her]93-elizabeth aunt]1226-her aunt moved slowly -- and [her]93-elizabeth patience and [her]93-elizabeth ideas were nearly worn out before the t?te-?-t?te was over . On [Mr.]2055-mr. and [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner 's coming up , [they]2047-they were all pressed to go into [the house]3026-the house and take some refreshment ; but this was declined , and [they]2047-they parted on each side with the utmost politeness . [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy handed [the ladies]269-the ladies into [the carriage]3221-the carriage , and when it drove off , [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth saw [him]100-mr. darcy walking slowly towards [the house]3026-the house .

The observations of [[her]93-elizabeth uncle]583-her uncle and [aunt]3947-aunt now began ; and each of [them]2047-they pronounced [him]100-mr. darcy to be infinitely superior to any thing [they]2047-they had expected . " [He]100-mr. darcy is perfectly well behaved , polite , and unassuming , "[583-her uncle] said [[her]93-elizabeth uncle]583-her uncle .

" There _ is _ something a little stately in [him]100-mr. darcy to be sure , "[1226-her aunt] replied [[her]93-elizabeth aunt]1226-her aunt , " but it is confined to [his]100-mr. darcy air , and is not unbecoming . [I]1226-her aunt can now say with [the housekeeper]839-the housekeeper , that though [some people]4088-some people may call [him]100-mr. darcy proud , _ [I]1226-her aunt _ have seen nothing of it . "[1226-her aunt]

" [I]583-her uncle was never more surprised than by [his]100-mr. darcy behaviour to [us]4502-us . It was more than civil ; it was really attentive ; and there was no necessity for such attention . [His]100-mr. darcy acquaintance with [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was very trifling . "[583-her uncle]

" To be sure , [Lizzy]93-elizabeth , "[1226-her aunt] said [[her]93-elizabeth aunt]1226-her aunt , " [he]100-mr. darcy is not so handsome as [Wickham]156-wickham ; or rather [he]100-mr. darcy has not [Wickham]156-wickham 's countenance , for [his]100-mr. darcy features are perfectly good . But how came [you]1226-her aunt to tell [us]2066-us that [he]100-mr. darcy was so disagreeable ? "[1226-her aunt]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth excused [herself]93-elizabeth as well as [she]93-elizabeth could ; said that [she]93-elizabeth had liked [him]2065-him better when [they]2066-us met in [Kent]18-kent than before , and that [she]93-elizabeth had never seen [him]2065-him so pleasant as this morning .

" But perhaps [he]100-mr. darcy may be a little whimsical in [his]100-mr. darcy civilities , "[583-her uncle] replied [[her]93-elizabeth uncle]583-her uncle . " [[Your]93-elizabeth great men]4503-your great men often are ; and therefore [I]583-her uncle shall not take [him]100-mr. darcy at [his]100-mr. darcy word about fishing , as [he]100-mr. darcy might change [his]100-mr. darcy mind another day , and warn [me]583-her uncle off [[his]100-mr. darcy grounds]4504-his grounds . "[583-her uncle]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth felt that [they]2066-us had entirely mistaken [his]2065-him character , but said nothing .

" From what [we]2066-us have seen of [him]100-mr. darcy , "[141-mrs. gardiner] continued [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner , " [I]141-mrs. gardiner really should not have thought that [he]100-mr. darcy could have behaved in so cruel a way by any body , as [he]100-mr. darcy has done by [poor Wickham]156-wickham . [He]100-mr. darcy has not an ill - natured look . On the contrary , there is something pleasing about [his]100-mr. darcy mouth when [he]100-mr. darcy speaks . And there is something of dignity in [his]100-mr. darcy countenance , that would not give [one]3064-one an unfavourable idea of [his]100-mr. darcy heart . But to be sure , [the good lady who shewed [us]2066-us [the house]3026-the house]4506-the good lady who shewed us the house , did give [him]100-mr. darcy a most flaming character ! [I]141-mrs. gardiner could hardly help laughing aloud sometimes . But [he]100-mr. darcy is [a liberal master]4508-a liberal master , [I]141-mrs. gardiner suppose , and _ that _ in the eye of [a servant]510-a servant comprehends every virtue . "[141-mrs. gardiner]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth here felt [herself]93-elizabeth called on to say something in vindication of [his]2068-his behaviour to [Wickham]156-wickham ; and therefore gave [them]2069-they to understand , in as guarded a manner as [she]93-elizabeth could , that by what [she]93-elizabeth had heard from [[his]2068-his relations in [Kent]18-kent]2070-his relations in kent , [his]2068-his actions were capable of a very different construction ; and that [his]2068-his character was by no means so faulty , nor [Wickham]156-wickham 's so amiable , as they had been considered in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire . In confirmation of this , [she]93-elizabeth related the particulars of all the pecuniary transactions in which they had been connected , without actually naming [her]93-elizabeth authority , but stating it to be such as might be relied on .

[Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner was surprised and concerned ; but as [they]2069-they were now approaching the scene of [her]93-elizabeth former pleasures , every idea gave way to the charm of recollection ; and [she]93-elizabeth was too much engaged in pointing out to [[her]93-elizabeth husband]276-her husband all the interesting spots in [[its]2072-its environs]2073-its environs , to think of any thing else . Fatigued as [she]93-elizabeth had been by the morning 's walk , [they]2069-they had no sooner dined than [she]93-elizabeth set off again in quest of [[her]93-elizabeth former acquaintance]2074-her former acquaintance , and the evening was spent in the satisfactions of an intercourse renewed after many years discontinuance .

The occurrences of the day were too full of interest to leave [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth much attention for [any of [these new friends]2076-these new friends]2075-any of these new friends ; and [she]93-elizabeth could do nothing but think , and think with wonder , of [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy 's civility , and above all , of [his]100-mr. darcy wishing [her]93-elizabeth to be acquainted with [[his]100-mr. darcy sister]569-his sister .

CHAPTER II .

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth had settled it that [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy would bring [[his]100-mr. darcy sister]569-his sister to visit [her]93-elizabeth , the very day after [her]93-elizabeth reaching [Pemberley]12-pemberley ; and was consequently resolved not to be out of sight of [the inn]1736-the inn the whole of that morning . But [her]93-elizabeth conclusion was false ; for on the very morning after [their]2076-these new friends own arrival at [Lambton]53-lambton , [these visitors]2080-these visitors came . [They]2076-these new friends had been walking about [the place]3023-the place with [some of [[their]2076-these new friends new friends]2083-their new friends]2082-some of their new friends , and were just returned to [the inn]1736-the inn to dress [themselves]2076-these new friends for dining with [the same family]2085-the same family , when the sound of [a carriage]3138-a carriage drew [them]2076-these new friends to a window , and [they]2076-these new friends saw [a gentleman]3404-a gentleman and [lady in a curricle]2088-lady in a curricle , driving up [the street]771-the street . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth immediately recognising the livery , guessed what it meant , and imparted no small degree of surprise to [[her]93-elizabeth relations]588-her relations , by acquainting [them]588-her relations with the honour which [she]93-elizabeth expected . [[Her]93-elizabeth uncle]583-her uncle and [aunt]3947-aunt were all amazement ; and the embarrassment of [her]93-elizabeth manner as [she]93-elizabeth spoke , joined to the circumstance itself , and many of the circumstances of the preceding day , opened to [them]588-her relations a new idea on the business . Nothing had ever suggested it before , but [they]588-her relations now felt that there was no other way of accounting for such attentions from such a quarter , than by supposing a partiality for [[their]588-her relations niece]1981-their niece . While these newly - born notions were passing in [their]588-her relations heads , the perturbation of [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth 's feelings was every moment increasing . [She]93-elizabeth was quite amazed at [her]93-elizabeth own discomposure ; but amongst other causes of disquiet , [she]93-elizabeth dreaded lest the partiality of [the brother]1272-the brother should have said too much in [her]93-elizabeth favour ; and more than commonly anxious to please , [she]93-elizabeth naturally suspected that every power of pleasing would fail [her]93-elizabeth .

[She]93-elizabeth retreated from the window , fearful of being seen ; and as [she]93-elizabeth walked up and down [the room]271-the room , endeavouring to compose [herself]93-elizabeth , saw such looks of enquiring surprise in [[her]93-elizabeth uncle]583-her uncle and [aunt]3947-aunt , as made every thing worse .

[Miss Darcy]139-miss darcy and [[her]139-miss darcy brother]3126-her brother appeared , and this formidable introduction took place . With astonishment did [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth see , that [[her]93-elizabeth new acquaintance]2099-her new acquaintance was at least as much embarrassed as [herself]93-elizabeth . Since [her]93-elizabeth being at [Lambton]53-lambton , [she]93-elizabeth had heard that [Miss Darcy]139-miss darcy was exceedingly proud ; but the observation of a very few minutes convinced [her]93-elizabeth , that [she]139-miss darcy was only exceedingly shy . [She]93-elizabeth found it difficult to obtain even a word from [her]139-miss darcy beyond a monosyllable .

[Miss Darcy]139-miss darcy was tall , and on a larger scale than [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth ; and , though little more than sixteen , [her]139-miss darcy figure was formed , and [her]139-miss darcy appearance womanly and graceful . [She]139-miss darcy was less handsome than [[her]139-miss darcy brother]3126-her brother , but there was sense and good humour in [her]139-miss darcy face , and [her]139-miss darcy manners were perfectly unassuming and gentle . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , who had expected to find in [her]139-miss darcy as acute and unembarrassed an observer as ever [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy had been , was much relieved by discerning such different feelings .

[They]2101-they had not been long together , before [Darcy]100-mr. darcy told [her]93-elizabeth that [Bingley]90-mr. bingley was also coming to wait on [her]93-elizabeth ; and [she]93-elizabeth had barely time to express [her]93-elizabeth satisfaction , and prepare for [such a visitor]2102-such a visitor , when [Bingley]90-mr. bingley 's quick step was heard on the stairs , and in a moment [he]90-mr. bingley entered [the room]271-the room . All [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth 's anger against [him]100-mr. darcy had been long done away ; but , had [she]93-elizabeth still felt any , it could hardly have stood its ground against the unaffected cordiality with which [he]100-mr. darcy expressed [himself]100-mr. darcy , on seeing [her]93-elizabeth again . [He]100-mr. darcy enquired in a friendly , though general way , after [[her]93-elizabeth family]905-her family , and looked and spoke with the same good - humoured ease that [he]100-mr. darcy had ever done .

To [Mr.]2105-mr. and [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner [he]100-mr. darcy was scarcely [a less interesting personage than to [herself]93-elizabeth]2106-a less interesting personage than to herself . [They]2107-they had long wished to see [him]100-mr. darcy . The whole party before [them]2107-they , indeed , excited a lively attention . The suspicions which had just arisen of [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy and [[their]2107-they niece]1981-their niece , directed [their]2107-they observation towards [each]887-each with an earnest , though guarded , enquiry ; and [they]2107-they soon drew from those enquiries the full conviction that one of [them]2107-they at least knew what it was to love . Of [the lady]595-the lady 's sensations [they]2107-they remained a little in doubt ; but that [the gentleman]306-the gentleman was overflowing with admiration was evident enough .

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , on [her]93-elizabeth side , had much to do . [She]93-elizabeth wanted to ascertain the feelings of [each of [[her]93-elizabeth visitors]1394-her visitors]2112-each of her visitors , [she]93-elizabeth wanted to compose [her]93-elizabeth own , and to make [herself]93-elizabeth agreeable to [all]778-all ; and in the latter object , where [she]93-elizabeth feared most to fail , [she]93-elizabeth was most sure of success , for those to whom [she]93-elizabeth endeavoured to give pleasure were prepossessed in [her]93-elizabeth favour . [Bingley]90-mr. bingley was ready , [Georgiana]175-georgiana was eager , and [Darcy]175-georgiana determined , to be pleased .

In seeing [Bingley]90-mr. bingley , [her]93-elizabeth thoughts naturally flew to [[her]93-elizabeth sister]348-her sister ; and oh ! how ardently did [she]93-elizabeth long to know , whether any of [his]90-mr. bingley were directed in a like manner . Sometimes [she]93-elizabeth could fancy , that [he]90-mr. bingley talked less than on former occasions , and once or twice pleased [herself]93-elizabeth with the notion that as [he]90-mr. bingley looked at [her]93-elizabeth , [he]90-mr. bingley was trying to trace a resemblance . But , though this might be imaginary , [she]93-elizabeth could not be deceived as to [his]90-mr. bingley behaviour to [Miss Darcy]139-miss darcy , who had been set up as [a rival of [Jane]94-jane]2116-a rival of jane . No look appeared on either side that spoke particular regard . Nothing occurred between [them]2117-we that could justify the hopes of [[his]90-mr. bingley sister]569-his sister . On this point [she]93-elizabeth was soon satisfied ; and two or three little circumstances occurred ere [they]2117-we parted , which , in [her]93-elizabeth anxious interpretation , denoted a recollection of [Jane]94-jane , not untinctured by tenderness , and a wish of saying more that might lead to the mention of [her]94-jane , had [he]90-mr. bingley dared . [He]90-mr. bingley observed to [her]93-elizabeth , at a moment when [the others]517-the others were talking together , and in a tone which had something of real regret , that it " was a very long time since [he]90-mr. bingley had had the pleasure of seeing [her]94-jane ; "[90-mr. bingley] and , before [she]93-elizabeth could reply , [he]90-mr. bingley added , " It is above eight months . [We]2117-we have not met since the 26th of November , when [we]2117-we were all dancing together at [Netherfield]2-netherfield . "[90-mr. bingley]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was pleased to find [his]90-mr. bingley memory so exact ; and [he]90-mr. bingley afterwards took occasion to ask [her]93-elizabeth , when unattended to by any of [the rest]270-the rest , whether _ all _ [[her]93-elizabeth sisters]3048-her sisters were at [Longbourn]7-longbourn . There was not much in the question , nor in the preceding remark , but there was a look and a manner which gave [them]2122-them meaning .

It was not often that [she]93-elizabeth could turn [her]93-elizabeth eyes on [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy [himself]100-mr. darcy ; but , whenever [she]93-elizabeth did catch a glimpse , [she]93-elizabeth saw an expression of general complaisance , and in all that [he]100-mr. darcy said , [she]93-elizabeth heard an accent so far removed from hauteur or disdain of [[his]100-mr. darcy companions]2123-his companions , as convinced [her]93-elizabeth that the improvement of manners which [she]93-elizabeth had yesterday witnessed , however temporary its existence might prove , had at least outlived one day . When [she]93-elizabeth saw [him]100-mr. darcy thus seeking the acquaintance , and courting the good opinion of [people , with whom any intercourse a few months ago would have been a disgrace]2124-people , with whom any intercourse a few months ago would have been a disgrace ; when [she]93-elizabeth saw [him]100-mr. darcy thus civil , not only to [herself]93-elizabeth , but to the very relations whom [he]100-mr. darcy had openly disdained , and recollected [their]2125-their last lively scene in [Hunsford Parsonage]26-hunsford parsonage , the difference , the change was so great , and struck so forcibly on [her]93-elizabeth mind , that [she]93-elizabeth could hardly restrain [her]93-elizabeth astonishment from being visible . Never , even in the company of [[his]100-mr. darcy dear friends]2126-his dear friends at [Netherfield]2-netherfield , or [his]100-mr. darcy dignified relations at [Rosings]22-rosings , had [she]93-elizabeth seen [him]100-mr. darcy so desirous to please , so free from self - consequence , or unbending reserve as now , when no importance could result from the success of [his]100-mr. darcy endeavours , and when even the acquaintance of those to whom [his]100-mr. darcy attentions were addressed , would draw down the ridicule and censure of [the ladies both of [Netherfield]2-netherfield and [Rosings]22-rosings]2127-the ladies both of netherfield and rosings .

[[Their]2125-their visitors]2128-their visitors staid with [them]2125-their above half an hour , and when [they]2125-their arose to depart , [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy called on [[his]100-mr. darcy sister]569-his sister to join [him]100-mr. darcy in expressing [their]2125-their wish of seeing [Mr.]2130-mr. and [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner , and [Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth , to dinner at [Pemberley]12-pemberley , before [they]2125-their left [the country]460-the country . [Miss Darcy]139-miss darcy , though with a diffidence which marked [her]139-miss darcy little in the habit of giving invitations , readily obeyed . [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner looked at [[her]141-mrs. gardiner niece]1304-her niece , desirous of knowing how _ [she]1304-her niece _ , whom the invitation most concerned , felt disposed as to its acceptance , but [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth had turned away [her]93-elizabeth head . Presuming , however , that this studied avoidance spoke rather a momentary embarrassment , than any dislike of the proposal , and seeing in [[her]93-elizabeth husband]276-her husband , who was fond of society , a perfect willingness to accept it , [she]93-elizabeth ventured to engage for [her]93-elizabeth attendance , and the day after the next was fixed on .

[Bingley]90-mr. bingley expressed great pleasure in the certainty of seeing [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth again , having still a great deal to say to [her]93-elizabeth , and many enquiries to make after all [[their]2125-their Hertfordshire friends]2134-their hertfordshire friends . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , construing all this into a wish of hearing [her]93-elizabeth speak of [[her]93-elizabeth sister]348-her sister , was pleased ; and on this account , as well as [some others]2136-some others , found [herself]93-elizabeth , when [[their]2125-their visitors]2128-their visitors left [them]2125-their , capable of considering the last half hour with some satisfaction , though while it was passing , the enjoyment of it had been little . Eager to be alone , and fearful of enquiries or hints from [[her]93-elizabeth uncle]583-her uncle and aunt , [she]93-elizabeth staid with [them]2125-their only long enough to hear [their]2125-their favourable opinion of [Bingley]90-mr. bingley , and then hurried away to dress .

But [she]93-elizabeth had no reason to fear [Mr.]2139-mr. and [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner 's curiosity ; it was not [their]2125-their wish to force [her]93-elizabeth communication . It was evident that [she]93-elizabeth was much better acquainted with [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy than [they]2125-their had before any idea of ; it was evident that [he]100-mr. darcy was very much in love with [her]93-elizabeth . [They]2125-their saw much to interest , but nothing to justify enquiry .

Of [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy it was now a matter of anxiety to think well ; and , as far as [their]2125-their acquaintance reached , there was no fault to find . [They]2125-their could not be untouched by [his]100-mr. darcy politeness , and had [they]2125-their drawn [his]100-mr. darcy character from [their]2125-their own feelings , and [[his]100-mr. darcy servant]2140-his servant 's report , without any reference to any other account , the circle in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire to which [he]100-mr. darcy was known , would not have recognised it for [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy . There was now an interest , however , in believing [the housekeeper]839-the housekeeper ; and [they]2125-their soon became sensible , that the authority of [a servant who had known [him]100-mr. darcy since [he]100-mr. darcy was four years old]2142-a servant who had known him since he was four years old , and whose own manners indicated respectability , was not to be hastily rejected . Neither had any thing occurred in the intelligence of [[their]2125-their Lambton friends]2143-their lambton friends , that could materially lessen its weight . [They]2125-their had nothing to accuse [him]100-mr. darcy of but pride ; pride [he]100-mr. darcy probably had , and if not , it would certainly be imputed by [the inhabitants of [a small market - town]2145-a small market - town , where [the family]432-the family did not visit]2144-the inhabitants of a small market - town , where the family did not visit . It was acknowledged , however , that [he]100-mr. darcy was [a liberal man]2147-a liberal man , and did much good among [the poor]3539-the poor .

With respect to [Wickham]156-wickham , [the travellers]2149-the travellers soon found that [he]100-mr. darcy was not held [there]325-there in much estimation ; for though the chief of [his]100-mr. darcy concerns , with [the son of [[his]100-mr. darcy patron]3662-his patron]2151-the son of his patron , were imperfectly understood , it was yet a well known fact that , on [his]100-mr. darcy quitting [Derbyshire]6-derbyshire , [he]100-mr. darcy had left many debts behind [him]100-mr. darcy , which [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy afterwards discharged .

As for [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , [her]93-elizabeth thoughts were at [Pemberley]12-pemberley this evening more than the last ; and the evening , though as it passed it seemed long , was not long enough to determine [her]93-elizabeth feelings towards [_ one _ in [that mansion]2154-that mansion]2153-_ one _ in that mansion ; and [she]93-elizabeth lay awake two whole hours , endeavouring to make them out . [She]93-elizabeth certainly did not hate [him]100-mr. darcy . No ; hatred had vanished long ago , and [she]93-elizabeth had almost as long been ashamed of ever feeling a dislike against [him]100-mr. darcy , that could be so called . The respect created by the conviction of [his]100-mr. darcy valuable qualities , though at first unwillingly admitted , had for some time ceased to be repugnant to [her]93-elizabeth feelings ; and it was now heightened into somewhat of a friendlier nature , by the testimony so highly in [his]100-mr. darcy favour , and bringing forward [his]100-mr. darcy disposition in so amiable a light , which yesterday had produced . But above all , above respect and esteem , there was a motive within [her]93-elizabeth of good will which could not be overlooked . It was gratitude.--Gratitude , not merely for having once loved [her]93-elizabeth , but for loving [her]93-elizabeth still well enough , to forgive all the petulance and acrimony of [her]93-elizabeth manner in rejecting [him]100-mr. darcy , and all the unjust accusations accompanying [her]93-elizabeth rejection . [He]100-mr. darcy who , [she]93-elizabeth had been persuaded , would avoid [her]93-elizabeth as [[his]100-mr. darcy greatest enemy]2155-his greatest enemy , seemed , on this accidental meeting , most eager to preserve the acquaintance , and without any indelicate display of regard , or any peculiarity of manner , where [their]2156-their two selves only were concerned , was soliciting the good opinion of [[her]93-elizabeth friends]330-her friends , and bent on making [her]93-elizabeth known to [[his]100-mr. darcy sister]569-his sister . Such a change in [a man of so much pride]2159-a man of so much pride , excited not only astonishment but gratitude -- for to love , ardent love , it must be attributed ; and as such its impression on [her]93-elizabeth was of a sort to be encouraged , as by no means unpleasing , though it could not be exactly defined . [She]93-elizabeth respected , [she]93-elizabeth esteemed , [she]93-elizabeth was grateful to [him]100-mr. darcy , [she]93-elizabeth felt a real interest in [his]100-mr. darcy welfare ; and [she]93-elizabeth only wanted to know how far [she]93-elizabeth wished that welfare to depend upon [herself]93-elizabeth , and how far it would be for the happiness of both that [she]93-elizabeth should employ the power , which [her]93-elizabeth fancy told [her]93-elizabeth [she]93-elizabeth still possessed , of bringing on the renewal of [his]100-mr. darcy addresses .

It had been settled in the evening , between [the aunt]2160-the aunt and [niece]2161-niece , that such a striking civility as [Miss Darcy]139-miss darcy 's , in coming to [them]2162-they on the very day of [her]139-miss darcy arrival at [Pemberley]12-pemberley , for [she]139-miss darcy had reached it only to a late breakfast , ought to be imitated , though it could not be equalled , by some exertion of politeness on [their]2162-they side ; and , consequently , that it would be highly expedient to wait on [her]139-miss darcy at [Pemberley]12-pemberley the following morning . [They]2162-they were , therefore , to go.--Elizabeth was pleased , though , when [she]93-elizabeth asked [herself]93-elizabeth the reason , [she]93-elizabeth had very little to say in reply .

[Mr. Gardiner]180-mr. gardiner left [them]2162-they soon after breakfast . The fishing scheme had been renewed the day before , and a positive engagement made of [his]180-mr. gardiner meeting [some of [the gentlemen at [Pemberley]12-pemberley]2164-the gentlemen at pemberley]2163-some of the gentlemen at pemberley by noon .

CHAPTER III .

Convinced as [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth now was that [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley 's dislike of [her]93-elizabeth had originated in jealousy , [she]93-elizabeth could not help feeling how very unwelcome [her]93-elizabeth appearance at [Pemberley]12-pemberley must be to [her]93-elizabeth , and was curious to know with how much civility on [that lady]2165-that lady 's side , the acquaintance would now be renewed .

On reaching [the house]3026-the house , [they]2162-they were shewn through [the hall]708-the hall into [the saloon]2168-the saloon , whose northern aspect rendered [it]2168-the saloon delightful for summer . [Its]2168-the saloon windows opening to the ground , admitted a most refreshing view of [the high woody hills behind [the house]3026-the house]2169-the high woody hills behind the house , and of the beautiful oaks and Spanish chesnuts which were scattered over [the intermediate lawn]2171-the intermediate lawn .

In [this room]4458-this room [they]2162-they were received by [Miss Darcy]139-miss darcy , who was sitting there with [Mrs. Hurst]101-mrs. hurst and [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley , and [the lady with whom [she]139-miss darcy lived in [London]5-london]2173-the lady with whom she lived in london . [Georgiana]175-georgiana 's reception of [them]2162-they was very civil ; but attended with all that embarrassment which , though proceeding from shyness and the fear of doing wrong , would easily give to those who felt [themselves]2162-they inferior , the belief of [her]175-georgiana being proud and reserved . [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner and [[her]141-mrs. gardiner niece]1304-her niece , however , did [her]175-georgiana justice , and pitied [her]175-georgiana .

By [Mrs. Hurst]101-mrs. hurst and [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley , [they]2162-they were noticed only by a curtsey ; and on [their]2162-they being seated , a pause , awkward as such pauses must always be , succeeded for a few moments . It was first broken by [Mrs. Annesley]215-mrs. annesley , [a genteel , agreeable - looking woman , whose endeavour to introduce some kind of discourse]2175-a genteel , agreeable - looking woman , whose endeavour to introduce some kind of discourse , proved [her]215-mrs. annesley to be more truly well bred than either of [the others]517-the others ; and between [her]215-mrs. annesley and [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner , with occasional help from [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , the conversation was carried on . [Miss Darcy]139-miss darcy looked as if [she]139-miss darcy wished for courage enough to join in it ; and sometimes did venture a short sentence , when there was least danger of its being heard .

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth soon saw that [she]93-elizabeth was [herself]93-elizabeth closely watched by [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley , and that [she]93-elizabeth could not speak a word , especially to [Miss Darcy]139-miss darcy , without calling [her]93-elizabeth attention . This observation would not have prevented [her]93-elizabeth from trying to talk to [the latter]499-the latter , had [they]2162-they not been seated at an inconvenient distance ; but [she]93-elizabeth was not sorry to be spared the necessity of saying much . [Her]93-elizabeth own thoughts were employing [her]93-elizabeth . [She]93-elizabeth expected every moment that [some of [the gentlemen]311-the gentlemen]2178-some of the gentlemen would enter [the room]271-the room . [She]93-elizabeth wished , [she]93-elizabeth feared that [the master of [the house]3026-the house]646-the master of the house might be amongst [them]2178-some of the gentlemen ; and whether [she]93-elizabeth wished or feared it most , [she]93-elizabeth could scarcely determine . After sitting in this manner a quarter of an hour , without hearing [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley 's voice , [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was roused by receiving from [her]93-elizabeth a cold enquiry after the health of [[her]93-elizabeth family]905-her family . [She]93-elizabeth answered with equal indifference and brevity , and [the other]3363-the other said no more .

The next variation which [their]2185-they visit afforded was produced by the entrance of [servants]1377-servants with cold meat , cake , and a variety of all the finest fruits in season ; but this did not take place till after many a significant look and smile from [Mrs. Annesley]215-mrs. annesley to [Miss Darcy]139-miss darcy had been given , to remind [her]93-elizabeth of [her]93-elizabeth post . There was now employment for [the whole party]531-the whole party ; for though [they]2185-they could not all talk , [they]2185-they could all eat ; and the beautiful pyramids of grapes , nectarines , and peaches , soon collected them round the table .

While thus engaged , [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth had a fair opportunity of deciding whether [she]93-elizabeth most feared or wished for the appearance of [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , by the feelings which prevailed on [his]100-mr. darcy entering [the room]271-the room ; and then , though but a moment before [she]93-elizabeth had believed [her]93-elizabeth wishes to predominate , [she]93-elizabeth began to regret that [he]100-mr. darcy came .

[He]100-mr. darcy had been some time with [Mr. Gardiner]180-mr. gardiner , who , with two or [three other gentlemen from [the house]3026-the house]2189-three other gentlemen from the house , was engaged by [the river]1911-the river , and had left [him]100-mr. darcy only on learning that [the ladies of the family]2192-the ladies of the family intended a visit to [Georgiana]175-georgiana that morning . No sooner did [he]100-mr. darcy appear , than [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth wisely resolved to be perfectly easy and unembarrassed;--a resolution the more necessary to be made , but perhaps not the more easily kept , because [she]93-elizabeth saw that the suspicions of [the whole party]531-the whole party were awakened against [them]531-the whole party , and that there was scarcely an eye which did not watch [his]100-mr. darcy behaviour when [he]100-mr. darcy first came into [the room]271-the room . In no countenance was attentive curiosity so strongly marked as in [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley 's , in spite of the smiles which overspread [her]102-miss bingley face whenever [she]102-miss bingley spoke to one of its objects ; for jealousy had not yet made [her]102-miss bingley desperate , and [her]102-miss bingley attentions to [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy were by no means over . [Miss Darcy]139-miss darcy , on [[her]139-miss darcy brother]3126-her brother 's entrance , exerted [herself]139-miss darcy much more to talk ; and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth saw that [he]100-mr. darcy was anxious for [[his]100-mr. darcy sister]569-his sister and [herself]139-miss darcy to get acquainted , and forwarded , as much as possible , every attempt at conversation on either side . [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley saw all this likewise ; and , in the imprudence of anger , took the first opportunity of saying , with sneering civility ,

" Pray , [Miss Eliza]93-elizabeth , are not the ----shire militia removed from [Meryton]9-meryton ? [They]4510-they must be a great loss to _ [[your]100-mr. darcy _ family]4511-your _ family . "[93-elizabeth]

In [Darcy]139-miss darcy 's presence [she]93-elizabeth dared not mention [Wickham]156-wickham 's name ; but [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth instantly comprehended that [he]100-mr. darcy was uppermost in [her]93-elizabeth thoughts ; and the various recollections connected with [him]100-mr. darcy gave [her]93-elizabeth a moment 's distress ; but , exerting [herself]93-elizabeth vigorously to repel the ill - natured attack , [she]93-elizabeth presently answered the question in a tolerably disengaged tone . While [she]93-elizabeth spoke , an involuntary glance shewed [[her]93-elizabeth Darcy]2197-her darcy with an heightened complexion , earnestly looking at [her]93-elizabeth , and [[his]100-mr. darcy sister]569-his sister overcome with confusion , and unable to lift up [her]93-elizabeth eyes . Had [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley known what pain [she]93-elizabeth was then giving [[her]102-miss bingley beloved friend]2199-her beloved friend , [she]102-miss bingley undoubtedly would have refrained from the hint ; but [she]102-miss bingley had merely intended to discompose [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , by bringing forward the idea of [a man to whom [she]93-elizabeth believed [her]93-elizabeth partial]2200-a man to whom she believed her partial , to make [her]93-elizabeth betray a sensibility which might injure [her]93-elizabeth in [Darcy]139-miss darcy 's opinion , and perhaps to remind [the latter]499-the latter of all the follies and absurdities , by which some part of [[her]93-elizabeth family]905-her family were connected with that corps . Not a syllable had ever reached [her]93-elizabeth of [Miss Darcy]139-miss darcy 's meditated elopement . To [no creature]2203-no creature had it been revealed , where secresy was possible , except to [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth ; and from all [Bingley]102-miss bingley 's connections [[her]93-elizabeth brother]3126-her brother was particularly anxious to conceal it , from that very wish which [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth had long ago attributed to [him]3126-her brother , of [their]2205-their becoming hereafter [her]93-elizabeth own . [He]3126-her brother had certainly formed such a plan , and without meaning that it should affect [his]3126-her brother endeavour to separate [him]3126-her brother from [Miss Bennet]93-elizabeth , it is probable that it might add something to [his]3126-her brother lively concern for the welfare of [[his]3126-her brother friend]307-his friend .

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth 's collected behaviour , however , soon quieted [his]3126-her brother emotion ; and as [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley , vexed and disappointed , dared not approach nearer to [Wickham]156-wickham , [Georgiana]175-georgiana also recovered in time , though not enough to be able to speak any more . [[Her]93-elizabeth brother]3126-her brother , whose eye [she]93-elizabeth feared to meet , scarcely recollected [her]93-elizabeth interest in the affair , and the very circumstance which had been designed to turn [his]3126-her brother thoughts from [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , seemed to have fixed them on [her]93-elizabeth more , and more cheerfully .

[Their]2208-their visit did not continue long after the question and answer above - mentioned ; and while [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy was attending [them]2208-their to [[their]2208-their carriage]2209-their carriage , [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley was venting [her]102-miss bingley feelings in criticisms on [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth 's person , behaviour , and dress . But [Georgiana]175-georgiana would not join [her]93-elizabeth . [[Her]93-elizabeth brother]3126-her brother 's recommendation was enough to ensure [her]93-elizabeth favour : [his]3126-her brother judgment could not err , and [he]3126-her brother had spoken in such terms of [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , as to leave [Georgiana]175-georgiana without the power of finding [her]175-georgiana otherwise than lovely and amiable . When [Darcy]175-georgiana returned to [the saloon]2168-the saloon , [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley could not help repeating to [him]100-mr. darcy some part of what [she]102-miss bingley had been saying to [[his]100-mr. darcy sister]569-his sister .

" How very ill [Eliza Bennet]93-elizabeth looks this morning , [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy , "[102-miss bingley] [she]102-miss bingley cried ; " [I]102-miss bingley never in [my]102-miss bingley life saw any one so much altered as [she]93-elizabeth is since the winter . [She]93-elizabeth is grown so brown and coarse ! [Louisa]132-louisa and [I]102-miss bingley were agreeing that [we]4512-we should not have known [her]93-elizabeth again . "[102-miss bingley]

However [little Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy might have liked such an address , [he]100-mr. darcy contented [himself]100-mr. darcy with coolly replying , that [he]100-mr. darcy perceived no other alteration than [her]102-miss bingley being rather tanned,--no miraculous consequence of travelling in the summer .

" For [my]102-miss bingley own part , "[102-miss bingley] [she]102-miss bingley rejoined , " [I]102-miss bingley must confess that [I]102-miss bingley never could see any beauty in [her]102-miss bingley . [Her]102-miss bingley face is too thin ; [her]102-miss bingley complexion has no brilliancy ; and [her]102-miss bingley features are not at all handsome . [Her]102-miss bingley nose wants character ; there is nothing marked in its lines . [Her]102-miss bingley teeth are tolerable , but not out of the common way ; and as for [her]102-miss bingley eyes , which have sometimes been called so fine , [I]102-miss bingley never could perceive any thing extraordinary in them . [They]4513-they have a sharp , shrewish look , which [I]102-miss bingley do not like at all ; and in [her]102-miss bingley air altogether , there is a self - sufficiency without fashion , which is intolerable . "[102-miss bingley]

Persuaded as [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley was that [Darcy]100-mr. darcy admired [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , this was not the best method of recommending [herself]102-miss bingley ; but [angry people]2213-angry people are not always wise ; and in seeing [him]100-mr. darcy at last look somewhat nettled , [she]102-miss bingley had all the success [she]102-miss bingley expected . [He]100-mr. darcy was resolutely silent however ; and , from a determination of making [him]100-mr. darcy speak , [she]102-miss bingley continued ,

" [I]102-miss bingley remember , when [we]4514-we first knew [her]102-miss bingley in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire , how amazed [we]4514-we all were to find that [she]102-miss bingley was [a reputed beauty]4515-a reputed beauty ; and [I]102-miss bingley particularly recollect [your]100-mr. darcy saying one night , after [they]4516-they had been dining at [Netherfield]2-netherfield , ' _ [She]102-miss bingley _ [a beauty!--I]4517-a beauty!--i should as soon call [[her]102-miss bingley mother]261-her mother a wit . ' But afterwards [she]102-miss bingley seemed to improve on [you]100-mr. darcy , and [I]102-miss bingley believe [you]100-mr. darcy thought [her]102-miss bingley rather pretty at one time . "[102-miss bingley]

" Yes , "[100-mr. darcy] replied [Darcy]100-mr. darcy , who could contain [himself]100-mr. darcy no longer , " but _ that _ was only when [I]100-mr. darcy first knew [her]102-miss bingley , for it is many months since [I]100-mr. darcy have considered [her]102-miss bingley as [one of the handsomest women of [my]100-mr. darcy acquaintance]4519-one of the handsomest women of my acquaintance . "[100-mr. darcy]

[He]100-mr. darcy then went away , and [Miss Bingley]102-miss bingley was left to all the satisfaction of having forced [him]100-mr. darcy to say what gave [no one]3275-no one any pain but [herself]102-miss bingley .

[Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth talked of all that had occurred , during [their]2215-their visit , as [they]2215-their returned , except what had particularly interested [them]2215-their both . The looks and behaviour of every body [they]2215-their had seen were discussed , except of [the person who had mostly engaged [their]2215-their attention]2216-the person who had mostly engaged their attention . [They]2215-their talked of [[his]100-mr. darcy sister]569-his sister , [[his]100-mr. darcy friends]423-his friends , [[his]100-mr. darcy house]3127-his house , [his]100-mr. darcy fruit , of every thing but [himself]100-mr. darcy ; yet [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was longing to know what [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner thought of [him]100-mr. darcy , and [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner would have been highly gratified by [[her]141-mrs. gardiner niece]1304-her niece 's beginning the subject .

CHAPTER IV .

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth had been a good deal disappointed in not finding a letter from [Jane]94-jane , on [their]2215-their first arrival at [Lambton]53-lambton ; and this disappointment had been renewed on each of the mornings that had now been spent [there]325-there ; but on the third , [her]93-elizabeth repining was over , and [[her]93-elizabeth sister]348-her sister justified by the receipt of two letters from [her]93-elizabeth at once , on one of which was marked that it had been missent elsewhere . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was not surprised at it , as [Jane]94-jane had written the direction remarkably ill .

[They]2215-their had just been preparing to walk as the letters came in ; and [[her]93-elizabeth uncle]583-her uncle and aunt , leaving [her]93-elizabeth to enjoy [them]2224-them in quiet , set off by [themselves]2215-their . [The one missent]2225-the one missent must be first attended to ; it had been written five days ago . The beginning contained an account of all [their]2215-their little parties and engagements , with such news as [the country]460-the country afforded ; but the latter half , which was dated a day later , and written in evident agitation , gave more important intelligence . It was to this effect :

" Since writing the above , dearest [Lizzy]93-elizabeth , something has occurred of a most unexpected and serious nature ; but [I]93-elizabeth am afraid of alarming [you]93-elizabeth -- be assured that [we]2215-their are all well . What [I]93-elizabeth have to say relates to poor [Lydia]95-lydia . An express came at twelve last night , just as [we]2215-their were all gone to bed , from [Colonel Forster]123-colonel forster , to inform [us]2215-their that [she]95-lydia was gone off to [Scotland]58-scotland with [one of [[his]123-colonel forster officers]4521-his officers]4520-one of his officers ; to own the truth , with Wickham!--Imagine [our]2215-their surprise . To [Kitty]97-lady catherine , however , it does not seem so wholly unexpected . [I]93-elizabeth am very , very sorry . So imprudent a match on both sides!--But [I]93-elizabeth am willing to hope the best , and that [his]123-colonel forster character has been misunderstood . Thoughtless and indiscreet [I]93-elizabeth can easily believe [him]123-colonel forster , but this step ( and let [us]2215-their rejoice over it ) marks nothing bad at heart . [His]123-colonel forster choice is disinterested at least , for [he]123-colonel forster must know [[my]93-elizabeth father]3259-my father can give [her]95-lydia nothing . [[Our]2215-their poor mother]4523-our poor mother is sadly grieved . [[My]93-elizabeth father]3259-my father bears it better . How thankful am [I]93-elizabeth , that [we]2215-their never let [them]4525-they know what has been said against [him]3259-my father ; [we]2215-their must forget it [ourselves]2215-their . [They]4525-they were off Saturday night about twelve , as is conjectured , but were not missed till yesterday morning at eight . [The express]4526-the express was sent off directly . [[My]93-elizabeth dear]3018-my dear [Lizzy]93-elizabeth , [they]4525-they must have passed within ten miles of [us]2215-their . [Colonel Forster]123-colonel forster gives [us]2215-their reason to expect [him]3259-my father here soon . [Lydia]95-lydia left a few lines for [[his]3259-my father wife]251-his wife , informing [her]251-his wife of [their]4525-they intention . [I]93-elizabeth must conclude , for [I]93-elizabeth can not be long from [[my]93-elizabeth poor mother]4529-my poor mother . [I]93-elizabeth am afraid [you]93-elizabeth will not be able to make it out , but [I]93-elizabeth hardly know what [I]93-elizabeth have written . "[93-elizabeth]

Without allowing [herself]2227-herself time for consideration , and scarcely knowing what [she]2227-herself felt , [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth on finishing this letter , instantly seized the other , and opening it with the utmost impatience , read as follows : it had been written a day later than the conclusion of the first .

" By this time , [[my]510-a servant dearest sister]4530-my dearest sister , [you]93-elizabeth have received [my]510-a servant hurried letter ; [I]510-a servant wish this may be more intelligible , but though not confined for time , [my]510-a servant head is so bewildered that [I]510-a servant can not answer for being coherent . [Dearest Lizzy]93-elizabeth , [I]510-a servant hardly know what [I]510-a servant would write , but [I]510-a servant have bad news for [you]93-elizabeth , and it can not be delayed . Imprudent as a marriage between [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham and [[our]4531-our poor [Lydia]95-lydia]4532-our poor lydia would be , [we]4531-our are now anxious to be assured it has taken place , for there is but too much reason to fear [they]4533-them are not gone to [Scotland]58-scotland . [Colonel Forster]123-colonel forster came yesterday , having left [Brighton]40-brighton the day before , not many hours after the express . Though [Lydia]95-lydia 's short letter to [Mrs. F.]217-mrs. f. gave [them]4533-them to understand that [they]4533-them were going to [Gretna Green]59-gretna green , something was dropped by [Denny]155-denny expressing [his]155-denny belief that [W.]218-w. never intended to go [there]325-there , or to marry [Lydia]95-lydia at all , which was repeated to [Colonel F.]219-colonel f. who instantly taking the alarm , set off from [B.]60-b. intending to trace [their]4533-them route . [He]219-colonel f. did trace [them]4533-them easily to [Clapham]61-clapham , but no farther ; for on entering [that place]4535-that place [they]4533-them removed into [a hackney - coach]4536-a hackney - coach and dismissed the chaise that brought [them]4533-them from [Epsom]62-epsom . All that is known after this is , that [they]4533-them were seen to continue [the [London]5-london road]4537-the london road . [I]510-a servant know not what to think . After making every possible enquiry on [that side [London]5-london]4538-that side london , [Colonel F.]219-colonel f. came on into [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire , anxiously renewing [them]4533-them at all [the turnpikes]4539-the turnpikes , and at [the inns in [Barnet]63-barnet and [Hatfield]64-hatfield]4540-the inns in barnet and hatfield , but without any success , [no such people]4541-no such people had been seen to pass through . With the kindest concern [he]219-colonel f. came on to [Longbourn]7-longbourn , and broke [his]219-colonel f. apprehensions to [us]4542-us in a manner most creditable to [his]219-colonel f. heart . [I]510-a servant am sincerely grieved for [him]219-colonel f. and [Mrs. F.]217-mrs. f. but [no one]3275-no one can throw any blame on [them]4533-them . [Our]4542-us distress , [[my]510-a servant dear]3018-my dear [Lizzy]93-elizabeth , is very great . [[My]510-a servant father]3259-my father and [mother]3249-mother believe the worst , but [I]510-a servant can not think so ill of [him]219-colonel f. . Many circumstances might make it more eligible for [them]4533-them to be married privately in [town]285-town than to pursue [their]4533-them first plan ; and even if _ [he]219-colonel f. _ could form such a design against [a young woman of [Lydia]95-lydia 's connections]4548-a young woman of lydia 's connections , which is not likely , can [I]510-a servant suppose [her]4548-a young woman of lydia 's connections so lost to every thing?--Impossible . [I]510-a servant grieve to find , however , that [Colonel F.]219-colonel f. is not disposed to depend upon [their]4533-them marriage ; [he]219-colonel f. shook [his]219-colonel f. head when [I]510-a servant expressed [my]510-a servant hopes , and said [he]219-colonel f. feared [W.]218-w. was not [a man to be trusted]4549-a man to be trusted . [[My]510-a servant poor mother]4529-my poor mother is really ill and keeps [[her]4529-my poor mother room]501-her room . Could [she]4529-my poor mother exert [herself]4529-my poor mother it would be better , but this is not to be expected ; and as to [[my]510-a servant father]3259-my father , [I]510-a servant never in [my]510-a servant life saw [him]3259-my father so affected . [Poor Kitty]97-lady catherine has anger for having concealed [their]4533-them attachment ; but as it was a matter of confidence one can not wonder . [I]510-a servant am truly glad , dearest [Lizzy]93-elizabeth , that [you]93-elizabeth have been spared something of these distressing scenes ; but now as the first shock is over , shall [I]510-a servant own that [I]510-a servant long for [your]93-elizabeth return ? [I]510-a servant am not so selfish , however , as to press for it , if inconvenient . Adieu . [I]510-a servant take up [my]510-a servant pen again to do , what [I]510-a servant have just told [you]93-elizabeth [I]510-a servant would not , but circumstances are such , that [I]510-a servant can not help earnestly begging [you]93-elizabeth all to come here , as soon as possible . [I]510-a servant know [[my]510-a servant dear uncle]3946-my dear uncle and [aunt]3947-aunt so well , that [I]510-a servant am not afraid of requesting it , though [I]510-a servant have still something more to ask of [the former]347-the former . [[My]510-a servant father]3259-my father is going to [London]5-london with [Colonel Forster]123-colonel forster instantly , to try to discover [her]3947-aunt . What [he]3259-my father means to do , [I]510-a servant am sure [I]510-a servant know not ; but [his]3259-my father excessive distress will not allow [him]3259-my father to pursue any measure in the best and safest way , and [Colonel Forster]123-colonel forster is obliged to be at [Brighton]40-brighton again to - morrow evening . In such an exigence [[my]510-a servant uncle]3468-my uncle 's advice and assistance would be every thing in [the world]323-the world ; [he]3259-my father will immediately comprehend what [I]510-a servant must feel , and [I]510-a servant rely upon [his]3259-my father goodness . "[510-a servant]

" Oh ! where , where is [[my]93-elizabeth uncle]3468-my uncle ? "[93-elizabeth] cried [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , darting from [her]93-elizabeth seat as [she]93-elizabeth finished the letter , in eagerness to follow [him]2228-him , without losing a moment of the time so precious ; but as [she]93-elizabeth reached the door , it was opened by [a servant]510-a servant , and [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy appeared . [Her]93-elizabeth pale face and impetuous manner made [him]2228-him start , and before [he]2228-him could recover [himself]2228-him enough to speak , [she]93-elizabeth , in whose mind every idea was superseded by [Lydia]95-lydia 's situation , hastily exclaimed , " [I]93-elizabeth beg [your]2228-him pardon , but [I]93-elizabeth must leave [you]2228-him . [I]93-elizabeth must find [Mr. Gardiner]180-mr. gardiner this moment , on business that can not be delayed ; [I]93-elizabeth have not an instant to lose . "[93-elizabeth]

" [Good God]107-god ! what is the matter ? "[2228-him] cried [he]2228-him , with more feeling than politeness ; then recollecting [himself]2228-him , " [I]2228-him will not detain [you]93-elizabeth a minute , but let [me]2228-him , or let [the servant]474-the servant , go after [Mr.]4561-mr. and [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner . [You]93-elizabeth are not well enough;--you can not go [yourself]93-elizabeth . "[2228-him]

[Elizabeth]93-elizabeth hesitated , but [her]93-elizabeth knees trembled under [her]93-elizabeth , and [she]93-elizabeth felt how little would be gained by [her]93-elizabeth attempting to pursue [them]2230-them . Calling back [the servant]474-the servant , therefore , [she]93-elizabeth commissioned [him]2228-him , though in so breathless an accent as made [her]93-elizabeth almost unintelligible , to fetch [[his]2228-him master]1980-his master and [mistress]4438-mistress [home]3223-home , instantly .

On [his]2228-him quitting [the room]271-the room , [she]93-elizabeth sat down , unable to support [herself]93-elizabeth , and looking so miserably ill , that it was impossible for [Darcy]100-mr. darcy to leave [her]93-elizabeth , or to refrain from saying , in a tone of gentleness and commiseration , " Let [me]4438-mistress call [[your]100-mr. darcy maid]4562-your maid . Is there nothing [you]100-mr. darcy could take , to give [you]100-mr. darcy present relief?--A glass of wine;--shall [I]4438-mistress get [you]100-mr. darcy one?--You are very ill . "[4438-mistress]

" No , [I]93-elizabeth thank [you]100-mr. darcy ; "[93-elizabeth] [she]93-elizabeth replied , endeavouring to recover [herself]93-elizabeth . " There is nothing the matter with [me]93-elizabeth . [I]93-elizabeth am quite well . [I]93-elizabeth am only distressed by some dreadful news which [I]93-elizabeth have just received from [Longbourn]7-longbourn . "[93-elizabeth]

[She]93-elizabeth burst into tears as [she]93-elizabeth alluded to it , and for a few minutes could not speak another word . [Darcy]100-mr. darcy , in wretched suspense , could only say something indistinctly of [his]100-mr. darcy concern , and observe [her]93-elizabeth in compassionate silence . At length , [she]93-elizabeth spoke again . " [I]93-elizabeth have just had a letter from [Jane]94-jane , with such dreadful news . It can not be concealed from any one . [[My]93-elizabeth youngest sister]4563-my youngest sister has left all [[her]4563-my youngest sister friends]330-her friends -- has eloped;--has thrown [herself]4563-my youngest sister into the power of -- of [Mr. Wickham]156-wickham . [They]4565-they are gone off together from [Brighton]40-brighton . _ [You]100-mr. darcy _ know [him]156-wickham too well to doubt the rest . [She]4563-my youngest sister has no money , no connections , nothing that can tempt [him]156-wickham to -- [she]4563-my youngest sister is lost for ever . "[93-elizabeth]

[Darcy]100-mr. darcy was fixed in astonishment . " When [I]93-elizabeth consider , "[93-elizabeth] [she]93-elizabeth added , in a yet more agitated voice , " that _ [I]93-elizabeth _ might have prevented it!--_I _ who knew what [he]156-wickham was . Had [I]93-elizabeth but explained some part of it only -- some part of what [I]93-elizabeth learnt , to [[my]93-elizabeth own family]3886-my own family ! Had [his]156-wickham character been known , this could not have happened . But it is all , all too late now . "[93-elizabeth]

" [I]100-mr. darcy am grieved , indeed , "[100-mr. darcy] cried [Darcy]100-mr. darcy ; " grieved -- shocked . But is it certain , absolutely certain ? "[100-mr. darcy]

" Oh yes!--They left [Brighton]40-brighton together on Sunday night , and were traced almost to [London]5-london , but not beyond ; [they]4567-they are certainly not gone to [Scotland]58-scotland . "[93-elizabeth]

" And what has been done , what has been attempted , to recover [her]4563-my youngest sister ? "[100-mr. darcy]

" [[My]93-elizabeth father]3259-my father is gone to [London]5-london , and [Jane]94-jane has written to beg [[my]93-elizabeth uncle]3468-my uncle 's immediate assistance , and [we]4570-we shall be off , [I]93-elizabeth hope , in half an hour . But nothing can be done ; [I]93-elizabeth know very well that nothing can be done . How is [such a man to be worked on]4571-such a man to be worked on ? How are they even to be discovered ? [I]93-elizabeth have not the smallest hope . It is every way horrible ! "[93-elizabeth]

[Darcy]100-mr. darcy shook [his]100-mr. darcy head in silent acquiesence .

" When _ [my]93-elizabeth _ eyes were opened to [[his]100-mr. darcy real character.--Oh]4572-his real character.--oh ! had [I]93-elizabeth known what [I]93-elizabeth ought , what [I]93-elizabeth dared , to do ! But [I]93-elizabeth knew not -- [I]93-elizabeth was afraid of doing too much . Wretched , wretched , mistake ! "[93-elizabeth]

[Darcy]100-mr. darcy made no answer . [He]100-mr. darcy seemed scarcely to hear [her]2236-her , and was walking up and down [the room]271-the room in earnest meditation ; [his]100-mr. darcy brow contracted , [his]100-mr. darcy air gloomy . [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth soon observed , and instantly understood it . [Her]93-elizabeth power was sinking ; every thing _ must _ sink under such a proof of family weakness , such an assurance of the deepest disgrace . [She]93-elizabeth could neither wonder nor condemn , but the belief of [his]100-mr. darcy self - conquest brought nothing consolatory to [her]93-elizabeth bosom , afforded no palliation of [her]93-elizabeth distress . It was , on the contrary , exactly calculated to make [her]93-elizabeth understand [her]93-elizabeth own wishes ; and never had [she]93-elizabeth so honestly felt that [she]93-elizabeth could have loved [him]100-mr. darcy , as now , when all love must be vain .

But self , though it would intrude , could not engross [her]93-elizabeth . [Lydia]95-lydia -- the humiliation , the misery , [she]93-elizabeth was bringing on [them]2238-them all , soon swallowed up every private care ; and covering [her]93-elizabeth face with [her]93-elizabeth handkerchief , [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth was soon lost to every thing else ; and , after a pause of several minutes , was only recalled to a sense of [her]93-elizabeth situation by the voice of [[her]93-elizabeth companion]1696-her companion , who , in a manner , which though it spoke compassion , spoke likewise restraint , said , " [I]1696-her companion am afraid [you]93-elizabeth have been long desiring [my]1696-her companion absence , nor have [I]1696-her companion any thing to plead in excuse of [my]1696-her companion stay , but real , though unavailing , concern . Would to heaven that any thing could be either said or done on [my]1696-her companion part , that might offer consolation to such distress.--But [I]1696-her companion will not torment [you]93-elizabeth with vain wishes , which may seem purposely to ask for [your]93-elizabeth thanks . This unfortunate affair will , [I]1696-her companion fear , prevent [[my]1696-her companion sister]3284-my sister 's having the pleasure of seeing [you]93-elizabeth at [Pemberley]12-pemberley to - day . "[1696-her companion]

" Oh , yes . Be so kind as to apologize for [us]4574-us to [Miss Darcy]139-miss darcy . Say that urgent business calls [us]4574-us [home]3223-home immediately . Conceal the unhappy truth as long as it is possible.--I know it can not be long . "[1696-her companion]

[He]1696-her companion readily assured [her]2240-her of [his]1696-her companion secrecy -- again expressed [his]1696-her companion sorrow for [her]2240-her distress , wished it a happier conclusion than there was at present reason to hope , and leaving [his]1696-her companion compliments for [her]2240-her relations , with only one serious , parting , look , went away .

As [he]1696-her companion quitted [the room]271-the room , [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth felt how improbable it was that [they]2242-their should ever see [each other]3157-each other again on such terms of cordiality as had marked [their]2242-their several meetings in [Derbyshire]6-derbyshire ; and as [she]93-elizabeth threw a retrospective glance over the whole of [their]2242-their acquaintance , so full of contradictions and varieties , sighed at the perverseness of those feelings which would now have promoted its continuance , and would formerly have rejoiced in its termination .

If gratitude and esteem are good foundations of affection , [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth 's change of sentiment will be neither improbable nor faulty . But if otherwise , if the regard springing from such sources is unreasonable or unnatural , in comparison of what is so often described as arising on a first interview with its object , and even before two words have been exchanged , nothing can be said in [her]93-elizabeth defence , except that [she]93-elizabeth had given somewhat of a trial to the latter method , in [her]93-elizabeth partiality for [Wickham]156-wickham , and that its ill - success might perhaps authorise [her]93-elizabeth to seek the other less interesting mode of attachment . Be that as it may , [she]93-elizabeth saw [him]156-wickham go with regret ; and in this early example of what [Lydia]95-lydia 's infamy must produce , found additional anguish as [she]93-elizabeth reflected on that wretched business . Never , since reading [Jane]94-jane 's second letter , had [she]93-elizabeth entertained a hope of [Wickham]156-wickham 's meaning to marry [her]93-elizabeth . [No one]3275-no one but [Jane]94-jane , [she]93-elizabeth thought , could flatter [herself]93-elizabeth with such an expectation . Surprise was the least of [her]93-elizabeth feelings on this developement . While the contents of the first letter remained on [her]93-elizabeth mind , [she]93-elizabeth was all surprise -- all astonishment that [Wickham]156-wickham should marry [a girl]3548-a girl , whom it was impossible [he]156-wickham could marry for money ; and how [Lydia]95-lydia could ever have attached [him]156-wickham , had appeared incomprehensible . But now it was all too natural . For such an attachment as this , [she]93-elizabeth might have sufficient charms ; and though [she]93-elizabeth did not suppose [Lydia]95-lydia to be deliberately engaging in an elopement , without the intention of marriage , [she]93-elizabeth had no difficulty in believing that neither [her]93-elizabeth virtue nor [her]93-elizabeth understanding would preserve [her]93-elizabeth from falling an easy prey .

[She]93-elizabeth had never perceived , while [the regiment]656-the regiment was in [Hertfordshire]4-hertfordshire , that [Lydia]95-lydia had any partiality for [him]156-wickham , but [she]93-elizabeth was convinced that [Lydia]95-lydia had wanted only encouragement to attach [herself]95-lydia to any body . Sometimes [one officer]2247-one officer , sometimes another had been [her]93-elizabeth favourite , as [their]2248-their attentions raised [them]2248-their in [her]93-elizabeth opinion . [Her]93-elizabeth affections had been continually fluctuating , but never without an object . The mischief of neglect and mistaken indulgence towards [such a girl.--Oh]2249-such a girl.--oh ! how acutely did [she]93-elizabeth now feel it .

[She]93-elizabeth was wild to be at [home]3223-home -- to hear , to see , to be upon the spot , to share with [Jane]94-jane in the cares that must now fall wholly upon [her]93-elizabeth , in [a family so deranged]2251-a family so deranged ; [a father]3248-a father absent , [a mother incapable of exertion , and requiring constant attendance]2253-a mother incapable of exertion , and requiring constant attendance ; and though almost persuaded that nothing could be done for [Lydia]95-lydia , [[her]93-elizabeth uncle]583-her uncle 's interference seemed of the utmost importance , and till [he]583-her uncle entered [the room]271-the room , the misery of [her]93-elizabeth impatience was severe . [Mr.]2256-mr. and [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner had hurried back in alarm , supposing , by [the servant]474-the servant 's account , that [[their]2258-their niece]1981-their niece was taken suddenly ill;--but satisfying [them]2258-their instantly on that head , [she]93-elizabeth eagerly communicated the cause of [their]2258-their summons , reading the two letters aloud , and dwelling on the postscript of the last , with trembling energy.--Though [Lydia]95-lydia had never been a favourite with [them]2258-their , [Mr.]2260-mr. and [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner could not but be deeply affected . Not [Lydia]95-lydia only , but all were concerned in it ; and after the first exclamations of surprise and horror , [Mr. Gardiner]180-mr. gardiner readily promised every assistance in [his]180-mr. gardiner power.--Elizabeth , though expecting no less , thanked [him]180-mr. gardiner with tears of gratitude ; and [all three]2261-all three being actuated by one spirit , every thing relating to [their]2261-all three journey was speedily settled . [They]2261-all three were to be off as soon as possible . " But what is to be done about [Pemberley]12-pemberley ? "[141-mrs. gardiner] cried [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner . " [John]200-john told [us]2261-all three [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy was here when [you]180-mr. gardiner sent for [us;--was]4576-us;--was it so ? "[141-mrs. gardiner]

" Yes ; and [I]141-mrs. gardiner told [him]100-mr. darcy [we]2261-all three should not be able to keep [our]2261-all three engagement . _ That _ is all settled . "[141-mrs. gardiner]

" That is all settled ; "[3363-the other] repeated [the other]3363-the other , as [she]3363-the other ran into [[her]3363-the other room]501-her room to prepare . " And are [they]4577-they upon such terms as for [her]3363-the other to disclose the real truth ! Oh , that [I]3363-the other knew how it was ! "[3363-the other]

But wishes were vain ; or at best could serve only to amuse [her]3363-the other in the hurry and confusion of the following hour . Had [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth been at leisure to be idle , [she]93-elizabeth would have remained certain that all employment was impossible to one so wretched as [herself]93-elizabeth ; but [she]93-elizabeth had [her]93-elizabeth share of business as well as [[her]93-elizabeth aunt]1226-her aunt , and amongst [the rest]270-the rest there were notes to be written to all [[their]2266-their friends]2267-their friends in [Lambton]53-lambton , with false excuses for [their]2266-their sudden departure . An hour , however , saw the whole completed ; and [Mr. Gardiner]180-mr. gardiner meanwhile having settled [his]180-mr. gardiner account at [the inn]1736-the inn , nothing remained to be done but to go ; and [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , after all the misery of the morning , found [herself]93-elizabeth , in a shorter space of time than [she]93-elizabeth could have supposed , seated in [the carriage]3221-the carriage , and on [the road]1317-the road to [Longbourn]7-longbourn .

CHAPTER V.

" [I]583-her uncle have been thinking it over again , [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , "[583-her uncle] said [[her]93-elizabeth uncle]583-her uncle , as [they]2272-they drove from [the town]1054-the town ; " and really , upon serious consideration , [I]583-her uncle am much more inclined than [I]583-her uncle was to judge as [[your]93-elizabeth eldest sister]4192-your eldest sister does of the matter . It appears to [me]583-her uncle so very unlikely , that [any young man]4579-any young man should form such a design against [a girl who is by no means unprotected or friendless , and who was actually staying in [[his]4579-any young man colonel 's family]4581-his colonel 's family]4580-a girl who is by no means unprotected or friendless , and who was actually staying in his colonel 's family , that [I]583-her uncle am strongly inclined to hope the best . Could [he]4579-any young man expect that [[her]4192-your eldest sister friends]330-her friends would not step forward ? Could [he]4579-any young man expect to be noticed again by [the regiment]656-the regiment , after such an affront to [Colonel Forster]123-colonel forster ? [His]4579-any young man temptation is not adequate to the risk . "[583-her uncle]

" Do [you]583-her uncle really think so ? "[93-elizabeth] cried [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , brightening up for a moment .

" Upon [my]141-mrs. gardiner word , "[141-mrs. gardiner] said [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner , " [I]141-mrs. gardiner begin to be of [[your]93-elizabeth uncle]3373-your uncle 's opinion . It is really too great a violation of decency , honour , and interest , for [him]3373-your uncle to be guilty of it . [I]141-mrs. gardiner can not think so very ill of [Wickham]156-wickham . Can [you]93-elizabeth , [yourself]93-elizabeth , [Lizzy]93-elizabeth , so wholly give [him]3373-your uncle up , as to believe [him]3373-your uncle capable of it ? "[141-mrs. gardiner]

" Not perhaps of neglecting [his]3373-your uncle own interest . But of every other neglect [I]583-her uncle can believe [him]3373-your uncle capable . If , indeed , it should be so ! But [I]583-her uncle dare not hope it . Why should [they]4585-they not go on to [Scotland]58-scotland , if that had been the case ? "[583-her uncle]

" In the first place , "[180-mr. gardiner] replied [Mr. Gardiner]180-mr. gardiner , " there is no absolute proof that [they]4585-they are not gone to [Scotland]58-scotland . "[180-mr. gardiner]

" Oh ! but [their]4585-they removing from the chaise into [an hackney coach]4586-an hackney coach is such a presumption ! And , besides , no traces of them were to be found on [the Barnet road]4587-the barnet road . "[583-her uncle]

" Well , then -- supposing [them]4585-they to be in [London]5-london . [They]4585-they may be [there]325-there , though for the purpose of concealment , for no more exceptionable purpose . It is not likely that money should be very abundant on either side ; and it might strike [them]4585-they that [they]4585-they could be more economically , though less expeditiously , married in [London]5-london , than in [Scotland]58-scotland . "[180-mr. gardiner]

" But why all this secrecy ? Why any fear of detection ? Why must [their]4585-they marriage be private ? Oh ! no , no , this is not likely . [[His]3373-your uncle most particular friend]4589-his most particular friend , [you]4590-you see by [Jane]94-jane 's account , was persuaded of [his]3373-your uncle never intending to marry [her]4589-his most particular friend . [Wickham]156-wickham will never marry [a woman]3036-a woman without some money . [He]156-wickham can not afford it . And what claims has [Lydia]95-lydia , what attractions has [she]95-lydia beyond youth , health , and good humour , that could make [him]3373-your uncle for [her]95-lydia sake , forego every chance of benefiting [himself]3373-your uncle by marrying well ? As to what restraint the apprehension of disgrace in [the corps]4592-the corps might throw on a dishonourable elopement with [her]95-lydia , [I]583-her uncle am not able to judge ; for [I]583-her uncle know nothing of the effects that such a step might produce . But as to [your]4590-you other objection , [I]583-her uncle am afraid it will hardly hold good . [Lydia]95-lydia has [no brothers]4593-no brothers to step forward ; and [he]3373-your uncle might imagine , from [[my]583-her uncle father]3259-my father 's behaviour , from [his]3259-my father indolence and the little attention [he]3259-my father has ever seemed to give to what was going forward in [[his]3259-my father family]394-his family , that _ [he]3259-my father _ would do as little , and think as little about it , as [any father]4596-any father could do , in such a matter . "[583-her uncle]

" But can [you]93-elizabeth think that [Lydia]95-lydia is so lost to every thing but love of [him]3373-your uncle , as to consent to live with [him]3373-your uncle on any other terms than marriage ? "[180-mr. gardiner]

" It does seem , and it is most shocking indeed , "[93-elizabeth] replied [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , with tears in [her]93-elizabeth eyes , " that [a sister]449-a sister 's sense of decency and virtue in such a point should admit of doubt . But , really , [I]93-elizabeth know not what to say . Perhaps [I]93-elizabeth am not doing [her]95-lydia justice . But [she]95-lydia is very young ; [she]95-lydia has never been taught to think on serious subjects ; and for the last half year , nay , for a twelvemonth , [she]95-lydia has been given up to nothing but amusement and vanity . [She]95-lydia has been allowed to dispose of [her]95-lydia time in the most idle and frivolous manner , and to adopt any opinions that came in [her]95-lydia way . Since the ----shire were first quartered in [Meryton]9-meryton , nothing but love , flirtation , and [officers]470-officers , have been in [her]95-lydia head . [She]95-lydia has been doing every thing in [her]95-lydia power by thinking and talking on the subject , to give greater -- what shall [I]93-elizabeth call it ? susceptibility to [her]95-lydia feelings ; which are naturally lively enough . And [we]4599-we all know that [Wickham]156-wickham has every charm of [person]4600-person and address that can captivate [a woman]3036-a woman . "[93-elizabeth]

" But [you]2274-you see that [Jane]94-jane , "[1226-her aunt] said [[her]2274-you aunt]1226-her aunt , " does not think so ill of [Wickham]156-wickham , as to believe [him]156-wickham capable of the attempt . "[1226-her aunt]

" Of whom does [Jane]94-jane ever think ill ? And who is there , whatever might be [their]4602-their former conduct , that [she]94-jane would believe capable of such an attempt , till it were proved against [them]4602-their ? But [Jane]94-jane knows , as well as [I]141-mrs. gardiner do , what [Wickham]156-wickham really is . [We]4599-we both know that [he]156-wickham has been profligate in every sense of the word . That [he]156-wickham has neither integrity nor honour . That [he]156-wickham is as false and deceitful , as [he]156-wickham is insinuating . "[141-mrs. gardiner]

" And do [you]141-mrs. gardiner really know all this ? "[141-mrs. gardiner] cried [Mrs. Gardiner]141-mrs. gardiner , whose curiosity as to the mode of [her]141-mrs. gardiner intelligence was all alive .

" [I]93-elizabeth do , indeed , "[93-elizabeth] replied [Elizabeth]93-elizabeth , colouring . " [I]141-mrs. gardiner told [you]141-mrs. gardiner the other day , of [his]156-wickham infamous behaviour to [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy ; and [you]141-mrs. gardiner , [yourself]141-mrs. gardiner , when last at [Longbourn]7-longbourn , heard in what manner [he]156-wickham spoke of [the man]3112-the man , who had behaved with such forbearance and liberality towards [him]156-wickham . And there are other circumstances which [I]141-mrs. gardiner am not at liberty -- which it is not worth while to relate ; but [his]156-wickham lies about [the whole Pemberley family]4604-the whole pemberley family are endless . From what [he]156-wickham said of [Miss Darcy]139-miss darcy , [I]141-mrs. gardiner was thoroughly prepared to see [a proud , reserved , disagreeable girl]4605-a proud , reserved , disagreeable girl . Yet [he]156-wickham knew to the contrary [himself]156-wickham . [He]156-wickham must know that [she]4605-a proud , reserved , disagreeable girl was as amiable and unpretending as [we]4606-we have found [her]4605-a proud , reserved , disagreeable girl . "[141-mrs. gardiner]

" But does [Lydia]95-lydia know nothing of this ? Can [she]95-lydia be ignorant of what [you]141-mrs. gardiner and [Jane]94-jane seem so well to understand ? "[141-mrs. gardiner]

" Oh , yes!--that , that is the worst of all . Till [I]141-mrs. gardiner was in [Kent]18-kent , and saw so much both of [Mr. Darcy]100-mr. darcy and [[his]100-mr. darcy relation]1529-his relation , [Colonel Fitzwilliam]192-colonel fitzwilliam , [I]141-mrs. gardiner was ignorant of the truth [myself]141-mrs. gardiner . And when [I]141-mrs. gardiner returned [home]3223-home , [the ----shire]4609-the ----shire was to leave [Meryton]9-meryton in a week or fortnight 's time . As that was the case , neither [Jane]94-jane , to whom [I]141-mrs. gardiner related the whole , nor [I]141-mrs. gardiner , thought it necessary to make [our]4610-our knowledge public ; for of what use could it apparently be to [any one]3122-any one , that the good opinion which [all the neighbourhood]4612-all the neighbourhood had of [him]100-mr. darcy , should then be overthrown ? And even when it was settled that [Lydia]95-lydia should go with [Mrs. Forster]204-mrs. forster , the necessity of opening [her]95-lydia eyes to [his]100-mr. darcy character never occurred to [me]141-mrs. gardiner .
